source_info.title: Furosemide
source_info.text:
【0】Furosemide
==========

【1】Brand names: Frusol, Diuresal. Find out how furosemide treats high blood pressure, heart failure and oedema, and how to take it.

【2】*   About furosemide
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking furosemide with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【3】Related conditions
------------------

【4】*   Heart failure
*   High blood pressure (hypertension)
*   Swollen ankles, feet and legs (oedema)

source_info.title: Bronchodilators
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Bronchodilators
===========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Side effects

【3】**Bronchodilators are a type of medication that make breathing easier by relaxing the muscles in the lungs and widening the airways (bronchi).**

【4】They're often used to treat long-term conditions where the airways may become narrow and inflamed, such as:

【5】*   asthma, a common lung condition caused by inflammation of the airways
*   chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a group of lung conditions, usually caused by smoking, that make breathing difficult

【6】Bronchodilators may be either:

【7】*   short-acting – used as short-term relief from sudden, unexpected attacks of breathlessness
*   long-acting – used regularly to help control breathlessness in asthma and COPD, and increase the effectiveness of corticosteroids in asthma

【8】Bronchodilators and corticosteroids
-----------------------------------

【9】Inhaled corticosteroids are the main treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent flare-ups in asthma.

【10】But some people may also benefit from taking bronchodilators to keep the airways open and enhance the effects of corticosteroids.

【11】Long-acting bronchodilators should never be taken without corticosteroids.

【12】In COPD initial treatment is with short- or long-acting bronchodilators, with corticosteroids added in some severe cases.

【13】Treatment with corticosteroids and bronchodilators may require the use of separate inhalers, but increasingly these medications are provided together in single inhalers.

【14】Types of bronchodilator
-----------------------

【15】The 3 most widely used bronchodilators are:

【16】*   beta-2 agonists, such as salbutamol, salmeterol, formoterol and vilanterol
*   anticholinergics, such as ipratropium and tiotropium
*   theophylline

【17】Beta-2 agonists and anticholinergics are available in both short-acting and long-acting forms, whereas theophylline is only available in a long-acting form.

【18】### Beta-2 agonists

【19】Beta-2 agonists are used for both asthma and COPD, although some types are only available for COPD.

【20】They're usually inhaled using a small handheld inhaler, but may also be available as tablets or syrup.

【21】For sudden, severe symptoms, they can also be injected or nebulised.

【22】A nebuliser is a compressor that turns liquid medication into a fine mist, allowing a large dose of the medicine to be inhaled through a mouthpiece or face mask.

【23】Beta-2 agonists work by stimulating receptors called beta-2 receptors in the muscles that line the airways, which causes them to relax and allows the airways to widen (dilate).

【24】They should be used with caution in people with:

【25】*   an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism) – a condition that occurs when there's too much thyroid hormone in the body
*   cardiovascular disease – conditions that affect the heart or blood vessels
*   an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia)
*   high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   diabetes – a condition that causes a person's blood sugar level to become too high

【26】In rare cases, beta-2 agonists can make some of the symptoms and possible complications of these conditions worse.

【27】### Anticholinergics

【28】Anticholinergics (also known as antimuscarinics) are mainly used to treat COPD, but a few can also be used for asthma.

【29】They're usually taken using an inhaler, but may be nebulised to treat sudden and severe symptoms.

【30】Anticholinergics cause the airways to widen by blocking the cholinergic nerves.

【31】These nerves release chemicals that can cause the muscles lining the airways to tighten.

【32】They should be used with caution in people with:

【33】*   benign prostate enlargement – where the prostate gland becomes enlarged, which can affect how you pee
*   a bladder outflow obstruction – any condition that affects the flow of urine out of the bladder, such as bladder stones or prostate cancer
*   glaucoma – a build-up of pressure in the eye

【34】If you have benign prostate enlargement or a bladder outflow obstruction, anticholinergics can cause problems, such as difficulty peeing and not being able to empty your bladder fully.

【35】Glaucoma can get worse if anticholinergic medication unintentionally gets into the eyes.

【36】### Theophylline

【37】Theophylline is usually taken in tablet or capsule form, but a different version called aminophylline can be given directly into a vein (intravenously) if your symptoms are severe.

【38】It's unclear exactly how theophylline works, but it seems to reduce any inflammation (swelling) in the airways, in addition to relaxing the muscles lining them.

【39】The effect of theophylline is weaker than other bronchodilators and corticosteroids.

【40】It's also more likely to cause side effects, so is often only used alongside these medicines if they're not effective enough.

【41】Theophylline should be used with caution in people with:

【42】*   an overactive thyroid
*   cardiovascular disease
*   liver problems, such as liver disease
*   high blood pressure
*   open sores that develop on the stomach lining (stomach ulcers)
*   a condition that affects the brain and causes repeated fits (seizures) (epilepsy)

【43】Theophylline may make these conditions worse. In people with liver problems, it can sometimes lead to a dangerous build-up of medication in the body.

【44】Other medicines can also cause an abnormal build-up of theophylline in the body. This should always be checked by your doctor.

【45】Older people may also need additional monitoring while taking theophylline.

【46】Side effects
------------

【47】The side effects of bronchodilators can vary, depending on the specific medication you're taking.

【48】Make sure you read the leaflet that comes with your medication to see what the specific side effects are.

【49】General side effects of bronchodilators include:

【50】*   trembling, particularly in the hands
*   headaches
*   a dry mouth
*   suddenly noticeable heartbeats (palpitations)
*   muscle cramps
*   a cough
*   nausea and vomiting
*   diarrhoea

【51】Find out more about the side effects of bronchodilators

【52】Pregnancy and breastfeeding
---------------------------

【53】In most cases bronchodilators should be taken as normal while pregnant or breastfeeding.

【54】But speak to your GP if you regularly use bronchodilators and you're considering having a baby or think you might be pregnant.

【55】Pregnancy may affect your asthma, so it's important to continue taking your medication and have it monitored regularly to make sure the condition is controlled.

【56】Find out more about taking medication during pregnancy

【57】Interactions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【58】Bronchodilators may interact with other medicines, which could affect the way they work or increase your risk of side effects.

【59】Some of the medicines that can interact with bronchodilators (particularly theophylline) include:

【60】*   some diuretics, a type of medication that helps remove fluid from the body
*   some antidepressants, including monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
*   digoxin, a medication used to treat arrhythmias
*   benzodiazepines, a type of sedative that may sometimes be used as a short-term treatment for anxiety or sleeping problems (insomnia)
*   lithium, a medication used to treat severe depression and bipolar disorder
*   quinolones, a type of antibiotic medication

【61】This is not a complete list of all the medications that can interact with bronchodilators, and not all of these interactions apply to each type of bronchodilator.

【62】Always carefully read the patient information leaflet that comes with your medication. 

【63】You may be able to find a specific leaflet on the medicines A to Z on the MHRA website. 

【64】If in doubt, speak to a pharmacist or GP.

【65】Page last reviewed: 05 October 2022  
Next review due: 05 October 2025

【66】*   Next : Side effects

source_info.title: Prostate cancer
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Prostate cancer
=========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  PSA testing
6.  Treatment
7.  Living with

【3】**It's not known exactly what causes prostate cancer, although a number of things can increase your risk of developing the condition.**

【4】These include:

【5】*   age – the risk rises as you get older, and most cases are diagnosed in men over 50 years of age
*   ethnic group – prostate cancer is more common in black men than in Asian men
*   family history – having a brother or father who developed prostate cancer before age 60 seems to increase your risk of developing it; research also shows that having a close female relative who developed breast cancer may also increase your risk of developing prostate cancer
*   obesity – recent research suggests there may be a link between obesity and prostate cancer, and a balanced diet and regular exercise may lower your risk of developing prostate cancer
*   diet – research is ongoing into the links between diet and prostate cancer, and there is some evidence that a diet high in calcium is linked to an increased risk of developing prostate cancer

【6】### Further information

【7】*   Prostate Cancer UK: are you at risk?
*   Prostate Cancer UK: diet, physical activity and your risk of prostate cancer
*   Cancer Research UK: prostate cancer risks and causes

【8】Page last reviewed: 18 October 2021  
Next review due: 18 October 2024

【9】*   Previous : Symptoms
*   Next : Diagnosis

source_info.title: Asthma
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Asthma
==================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Asthma attacks

【3】**Most children and adults with asthma have times when their breathing becomes more difficult.**

【4】Some people with severe asthma may have breathing problems most of the time.

【5】The most common symptoms of asthma are:

【6】*   wheezing (a whistling sound when breathing)
*   breathlessness
*   a tight chest – it may feel like a band is tightening around it
*   coughing

【7】Many things can cause these symptoms, but they're more likely to be asthma if they:

【8】*   happen often and keep coming back
*   are worse at night and early in the morning
*   seem to happen in response to an asthma trigger like exercise or an allergy (such as to pollen or animal fur)

【9】See a GP if you think you or your child may have asthma, or you have asthma and are finding it hard to control.

【10】Asthma attacks
--------------

【11】Asthma can sometimes get worse for a short time – this is known as an asthma attack. It can happen suddenly, or gradually over a few days.

【12】Signs of a severe asthma attack include:

【13】*   wheezing, coughing and chest tightness becoming severe and constant
*   being too breathless to eat, speak or sleep
*   breathing faster
*   a fast heartbeat
*   drowsiness, confusion, exhaustion or dizziness
*   blue lips or fingers
*   fainting

【14】Read about what to do during an asthma attack.

【15】Page last reviewed: 19 April 2021  
Next review due: 19 April 2024

【16】*   Previous : Asthma
*   Next : Causes

source_info.title: Acute kidney injury
source_info.text:
【0】Acute kidney injury
===================

【1】**Acute kidney injury (AKI) is where your kidneys suddenly stop working properly. It can range from minor loss of kidney function to complete kidney failure.**

【2】AKI normally happens as a complication of another serious illness. It's not the result of a physical blow to the kidneys, as the name might suggest.

【3】This type of kidney damage is usually seen in older people who are unwell with other conditions and the kidneys are also affected.

【4】It's essential that AKI is detected early and treated promptly.

【5】Without quick treatment, abnormal levels of salts and chemicals can build up in the body, which affects the ability of other organs to work properly. 

【6】If the kidneys shut down completely, this may require temporary support from a dialysis machine, or lead to death.

【7】AKI can also affect children and young people.

【8】Find out more from infoKID about AKI in children

【9】Symptoms of acute kidney injury
-------------------------------

【10】Symptoms of AKI include:

【11】*   feeling sick or being sick
*   diarrhoea
*   dehydration
*   peeing less than usual
*   confusion
*   drowsiness

【12】Even if it does not progress to complete kidney failure, AKI needs to be taken seriously.

【13】It has an effect on the whole body, changes how some medicines are handled by the body, and could make some existing illnesses more serious.

【14】AKI is different from chronic kidney disease, where the kidneys gradually lose function over a long period of time.

【15】Who's at risk of acute kidney injury?
-------------------------------------

【16】You're more likely to get AKI if:

【17】*   you're aged 65 or over
*   you already have a kidney problem, such as chronic kidney disease
*   you have a long-term disease, such as heart failure, liver disease or diabetes
*   you're dehydrated or unable to maintain your fluid intake independently
*   you have a blockage in your urinary tract (or are at risk of this)
*   you have a severe infection or sepsis
*   you're taking certain medicines, including non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS), such as ibuprofen, or blood pressure medicines, such as ACE inhibitors or diuretics; diuretics help the kidneys get rid of extra fluid from the body, but may become less helpful when a person is dehydrated or suffering from a severe illness
*   you're given aminoglycosides – a type of antibiotic that's usually only given in hospital; these medicines are only likely to increase the risk of AKI if you're dehydrated or ill

【18】Causes of acute kidney injury
-----------------------------

【19】Most cases of AKI are caused by reduced blood flow to the kidneys, usually in someone who's already unwell with another health condition.

【20】This reduced blood flow could be caused by:

【21】*   low blood volume after bleeding, excessive vomiting or diarrhoea, or severe dehydration
*   the heart pumping out less blood than normal as a result of heart failure, liver failure or sepsis
*   certain medicines that reduce blood pressure or blood flow to the kidneys, such as ACE inhibitors, certain diuretics or NSAIDs

【22】AKI can also be caused by a problem with the kidney itself, such as inflammation of the filters in the kidney (glomerulonephritis), the blood vessels (vasculitis), or other structures in the kidney.

【23】This may be caused by a reaction to some medicines, infections or the liquid dye used in some types of X-rays.

【24】It may sometimes be the result of a blockage affecting the drainage of the kidneys, such as:

【25】*   an enlarged prostate
*   a tumour in the pelvis, such as an ovarian or bladder tumour
*   kidney stones

【26】Diagnosing acute kidney injury
------------------------------

【27】A doctor may suspect AKI if you:

【28】*   are in an "at risk" group and suddenly fall ill
*   get symptoms of AKI

【29】AKI is usually diagnosed with a blood test to measure your levels of creatinine, a chemical waste product produced by the muscles.

【30】If there's a lot of creatinine in your blood, it means your kidneys are not working as well as they should.

【31】You may also be asked to give a pee sample.

【32】Find out more from InfoKID about AKI in children

【33】### Investigating the underlying cause

【34】Urine can be tested for protein, blood cells, sugar and waste products, which may give clues to the underlying cause.

【35】Doctors also need to know about:

【36】*   any other symptoms, such as signs of sepsis or signs of heart failure
*   any other medical conditions
*   any medicine that's been taken in the past week, as some medicines can cause AKI

【37】An ultrasound scan should reveal if the cause is a blockage in the urinary system, such as an enlarged prostate or bladder tumour.

【38】Treating acute kidney injury
----------------------------

【39】Treatment of AKI depends on what's causing your illness and how severe it is.

【40】You may need:

【41】*   to increase your intake of water and other fluids if you're dehydrated
*   antibiotics if you have an infection
*   to stop taking certain medicines (at least until the problem is sorted)
*   a urinary catheter, a thin tube used to drain the bladder if there's a blockage

【42】You may need to go to hospital for some treatments.

【43】Most people with AKI make a full recovery, but some people go on to develop chronic kidney disease or long-term kidney failure as a result.

【44】In severe cases, dialysis – where a machine filters the blood to rid the body of harmful waste, extra salt and water – may be needed.

【45】Preventing acute kidney injury
------------------------------

【46】Those at risk of AKI should be monitored with regular blood tests if they become unwell or start new medicine. 

【47】It's also useful to check how much pee you're passing.

【48】Any warning signs of AKI, such as vomiting or producing little pee, require immediate investigation for AKI and treatment.

【49】People who are dehydrated or at risk of dehydration may need to be given fluids through a drip.

【50】Any medicine that seems to be making the problem worse or directly damaging the kidneys needs to be stopped, at least temporarily.

【51】Complications of acute kidney injury
------------------------------------

【52】The most serious complications of acute kidney injury include:

【53】*   high levels of potassium in the blood – in severe cases, this can lead to muscle weakness, paralysis and heart rhythm problems
*   too much fluid in the body, which can cause build-up of fluid in the arms and legs (oedema) or in the lungs (pulmonary oedema)
*   acidic blood (metabolic acidosis) – which can cause nausea, vomiting, drowsiness and breathlessness
*   chronic kidney disease

【54】Page last reviewed: 08 September 2022  
Next review due: 08 September 2025

text.text: 【8】Find out more from infoKID about AKI in children
text.content:
【0】Acute kidney injury
===================

【1】**Acute kidney injury (AKI) is where your kidneys suddenly stop working properly. It can range from minor loss of kidney function to complete kidney failure.**

【2】AKI normally happens as a complication of another serious illness. It's not the result of a physical blow to the kidneys, as the name might suggest.

【3】This type of kidney damage is usually seen in older people who are unwell with other conditions and the kidneys are also affected.

【4】It's essential that AKI is detected early and treated promptly.

【5】Without quick treatment, abnormal levels of salts and chemicals can build up in the body, which affects the ability of other organs to work properly. 

【6】If the kidneys shut down completely, this may require temporary support from a dialysis machine, or lead to death.

【7】AKI can also affect children and young people.

【8】Find out more from infoKID about AKI in children

【9】Symptoms of acute kidney injury
-------------------------------

【10】Symptoms of AKI include:

【11】*   feeling sick or being sick
*   diarrhoea
*   dehydration
*   peeing less than usual
*   confusion
*   drowsiness

【12】Even if it does not progress to complete kidney failure, AKI needs to be taken seriously.

【13】It has an effect on the whole body, changes how some medicines are handled by the body, and could make some existing illnesses more serious.

【14】AKI is different from chronic kidney disease, where the kidneys gradually lose function over a long period of time.

【15】Who's at risk of acute kidney injury?
-------------------------------------

【16】You're more likely to get AKI if:

【17】*   you're aged 65 or over
*   you already have a kidney problem, such as chronic kidney disease
*   you have a long-term disease, such as heart failure, liver disease or diabetes
*   you're dehydrated or unable to maintain your fluid intake independently
*   you have a blockage in your urinary tract (or are at risk of this)
*   you have a severe infection or sepsis
*   you're taking certain medicines, including non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS), such as ibuprofen, or blood pressure medicines, such as ACE inhibitors or diuretics; diuretics help the kidneys get rid of extra fluid from the body, but may become less helpful when a person is dehydrated or suffering from a severe illness
*   you're given aminoglycosides – a type of antibiotic that's usually only given in hospital; these medicines are only likely to increase the risk of AKI if you're dehydrated or ill

【18】Causes of acute kidney injury
-----------------------------

【19】Most cases of AKI are caused by reduced blood flow to the kidneys, usually in someone who's already unwell with another health condition.

【20】This reduced blood flow could be caused by:

【21】*   low blood volume after bleeding, excessive vomiting or diarrhoea, or severe dehydration
*   the heart pumping out less blood than normal as a result of heart failure, liver failure or sepsis
*   certain medicines that reduce blood pressure or blood flow to the kidneys, such as ACE inhibitors, certain diuretics or NSAIDs

【22】AKI can also be caused by a problem with the kidney itself, such as inflammation of the filters in the kidney (glomerulonephritis), the blood vessels (vasculitis), or other structures in the kidney.

【23】This may be caused by a reaction to some medicines, infections or the liquid dye used in some types of X-rays.

【24】It may sometimes be the result of a blockage affecting the drainage of the kidneys, such as:

【25】*   an enlarged prostate
*   a tumour in the pelvis, such as an ovarian or bladder tumour
*   kidney stones

【26】Diagnosing acute kidney injury
------------------------------

【27】A doctor may suspect AKI if you:

【28】*   are in an "at risk" group and suddenly fall ill
*   get symptoms of AKI

【29】AKI is usually diagnosed with a blood test to measure your levels of creatinine, a chemical waste product produced by the muscles.

【30】If there's a lot of creatinine in your blood, it means your kidneys are not working as well as they should.

【31】You may also be asked to give a pee sample.

【32】Find out more from InfoKID about AKI in children

【33】### Investigating the underlying cause

【34】Urine can be tested for protein, blood cells, sugar and waste products, which may give clues to the underlying cause.

【35】Doctors also need to know about:

【36】*   any other symptoms, such as signs of sepsis or signs of heart failure
*   any other medical conditions
*   any medicine that's been taken in the past week, as some medicines can cause AKI

【37】An ultrasound scan should reveal if the cause is a blockage in the urinary system, such as an enlarged prostate or bladder tumour.

【38】Treating acute kidney injury
----------------------------

【39】Treatment of AKI depends on what's causing your illness and how severe it is.

【40】You may need:

【41】*   to increase your intake of water and other fluids if you're dehydrated
*   antibiotics if you have an infection
*   to stop taking certain medicines (at least until the problem is sorted)
*   a urinary catheter, a thin tube used to drain the bladder if there's a blockage

【42】You may need to go to hospital for some treatments.

【43】Most people with AKI make a full recovery, but some people go on to develop chronic kidney disease or long-term kidney failure as a result.

【44】In severe cases, dialysis – where a machine filters the blood to rid the body of harmful waste, extra salt and water – may be needed.

【45】Preventing acute kidney injury
------------------------------

【46】Those at risk of AKI should be monitored with regular blood tests if they become unwell or start new medicine. 

【47】It's also useful to check how much pee you're passing.

【48】Any warning signs of AKI, such as vomiting or producing little pee, require immediate investigation for AKI and treatment.

【49】People who are dehydrated or at risk of dehydration may need to be given fluids through a drip.

【50】Any medicine that seems to be making the problem worse or directly damaging the kidneys needs to be stopped, at least temporarily.

【51】Complications of acute kidney injury
------------------------------------

【52】The most serious complications of acute kidney injury include:

【53】*   high levels of potassium in the blood – in severe cases, this can lead to muscle weakness, paralysis and heart rhythm problems
*   too much fluid in the body, which can cause build-up of fluid in the arms and legs (oedema) or in the lungs (pulmonary oedema)
*   acidic blood (metabolic acidosis) – which can cause nausea, vomiting, drowsiness and breathlessness
*   chronic kidney disease

【54】Page last reviewed: 08 September 2022  
Next review due: 08 September 2025

source_info.title: Amnesia, see Memory loss (amnesia)
source_info.text:
【0】Amnesia, see Memory loss (amnesia)
Memory loss (amnesia)
=====================

【1】**Most people forget things from time to time, but see a GP if you keep having problems with your memory. It could be caused by something that can be treated.**

【2】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【3】*   memory problems are affecting your day-to-day life

【4】It's often nothing serious, but it's best to get checked because any treatment you need may work better if it's started early.

【5】### Important: Concern for a relative

【6】If you're worried about an older relative who's becoming increasingly forgetful, speak to a GP about whether it could be a sign of dementia.

【7】What happens at your appointment
--------------------------------

【8】If you're having problems with your memory, a GP will ask you some questions to try to find the cause.

【9】It might be useful to bring someone else with you who can help describe the problems you're having.

【10】The GP may refer you to a memory specialist for an in-depth assessment. Further tests, such as scans, may also sometimes be needed.

【11】Any treatment that's recommended will depend on the cause of your memory problems.

【12】Causes of memory loss
---------------------

【13】Memory loss can just be a natural part of getting older.

【14】Sometimes it may be caused by something common and treatable like:

【15】*   stress
*   anxiety or depression
*   sleeping problems (insomnia)

【16】Occasionally, memory loss can be a sign of something more serious, such as dementia.

【17】Do not try to self-diagnose the cause of your memory loss – always see a GP.

【18】Page last reviewed: 09 October 2023  
Next review due: 09 October 2026

source_info.title: How to warm up before exercising
source_info.text:
【0】How to warm up before exercising
================================

【1】**Warm up properly before exercising to prevent injury and make your workouts more effective.**

【2】This warm-up routine should take at least 6 minutes. Warm up for longer if you feel the need.

【3】March on the spot: keep going for 3 minutes
-------------------------------------------

【4】Start off marching on the spot and then march forwards and backwards. Pump your arms up and down in rhythm with your steps, keeping the elbows bent and the fists soft.

【5】Heel digs: aim for 60 heel digs in 60 seconds
---------------------------------------------

【6】For heel digs, place alternate heels to the front, keeping the front foot pointing up, and punch out with each heel dig. Keep a slight bend in the supporting leg.

【7】Knee lifts: aim for 30 knee lifts in 30 seconds
-----------------------------------------------

【8】To do knee lifts, stand tall and bring up alternate knees to touch the opposite hand. Keep your abs tight and back straight. Keep a slight bend in the supporting leg.

【9】Shoulder rolls: 2 sets of 10 repetitions
----------------------------------------

【10】For shoulder rolls, keep marching on the spot. Roll your shoulders forwards 5 times and backwards 5 times. Let your arms hang loose by your sides.

【11】Knee bends: 10 repetitions
--------------------------

【12】To do knee bends, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your hands stretched out. Lower yourself no more than 10cm by bending your knees. Come up and repeat.

【13】Video: basic warm-up (5 minutes)
--------------------------------

【14】This aerobic warm-up video is suitable for all levels. Do this before starting on more rigorous exercise.

【15】Media last reviewed: 8 December 2020  
Media review due: 8 December 2023

【16】See exercise video safety information

【17】The exercises in this series of videos are suitable for most people in good health with a reasonable level of fitness.

【18】Unless stated otherwise, they are general exercises only and are not aimed at treating any specific cause of pain or condition. Video titles and descriptions can give more information on how difficult the exercises are and who they are for.

【19】Get advice from a healthcare professional before trying them if:

【20】*   you are not sure if the exercises are suitable for your current level of fitness
*   you have a health problem, an injury, any symptoms, are feeling unwell, or you have had a recent health event such as a heart attack or operation
*   you have any other concerns about your health
*   you are pregnant or have recently given birth

【21】Stop the exercise immediately if you feel any pain or become unwell. If you are concerned about any symptoms, or they do not go away, get help from 111 online or call 111 for advice.

text.content:
【0】How to warm up before exercising
================================

【1】**Warm up properly before exercising to prevent injury and make your workouts more effective.**

【2】This warm-up routine should take at least 6 minutes. Warm up for longer if you feel the need.

【3】March on the spot: keep going for 3 minutes
-------------------------------------------

【4】Start off marching on the spot and then march forwards and backwards. Pump your arms up and down in rhythm with your steps, keeping the elbows bent and the fists soft.

【5】Heel digs: aim for 60 heel digs in 60 seconds
---------------------------------------------

【6】For heel digs, place alternate heels to the front, keeping the front foot pointing up, and punch out with each heel dig. Keep a slight bend in the supporting leg.

【7】Knee lifts: aim for 30 knee lifts in 30 seconds
-----------------------------------------------

【8】To do knee lifts, stand tall and bring up alternate knees to touch the opposite hand. Keep your abs tight and back straight. Keep a slight bend in the supporting leg.

【9】Shoulder rolls: 2 sets of 10 repetitions
----------------------------------------

【10】For shoulder rolls, keep marching on the spot. Roll your shoulders forwards 5 times and backwards 5 times. Let your arms hang loose by your sides.

【11】Knee bends: 10 repetitions
--------------------------

【12】To do knee bends, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your hands stretched out. Lower yourself no more than 10cm by bending your knees. Come up and repeat.

【13】Video: basic warm-up (5 minutes)
--------------------------------

【14】This aerobic warm-up video is suitable for all levels. Do this before starting on more rigorous exercise.

【15】Media last reviewed: 8 December 2020  
Media review due: 8 December 2023

*   you have a health problem, an injury, any symptoms, are feeling unwell, or you have had a recent health event such as a heart attack or operation
*   you have any other concerns about your health
*   you are pregnant or have recently given birth

【21】Stop the exercise immediately if you feel any pain or become unwell. If you are concerned about any symptoms, or they do not go away, get help from 111 online or call 111 for advice.

source_info.title: IVF
source_info.text:
【0】Getting started \- IVF
======================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Availability
3.  Getting started
4.  What happens
5.  Risks
6.  Support

【3】**If you're having problems getting pregnant, see your GP. They will look at your medical history and give you a physical examination.**

【4】They may also recommend some lifestyle changes to help increase your chances of getting pregnant 通用删除1(英):<u>(see planning your pregnancy)</u>.

【5】Unless there are reasons that may put you at high risk of infertility, such as cancer treatment, you'll usually only be considered for infertility investigations and treatment if you've been trying for a baby for at least a year without becoming pregnant.

【6】If appropriate, your GP can refer you to a fertility specialist at an NHS hospital or fertility clinic.

【7】Seeing a fertility specialist
-----------------------------

【8】The specialist will ask about your fertility history, and may carry out a physical examination.

【9】Women may have tests to check the levels of hormones in their blood and how well their ovaries are working.

【10】They may also have an ultrasound scan or other tests to see if there are any blockages or structural problems.

【11】Men may be asked for a semen sample to test sperm quality.

【12】If IVF is the best treatment for you, the specialist will refer you to an assisted conception unit.

【13】Read more about diagnosing infertility.

【14】At the assisted conception unit
-------------------------------

【15】Once you're accepted for treatment at the assisted conception unit, you and your partner will have blood tests, including tests for HIV, hepatitis B and hepatitis C.

【16】Your cervical screening tests should also be up-to-date.

【17】The clinic should also check that you've been offered screening for sickle cell and thalassaemia if your ancestors come from a country where these conditions are more common. Anyone can ask to have this test for free on the NHS from their GP.

【18】If you're planning to use donor eggs, check that these have been screened. All IVF clinics in the UK are required to screen donor eggs and sperm.

【19】The specialist will investigate the number of eggs in your body (your ovarian reserve) to estimate how your ovaries will respond to IVF treatment.

【20】This can be assessed by measuring a substance called anti-mullerian hormone (AMH) in your blood, or by counting the number of egg-containing follicles, known as your antral follicle count (AFC), using a vaginal ultrasound scan.

【21】Your specialist will then discuss your treatment plan with you in detail and talk to you about any support or guidance you may find helpful.

【22】Read more about what happens during IVF and the support available during IVF.

【23】Page last reviewed: 18 October 2021  
Next review due: 18 October 2024

【24】*   Previous : Availability
*   Next : What happens

source_info.title: Neuroendocrine tumours and carcinoid syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Neuroendocrine tumours and carcinoid syndrome
=============================================

【1】**Neuroendocrine tumours (NETs) are rare tumours of the neuroendocrine system, the system in the body that produces hormones. They can be cancerous or non-cancerous.**

【2】The tumour usually grows in the bowels or appendix, but it can also be found in the stomach, pancreas, lung, breast, kidney, ovaries or testicles. It tends to grow very slowly.

【3】Neuroendocrine tumours are sometimes referred to as carcinoid tumours, particularly when they affect the small bowel, large bowel or appendix.

【4】Carcinoid syndrome is the collection of symptoms some people with a neuroendocrine tumour may have.

【5】It is more common when the tumour has spread to the liver and releases hormones such as serotonin into the bloodstream.

【6】Carcinoid syndrome can also happen in people with lung and pancreatic NETs, but this is rare.

【7】About 4,000 people are diagnosed with a neuroendocrine tumour each year in the UK, but not everyone with a tumour will have carcinoid syndrome.

【8】Cancer Research UK has more information about different types of neuroendocrine tumours

【9】Signs and symptoms
------------------

【10】In the early stages of having a neuroendocrine tumour, you may not have any symptoms.

【11】You may also not have symptoms if the tumour is just in your digestive system, as any hormones it produces will be broken down by your liver.

【12】If symptoms do develop, they tend to be general and can be easily mistaken for signs of other illnesses.

【13】Symptoms may result from both the tumour itself and from any hormones it releases into the bloodstream.

【14】### Symptoms caused by the tumour

【15】Symptoms will depend on where in the body the tumour develops:

【16】*   a tumour in the bowel may cause tummy pain, a blocked bowel (diarrhoea, constipation, feeling sick or being sick) and bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)
*   a tumour in the lung may cause a cough, which may make you cough up blood, and cause wheezing, shortness of breath, chest pain and tiredness
*   a tumour in the stomach may cause pain, weight loss, tiredness and weakness

【17】Some tumours may not cause any symptoms and are discovered by chance.

【18】For example, a tumour in the appendix may only be found when the appendix is being removed for another reason.

【19】### Symptoms caused by the hormones (carcinoid syndrome)

【20】Typical symptoms of carcinoid syndrome include:

【21】*   diarrhoea, tummy pain and loss of appetite
*   flushing of the skin, particularly the face
*   fast heart rate
*   breathlessness and wheezing

【22】These symptoms may come on unexpectedly, as the hormones can be produced by the tumour at any time.

【23】Some people may also develop carcinoid heart disease, where the heart valves thicken and stop working properly.

【24】There's also a risk of developing a rare but serious condition called a carcinoid crisis, which involves severe flushing, breathlessness and a changes in your blood pressure.

【25】What causes neuroendocrine tumours?
-----------------------------------

【26】It's not known exactly why neuroendocrine tumours develop, but it's thought that most occur by chance.

【27】Your chances of developing a neuroendocrine tumour may be increased if you have:

【28】*   a rare family syndrome called multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1)
*   parents or siblings (brothers or sisters) with a carcinoid tumour
*   conditions called neurofibromatosis or tuberous sclerosis

【29】Read more about neuroendocrine tumours on the Cancer Research UK website

【30】Diagnosing neuroendocrine tumours
---------------------------------

【31】A neuroendocrine tumour may be found incidentally – for example, as a surgeon is removing an appendix.

【32】In this case, the tumour will often be caught early and removed along with the appendix, causing no further problems.

【33】Otherwise, people usually see their GP after they have developed symptoms.

【34】A neuroendocrine tumour may be diagnosed after carrying out a series of scans and tests, which may include measuring the amount of serotonin in your urine and having an endoscopy.

【35】Treating neuroendocrine tumours and carcinoid syndrome
------------------------------------------------------

【36】If the tumour is caught early, it may be possible to completely remove it and cure the cancer altogether.

【37】Otherwise, surgeons will remove as much of the tumour as possible (debulking).

【38】If the tumour cannot be removed, but it's not growing or causing symptoms, you may not need treatment straight away – it might just be carefully monitored. 

【39】If it's causing symptoms, you may be offered treatment.

【40】This can include:

【41】*   injections of medicines called somatostatin analogues, such as octreotide and lanreotide, which can slow down the growth of the tumour
*   radiotherapy to kill some of the cancer cells 
*   a procedure to block the blood supply to the tumour (for tumours in the liver), known as hepatic artery embolisation
*   a procedure that uses a heated probe to kill cancer cells (for tumours in the liver), called radiofrequency ablation
*   chemotherapy to shrink the tumour and control your symptoms
*   targeted drugs to help control the growth of the tumour, such as sunitinib, everolimus and interferon.

【42】You may also be given medicine to widen your airways (to relieve wheezing and breathlessness) and anti-diarrhoea medicine.

【43】Read more about surgery and treatments for neuroendocrine tumours on the Cancer Research UK website

【44】What can I do to help myself?
-----------------------------

【45】There are things you can do yourself to manage some of the symptoms of carcinoid syndrome.

【46】Generally, you should avoid triggers of flushing, such as:

【47】*   alcohol
*   large meals
*   spicy foods
*   foods containing the substance tyramine, such as aged cheese and salted or pickled meats
*   stress

【48】If you have diarrhoea, it's important to keep drinking little and often to avoid dehydration.

【49】Outlook
-------

【50】If the whole tumour can be removed, this may cure the cancer and symptoms altogether.

【51】But even if surgeons cannot remove the entire tumour, it usually grows slowly and can be controlled with medicine.

【52】You might have treatment to help with symptoms if the tumour has spread to another organ, such as the liver.

【53】Survival for people with neuroendocrine tumours depends on many things, including the person's condition and the type of tumour they have.

【54】Page last reviewed: 24 May 2021  
Next review due: 24 May 2024

source_info.title: Chlamydia
source_info.text: 【0】Overview \- Chlamydia ===================== 【1】Contents -------- 【2】1. Overview 2. Symptoms 3. Diagnosis 4. Treatment 5. Complications 【3】**Chlamydia is 1 of the most common sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in the UK.** 【4】It's passed on through unprotected sex (sex without a condom) and is particularly common in sexually active teenagers and young adults. 【5】If you're a woman, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year, and when you have sex with new or casual partners. 【6】If you're a man, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year if you are not using condoms with new or casual partners. 【7】Symptoms of chlamydia --------------------- 【8】Most people with chlamydia do not notice any symptoms and do not know they have it. 【9】If you do develop symptoms, you may experience: 【10】* pain when peeing * unusual discharge from the vagina, penis or bottom * in women, pain in the tummy, bleeding after sex and bleeding between periods * in men, pain and swelling in the testicles 【11】If you think you're at risk of having a sexually transmitted infection (STI) or have any symptoms of chlamydia, visit a GP, community contraceptive service or local genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic to get tested. 【12】How do you get chlamydia? ------------------------- 【13】Chlamydia is a bacterial infection. The bacteria are usually spread through sex or contact with infected genital fluids (semen or vaginal fluid). 【14】You can get chlamydia through: 【15】* unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex * sharing sex toys that are not washed or covered with a new condom each time they're used * your genitals coming into contact with your partner's genitals – this means you can get chlamydia from someone even if there's no penetration, orgasm or ejaculation * infected semen or vaginal fluid getting into your eye 【16】It can also be passed by a pregnant woman to her baby. 【17】Chlamydia cannot be passed on through casual contact, such as kissing and hugging, or from sharing baths, towels, swimming pools, toilet seats or cutlery. 【18】Is chlamydia serious? --------------------- 【19】Although chlamydia does not usually cause any symptoms and can normally be treated with a short course of antibiotics, it can be serious if it's not treated early on. 【20】If left untreated, the infection can spread to other parts of your body and lead to long-term health problems, especially in women. 【21】In women, untreated chlamydia can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), ectopic pregnancy and infertility. 【22】In men, in rare cases, chlamydia can spread to the testicles and epididymis (tubes that carry sperm from the testicles), causing them to become painful and swollen. This is known as epididymitis or epididymo-orchitis (inflammation of the testicles). 【23】It can also sometimes cause reactive arthritis in men and women. 【24】This is why it's important to get tested and treated as soon as possible if you think you might have chlamydia. 【25】Find out more about the complications of chlamydia 【26】Getting tested for chlamydia ---------------------------- 【27】Testing for chlamydia is done with a urine test or a swab test. 【28】You do not always need a physical examination by a nurse or doctor. 【29】Anyone can get a free and confidential chlamydia test at a sexual health clinic, a genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic or a GP surgery. 【30】In England, if you're a woman under 25 years old, you may be offered a chlamydia test when you visit some health services, for example a pharmacy or GP. This offer is part of the National Chlamydia Screening Programme (NCSP). 【31】If you're offered a chlamydia test you should consider taking it. 【32】If you're a woman, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year, and when you have sex with new or casual partners. 【33】If you're a man, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year if you are not using condoms with new or casual partners. 【34】You can also buy chlamydia testing kits to do at home. 【35】Find out more about chlamydia diagnosis 【36】How chlamydia is treated ------------------------ 【37】Chlamydia can usually be treated easily with antibiotics. 【38】You may be given a course of doxycycline to take for a week or azithromycin to take once a day for 3 days. 【39】If you have doxycycline, you should not have sex (including oral sex) until you and your current sexual partner have finished treatment. 【40】If you have azithromycin, you should wait 7 days after treatment before having sex (including oral sex). 【41】It's important that your current sexual partner and any other recent sexual partners you have had are also tested and treated to help stop the spread of the infection. 【42】Under-25s who have chlamydia should be offered another test 3 to 6 months after being treated. 【43】This is because young adults who test positive for chlamydia are at increased risk of catching it again. 【44】Sexual health or genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinics can help you contact your sexual partners. 【45】Either you or the clinic can speak to them, or they can be sent a note advising them to get tested. 【46】The note will not have your name on it, so your confidentiality will be protected. 【47】Preventing chlamydia -------------------- 【48】Anyone who's sexually active can catch chlamydia. 【49】You're most at risk if you have a new sexual partner or do not use a barrier method of contraception, such as a condom, when having sex. 【50】You can help to prevent the spread of chlamydia by: 【51】* using a condom every time you have vaginal or anal sex * using a condom to cover the penis during oral sex * using a dam (a piece of thin, soft plastic or latex) to cover the female genitals during oral sex or when rubbing female genitals together * not sharing sex toys 【52】If you do share sex toys, wash them or cover them with a new condom between each person who uses them. 【53】Common questions ---------------- 【54】Find answers to some common questions about chlamydia: 【55】* How soon do STI symptoms appear? * What should I do if I think I've got an STI? * Are sex toys safe? * What services do sexual health clinics (GUM clinics) provide? 【56】Community content from HealthUnlocked 【57】Page last reviewed: 01 September 2021 Next review due: 01 September 2024 【58】* Next : Symptoms

【2】1.  Overview

2.  Symptoms

3.  Diagnosis

4.  Treatment

5.  Complications
text.content: 【0】Overview \- Chlamydia ===================== 【1】Contents -------- 【2】1. Overview 2. Symptoms 3. Diagnosis 4. Treatment 5. Complications 【3】**Chlamydia is 1 of the most common sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in the UK.** 【4】It's passed on through unprotected sex (sex without a condom) and is particularly common in sexually active teenagers and young adults. 【5】If you're a woman, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year, and when you have sex with new or casual partners. 【6】If you're a man, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year if you are not using condoms with new or casual partners. 【7】Symptoms of chlamydia --------------------- 【8】Most people with chlamydia do not notice any symptoms and do not know they have it. 【9】If you do develop symptoms, you may experience: 【10】* pain when peeing * unusual discharge from the vagina, penis or bottom * in women, pain in the tummy, bleeding after sex and bleeding between periods * in men, pain and swelling in the testicles 【11】If you think you're at risk of having a sexually transmitted infection (STI) or have any symptoms of chlamydia, visit a GP, community contraceptive service or local genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic to get tested. 【12】How do you get chlamydia? ------------------------- 【13】Chlamydia is a bacterial infection. The bacteria are usually spread through sex or contact with infected genital fluids (semen or vaginal fluid). 【14】You can get chlamydia through: 【15】* unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex * sharing sex toys that are not washed or covered with a new condom each time they're used * your genitals coming into contact with your partner's genitals – this means you can get chlamydia from someone even if there's no penetration, orgasm or ejaculation * infected semen or vaginal fluid getting into your eye 【16】It can also be passed by a pregnant woman to her baby. 【17】Chlamydia cannot be passed on through casual contact, such as kissing and hugging, or from sharing baths, towels, swimming pools, toilet seats or cutlery. 【18】Is chlamydia serious? --------------------- 【19】Although chlamydia does not usually cause any symptoms and can normally be treated with a short course of antibiotics, it can be serious if it's not treated early on. 【20】If left untreated, the infection can spread to other parts of your body and lead to long-term health problems, especially in women. 【21】In women, untreated chlamydia can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), ectopic pregnancy and infertility. 【22】In men, in rare cases, chlamydia can spread to the testicles and epididymis (tubes that carry sperm from the testicles), causing them to become painful and swollen. This is known as epididymitis or epididymo-orchitis (inflammation of the testicles). 【23】It can also sometimes cause reactive arthritis in men and women. 【24】This is why it's important to get tested and treated as soon as possible if you think you might have chlamydia. 【25】Find out more about the complications of chlamydia 【26】Getting tested for chlamydia ---------------------------- 【27】Testing for chlamydia is done with a urine test or a swab test. 【28】You do not always need a physical examination by a nurse or doctor. 【29】Anyone can get a free and confidential chlamydia test at a sexual health clinic, a genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic or a GP surgery. 【30】In England, if you're a woman under 25 years old, you may be offered a chlamydia test when you visit some health services, for example a pharmacy or GP. This offer is part of the National Chlamydia Screening Programme (NCSP). 【31】If you're offered a chlamydia test you should consider taking it. 【32】If you're a woman, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year, and when you have sex with new or casual partners. 【33】If you're a man, sexually active and under 25 in England, it's recommended that you have a chlamydia test once a year if you are not using condoms with new or casual partners. 【34】You can also buy chlamydia testing kits to do at home. 【35】Find out more about chlamydia diagnosis 【36】How chlamydia is treated ------------------------ 【37】Chlamydia can usually be treated easily with antibiotics. 【38】You may be given a course of doxycycline to take for a week or azithromycin to take once a day for 3 days. 【39】If you have doxycycline, you should not have sex (including oral sex) until you and your current sexual partner have finished treatment. 【40】If you have azithromycin, you should wait 7 days after treatment before having sex (including oral sex). 【41】It's important that your current sexual partner and any other recent sexual partners you have had are also tested and treated to help stop the spread of the infection. 【42】Under-25s who have chlamydia should be offered another test 3 to 6 months after being treated. 【43】This is because young adults who test positive for chlamydia are at increased risk of catching it again. 【44】Sexual health or genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinics can help you contact your sexual partners. 【45】Either you or the clinic can speak to them, or they can be sent a note advising them to get tested. 【46】The note will not have your name on it, so your confidentiality will be protected. 【47】Preventing chlamydia -------------------- 【48】Anyone who's sexually active can catch chlamydia. 【49】You're most at risk if you have a new sexual partner or do not use a barrier method of contraception, such as a condom, when having sex. 【50】You can help to prevent the spread of chlamydia by: 【51】* using a condom every time you have vaginal or anal sex * using a condom to cover the penis during oral sex * using a dam (a piece of thin, soft plastic or latex) to cover the female genitals during oral sex or when rubbing female genitals together * not sharing sex toys 【52】If you do share sex toys, wash them or cover them with a new condom between each person who uses them. 【53】Common questions ---------------- 【54】Find answers to some common questions about chlamydia: 【55】* How soon do STI symptoms appear? * What should I do if I think I've got an STI? * Are sex toys safe? * What services do sexual health clinics (GUM clinics) provide? 【56】Community content from HealthUnlocked 【57】Page last reviewed: 01 September 2021 Next review due: 01 September 2024 【58】* Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: Folic acid
source_info.text:
【0】About folic acid
================

【1】Folic acid is the synthetic version of the vitamin folate, also known as vitamin B9.

【2】Folate helps the body make healthy red blood cells and is found in certain foods.

【3】Folic acid is used to:

【4】*   treat or prevent folate deficiency anaemia
*   help your baby's brain, skull and spinal cord develop properly in pregnancy, to avoid development problems (called neural tube defects) such as spina bifida
*   help reduce side effects from methotrexate, a medicine used to treat severe arthritis, Crohn's disease or psoriasis

【5】Folic acid is available on prescription. It comes as tablets or as a liquid you swallow.

【6】You can also buy lower dose tablets from pharmacies and supermarkets.

【7】Folic acid can also be combined with:

【8】*   ferrous fumarate and ferrous sulphate, to treat iron deficiency anaemia
*   other vitamins and minerals, as a multivitamin and mineral supplement

【9】Key facts
---------

【10】*   You'll usually take folic acid once a day, but sometimes you'll only need to take it once a week. Your doctor will explain how often to take it.
*   Most adults and children can take folic acid.
*   If you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant, it's recommended you take folic acid until you're 12 weeks pregnant. It helps your baby grow normally.
*   You're unlikely to get side effects with folic acid, but some people feel sick, lose their appetite, get wind or feel bloated. These side effects are usually mild and do not last long.
*   It's best not to drink alcohol while taking folic acid, as it can stop your folic acid from working as well.

【11】More in Folic acid
------------------

【12】*   About folic acid
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking folic acid with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【13】Page last reviewed: 5 April 2022  
Next review due: 5 April 2025

【2】Folate helps the body make healthy red blood cells and is found in certain foods.

【3】Folic acid is used to:

【4】*   treat or prevent folate deficiency anaemia
*   help your baby's brain, skull and spinal cord develop properly in pregnancy, to avoid development problems (called neural tube defects) such as spina bifida
*   help reduce side effects from methotrexate, a medicine used to treat severe arthritis, Crohn's disease or psoriasis

【5】Folic acid is available on prescription. It comes as tablets or as a liquid you swallow.

【6】You can also buy lower dose tablets from pharmacies and supermarkets.

【7】Folic acid can also be combined with:

【8】*   ferrous fumarate and ferrous sulphate, to treat iron deficiency anaemia
*   other vitamins and minerals, as a multivitamin and mineral supplement

【9】Key facts
---------

【10】*   You'll usually take folic acid once a day, but sometimes you'll only need to take it once a week. Your doctor will explain how often to take it.
*   Most adults and children can take folic acid.
*   If you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant, it's recommended you take folic acid until you're 12 weeks pregnant. It helps your baby grow normally.
*   You're unlikely to get side effects with folic acid, but some people feel sick, lose their appetite, get wind or feel bloated. These side effects are usually mild and do not last long.
*   It's best not to drink alcohol while taking folic acid, as it can stop your folic acid from working as well.

【11】More in Folic acid
------------------

【12】*   About folic acid
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking folic acid with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

Next review due: 5 April 2025

source_info.title: Statins
source_info.text:
【0】Considerations \- Statins
=========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Uses
3.  Considerations
4.  Side effects

【3】**Statins should not be taken if you have liver disease or if blood tests suggest that your liver may not be working properly.**

【4】This is because statins can affect your liver, and this is more likely to cause serious problems if you already have a damaged liver.

【5】Before starting to take statins, you should have a blood test to check how well your liver and kidneys are working. You should also have a routine blood test to check the health of your liver 3 months after treatment begins, and again after 12 months.

【6】Pregnancy and breastfeeding
---------------------------

【7】Statins should not be taken by anyone who is pregnant or breastfeeding, as there's no firm evidence on whether it's safe to do so.

【8】Contact a GP for advice if you become pregnant while taking statins.

【9】People at an increased risk of side effects
-------------------------------------------

【10】Statins should be taken with caution if you're at an increased risk of developing a rare side effect called myopathy, which is where the tissues of your muscles become damaged and painful. Severe myopathy (rhabdomyolysis) can lead to kidney damage.

【11】Things that can increase this risk include:

【12】*   being over 70 years old
*   having a history of liver disease
*   regularly drinking large quantities of alcohol
*   having a history of muscle-related side effects when taking a statin or fibrate (another type of medicine for high cholesterol)
*   having a family history of myopathy or rhabdomyolysis

【13】If one or more of these apply to you, you may need to be frequently monitored to check for complications. A lower dose of statin may also be recommended.

【14】If you have an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism), treatment may be delayed until this problem is treated. This is because having an underactive thyroid can lead to an increased cholesterol level, and treating hypothyroidism may cause your cholesterol level to decrease, without the need for statins. Statins are also more likely to cause muscle damage in people with an underactive thyroid.

【15】Read more about the side effects of statins.

【16】Interactions
------------

【17】Statins can react unpredictably with certain other substances (known as "interacting"), potentially increasing the risk of serious side effects, such as muscle damage.

【18】Medicines that can interact with some types of statin include:

【19】*   **certain** **antibiotics** **and** **antifungals**
*   **certain** **HIV** **medicines**
*   **warfarin** – a medicine commonly used to prevent blood clots
*   **ciclosporin** – a medicine that suppresses the immune system and is used to treat a wide range of conditions, including psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis
*   **danazol** – a synthetic (manmade) hormone medicine used to treat conditions such as endometriosis
*   **verapamil and diltiazem** – types of medicine called calcium channel blockers, which are used to treat various conditions affecting the heart and blood vessels
*   **amiodarone** – a medicine sometimes used to treat arrhythmia (irregular heartbeats)
*   **fibrates** – medicines that, like statins, help reduce cholesterol levels in the blood

【20】If you're taking statins and need to take one of these medicines, a doctor may prescribe an alternative statin or your current statin at a lower dosage. In some cases, they may recommend that you temporarily stop taking your statin.

【21】### Food and alcohol

【22】Grapefruit juice can affect some statins and increase your risk of side effects. A doctor may advise you to avoid it completely or only consume small quantities.

【23】The doctor will also ask you how much alcohol you drink before prescribing statins. People who regularly drink large amounts of alcohol are at increased risk of getting more serious side effects.

【24】If you're prescribed a statin, you may be able to continue drinking alcohol. However, you should not drink more than 14 units of alcohol a week.

【25】Researching your medicine
-------------------------

【26】For full details of cautions and interactions relating to your specific medicine, check the patient information leaflet that comes with it.

【27】If in doubt, contact a GP or pharmacist for advice.

【28】Page last reviewed: 03 October 2022  
Next review due: 03 October 2025

*   Next : Side effects

source_info.title: Chloramphenicol
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking chloramphenicol
===================================================================

【1】Chloramphenicol and pregnancy
-----------------------------

【2】Chloramphenicol eye treatments and eardrops can be used in pregnancy. Only tiny amounts are absorbed into the bloodstream and it's not thought that these can harm your baby.

【3】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist about the best treatment for you. This will depend on how bad the infection is and whether there are other medicines that might be more suitable.

【4】Chloramphenicol and breastfeeding
---------------------------------

【5】If your baby was born well and healthy it is OK to use chloramphenicol eye treatment and eardrops while breastfeeding.

【6】If there is a family history of any sort of blood disorder, including aplastic anaemia, you may be advised not to use chloramphenicol.

【7】It's not yet known how much chloramphenicol passes into breast milk, but it's likely to be a tiny amount for preparations used for the eyes and ears. However, until we know more about chloramphenicol in breastfeeding, other medicines might be recommended.

【8】Wash your hands thoroughly before picking up your baby.

【9】If you notice your baby has a stomach upset, seems unusually unsettled, has a rash, or seems an unusual colour, talk to your health visitor, midwife or doctor as soon as possible.

【10】Chloramphenicol and fertility
-----------------------------

【11】There's no evidence to suggest that using chloramphenicol reduces fertility in either men or women.

【12】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【13】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【14】Find out more about how chloramphenicol can affect you and your baby during pregnancy on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPs) website.

【15】More in Chloramphenicol
-----------------------

【16】*   About chloramphenicol
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using chloramphenicol with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【17】Page last reviewed: 9 February 2022  
Next review due: 9 February 2025

source_info.title: Diazepam
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about diazepam
===============================

【1】How does diazepam work?

【2】Diazepam belongs to a group of medicines called benzodiazepines.

【3】It works by increasing the levels of a calming chemical in your brain.

【4】Depending on your health condition, this can make you feel drowsy, relieve anxiety, stop seizures or relax tense muscles.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】Diazepam will work quite quickly or more slowly depending on what you're taking it for:

【7】*   **seizures or fits** – diazepam rectal tubes should start to work within 10 minutes
*   **anxiety** – you should start to feel a bit better within a few hours, but it may take a week or 2 for you to feel the full effects
*   **muscle spasms** – you should begin to feel less pain after 15 minutes. Your muscles will start to relax when you have been taking diazepam regularly for a few days

【8】Are there any long-term side effects?

【9】You'll usually take diazepam for no longer than 2 to 4 weeks.

【10】If you're prescribed diazepam for more than 4 weeks, your dose may be reduced gradually when you stop taking it to prevent withdrawal symptoms.

【11】Is diazepam addictive?

【12】It is possible to become addicted to diazepam. To reduce the risk of becoming addicted, it's best to take the lowest dose that treats your symptoms, and to take it for only a short time (2 to 4 weeks).

【13】You're more likely to get addicted if you need to take a higher dose for a longer time, or if you've ever had problems with alcohol or drugs.

【14】### Important

【15】Take diazepam tablets or liquid for as short a time as possible.

【16】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【17】If you have been taking a high dose of diazepam or have been taking it for a long time, your doctor will probably recommend reducing your dose gradually.

【18】If you suddenly stop taking it, you may get some side effects, such as:

【19】*   confusion
*   seizures or fits
*   depression
*   feeling nervous or irritable
*   sweating
*   diarrhoea

【20】You're less likely to get these side effects if you reduce your dose gradually.

【21】Are there other medicines for anxiety and for seizures or fits?

【22】There are different types of medicines for treating anxiety or seizures or fits.

【23】For anxiety, depending on your symptoms, you may need a medicine to treat your physical symptoms, as well as your psychological ones.

【24】Your doctor will usually start you on a type of antidepressant called a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as sertraline, paroxetine or escitalopram.

【25】For seizures or fits, a medicine called midazolam can be used. It comes as a pre-filled syringe and is given inside your mouth between your cheek and your gum (buccal cavity).

【26】You can use this instead of rectal diazepam, which is inserted into your bottom (anus).

【27】You can discuss the different options with your doctor. They'll help you decide which medicine is best for you.

【28】Can I take diazepam before surgery?

【29】Diazepam can be given as a pre-med to relax you before an operation or dental treatment that may be uncomfortable or make you feel anxious.

【30】It's important to tell your doctor or dentist if you're already taking diazepam.

【31】### Important

【32】Tell your doctor that you take diazepam if you're going to be put to sleep (using a general anaesthetic) or having any kind of major operation.

【33】Can I take diazepam with me if I'm travelling abroad?

【34】It depends on which country you're travelling to. Different countries have different rules and regulations for diazepam.

【35】It's important to plan ahead and find out whether you can take your medicine abroad. It's best to only take the amount that you need while abroad.

【36】You can check the rules by contacting the embassy for the country you're visiting. You can find a full list of foreign embassies in the UK on the GOV.UK website.

【37】Will it affect my contraception?

【38】Diazepam will not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【39】But some contraceptive pills can keep diazepam in your body for longer and increase its effect.

【40】You can also get bleeding in between your periods if you take diazepam and contraceptive pills together.

【41】But your contraception will still work.

【42】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【43】Do not drive a car or ride a bike if diazepam makes you sleepy, gives you blurred vision, or makes you feel dizzy, clumsy or unable to concentrate or make decisions.

【44】This may be more likely when you first start taking diazepam, but it could happen at any time, for example when starting another medicine.

【45】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【46】Even if your ability to drive is not affected, the police have the right to request a saliva sample to check how much diazepam is in your body.

【47】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking diazepam. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【48】Can I operate machinery or tools while I'm taking it?

【49】Do not operate machinery or tools if you get any side effects, such as feeling sleepy, being forgetful, or poor co-ordination.

【50】Can I drink alcohol while taking diazepam?

【51】Do not drink alcohol while you're taking diazepam. Alcohol can increase the effects of diazepam. It can make you go into a very deep sleep. There's a risk you will not be able to breathe properly, and you may have difficulty waking up.

【52】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【53】Grapefruit juice may increase the amount of diazepam in your blood. It's a good idea to avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice while taking diazepam.

【54】Caffeine is a stimulant and may reduce the calming effects of diazepam. It's best not to have drinks like coffee, tea, cola and energy drinks because they contain caffeine.

【55】Do not drink alcohol while you're taking diazepam.

【56】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【57】Using cannabis, heroin or methadone with diazepam will increase the drowsy effects of diazepam. It can make you go into a very deep sleep.

【58】There's a risk you will not be able to breathe properly, and you may have difficulty waking up.

【59】Using cocaine or other stimulants like MDMA (ecstasy) and amphetamines with diazepam can also make you drowsy.

【60】Talk to your doctor if you think you might use recreational drugs while taking diazepam.

【61】You can find out more about the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

【62】Can lifestyle changes help with anxiety and insomnia?

【63】If you have anxiety, there are some lifestyle changes you can make to help ease symptoms:

【64】*   try a book or online course on anxiety
*   exercise regularly
*   learn to relax
*   avoid caffeine
*   quit smoking if you can
*   try not to drink alcohol
*   contact support groups run by charities like Anxiety UK, Mind and Rethink Mental Illness

【65】If you're having trouble sleeping, there are some things you can do to help with insomnia and getting to sleep:

【66】*   set regular times for going to bed and waking up
*   relax before bedtime – try taking a warm bath or listening to calming music
*   use thick curtains or blinds, an eye mask and earplugs to stop you being woken up by light and noise
*   avoid caffeine, cigarettes, vaping, alcohol, heavy meals and exercise for a few hours before going to bed
*   do not watch TV or use phones, tablets or computers just before going to bed
*   do not nap during the day
*   write a list of your worries, and any ideas about how to solve them, before you go to bed to help you forget about them until the morning

【67】More in Diazepam
----------------

【68】*   About diazepam
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking diazepam with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【69】Page last reviewed: 3 February 2022  
Next review due: 3 February 2025

【34】It depends on which country you're travelling to. Different countries have different rules and regulations for diazepam.

【49】Do not operate machinery or tools if you get any side effects, such as feeling sleepy, being forgetful, or poor co-ordination.

【50】Can I drink alcohol while taking diazepam?

【51】Do not drink alcohol while you're taking diazepam. Alcohol can increase the effects of diazepam. It can make you go into a very deep sleep. There's a risk you will not be able to breathe properly, and you may have difficulty waking up.

【52】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【53】Grapefruit juice may increase the amount of diazepam in your blood. It's a good idea to avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice while taking diazepam.

【54】Caffeine is a stimulant and may reduce the calming effects of diazepam. It's best not to have drinks like coffee, tea, cola and energy drinks because they contain caffeine.

【55】Do not drink alcohol while you're taking diazepam.

【56】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【57】Using cannabis, heroin or methadone with diazepam will increase the drowsy effects of diazepam. It can make you go into a very deep sleep.

【58】There's a risk you will not be able to breathe properly, and you may have difficulty waking up.

【59】Using cocaine or other stimulants like MDMA (ecstasy) and amphetamines with diazepam can also make you drowsy.

【60】Talk to your doctor if you think you might use recreational drugs while taking diazepam.

【61】You can find out more about the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

【62】Can lifestyle changes help with anxiety and insomnia?

【63】If you have anxiety, there are some lifestyle changes you can make to help ease symptoms:

【64】*   try a book or online course on anxiety
*   exercise regularly
*   learn to relax
*   avoid caffeine
*   quit smoking if you can
*   try not to drink alcohol
*   contact support groups run by charities like Anxiety UK, Mind and Rethink Mental Illness

【65】If you're having trouble sleeping, there are some things you can do to help with insomnia and getting to sleep:

【66】*   set regular times for going to bed and waking up
*   relax before bedtime – try taking a warm bath or listening to calming music
*   use thick curtains or blinds, an eye mask and earplugs to stop you being woken up by light and noise
*   avoid caffeine, cigarettes, vaping, alcohol, heavy meals and exercise for a few hours before going to bed
*   do not watch TV or use phones, tablets or computers just before going to bed
*   do not nap during the day
*   write a list of your worries, and any ideas about how to solve them, before you go to bed to help you forget about them until the morning

【67】More in Diazepam
----------------

【68】*   About diazepam
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking diazepam with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【69】Page last reviewed: 3 February 2022  
Next review due: 3 February 2025

source_info.title: Pseudoephedrine (Sudafed)
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take pseudoephedrine \- Brand names: Sudafed, Galpseud, Boots Decongestant, Care Decongestant
================================================================================================================

【1】Who can take pseudoephedrine
----------------------------

【2】Most adults and children aged 12 years and over can take pseudoephedrine.

【3】You can sometimes give pseudoephedrine to children aged 6 years and over if they have a stuffy nose, but this depends on their symptoms. Ask a pharmacist for advice.

【4】### Important

【5】Do not give pseudoephedrine to children under 6 years. This includes cough and cold medicines containing pseudoephedrine. Always check the label.

【6】Who may not be able to take pseudoephedrine
-------------------------------------------

【7】Pseudoephedrine is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell a pharmacist or doctor before taking it if you have:

【8】*   ever had an allergic reaction to pseudoephedrine or any other medicine
*   high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   heart disease
*   taken medicines for depression known as monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) in the last 2 weeks
*   diabetes
*   an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism)
*   glaucoma (increased pressure in the eye)
*   an enlarged prostate (this causes difficulty peeing or needing to pee often)
*   liver or kidney problems

【9】More in Pseudoephedrine (Sudafed)
---------------------------------

【10】*   About pseudoephedrine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【11】Page last reviewed: 2 November 2022  
Next review due: 2 November 2025
