source_info.title: Diverticular disease and diverticulitis
source_info.text:
【0】Diverticular disease and diverticulitis
=======================================

【1】**Diverticular disease and diverticulitis are conditions that affect the large intestine (bowel), causing tummy (abdominal) pain and other symptoms. They're caused by small bulges or pouches in the walls of the intestine called diverticula.**

【2】Information:

【3】Diverticulosis is when there are diverticula in your bowel, but they're not causing any symptoms.

【4】Most people will get some diverticula as they get older, but most people will not get any symptoms.

【5】Symptoms of diverticular disease and diverticulitis
---------------------------------------------------

【6】The symptoms of diverticular disease include:

【7】*   pain in the lower left side of your tummy (abdomen) – a small number of people get pain on the right side
*   tummy pain that gets worse after you eat, and gets better after you poo or fart
*   constipation
*   diarrhoea
*   blood in your poo
*   bloating

【8】If your intestine becomes infected or inflamed, it's called diverticulitis. You may also have symptoms such as:

【9】*   severe, constant tummy pain
*   high temperature
*   bleeding or passing slime (mucus) from your bottom

【10】Information:

【11】The symptoms of diverticular disease and diverticulitis are similar to those of other conditions such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

【12】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【13】*   there is blood or slime (mucus) in your poo
*   you have tummy pain that's getting worse or does not go away
*   you have a high temperature, or you feel hot or shivery
*   you keep being sick and cannot keep fluid down
*   you have diarrhoea for more than 7 days or are being sick for more than 2 days

【14】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【15】Tests for diverticular disease and diverticulitis
-------------------------------------------------

【16】The GP will ask questions to find out what's causing your symptoms. You may need a blood test or to give a poo sample to help find what's wrong.

【17】You may need further tests to confirm if you have diverticular disease or diverticulitis and rule out other conditions. Further tests you may have include:

【18】*   a colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy, where a thin tube with a small camera on it is used to check inside your bowels
*   a CT scan

【19】Treating diverticular disease and diverticulitis
------------------------------------------------

【20】Treatments that can help with the symptoms of diverticular disease include:

【21】*   painkillers such as paracetamol
*   bulk-forming laxatives for constipation and diarrhoea
*   medicines to help with stomach cramps (antispasmodics)

【22】Diverticulitis is treated with:

【23】*   antibiotics if the diverticulitis is caused by an infection
*   painkillers such as paracetamol

【24】Things you can do to help with diverticular disease and diverticulitis
----------------------------------------------------------------------

【25】If you have diverticular disease or diverticulitis there are things you can do to reduce the risk of your symptoms getting worse in the future.

【26】### Do

【27】*   eat a healthy, balanced diet including whole grains, fruits and vegetables – there are no specific foods you need to avoid

【28】*   slowly increase how much fibre you eat if you do not each much fibre – and make sure to also drink plenty of water

【29】*   stop smoking if you smoke

【30】*   maintain a healthy weight

【31】### Don’t

【32】*   do not take NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen) or opioid painkillers (such as codeine) – they can cause stomach problems or constipation, and increase the risk of getting a hole (perforation) in your bowel

【33】Complications of diverticulitis
-------------------------------

【34】Rarely, diverticulitis can lead to serious complications such as:

【35】*   a build-up of pus (abscess) in your bowel
*   a blockage in your bowel
*   an opening from your bowel to another organ, such as your bladder, called a fistula
*   a hole (perforation) in your bowel, which can cause a severe infection called peritonitis

【36】These problems can sometimes be treated with antibiotics or surgery.

【37】For example, you may need surgery to drain an abscess or remove an infected part of the bowel.

【38】Some people will need to have a colostomy (where your bowel is brought out of a hole in your tummy and a bag is attached to collect your poo).

【39】Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:
----------------------------------------------------

【40】You or someone you care for:

【41】*   has severe tummy pain and is either vomiting, has a swollen tummy, or cannot poo or fart
*   is bleeding heavily from their bottom
*   is acting confused, has pale or blotchy skin, has a very high or low temperature, or is breathless or breathing rapidly – these could all be signs of sepsis

【42】Page last reviewed: 07 September 2023  
Next review due: 07 September 2026

source_info.title: Cornea transplant
source_info.text:
【0】When it is needed \- Cornea transplant
======================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  When it is needed
3.  How it is performed
4.  Afterwards
5.  Risks

【3】**Cornea transplants are usually performed to correct problems with your eyesight caused by certain medical conditions.**

【4】They're also sometimes used to relieve pain in a damaged or diseased eye, or to treat emergencies such as severe infection or damage.

【5】Some of the most common reasons for requiring a cornea transplant include:

【6】Keratoconus
-----------

【7】Keratoconus is a condition that causes the cornea to weaken, get thinner and change shape. It affects between 1 in 3,000 to 1 in 10,000 people.

【8】The exact cause of the condition is unknown. There may be a genetic link, and it's more common in people with multiple allergic conditions, such as eczema and asthma. 

【9】Keratoconus is one of the most common reasons for corneal transplantation in younger patients.

【10】It does not usually appear until the early teens, but can occasionally occur earlier.

【11】Many cases of keratoconus are mild and can be managed by using contact lenses or glasses.

【12】But in some patients it can progress to the point where a cornea transplant is necessary.

【13】Degenerative conditions
-----------------------

【14】Certain conditions may affect the eyes and cause them to slowly develop problems over time.

【15】One example is Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy, where the functioning of the cells lining the inner cornea (the endothelium) begins to deteriorate. 

【16】This happens faster as you get older. As the cells weaken, instead of clearing excess fluid, they allow it to build up, leading to cloudy vision.

【17】Other reasons
-------------

【18】A cornea transplant may also be performed if:

【19】*   a small hole develops in the cornea as a result of damage (known as corneal perforation)
*   an infection in the cornea does not respond to antibiotics and keeps returning
*   the cornea is scarred because of an infection or injury

【20】Page last reviewed: 13 July 2021  
Next review due: 13 July 2024

【21】*   Previous : Cornea transplant
*   Next : How it is performed

source_info.title: Latanoprost
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about latanoprost \- Brand names: Xalatan, Monopost
====================================================================

【1】How does it work?

【2】Latanoprost is from a group of medicines known as prostaglandin analogues.

【3】It works by increasing the natural flow of fluid from inside your eye into your bloodstream. This lowers the pressure within your eye and stops your sight getting worse.

【4】How long does it take to work?

【5】The pressure in your eye will start to reduce 3 to 4 hours after using the eye drops.

【6】Latanoprost reaches full effect after 8 to 12 hours, and the reduced pressure will last for at least 24 hours.

【7】Are there any long-term side effects?

【8】Latanoprost can be used for many years with no long-term side effects.

【9】Are there other treatments for high pressure in the eye?

【10】There are other eye medicines that work in a similar way to latanoprost, including:

【11】*   bimatoprost
*   tafluprost
*   travoprost

【12】Latanoprost can be combined with a beta blocker called timolol. These eye drops are known by the brand names Xalacom and Fixapost.

【13】They can be prescribed to reduce high pressure in the eye, by helping to drain fluid from inside it.

【14】Treatments for glaucoma can include laser treatments and surgery. They cannot reverse any loss of vision, but they can help to stop it getting worse.

【15】Can latanoprost make heart problems worse?

【16】In rare cases, a side effect of latanoprost can be chest pain (angina) and a fast heart rate (palpitations).

【17】However, if you have an existing heart condition such as atrial fibrillation, there are no reports of latanoprost making it worse.

【18】Will it affect my contraception?

【19】Latanoprost does not stop any type of contraception from working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【20】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【21】You may have blurred vision for for a short while after putting the latanoprost drops in. If this happens to you, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery until you can see clearly again.

【22】Many people with glaucoma can continue driving a car or motorbike, but their eyesight must be up to the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency's (DVLA's) standards.

【23】GOV.UK has more information on eye conditions and driving

【24】Can I drink alcohol while using latanoprost?

【25】Yes, you can drink alcohol with latanoprost.

【26】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【27】You can eat and drink normally while using latanoprost.

【28】More in Latanoprost
-------------------

【29】*   About latanoprost
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using latanoprost with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【0】Common questions about latanoprost \- Brand names: Xalatan, Monopost
====================================================================

【1】How does it work?

【2】Latanoprost is from a group of medicines known as prostaglandin analogues.

【3】It works by increasing the natural flow of fluid from inside your eye into your bloodstream. This lowers the pressure within your eye and stops your sight getting worse.

【4】How long does it take to work?

【5】The pressure in your eye will start to reduce 3 to 4 hours after using the eye drops.

【6】Latanoprost reaches full effect after 8 to 12 hours, and the reduced pressure will last for at least 24 hours.

【7】Are there any long-term side effects?

【13】They can be prescribed to reduce high pressure in the eye, by helping to drain fluid from inside it.

【14】Treatments for glaucoma can include laser treatments and surgery. They cannot reverse any loss of vision, but they can help to stop it getting worse.

【17】However, if you have an existing heart condition such as atrial fibrillation, there are no reports of latanoprost making it worse.

【18】Will it affect my contraception?

【19】Latanoprost does not stop any type of contraception from working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【20】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【22】Many people with glaucoma can continue driving a car or motorbike, but their eyesight must be up to the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency's (DVLA's) standards.

【23】GOV.UK has more information on eye conditions and driving

【24】Can I drink alcohol while using latanoprost?

【25】Yes, you can drink alcohol with latanoprost.

【26】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【27】You can eat and drink normally while using latanoprost.

source_info.title: Citalopram
source_info.text:
【0】Taking citalopram with other medicines and herbal supplements
=============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines can be affected by citalopram, and other medicines can affect the way citalopram works. Using citalopram with other medicines can increase the chances of you having side effects.

【3】Before you start taking citalopram, tell your doctor if you're taking:

【4】*   any medicines that affect your heartbeat – citalopram can make your heart beat faster or cause an irregular heartbeat  
    (arrhythmia)
*   any other medicines for depression – some rarely used antidepressants can affect citalopram and cause very high blood pressure even if you have not taken them for a few weeks

【5】Mixing citalopram with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【6】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're being treated with citalopram because it increases your risk of side effects.

【7】It's not possible to say that other herbal remedies or supplements are safe to take with citalopram. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【10】More in Citalopram
------------------

【11】*   About citalopram
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking citalopram with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

Next review due: 9 February 2025

source_info.title: Atopic eczema
source_info.text:
【0】Complications \- Atopic eczema
==============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications

【3】**People with atopic eczema can sometimes develop further physical and psychological problems.**

【4】Bacterial skin infections
-------------------------

【5】As atopic eczema can cause your skin to become cracked and broken, there's a risk of the skin becoming infected with bacteria. The risk is higher if you scratch your eczema or do not use your treatments correctly.

【6】Signs of a bacterial infection can include:

【7】*   fluid oozing from the skin
*   a yellow crust on the skin surface
*   small yellowish-white spots appearing in the eczema
*   the skin becoming swollen and sore
*   feeling hot and shivery and generally unwell

【8】Your normal symptoms may also get rapidly worse and your eczema may not respond to your regular treatments.

【9】You should see a doctor as soon as possible if you think your or your child's skin may have become infected.

【10】They may prescribe antibiotics to treat the infection, as well as making sure the skin inflammation that led to the infection is well controlled.

【11】Speak to a GP if these do not help or your symptoms get worse.

【12】Once your infection has cleared, a GP will prescribe new supplies of any creams and ointments you're using to avoid contamination. Old treatments should be disposed of.

【13】Viral skin infections
---------------------

【14】It's also possible for eczema to become infected with the herpes simplex virus, which normally causes cold sores. This can develop into a serious condition called eczema herpeticum.

【15】Symptoms of eczema herpeticum include:

【16】*   areas of painful eczema that quickly get worse
*   groups of fluid-filled blisters that break open and leave small, shallow open sores on the skin
*   feeling hot, shivery and generally unwell, in some cases

【17】Eczema herpeticum rash on white skin.

【18】Credit:

【19】JOHN RADCLIFFE HOSPITAL/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/256206/view

【20】Contact a doctor immediately if you suspect eczema herpeticum. If you cannot contact a GP, call NHS 111 or go to your nearest hospital.

【21】If you're diagnosed with eczema herpeticum, you'll be given an antiviral medicine called aciclovir.

【22】Psychological effects
---------------------

【23】As well as affecting you or your child physically, atopic eczema may also affect you psychologically.

【24】### Bullying

【25】Schoolchildren may experience teasing or bullying if they have atopic eczema. Any kind of bullying can be traumatic and difficult for a child to deal with.

【26】Your child may become quiet and withdrawn. Explain the situation to your child's teacher and encourage your child to tell you how they're feeling.

【27】Find out about regional support groups on the National Eczema Society website where you may be able to meet other people living with atopic eczema.

【28】### Problems sleeping

【29】Sleep-related problems are common among people with eczema.

【30】A lack of sleep may affect mood and behaviour. It may also make it more difficult to concentrate at school or work.

【31】If your child has problems sleeping because of their eczema, they may fall behind with their schoolwork. It might help to let their teacher know about their condition so it can be taken into consideration.

【32】During a severe eczema flare-up, your child may need time off from school. This may also affect their ability to keep up with their studies.

【33】### Self-confidence

【34】Atopic eczema can affect the self-confidence of both adults and children. Children may find it particularly difficult to deal with their condition, which may lead to them having a poor self-image.

【35】If your child is severely lacking in confidence, it may affect their ability to develop social skills. Support and encouragement will help boost your child's self-confidence and give them a more positive attitude about their appearance.

【36】Speak to a GP if you're concerned your child's eczema is severely affecting their confidence. They may benefit from specialist psychological support.

【37】Page last reviewed: 13 November 2023  
Next review due: 13 November 2026

【38】*   Previous : Treatment

source_info.title: Sickle cell disease
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Sickle cell disease
===============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Carriers

【3】**Sickle cell disease can cause a wide range of symptoms.**

【4】These can start from a few months of age, although many children have few or no symptoms if treatment is started early on.

【5】The main symptoms are:

【6】*   painful episodes
*   getting infections often
*   anaemia

【7】Painful episodes
----------------

【8】Episodes of pain known as sickle cell crises are one of the most common and distressing symptoms of sickle cell disease.

【9】They happen when blood vessels to part of the body become blocked.

【10】The pain can be severe and last for several days or weeks.

【11】A sickle cell crisis can affect any part of the body, but is most common in the limbs or back.

【12】How often someone with sickle cell disease gets episodes of pain varies a lot.

【13】Some people may have one every week, while others may have less than 1 a year.

【14】It's not always clear what triggers pain, but sometimes painful episodes can be caused by the weather (such as wind, rain or cold), dehydration, stress or strenuous exercise.

【15】Infections
----------

【16】People with sickle cell disease are more vulnerable to infections, particularly when they're young.

【17】Infections can range from mild, such as colds, to much more serious and potentially life threatening, such as meningitis.

【18】Vaccinations and daily doses of antibiotics can help reduce the risk of many infections.

【19】Anaemia
-------

【20】Nearly all people with sickle cell disease have anaemia, where the haemoglobin in the blood is low.

【21】Haemoglobin is the substance found in red blood cells that's used to transport oxygen around the body.

【22】This does not usually cause many symptoms, but sometimes it can get worse if you become infected with the virus that causes slapped cheek syndrome (parvovirus).

【23】This can lead to a sudden drop in the number of red blood cells and may cause additional symptoms, such as headaches, a rapid heartbeat, dizziness and fainting.

【24】It's usually treated with a blood transfusion.

【25】Other problems
--------------

【26】Sickle cell disease can also sometimes cause a wide range of other problems.

【27】These include:

【28】*   delayed growth during childhood and delayed puberty
*   gallstones, which can cause tummy (abdominal) pain and yellow skin and eyes (jaundice)
*   bone and joint pain
*   a persistent and painful erection of the penis (priapism), which can sometimes last several hours
*   painful open sores on the lower legs (leg ulcers)
*   strokes or transient ischaemic attacks, where the flow of blood to the brain is blocked or interrupted
*   a serious lung condition called acute chest syndrome, which can cause a fever, cough, chest pain and breathing difficulties
*   swelling of the spleen, which can cause shortness of breath, a rapid heartbeat, tummy pain, a swollen tummy and anaemia
*   eyesight problems, such as floaters, blurred or patchy vision, reduced night vision and occasionally sudden vision loss
*   high blood pressure in the blood vessels that carry blood from the heart to the lungs (pulmonary hypertension) 
*   kidney or urinary problems, including blood in the urine and bedwetting

【29】Find out how sickle cell disease is treated

【30】Page last reviewed: 30 November 2022  
Next review due: 30 November 2025

【31】*   Previous : Sickle cell disease
*   Next : Causes

source_info.title: Tramadol
source_info.text:
【0】Taking tramadol with other medicines and herbal supplements
===========================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines can affect the way tramadol works and increase the chances of you having side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor if you are taking any medicines:

【4】*   for depression
*   for mental health problems
*   for pain relief
*   to help you sleep
*   to reduce tension or anxiety
*   to treat symptoms of an allergy
*   to help prevent blood clots (such as warfarin)
*   to treat an infection

【5】Some medicines may weaken or shorten the effect of tramadol. Tell your doctor if you're taking:

【6】*   carbamazepine to treat epilepsy
*   buprenorphine, a painkiller
*   Ondansetron, to stop you feeling sick
*   Rifampicin, an antibiotic

【7】### Important

【8】Do not take medicines called monoamine oxidase inhibitors or MAOIs (which are used to treat depression) with tramadol. The combination can cause significant side effects such as anxiety, confusion and hallucinations.

【9】Taking tramadol with other painkillers
--------------------------------------

【10】It's safe to take tramadol with paracetamol, ibuprofen or aspirin (aspirin is only suitable for most people aged 16 and over).

【11】Some everyday painkillers that you can buy from pharmacies contain codeine, which is a similar medicine to tramadol. Codeine-containing painkillers that you can buy from pharmacies These include co-codamol, Nurofen Plus and Solpadeine. Do not take these pharmacy-bought painkillers with tramadol because you are more likely to get side effects.

【12】Mixing tramadol with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------

【13】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with tramadol. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【14】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【15】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【16】More in Tramadol
----------------

【17】*   About tramadol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking tramadol with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【18】Page last reviewed: 19 January 2022  
Next review due: 19 January 2025

source_info.title: Aneurysm (brain), see Brain aneurysm
source_info.text:
【0】Aneurysm (brain), see Brain aneurysm
Overview \- Brain aneurysm
==========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Prevention

【3】**An aneurysm is a bulge in a blood vessel caused by a weakness in the blood vessel wall, usually where it branches.**

【4】As blood passes through the weakened blood vessel, the blood pressure causes a small area to bulge outwards like a balloon.

【5】Aneurysms can develop in any blood vessel in the body, but the 2 most common places are:

【6】*   the artery that transports blood away from the heart to the rest of the body (the abdominal aorta)
*   the brain

【7】This topic is about brain aneurysms.

【8】There's a separate topic about abdominal aortic aneurysm.

【9】About brain aneurysms
---------------------

【10】The medical term for an aneurysm that develops inside the brain is an intracranial or cerebral aneurysm.

【11】Most brain aneurysms only cause noticeable symptoms if they burst (rupture).

【12】This leads to an extremely serious condition known as a subarachnoid haemorrhage, where bleeding caused by the ruptured aneurysm can cause extensive brain damage and symptoms.

【13】Symptoms of a burst brain aneurysm include:

【14】*   a sudden agonising headache – it's been described as a "thunderclap headache", similar to a sudden hit on the head, resulting in a blinding pain unlike anything experienced before
*   a stiff neck
*   sickness and vomiting
*   pain on looking at light

【15】Find out more about the symptoms of a brain aneurysm

【16】A ruptured brain aneurysm is a medical emergency.

【17】If you think someone has had a brain haemorrhage, call 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance.

【18】How brain aneurysms are treated
-------------------------------

【19】If a brain aneurysm is detected before it ruptures, treatment may be recommended to prevent it rupturing in future.

【20】Most aneurysms do not rupture, so treatment is only carried out if the risk of a rupture is particularly high.

【21】Factors that affect whether treatment is recommended include your age, the size and position of the aneurysm, your family medical history, and any other health conditions you have.

【22】If treatment is recommended, this usually involves either filling the aneurysm with tiny metal coils (coiling) or an open operation to seal it shut with a tiny metal clip (surgical clipping).

【23】The same techniques used to prevent ruptures are also used to treat brain aneurysms that have already ruptured.

【24】If your risk of a rupture is low, you'll have regular check-ups to monitor your aneurysm.

【25】You may also be given medicine to reduce your blood pressure and advice about ways you can reduce your chances of a rupture, such as stopping smoking if you smoke.

【26】Why brain aneurysms develop
---------------------------

【27】Exactly what causes the wall of affected blood vessels to weaken is still unclear, although risk factors have been identified.

【28】These include: 

【29】*   smoking
*   high blood pressure
*   a family history of brain aneurysms

【30】In some cases, an aneurysm may develop because there was a weakness in the walls of the blood vessels at birth.

【31】Who's affected
--------------

【32】It's difficult to estimate exactly how many people are affected by brain aneurysms because they usually cause no symptoms and pass undetected.

【33】Some experts believe it could be as high as 1 in 20 people, while others think the figure is much lower at around 1 in 100 people.

【34】The number of aneurysms that actually rupture is much smaller. Only around 1 in 15,000 people have a ruptured brain aneurysm in England each year.

【35】Brain aneurysms can develop in anyone at any age, but are more common in people over the age of 40.

【36】Women tend to be affected more commonly than men.

【37】Preventing brain aneurysms
--------------------------

【38】The best way to prevent getting an aneurysm, or reduce the risk of an aneurysm growing bigger and possibly rupturing, is to avoid activities that could damage your blood vessels.

【39】Things to avoid include:

【40】*   smoking
*   eating a high-fat diet
*   not controlling high blood pressure
*   being overweight or obese

【41】Find out more about preventing aneurysms

【42】Page last reviewed: 11 April 2022  
Next review due: 11 April 2025

【43】*   Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: Blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
source_info.text:
【0】Blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
====================================

【1】**Cyanosis is where your skin or lips turn blue or grey. It can be a sign of a serious problem.**

【2】How to tell if you have blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
------------------------------------------------------------

【3】If you have cyanosis, you may notice a blue or grey colour on your:

【4】*   lips
*   tongue
*   gums
*   skin 通用删除1(英):<u>(black or brown skin may turn grey - this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, lips, gums and inside the eyelids)</u>
*   ears
*   under your nails

【5】Your hands and feet are usually a normal temperature. They may be cold if you also have poor blood circulation, which can be a cause of cyanosis.

【6】Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

【7】*   you or your child's lips, tongue, face or skin suddenly turn blue or grey - on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, lips, gums and inside the eyelids

【8】You or your child may also:

【9】*   have difficulty breathing
*   have chest pain
*   be confused, drowsy or dizzy

【10】Your child may also be limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do. Their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face.

【11】These are signs of a serious medical problem.

【12】Urgent advice: Get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------

【13】*   you or your child's fingers, toes, hands and feet are blue or grey - on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet

【14】This may be a sign of poor blood circulation.

【15】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【16】Causes of blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
----------------------------------------------

【17】Blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis) happens when there's not enough oxygen in your blood, or you have poor blood circulation.

【18】It can be caused by a serious problem with the:

【19】*   lungs, like asthma or pneumonia
*   airways, like choking or croup
*   heart, like heart failure or congenital heart disease

【20】Other causes of cyanosis include:

【21】*   Raynaud's, which affects your fingers and toes
*   beta blockers, medicines used to treat high blood pressure
*   a blood clot that stops the blood supply to a limb
*   being in cold air or water
*   wearing clothing or jewellery that's too tight

【22】Treatment for blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
--------------------------------------------------

【23】Cyanosis is a symptom of many different conditions.

【24】Treatment depends on the cause.

【25】Page last reviewed: 04 October 2023  
Next review due: 04 October 2026

source_info.title: Stillbirth
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Stillbirth
====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  What happens if your unborn baby dies
4.  Preventing stillbirth

【3】**A large proportion of stillbirths happen in otherwise healthy babies, and the reason often can't be explained. But there are some causes we do know about.**

【4】Complications with the placenta
-------------------------------

【5】Many stillbirths are linked to complications with the placenta. The placenta is the organ that links the baby's blood supply to the mother's and nourishes the baby in the womb.

【6】If there have been problems with the placenta, stillborn babies are usually born perfectly formed, although often small.

【7】With more research, it's hoped that placental causes may be better understood, leading to improved detection and better care for these babies.

【8】Other causes of stillbirth
--------------------------

【9】Other conditions that can cause or may be associated with stillbirth include:

【10】*   bleeding (haemorrhage) before or during labour
*   placental abruption – where the placenta separates from the womb before the baby is born (there may be bleeding or abdominal pain)
*   pre-eclampsia – a condition that causes high blood pressure in the mother
*   a problem with the umbilical cord, which attaches the placenta to the baby's tummy button – the cord can slip down through the entrance of the womb before the baby is born (cord prolapse) or can be wrapped around the baby and become knotted 
*   intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) or obstetric cholestasis – a liver disorder associated with severe itching during pregnancy
*   a genetic physical defect in the baby
*   pre-existing diabetes
*   an infection in the mother that also affects the baby

【11】Infections
----------

【12】Usually this will be a bacterial infection that travels from the vagina into the womb (uterus). These bacteria include group B streptococcus, E. coli, klebsiella, enterococcus, Haemophilus influenza, chlamydia, and mycoplasma or ureaplasma.

【13】Some bacterial infections, such as chlamydia and mycoplasma or ureaplasma, which are sexually transmitted infections, can be prevented by using condoms during sex.

【14】Other infections that can cause stillbirths include:  

【15】*   rubella – commonly known as German measles
*   flu – it's recommended that all pregnant women have the seasonal flu vaccine, regardless of stage of pregnancy
*   parvovirus B19 – this causes slapped cheek syndrome, a common childhood infection that's dangerous for pregnant women
*   coxsackie virus – this can cause hand, foot and mouth disease in humans
*   cytomegalovirus – a common virus spread through bodily fluids, such as saliva or urine, which often causes few symptoms in the mother
*   herpes simplex – the virus that causes genital herpes and cold sores
*   listeriosis – an infection that usually develops after eating food contaminated by listeria bacteria 通用删除1(英):<u>(see foods to avoid in pregnancy)</u>
*   leptospirosis – a bacterial infection spread by animals such as mice and rats
*   Lyme disease – a bacterial infection spread by infected ticks
*   Q fever – a bacterial infection caught from animals such as sheep, goats and cows
*   toxoplasmosis – an infection caused by a parasite found in soil and cat faeces
*   malaria – a serious tropical disease spread by mosquitoes

【16】Increased risk
--------------

【17】There are also a number of things that may increase your risk of having a stillborn baby, including:

【18】*   having twins or a multiple pregnancy
*   having a baby who doesn't grow as they should in the womb
*   being over 35 years of age
*   smoking, drinking alcohol or misusing drugs while pregnant
*   being obese – having a body mass index above 30
*   having a pre-existing physical health condition, such as epilepsy

【19】Your baby's growth
------------------

【20】Your midwife will check the growth and wellbeing of your baby at each antenatal appointment and plot the baby's growth on a chart.

【21】Every baby is different and should grow to the size that's normal for them. Some babies are naturally small, but all babies should continue to grow steadily throughout pregnancy.

【22】If a baby is smaller than expected or their growth pattern tails off as the pregnancy continues, it may be because the placenta isn't working properly. This increases the risk of stillbirth.

【23】Problems with a baby's growth should be picked up during antenatal appointments.

【24】Your baby's movements
---------------------

【25】It's important to be aware of your baby's movements and know what's normal for your baby.

【26】Tell your midwife immediately if you notice the baby's movements slowing down or stopping. Don't wait until the next day.

【27】See preventing stillbirth for more information.

【28】Page last reviewed: 16 March 2021  
Next review due: 16 March 2024

【29】*   Previous : Stillbirth
*   Next : What happens if your unborn baby dies

【0】Causes \- Stillbirth
====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  What happens if your unborn baby dies
4.  Preventing stillbirth

【3】**A large proportion of stillbirths happen in otherwise healthy babies, and the reason often can't be explained. But there are some causes we do know about.**

【4】Complications with the placenta
-------------------------------

【5】Many stillbirths are linked to complications with the placenta. The placenta is the organ that links the baby's blood supply to the mother's and nourishes the baby in the womb.

【6】If there have been problems with the placenta, stillborn babies are usually born perfectly formed, although often small.

【7】With more research, it's hoped that placental causes may be better understood, leading to improved detection and better care for these babies.

source_info.title: Co-dydramol
source_info.text:
【0】About co-dydramol \- Brand names: Paramol, Remedeine, Remedeine Forte
=====================================================================

【1】Co-dydramol is a mixture of 2 different painkillers: paracetamol and dihydrocodeine. Dihydrocodeine belongs to a group of medicines called opiates.

【2】It's used to treat aches and pains, including headaches, migraines, muscle and joint pain, period pain and toothache.

【3】Paracetamol and dihydrocodeine work by blocking messengers in the nerves and brain that tell your body that you're in pain.

【4】You'll usually take co-dydramol when everyday painkillers such as aspirin, ibuprofen and paracetamol have not worked on their own.

【5】Co-dydramol comes in 4 different strengths. You can buy lower-strength tablets from pharmacies. Higher-strength tablets are only available on prescription.

【6】Co-dydramol usually comes as tablets.

【7】Key facts
---------

【8】*   Co-dydramol takes up to 1 hour to work and keeps working for about 5 hours.
*   The most common side effects of co-dydramol are constipation and feeling sick or sleepy.
*   If you've bought co-dydramol from a pharmacy, do not use it for more than 3 days without talking to your doctor.
*   It's possible to become addicted to the dihydrocodeine in co-dydramol, but your doctor will explain how to reduce the risks of becoming addicted.
*   If you need to take co-dydramol for more than a few weeks, your treatment plan may include details of how and when to stop taking this medicine.

【9】More in Co-dydramol
-------------------

【10】*   About co-dydramol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【11】Page last reviewed: 9 August 2023  
Next review due: 9 August 2026

source_info.title: Cataracts (children), see Childhood cataracts
source_info.text:
【0】Cataracts (children), see Childhood cataracts
Diagnosis \- Childhood cataracts
================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**It's important childhood cataracts are diagnosed as early as possible. Early treatment can significantly reduce the risk of long-term vision problems.**

【4】Newborn screening
-----------------

【5】All parents are offered a newborn physical screening examination for their baby within 72 hours of birth and again when their baby is 6 to 8 weeks old.

【6】Childhood cataracts are among the conditions screened for during the newborn physical examination.

【7】Your baby's eyes are checked by looking at their general appearance and how they move.

【8】If your baby's eye looks cloudy, it could be a sign they have cataracts.

【9】An important part of the check is looking for the "red reflex" using a bright light.

【10】The red reflex is a reflection from the back of the eye that's similar to the red eye effect sometimes seen in flash photography.

【11】If no red reflex, or a weak one, is seen, it may mean there's cloudiness in the lens.

【12】Vision tests for older babies and children
------------------------------------------

【13】Although cataracts can be present from birth (congenital), they sometimes do not develop until a child is older. 

【14】Visit a GP or tell your health visitor if you have any concerns about your child's eyesight at any stage.

【15】You should also make sure your child has routine eye tests to check for any problems with their vision.

【16】All children under the age of 16 are entitled to free sight tests, which they should have about every 2 years.

【17】Read more about eye tests for children.

【18】Referral to a specialist
------------------------

【19】If it's thought your baby or child may have cataracts, they'll usually be referred to hospital to see an ophthalmologist as soon as possible. 

【20】An ophthalmologist is a doctor who specialises in eye conditions and their treatment.

【21】Before the ophthalmologist examines your baby, they'll apply drops to their eyes to dilate (widen) their pupils.

【22】Although the drops will sting, they will not damage your baby's eyes and the effect will wear off after a few hours.

【23】The ophthalmologist will examine your baby's eyes using medical instruments that have a light at one end and produce a magnified image of the eye.

【24】Bright light is shone into your child's eyes, enabling the ophthalmologist to look inside them.

【25】They'll diagnose cataracts if they can see them in the lens.

【26】If your child is diagnosed with cataracts, the ophthalmologist will discuss the treatment options with you.

【27】Page last reviewed: 13 April 2022  
Next review due: 13 April 2025

【28】*   Previous : Causes
*   Next : Treatment

source_info.title: Crohn's disease
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Crohn's disease
===========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with

【3】**Without treatment, symptoms of Crohn's disease can be constant or may come and go every few weeks or months.**

【4】When the symptoms come back, it's called a flare-up or relapse. The periods between flare-ups are called remission.

【5】Common symptoms
---------------

【6】The main symptoms of Crohn's disease are:

【7】*   diarrhoea – which may come on suddenly
*   stomach aches and cramps – most often in the lower-right part of your tummy
*   blood in your poo
*   tiredness (fatigue)
*   weight loss

【8】You might not have all these symptoms.

【9】Other symptoms
--------------

【10】Some people with Crohn's disease also have:

【11】*   a high temperature
*   feeling and being sick
*   joint pains
*   sore, red eyes
*   patches of painful, red and swollen skin – usually on the legs
*   mouth ulcers

【12】Children with Crohn's disease may grow more slowly than usual.

【13】When to see a GP
----------------

【14】See a GP if you or your child have:

【15】*   blood in your poo
*   diarrhoea for more than 7 days
*   frequent stomach aches or cramps
*   lost weight for no reason, or your child is not growing as fast as you'd expect

【16】A GP will try to find out what's causing your symptoms and may refer you for tests to check for Crohn's disease.

【17】Page last reviewed: 22 April 2021  
Next review due: 22 April 2024

【18】*   Previous : Crohn's disease
*   Next : Diagnosis

source_info.title: Congenital heart disease
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Congenital heart disease
=====================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Types
3.  Symptoms
4.  Causes
5.  Diagnosis
6.  Treatment
7.  Complications
8.  Prevention

【3】**Treatment for congenital heart disease depends on the specific defect you or your child has.**

【4】The majority of congenital heart disease problems are mild heart defects and don't usually need to be treated, although it's likely that you'll have regular check-ups to monitor your health in an outpatient setting throughout life.

【5】More severe heart defects usually require surgery or catheter intervention (where a thin hollow tube is inserted into the heart via an artery) and long-term monitoring of the heart throughout adult life by a congenital heart disease specialist.

【6】In some cases, medications may be used to relieve symptoms or stabilise the condition before and/or after surgery or intervention.

【7】These may include diuretics (water tablets) to remove fluid from the body and make breathing easier, and other medication, such as digoxin to slow down the heartbeat and increase the strength of the heart's pumping function.

【8】Aortic valve stenosis
---------------------

【9】The urgency for treatment for aortic valve stenosis depends on how narrow the valve is. Treatment may be needed immediately, or it could be delayed until the development of symptoms.

【10】If treatment is required, a procedure called a balloon valvuloplasty is often the recommended treatment option in children and younger people.

【11】During the procedure, a small tube (catheter) is passed through the blood vessels to the site of the narrowed valve. A balloon attached to the catheter is inflated, which helps to stretch or widen the valve and relieve any blockage in blood flow.

【12】If balloon valvuloplasty is ineffective or unsuitable, it's usually necessary to remove and replace the valve using open heart surgery. This is where the surgeon makes a cut in the chest to access the heart.

【13】There are several options for replacing aortic valves, including valves made from animal or human tissue, or your own pulmonary valve. If the pulmonary valve is used, it will be replaced at the same time with a donor pulmonary valve. This type of specialised surgery is known as the Ross procedure. In older children or adults, it's more likely that metal valves will be used.

【14】Some people also develop a leak of the aortic valve which will require monitoring. If the leak starts to cause problems with the heart, the aortic valve will need to be replaced.

【15】Read more about aortic valve replacement.

【16】Coarctation of the aorta
------------------------

【17】If your child has the more serious form of coarctation of the aorta that develops shortly after birth, surgery to restore the flow of blood through the aorta is usually recommended in the first few days of life.

【18】Several surgical techniques can be used, including:

【19】*   removing the narrowed section of the aorta and reconnecting the 2 remaining ends
*   inserting a catheter into the aorta and widening it with a balloon or metal tube (stent)
*   removing sections of blood vessels from other parts of your child's body and using them to create an aorta in the region of the coarctation or bypass around the site of the blockage (this is similar to a coronary artery bypass graft, which is used to treat heart disease)

【20】Sometimes, older children and adults can develop a newly diagnosed coarctation or partial recurrence of the previous blockage. The main goal of treatment will be to control high blood pressure using a combination of diet, exercise and medicine.

【21】Some people will need to have the narrowed section of the aorta widened with a balloon and stent.

【22】Read more about treating high blood pressure.

【23】Ebstein's anomaly
-----------------

【24】In many cases, Ebstein's anomaly is mild and doesn't require treatment. However, some people may need medicines to help control their heart rate and rhythm. Surgery to repair the abnormal tricuspid valve is usually recommended if the valve is very leaky.

【25】If valve repair surgery is ineffective or unsuitable, a replacement valve may be implanted. If Ebstein's anomaly occurs along with an atrial septal defect, the hole will be closed at the same time.

【26】Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
------------------------------

【27】Some cases of PDA can be treated with medicine shortly after birth.

【28】There are 2 types of medication to effectively stimulate the closure of the duct responsible for PDA. These are indomethacin and a special form of ibuprofen.

【29】If the PDA doesn't close with medication, the duct may be sealed with a coil or plug. These can be implanted using a catheter (keyhole surgery).

【30】Sometimes the duct may need to be tied shut to close it. This is done using open heart surgery.

【31】Pulmonary valve stenosis
------------------------

【32】Mild pulmonary valve stenosis doesn't require treatment, because it doesn't cause any symptoms or problems.

【33】More severe cases of pulmonary valve stenosis usually require treatment, even if they cause few or no symptoms. This is because there's a high risk of heart failure in later life if it's not treated.

【34】As with aortic valve stenosis, the main treatment for pulmonary valve stenosis is a balloon to the pulmonary valve (valvuloplasty). However, if this is ineffective or the valve isn't suitable for this treatment, surgery may be needed to open the valve (valvotomy) or replace it with an animal or human valve.

【35】Some patients develop leaking of the pulmonary valve after treatment of pulmonary valve stenosis. This will require ongoing monitoring and if the leak starts to cause a problem with the heart then the valve will need to be replaced. This can be performed with open heart surgery or, increasingly, using catheter intervention which is a much less invasive procedure.

【36】Septal defects
--------------

【37】The treatment of ventricular and atrial septal defects depends on the size of the hole. No treatment will be required if your child has a small septal defect that doesn't cause any symptoms or stretch on the heart. These types of septal defects have an excellent outcome and don't pose a threat to your child's health.

【38】If your child has a larger ventricular septal defect, surgery is usually recommended to close the hole.

【39】A large atrial septal defect and some types of ventricular septal defect can be closed with a special device inserted with a catheter. If the defect is too big or not suitable for the device, surgery may be needed to close the hole.

【40】Unlike open heart surgery, the catheter procedure doesn't cause any scarring and is associated with just a small bruise in the groin. Recovery is very quick. This procedure is undertaken in specialist units that treat congenital heart problems in children and a small number of additional adult centres.

【41】Single ventricle defects
------------------------

【42】Tricuspid atresia and hypoplastic left heart syndrome are treated in much the same way.

【43】Shortly after birth, your baby will be given an injection of medicine called prostaglandin. This will encourage the mixing of oxygen-rich blood with oxygen-poor blood. The condition will then need to be treated using a 3-stage procedure.

【44】The first stage is usually performed during the first few days of life. An artificial passage known as a shunt is created between the heart and lungs, so blood can get to the lungs. However, not all babies will need a shunt.

【45】The second stage will be performed when your child is 3 to 6 months old. The surgeon will connect veins that carry oxygen-poor blood from the upper part of the body (superior vena cava) directly to your child's pulmonary artery. This will allow blood to flow into the lungs, where it can be filled with oxygen.

【46】The final stage is usually performed when your child is 18 to 36 months old. It involves connecting the remaining lower body vein (inferior vena cava) to the pulmonary artery, effectively bypassing the heart.

【47】Patients treated in this way with a single ventricle are complex and need lifelong specialist care. There may be significant complications after such complex surgery, which may limit the ability to exercise and shorten life expectancy.

【48】A heart transplant may be recommended for a small number of people but is limited by the lack of available hearts for transplantation.

【49】Read more about the heart transplant waiting list.

【50】Tetralogy of Fallot
-------------------

【51】Tetralogy of Fallot is treated using surgery. If your baby is born with severe symptoms, surgery may be recommended soon after birth. If the symptoms are less severe, surgery will usually be carried out when your child is 4 to 6 months old.

【52】During the operation, the surgeon will close the hole in the heart and open up the narrowing in the pulmonary valve.

【53】Some people develop leaking of the pulmonary valve after treatment of Tetralogy of Fallot. This will require ongoing monitoring and if the leak starts to cause a problem with the heart, the valve will need to be replaced. This can be performed with open heart surgery or, increasingly, using catheter intervention which is a much less invasive procedure.

【54】Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)
---------------------------------------------------

【55】TAPVC is treated with surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon will reconnect the abnormally positioned veins into the correct position in the left atrium.

【56】The timing of surgery will usually depend on whether your child's pulmonary vein (the vein connecting the lungs and heart) is also obstructed or narrowed.

【57】If the pulmonary vein is obstructed, surgery will be performed shortly after birth. If the vein isn't obstructed, surgery can often be postponed until your child is a few weeks or months old.

【58】Transposition of the great arteries
-----------------------------------

【59】As with treatment for single ventricle defects, your baby will be given an injection of a medication called prostaglandin shortly after birth. This will prevent the passage between the aorta and pulmonary arteries (the ductus arteriosus) closing after birth.

【60】Keeping the ductus arteriosus open means that oxygen-rich blood is able to mix with oxygen-poor blood, which should help relieve your baby's symptoms.

【61】In some cases, it may also be necessary to use a catheter to create a temporary hole in the atrial septum (the wall separating the 2 upper chambers of the heart) to further encourage the mixing of blood.

【62】Once your baby's health has stabilised, it's likely that surgery will be recommended. This should ideally be carried out during the first month of the baby's life. A surgical technique called arterial switch is used, which involves detaching the transposed arteries and reattaching them in the correct position.

【63】Truncus arteriosus
------------------

【64】Your baby may be given medicines to help stabilise their condition. Once your baby is in a stable condition, surgery will be used to treat truncus arteriosus. This is usually carried out within a few weeks of birth.

【65】The abnormal blood vessel will be split to create 2 new blood vessels, and each one will be reconnected in the correct position.

【66】Exercise
--------

【67】In the past, children with congenital heart disease were discouraged from exercising. However, exercise is now believed to improve health, boost self-esteem and help prevent problems developing in later life.

【68】Even if your child can't do strenuous exercise, they can still benefit from a more limited programme of physical activity, such as walking or, in some cases, swimming.

【69】Your child's heart specialist can give you more detailed advice about the right level of physical activity that's suitable for your child.

【70】Page last reviewed: 07 September 2021  
Next review due: 07 September 2024

*   Next : Complications

【4】The majority of congenital heart disease problems are mild heart defects and don't usually need to be treated, although it's likely that you'll have regular check-ups to monitor your health in an outpatient setting throughout life.

【5】More severe heart defects usually require surgery or catheter intervention (where a thin hollow tube is inserted into the heart via an artery) and long-term monitoring of the heart throughout adult life by a congenital heart disease specialist.

【6】In some cases, medications may be used to relieve symptoms or stabilise the condition before and/or after surgery or intervention.

【7】These may include diuretics (water tablets) to remove fluid from the body and make breathing easier, and other medication, such as digoxin to slow down the heartbeat and increase the strength of the heart's pumping function.

【8】Aortic valve stenosis
---------------------

【9】The urgency for treatment for aortic valve stenosis depends on how narrow the valve is. Treatment may be needed immediately, or it could be delayed until the development of symptoms.

【10】If treatment is required, a procedure called a balloon valvuloplasty is often the recommended treatment option in children and younger people.

【11】During the procedure, a small tube (catheter) is passed through the blood vessels to the site of the narrowed valve. A balloon attached to the catheter is inflated, which helps to stretch or widen the valve and relieve any blockage in blood flow.

【12】If balloon valvuloplasty is ineffective or unsuitable, it's usually necessary to remove and replace the valve using open heart surgery. This is where the surgeon makes a cut in the chest to access the heart.

【13】There are several options for replacing aortic valves, including valves made from animal or human tissue, or your own pulmonary valve. If the pulmonary valve is used, it will be replaced at the same time with a donor pulmonary valve. This type of specialised surgery is known as the Ross procedure. In older children or adults, it's more likely that metal valves will be used.

【14】Some people also develop a leak of the aortic valve which will require monitoring. If the leak starts to cause problems with the heart, the aortic valve will need to be replaced.

<mark>【15】Read more about aortic valve replacement.</mark>

【16】Coarctation of the aorta
------------------------

【17】If your child has the more serious form of coarctation of the aorta that develops shortly after birth, surgery to restore the flow of blood through the aorta is usually recommended in the first few days of life.

【18】Several surgical techniques can be used, including:

【19】*   removing the narrowed section of the aorta and reconnecting the 2 remaining ends
*   inserting a catheter into the aorta and widening it with a balloon or metal tube (stent)
*   removing sections of blood vessels from other parts of your child's body and using them to create an aorta in the region of the coarctation or bypass around the site of the blockage (this is similar to a coronary artery bypass graft, which is used to treat heart disease)

【20】Sometimes, older children and adults can develop a newly diagnosed coarctation or partial recurrence of the previous blockage. The main goal of treatment will be to control high blood pressure using a combination of diet, exercise and medicine.

【21】Some people will need to have the narrowed section of the aorta widened with a balloon and stent.

<mark>【22】Read more about treating high blood pressure.</mark>

【23】Ebstein's anomaly
-----------------

【24】In many cases, Ebstein's anomaly is mild and doesn't require treatment. However, some people may need medicines to help control their heart rate and rhythm. Surgery to repair the abnormal tricuspid valve is usually recommended if the valve is very leaky.

【25】If valve repair surgery is ineffective or unsuitable, a replacement valve may be implanted. If Ebstein's anomaly occurs along with an atrial septal defect, the hole will be closed at the same time.

【26】Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
------------------------------

【27】Some cases of PDA can be treated with medicine shortly after birth.

【28】There are 2 types of medication to effectively stimulate the closure of the duct responsible for PDA. These are indomethacin and a special form of ibuprofen.

【29】If the PDA doesn't close with medication, the duct may be sealed with a coil or plug. These can be implanted using a catheter (keyhole surgery).

【30】Sometimes the duct may need to be tied shut to close it. This is done using open heart surgery.

【31】Pulmonary valve stenosis
------------------------

【32】Mild pulmonary valve stenosis doesn't require treatment, because it doesn't cause any symptoms or problems.

【33】More severe cases of pulmonary valve stenosis usually require treatment, even if they cause few or no symptoms. This is because there's a high risk of heart failure in later life if it's not treated.

【34】As with aortic valve stenosis, the main treatment for pulmonary valve stenosis is a balloon to the pulmonary valve (valvuloplasty). However, if this is ineffective or the valve isn't suitable for this treatment, surgery may be needed to open the valve (valvotomy) or replace it with an animal or human valve.

【35】Some patients develop leaking of the pulmonary valve after treatment of pulmonary valve stenosis. This will require ongoing monitoring and if the leak starts to cause a problem with the heart then the valve will need to be replaced. This can be performed with open heart surgery or, increasingly, using catheter intervention which is a much less invasive procedure.

【36】Septal defects
--------------

【37】The treatment of ventricular and atrial septal defects depends on the size of the hole. No treatment will be required if your child has a small septal defect that doesn't cause any symptoms or stretch on the heart. These types of septal defects have an excellent outcome and don't pose a threat to your child's health.

【38】If your child has a larger ventricular septal defect, surgery is usually recommended to close the hole.

【39】A large atrial septal defect and some types of ventricular septal defect can be closed with a special device inserted with a catheter. If the defect is too big or not suitable for the device, surgery may be needed to close the hole.

【40】Unlike open heart surgery, the catheter procedure doesn't cause any scarring and is associated with just a small bruise in the groin. Recovery is very quick. This procedure is undertaken in specialist units that treat congenital heart problems in children and a small number of additional adult centres.

【41】Single ventricle defects
------------------------

【42】Tricuspid atresia and hypoplastic left heart syndrome are treated in much the same way.

【43】Shortly after birth, your baby will be given an injection of medicine called prostaglandin. This will encourage the mixing of oxygen-rich blood with oxygen-poor blood. The condition will then need to be treated using a 3-stage procedure.

【44】The first stage is usually performed during the first few days of life. An artificial passage known as a shunt is created between the heart and lungs, so blood can get to the lungs. However, not all babies will need a shunt.

【45】The second stage will be performed when your child is 3 to 6 months old. The surgeon will connect veins that carry oxygen-poor blood from the upper part of the body (superior vena cava) directly to your child's pulmonary artery. This will allow blood to flow into the lungs, where it can be filled with oxygen.

【46】The final stage is usually performed when your child is 18 to 36 months old. It involves connecting the remaining lower body vein (inferior vena cava) to the pulmonary artery, effectively bypassing the heart.

【47】Patients treated in this way with a single ventricle are complex and need lifelong specialist care. There may be significant complications after such complex surgery, which may limit the ability to exercise and shorten life expectancy.

【48】A heart transplant may be recommended for a small number of people but is limited by the lack of available hearts for transplantation.

【49】Read more about the heart transplant waiting list.

【50】Tetralogy of Fallot
-------------------

【51】Tetralogy of Fallot is treated using surgery. If your baby is born with severe symptoms, surgery may be recommended soon after birth. If the symptoms are less severe, surgery will usually be carried out when your child is 4 to 6 months old.

【52】During the operation, the surgeon will close the hole in the heart and open up the narrowing in the pulmonary valve.

【53】Some people develop leaking of the pulmonary valve after treatment of Tetralogy of Fallot. This will require ongoing monitoring and if the leak starts to cause a problem with the heart, the valve will need to be replaced. This can be performed with open heart surgery or, increasingly, using catheter intervention which is a much less invasive procedure.

【54】Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)
---------------------------------------------------

【55】TAPVC is treated with surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon will reconnect the abnormally positioned veins into the correct position in the left atrium.

【56】The timing of surgery will usually depend on whether your child's pulmonary vein (the vein connecting the lungs and heart) is also obstructed or narrowed.

【57】If the pulmonary vein is obstructed, surgery will be performed shortly after birth. If the vein isn't obstructed, surgery can often be postponed until your child is a few weeks or months old.

【58】Transposition of the great arteries
-----------------------------------

【59】As with treatment for single ventricle defects, your baby will be given an injection of a medication called prostaglandin shortly after birth. This will prevent the passage between the aorta and pulmonary arteries (the ductus arteriosus) closing after birth.

【60】Keeping the ductus arteriosus open means that oxygen-rich blood is able to mix with oxygen-poor blood, which should help relieve your baby's symptoms.

【61】In some cases, it may also be necessary to use a catheter to create a temporary hole in the atrial septum (the wall separating the 2 upper chambers of the heart) to further encourage the mixing of blood.

【62】Once your baby's health has stabilised, it's likely that surgery will be recommended. This should ideally be carried out during the first month of the baby's life. A surgical technique called arterial switch is used, which involves detaching the transposed arteries and reattaching them in the correct position.

【63】Truncus arteriosus
------------------

【64】Your baby may be given medicines to help stabilise their condition. Once your baby is in a stable condition, surgery will be used to treat truncus arteriosus. This is usually carried out within a few weeks of birth.

【65】The abnormal blood vessel will be split to create 2 new blood vessels, and each one will be reconnected in the correct position.

【66】Exercise
--------

【67】In the past, children with congenital heart disease were discouraged from exercising. However, exercise is now believed to improve health, boost self-esteem and help prevent problems developing in later life.

【68】Even if your child can't do strenuous exercise, they can still benefit from a more limited programme of physical activity, such as walking or, in some cases, swimming.

【69】Your child's heart specialist can give you more detailed advice about the right level of physical activity that's suitable for your child.

【70】Page last reviewed: 07 September 2021  
Next review due: 07 September 2024

【71】*   Previous : Diagnosis
*   Next : Complications

source_info.title: Sodium cromoglicate eye drops
source_info.text:
【0】About sodium cromoglicate eye drops \- Brand names: Allercrom, Catacrom, Murine Hayfever Relief, Opticrom, Optrex
=================================================================================================================

【1】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops are part of a group of medicines called anti-allergics.

【2】They are used to treat allergic conjunctivitis, a condition triggered by hay fever, house mites and other allergies. It can irritate your eyes and make them red, watery, itchy and puffy.

【3】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops work by stopping the release of the natural substances (including histamine) in your body that cause allergic reactions. They also reduce how severe your symptoms are when you come into contact with any substances you’re allergic to.

【4】Sodium cromoglicate comes as eye drops in bottles that contain a preservative (which makes it last longer before expiring). They also come as single-dose droppers that are preservative-free. These are thrown away after use.

【5】You can buy the eye drops from pharmacies and supermarkets, without a prescription.

【6】Sodium cromoglicate also comes as capsules that are only available on prescription.

【7】Important
---------

【8】If you have bought the eye drops without the advice of a doctor or pharmacist, you must be sure that your eye irritation is caused by an allergy.

【9】Key facts
---------

【10】*   For sodium cromoglicate eye drops to work properly, you need to use them regularly for 2 weeks. If there is no change after that, speak to a pharmacist or your doctor.
*   Do not use sodium cromoglicate eye drops for more than 4 weeks after first opening the bottle. If you use them for longer they may not work as well, and it could cause eye infections.
*   Sodium cromoglicate eye drops may sting your eyes a little when you first drop them in, but this does not last long.
*   It's safe to use sodium cromoglicate eye drops with most prescription medicines.

【11】More in Sodium cromoglicate eye drops
-------------------------------------

【12】*   About sodium cromoglicate eye drops
*   Who can and cannot use them
*   How and when to use them
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using sodium cromoglicate eye drops with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【13】Page last reviewed: 22 July 2022  
Next review due: 22 July 2025

source_info.title: Breast cancer in women
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Breast cancer in women
================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Prevention

【3】**The causes of breast cancer are not fully understood, making it difficult to say why one woman may develop breast cancer and another may not.**

【4】However, there are risk factors known to affect your likelihood of developing breast cancer. Some of these you cannot do anything about, but there are some you can change.

【5】Age
---

【6】The risk of developing breast cancer increases with age. The condition is most common in women over age 50 who have been through the menopause. About 8 out of 10 cases of breast cancer happen in women over 50.

【7】All women who are 50 to 70 years of age should be screened for breast cancer every 3 years as part of the NHS Breast Screening Programme.

【8】Women over the age of 70 are still eligible to be screened and can arrange this through their GP or local screening unit.

【9】Find out more about breast screening.

【10】Family history
--------------

【11】If you have close relatives who have had breast cancer or ovarian cancer, you may have a higher risk of developing breast cancer.

【12】However, because breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, it's possible for it to occur in more than one family member by chance.

【13】Most cases of breast cancer do not run in families, but genes known as BRCA1 and BRCA2 can increase your risk of developing both breast and ovarian cancer. It's possible for these genes to be passed on from a parent to their child. 

【14】The genes TP53 and CHEK2, are also associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

【15】Speak to a GP if breast or ovarian cancer runs in your family and you're worried you may get it too. They may refer you for an NHS genetic test, which will tell you if you have inherited one of the cancer-risk genes.

【16】Find out more about predictive genetic tests for cancer-risk genes.

【17】Previous breast cancer or lump
------------------------------

【18】If you have previously had breast cancer or early non-invasive cancer cell changes in breast ducts, you have a higher risk of developing it again, either in your other breast or in the same breast.

【19】A benign breast lump does not mean you have breast cancer, but certain types of breast lumps may slightly increase your risk of developing cancer.

【20】Some benign changes in your breast tissue, such as cells growing abnormally in ducts (atypical ductal hyperplasia), or abnormal cells inside your breast lobes (lobular carcinoma in situ), can make getting breast cancer more likely.

【21】Dense breast tissue
-------------------

【22】Your breasts are made up of thousands of tiny glands (lobules) that produce milk. This glandular tissue contains a higher concentration of breast cells than other breast tissue, making it denser.

【23】Women with dense breast tissue may have a higher risk of developing breast cancer as there are more cells that can become cancerous.

【24】Dense breast tissue can also make a breast scan (mammogram) difficult to read, as any lumps or areas of abnormal tissue are harder to see.

【25】Younger women tend to have denser breasts. As you get older, the amount of glandular tissue in your breasts decreases and is replaced by fat, so your breasts become less dense.

【26】Hormones and hormone medicine
-----------------------------

【27】### Exposure to oestrogen

【28】The female hormone oestrogen can sometimes stimulate breast cancer cells and cause them to grow.

【29】The ovaries, where your eggs are stored, begin to produce oestrogen when you start puberty, to regulate your periods.

【30】Your risk of developing breast cancer may rise slightly with the amount of oestrogen your body is exposed to.

【31】For example, if you started having periods at a young age and experienced the menopause later than average, you will have been exposed to oestrogen over a longer period of time.

【32】In the same way, not having children or having children later in life may slightly increase your risk of developing breast cancer because your exposure to oestrogen is not interrupted by pregnancy.

【33】### Hormone replacement therapy (HRT)

【34】Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

【35】All types of HRT can increase the risk of breast cancer, except for vaginal oestrogen.

【36】There is no increased risk of breast cancer if you take HRT for less than 1 year.

【37】But if you take HRT for longer than 1 year, you have a higher risk of breast cancer than women who never use HRT.

【38】The increased risk of breast cancer falls after you stop taking HRT, but some increased risk remains for more than 10 years compared to women who have never used HRT.

【39】Find out more about the risks of HRT.

【40】### Contraceptive pill

【41】Research shows that women who take the contraceptive pill have a slightly increased risk of developing breast cancer.

【42】However, the risk starts to decrease once you stop taking the pill, and your risk of breast cancer is back to normal 10 years after stopping.

【43】Cancer Research UK has more information about the contraceptive pill and cancer risk.

【44】Lifestyle factors
-----------------

【45】### Being overweight or obese

【46】If you have experienced the menopause and are overweight or obese, you may be more at risk of developing breast cancer.

【47】This is thought to be linked to the amount of oestrogen in your body, as being overweight or obese after the menopause causes more oestrogen to be produced.

【48】### Alcohol

【49】Drinking alcohol increases the risk of getting breast cancer.

【50】People who drink even small amounts of alcohol on a regular basis have a greater risk of getting breast cancer than people who do not drink alcohol at all. The more alcohol you drink, the more your risk of getting breast cancer increases.

【51】Radiation
---------

【52】Certain medical procedures that use radiation, such as X-rays and CT scans, may slightly increase your risk of developing breast cancer.

【53】If you had radiotherapy to your chest area for Hodgkin lymphoma you should have already received a letter from the Department of Health and Social Care inviting you for a consultation with a specialist to discuss your increased risk of developing breast cancer.

【54】See your GP if you were not contacted or if you did not attend a consultation. You're usually entitled to have your breast checked with an MRI scan.

【55】If you currently need radiotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma, your specialist should discuss the risk of breast cancer before your treatment begins.

【56】Want to know more?
------------------

【57】*   Breast Cancer Now: the causes of breast cancer
*   Cancer Research UK: breast cancer risks and causes
*   Macmillan Cancer Support: understanding breast cancer

【58】Page last reviewed: 28 October 2019  
Next review due: 28 October 2022
