【0】Methylphenidate for children \- Brand names: Ritalin, Concerta, Medikinet, Delmosart, Equasym
=============================================================================================

<mark>【1】On this page</mark>
------------

【2】1.  About methylphenidate for children
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take methylphenidate
4.  How and when to give methylphenidate to children
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of methylphenidate
7.  Cautions with other medicines
8.  Common questions about methylphendiate for children

【3】1\. About methylphenidate for children
--------------------------------------

【4】Methylphenidate belongs to a group of medicines, called stimulants. They work by increasing activity in the brain, particularly in areas that help control attention and behaviour.

【5】Methylphenidate is used to treat children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). It helps with hyperactivity and impulsive behaviour, and allows them to concentrate better. It is also used to treat adults with ADHD or narcolepsy (a sleep disorder).

【6】Methylphenidate is only available on prescription. It comes as standard (immediate release) tablets and capsules and slow release (also called extended, modified or prolonged release) tablets and capsules.

【7】Some children may need to take both slow release and standard methylphenidate to help improve their ADHD.

【8】For adults aged 18 and over, read our information on methylphenidate for adults.

【9】2\. Key facts
-------------

【10】*   Methylphenidate is a controlled drug, which means that you may have to prove your identity when collecting your prescription. Collect your prescription within 28 days.
*   If your child takes slow release methylphenidate, give it to them once a day. If they are taking standard tablets or capsules, your doctor may recommend giving it up to 3 times a day.
*   It's best to stick to the same brand, particularly if your child has slow release methylphenidate. Different brands work differently in how they release the medicine into the body, and this can affect how they work to manage your child's symptoms.
*   Methylphenidate makes your child less hyperactive and impulsive, and helps them concentrate.
*   Methylphenidate for children is also known by the brand names Matoride, Tranquilin, Xaggitin and Xenidate.

【11】3\. Who can and cannot take methylphenidate
-------------------------------------------

【12】Methylphenidate can be taken by most children aged 4 and over, although, it is not suitable for all children. Tell your child's doctor before they start taking this medicine if:

【13】*   they have ever had an allergic reaction to methylphenidate or any other medicine
*   they have difficulty swallowing, as some brands may not be suitable
*   they have heart problems
*   they have an overactive thyroid
*   have a tumour in the adrenal gland (phaeochromocytoma)
*   they have mental health problems (or a close family member has mental health problems)
*   they have high blood pressure or problems with their blood vessels, such as vasculitis
*   they have epilepsy
*   they have sudden muscle twitches in their face or body (tics), or there is a close family member with Tourette's syndrome
*   either they or a a close family member has glaucoma

【14】4\. How and when to give methylphenidate to children
----------------------------------------------------

【15】Always follow the advice of your child's doctor and the instructions that come with the medicine. Different brands of methylphenidate tablets and capsules may have different instructions.

【16】### Dosage

【17】The usual dose of methylphenidate depends on whether your child has standard or slow release medicine. In some cases, the specialist may prescribe both.

【18】Although standard tablets and capsules are sometimes called immediate release, they can still take a while to start working.

【19】Slow release tablets and capsules are sometimes called extended release, modified release, or prolonged release. These tablets and capsules let the medicine pass into your child's body gradually.

【20】#### Dose for standard tablets and capsules

【21】The usual starting dose for children is 5mg, given once or twice a day. Your doctor may increase your child's dose gradually (usually weekly) until they find the dose that works best. Your child may need to take it 2 or 3 times a day.

【22】Give your child their methylphenidate first thing in the morning. If they have a second dose, give it to them at around lunchtime (early afternoon) and, if prescribed, a third dose in the late afternoon or evening.

【23】Try to leave at least 4 hours between doses. If your child has a third dose, try to give it to them at least 4 hours before bedtime so it does not affect their sleep.

【24】Although they are called immediate release, it can still take a while for the medicine to work. You may not see any changes in behaviour straight away.

【25】Let your child's school know if they need to take their medicine during the school day.

【26】#### Dose for slow release tablets and capsules

【27】Slow release tablets and capsules start to work with a first release of the medicine into the body. After that, the medicine continues to release into the body more slowly.

【28】The usual starting dose for:

【29】*   **tablets** is 18mg, given once in the morning - your child's doctor may gradually increase the dose by 18mg at a time (usually weekly, up to 54mg max) until they find the dose that works well for your child.
*   **capsules** is 10mg, given once in the morning - your child's doctor may increase the dose gradually (usually weekly, up to 60mg max) until they find the dose that works well for your child.

【30】Check the leaflet that comes with the medicine for when to give it and whether it should be taken with food.

【31】If your child is taking Equasym XL, give them their medicine about 30 minutes before breakfast. If they're taking Medikinet XL, give it to them with or after breakfast.

【32】### How to give children tablets or capsules

【33】Give your child the tablets or capsules with a drink of water, milk or juice. Tell them to swallow the medicine whole, not chew it.

【34】If your child has problems swallowing pills, then it's OK to crush standard tablets (Medikinet or Ritalin). Mix the crushed tablets with a small amount of soft food such as yogurt, honey or jam.

【35】#### Important

【36】Do not crush or break slow release tablets because the medicine will not work properly.

【37】However, if your child takes slow release capsules, you can open the capsule and mix the contents with a small amount of soft food such as yogurt, honey or jam.

【38】Give your child the mixture straight away and tell them to swallow it without chewing.

【39】### Will their dose go up or down?

【40】Your child will usually start on a low dose of methylphenidate, taken once or twice a day. The doctor will increase the dose gradually, until they find the dose that works best for your child.

【41】If your child starts on standard methylphenidate, the doctor may later switch them to slow release methylphenidate. They only have to take this once a day.

【42】### How long will they take it for?

【43】If methylphenidate is working well to control your child's symptoms, they might need to take it for several months or even years. However, it's not usually a life-long medicine.

【44】Your doctor will usually monitor how your child is every 6 months. This gives them a better idea about how your child is getting on with their medicine and whether they still need it.

【45】### What if my child is sick?

【46】If your child is sick (vomits) less than 30 minutes after taking their methylphenidate, give them the same dose again.

【47】If it’s more than 30 minutes after taking their medicine, do not give your child another dose, just wait until their next dose is due.

【48】If your child is sick again, ask your doctor or pharmacist for advice.

【49】### What if I forget to give a dose?

【50】If you forget to give your child their medicine, skip the missed dose and wait until it’s time for the next dose. Give them the next dose as usual.

【51】Never give them a double dose to make up for a forgotten dose.

【52】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to give your child their medicine.

【53】### What if they take too much?

【54】The amount of methylphenidate that can lead to an overdose varies from person to person.

【55】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【56】Your child takes too much methylphenidate and has:

【57】*   a seizure or fit (uncontrollable jerking and shaking)
*   a fast, slow or uneven heart beat (palpitations) – your child may feel their heart is beating faster or slower than normal or may say it is racing

【58】Take the methylphenidate packet, or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine with you.

【59】#### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【60】*   your child takes more than their prescribed dose of methylphenidate

【61】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【62】If you need advice for a child under the age of 5 years, call 111.

【63】#### Important

【64】Keep methylphenidate in a cupboard. Make sure children cannot see or reach this medicine.

【65】5\. Side effects
----------------

【66】Like all medicines, methylphenidate can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【67】### Common side effects

【68】These common side effects may happen in more than 1 in 100 people:

【69】*   headaches
*   feeling aggressive, irritable, depressed, anxious or tense
*   trouble sleeping (insomnia)
*   loss of appetite – this can lead to weight loss or poor weight gain
*   stomach ache
*   dry mouth
*   feeling or being sick (nausea or vomiting)

【70】Keep giving your child the medicine, but tell your doctor if they bother your child or do not go away:

【71】### Serious side effects

【72】Serious side effects are uncommon and happen in less than 1 in 100 people.

【73】Tell your doctor straight away if your child:

【74】*   has changes in mood or personality
*   has thoughts about harming themselves
*   has a fast or irregular heartbeat (palpitations) – your child may feel their heart is beating much faster than normal or may say it is racing
*   starts seeing, feeling or hearing things that are not real (hallucinations)
*   has started to get facial tics – these are quick, little movements in the muscles of the face that cannot be controlled and are sudden, if this starts happening, their doctor will stop your treatment

【75】Methylphenidate can also cause a small increase in blood pressure and pulse rate. For this reason, your doctor will usually measure your child’s blood pressure and pulse every 6 months.

【76】#### Growth in children

【77】If your child takes methylphenidate for longer than a year, it can slow down their growth. However this happens in less than 1 in 10 children.

【78】Your doctor will check your child’s height, weight and appetite every 6 months to make sure they are growing OK.

【79】#### Serious allergic reaction

【80】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to methylphenidate.

【81】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【82】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【83】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【84】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【85】These are not all the side effects of methylphenidate. For a full list, see the leaflet inside the medicine packet.

<mark>【86】Information:

【87】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【88】Visit Yellow Card for further information.</mark>

【89】6\. How to cope with side effects of methylphenidate
----------------------------------------------------

【90】**What to do about:**

【91】*   **headaches** – make sure your child rests and drinks plenty of fluids. Painkillers such as paracetamol (Calpol) can help. Talk to your doctor if your child's headaches are severe or do not go away.
*   **feeling aggressive, irritable, depressed, anxious or tense** – this may go away as your child gets used to the medicine. If it does not, speak to your doctor. They may want to recommend a lower dose or try a different medicine.
*   **trouble sleeping** – if your child is finding it hard to sleep, try giving the last dose at least 6 hours before bedtime. Speak to your doctor if this does not help. They may want to try slow release instead.
*   **loss of appetite** – it may help to give them methylphenidate with a meal. You may notice they lose some weight during the first few months of treatment. Your child will probably put this weight back on once they are used to the medicine. If you notice they are losing a lot of weight speak to your doctor.
*   **dry mouth** – this usually improves quite quickly. It may help to give them small sips of water and citrus fruits like oranges or satsumas.
*   **feeling or being sick** – stick to simple meals and do not give your child rich or spicy food if they feel sick. It might help to give them their methylphenidate with or after a meal or snack. If they are being sick, encourage them to take small, frequent sips of water or squash to avoid dehydration. If your child keeps being sick or having severe stomach pains, see a doctor.

【92】7\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【93】There are some medicines that can affect the way methylphenidate works.

【94】If your child is taking any of the following medicines, talk to your doctor or pharmacist before giving them methylphenidate:

【95】*   medicines to treat depression or other mental health problems
*   medicines for epilepsy
*   blood pressure medicines
*   medicines that treat or prevent blood clots
*   medicines for coughs and colds

【96】Some cough and cold medicines can affect blood pressure so speak to your pharmacist or doctor if you're buying these for your child. It’s important to check whether they are OK for them to have while taking methylphenidate.

【97】### Mixing methylphenidate with herbal remedies and supplements

【98】There's very little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements while taking methylphenidate. Check with your doctor or pharmacist before giving any to your child.

【99】Some studies have suggested that omega-3 and omega-6 supplements can help with ADHD. However, the evidence is limited and more research is needed.

【100】### Important: Medicine safety

【101】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【102】8\. Common questions about methylphendiate for children
-------------------------------------------------------

【103】How does methylphenidate work?

【104】Methylphenidate belongs to a group of medicines called stimulants. They increase activity in the brain, particularly in areas that help control attention and behaviour.

【105】It's not known exactly how methylphenidate works. It's thought to boost the levels of chemicals called dopamine and noradrenaline in the brain.

【106】This can increase activity in the parts of your child's brain that control attention and behaviour.

【107】This makes them less hyperactive or impulsive. It will also help them to pay attention and concentrate better.

【108】How long does it take to work?

【109】When your child first starts taking methylphenidate they will be on a low dose. Your doctor will usually increase this gradually until they find the dose that works for your child.

【110】This means it might take a few weeks before you see any benefits. When your doctor has found the right dose, methylphenidate should start to work within 30 to 60 minutes of your child taking it.

【111】The medicine makes your child less hyperactive or impulsive, and helps their concentration. How quickly it works depends on whether it's standard or slow release.

【112】How long will my child take it for?

【113】Your child may need to take methylphenidate for several months or even years. They will not usually need to take it for the rest of their life.

【114】Your child will have regular check-ups, usually every 6 months or so.

【115】Your doctor may recommend stopping methylphenidate for a while, or reducing the dose. This will normally be during the school holidays and can be called “a medicine break”. This is to check whether it’s still helping.

【116】As your child gets to puberty, or just after, the doctor may stop their methylphenidate. But if the medicine is still helping, they may recommend that your child keep taking it, even as an adult.

【117】Is it safe to take for a long time?

【118】There is no evidence that methylphenidate is harmful as long as it is taken exactly as prescribed and your child is monitored carefully. This is why it’s a good idea for them to have regular reviews with their doctor to check whether it’s still needed.

【119】What will happen if my child stops taking it?

【120】Only stop giving your child methylphenidate if your doctor tells you to.

【121】If your child suddenly stops taking methylphenidate, you may notice withdrawal symptoms such as depression.

【122】Talk to your doctor if you want to stop giving your child methylphenidate. They may want to slowly reduce the amount that your child takes before stopping completely. This is to help avoid any extra side effects.

【123】Is it addictive?

【124】As long as you follow your doctor’s instructions carefully, methylphenidate does not generally cause addiction issues.

【125】Do not stop giving methylphenidate to your child suddenly. Talk to your doctor first, as they may want to reduce the dose gradually. This reduces the risk of your child having extra side effects when they stop taking this medicine.

【126】Addiction problems usually only occur if you give methylphenidate more often than prescribed, or at a higher dose than recommended.

【127】Does my child need to stick to the same brand of methylphenidate?

【128】Once your child is on a brand of methylphenidate that works for them, they'll usually keep taking the same brand. This is because it can be a problem to change brands, particularly if they're taking slow release tablets or capsules.

【129】Different brands of slow release methylphenidate tablets and capsules work differently in how they release the medicine into the body. This can affect how they work to manage symptoms. Side effects can also vary.

【130】Different brands also have different instructions for how and when to take it, such as whether to take it with food.

【131】If your child does need to change brands, check the instructions that come with the medicine carefully.

【132】Can my child take it with painkillers?

【133】You can give your child painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen, unless your doctor has told you not to.

【134】Is there any food or drink they need to avoid?

【135】There's no particular food or drink that your child needs to avoid when taking methylphenidate.

【136】Are medicines the first treatment option for children with ADHD?

【137】If a child has ADHD, their doctor will usually only prescribe a medicine if other treatments have not helped. Their symptoms may still be causing problems, even after trying practical things like:

【138】*   taking regular breaks to move around
*   reducing distractions, for example by using headphones
*   having instructions written down clearly

【139】Medicines are usually only used for ADHD as part of a treatment programme. Other treatments can include:

【140】*   therapies to improve specific skills and behaviours
*   training for parents to help them manage their child’s behaviour
*   additional support at school

【141】If you have any questions or worries about your child’s medicine, speak to your doctor.

【142】What if methylphenidate is not helping my child?

【143】Some people find that methylphenidate does not work for their child. In this case, the doctor may recommend trying a different medicine or psychological treatments.

【144】Other medicines for ADHD include dexamfetamine, lisdexamfetamine and atomoxetine.

【145】Non-medicine treatments for ADHD include, behavioural therapy and talking therapy.

【146】Speak to your doctor if you are interested in finding out about alternative treatments. Do not stop giving your child methylphenidate without talking to your doctor first.

【147】Can taking supplements help ADHD?

【148】Some studies have suggested that omega-3 and omega-6 supplements can help with ADHD. However, the evidence is very limited and more research is needed.

【149】Talk to your doctor before giving any supplements to your child. This is because some can react with medicine - causing side effects, or can make the medicine work less well.

【150】Related conditions
------------------

【151】*   Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

【152】Useful resources
----------------

【153】*   HealthUnlocked: methylphenidate forum
*   ADHD Foundation: charity
*   Medicines for Children (information about methylphenidate): charity

【154】Page last reviewed: 27 July 2021  
Next review due: 27 July 2024

source_info.title: Cyclizine
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of cyclizine
=========================

【1】Like all medicines, cyclizine can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of cyclizine happen in more than 1 in 100 people. They're usually mild and go away by themselves. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Feeling drowsy

【5】Do not drive, cycle or use tools or machinery if you're feeling this way. Do not drink alcohol, as it'll make you feel more tired. If this does not help, talk to your doctor. They may suggest a different anti-sickness medicine.

【6】Blurred vision

【7】Do not drive, cycle or use tools or machinery while this is happening. If it lasts for more than 2 days, speak to your doctor.

【8】Dry mouth

【9】Try chewing sugar-free gum or sucking sugar-free sweets.

【10】Headaches

【11】Rest and drink plenty of fluids. You can take an everyday painkiller like paracetamol or ibuprofen. Talk to your doctor if the headaches are severe or last longer than a week.

【12】Constipation

【13】Get more fibre into your diet, such as fresh fruit and vegetables and cereals. Try to drink several glasses of water or another non-alcoholic liquid each day. If you can, it may also help to increase your level of exercise.

【14】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【15】Serious side effects
--------------------

【16】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 10,000 people.

【17】Call your doctor or call 111 now if:

【18】*   you get muscle stiffness or shaking, or unusual face or tongue movements
*   you get severe bleeding or bleeding that you cannot stop, such as cuts or nosebleeds that do not stop within 10 minutes
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin – these can be signs of liver problems

【19】### Serious allergic reaction

【20】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to cyclizine.

【21】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【22】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【23】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【24】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【25】Other side effects
------------------

【26】These are not all the side effects of cyclizine. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【27】Information:

【28】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【29】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【30】More in Cyclizine
-----------------

【31】*   About cyclizine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking cyclizine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【32】Page last reviewed: 1 April 2022  
Next review due: 1 April 2025

source_info.title: Subdural haematoma
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Subdural haematoma
==============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery

【3】**A subdural haematoma is a serious condition where blood collects between the skull and the surface of the brain. It's usually caused by a head injury.**

【4】Symptoms of a subdural haematoma can include:

【5】*   a headache that keeps getting worse
*   feeling and being sick
*   confusion
*   personality changes, such as being unusually aggressive or having rapid mood swings
*   feeling drowsy
*   loss of consciousness

【6】The symptoms can develop soon after a severe head injury (acute subdural haematoma), or very occasionally a few days or weeks after a more minor head injury (subacute or chronic subdural haematoma).

【7】Read more about the symptoms of a subdural haematoma.

【8】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【9】You should always seek emergency medical treatment after a severe head injury.

【10】Go to your nearest A&E department or call 999.

【11】If you develop the symptoms above any time after a minor head injury, you should also go to your nearest A&E department or call 999 for an ambulance as soon as possible.

【12】A subdural haematoma can be very serious and needs to be assessed as quickly as possible.

【13】Read more about diagnosing subdural haematomas.

【14】What causes subdural haematomas?
--------------------------------

【15】A subdural haematoma occurs when a blood vessel in the space between the skull and the brain (the subdural space) is damaged.

【16】Blood escapes from the blood vessel, leading to the formation of a blood clot (haematoma) that places pressure on the brain and damages it.

【17】Head injuries that cause subdural haematomas are often severe, such as those from a car crash, fall or violent assault.

【18】But minor bumps to the head can also lead to a subdural haematoma in a few cases.

【19】A minor head injury is more likely to lead to a subdural haematoma if you're over 60, taking anticoagulant ("blood-thinning") medicine or have a history of alcohol misuse.

【20】Read more about the causes of a subdural haematoma.

【21】How subdural haematomas are treated
-----------------------------------

【22】Subdural haematomas usually need to be treated with surgery as soon as possible.

【23】The 2 most widely used surgical techniques for subdural haematomas are:

【24】*   **craniotomy** – a section of the skull is temporarily removed so the surgeon can access and remove the haematoma
*   **burr holes** – a small hole is drilled into the skull and a tube is inserted through the hole to help drain the haematoma

【25】In a few cases, very small subdural haematomas may be carefully monitored first to see if they heal without having an operation.

【26】Read more about treating subdural haematomas.

【27】Outlook
-------

【28】A subdural haematoma is a serious condition that carries a high risk of death, particularly in older people and those whose brain was severely damaged.

【29】Acute subdural haematomas are the most serious type because they're often associated with significant damage to the brain.

【30】Those who survive an acute subdural haematoma may take a long time to recover, and may be left with physical disabilities and cognitive problems such as memory and speech problems.

【31】The outlook is generally better for subacute and chronic haematomas. Most people who are fit enough to have surgery eventually make a full recovery.

【32】But because many people with these types of haematoma are older, they may be too frail to have treatment.

【33】Read more about recovering from a subdural haematoma.

【34】Page last reviewed: 19 August 2021  
Next review due: 19 August 2024

【35】*   Next : Symptoms

text.text: 【13】Read more about diagnosing subdural haematomas.
text.content:
【0】Overview \- Subdural haematoma
==============================

<mark>【1】Contents
【2】1.  Overview

2.  Symptoms

3.  Causes

4.  Diagnosis

5.  Treatment

6.  Recovery</mark>overy

【3】**A subdural haematoma is a serious condition where blood collects between the skull and the surface of the brain. It's usually caused by a head injury.**

【4】Symptoms of a subdural haematoma can include:

【5】*   a headache that keeps getting worse
*   feeling and being sick
*   confusion
*   personality changes, such as being unusually aggressive or having rapid mood swings
*   feeling drowsy
*   loss of consciousness

【6】The symptoms can develop soon after a severe head injury (acute subdural haematoma), or very occasionally a few days or weeks after a more minor head injury (subacute or chronic subdural haematoma).

<mark>【7】Read more about the symptoms of a subdural haematoma.</mark>

【8】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【9】You should always seek emergency medical treatment after a severe head injury.

【10】Go to your nearest A&E department or call 999.

【11】If you develop the symptoms above any time after a minor head injury, you should also go to your nearest A&E department or call 999 for an ambulance as soon as possible.

【12】A subdural haematoma can be very serious and needs to be assessed as quickly as possible.

【13】Read more about diagnosing subdural haematomas.

【14】What causes subdural haematomas?
--------------------------------

【15】A subdural haematoma occurs when a blood vessel in the space between the skull and the brain (the subdural space) is damaged.

【16】Blood escapes from the blood vessel, leading to the formation of a blood clot (haematoma) that places pressure on the brain and damages it.

【17】Head injuries that cause subdural haematomas are often severe, such as those from a car crash, fall or violent assault.

【18】But minor bumps to the head can also lead to a subdural haematoma in a few cases.

【19】A minor head injury is more likely to lead to a subdural haematoma if you're over 60, taking anticoagulant ("blood-thinning") medicine or have a history of alcohol misuse.

【20】Read more about the causes of a subdural haematoma.

【21】How subdural haematomas are treated
-----------------------------------

【22】Subdural haematomas usually need to be treated with surgery as soon as possible.

【23】The 2 most widely used surgical techniques for subdural haematomas are:

【24】*   **craniotomy** – a section of the skull is temporarily removed so the surgeon can access and remove the haematoma
*   **burr holes** – a small hole is drilled into the skull and a tube is inserted through the hole to help drain the haematoma

【25】In a few cases, very small subdural haematomas may be carefully monitored first to see if they heal without having an operation.

【26】Read more about treating subdural haematomas.

【27】Outlook
-------

【28】A subdural haematoma is a serious condition that carries a high risk of death, particularly in older people and those whose brain was severely damaged.

【29】Acute subdural haematomas are the most serious type because they're often associated with significant damage to the brain.

【30】Those who survive an acute subdural haematoma may take a long time to recover, and may be left with physical disabilities and cognitive problems such as memory and speech problems.

【31】The outlook is generally better for subacute and chronic haematomas. Most people who are fit enough to have surgery eventually make a full recovery.

【32】But because many people with these types of haematoma are older, they may be too frail to have treatment.

【33】Read more about recovering from a subdural haematoma.

【34】Page last reviewed: 19 August 2021  
Next review due: 19 August 2024

【35】*   Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: IBD, see Inflammatory bowel disease
source_info.text:
【0】IBD, see Inflammatory bowel disease
Inflammatory bowel disease
==========================

【1】**Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a term used to describe conditions that cause severe tummy pain and diarrhoea. IBD is long-term, but there are treatments that can help with the symptoms.**

【2】The main types of IBD are Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

【3】Information:

【4】IBD is different to irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), even though some of the symptoms may be similar.

【5】Symptoms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
--------------------------------------------

【6】The main symptoms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) can include:

【7】*   diarrhoea that lasts longer than 4 weeks
*   tummy pain
*   blood or mucus (clear slime) in your poo
*   bleeding from your bottom
*   feeling tired all the time
*   losing weight without trying

【8】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【9】*   you have diarrhoea that lasts more than 7 days
*   you have tummy pain or bloating that will not go away or keeps coming back
*   you have blood or mucus (clear slime) in your poo
*   you've been losing a lot of weight without trying

【10】Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:
----------------------------------------------------

【11】*   you have severe tummy pain
*   you're bleeding non-stop from your bottom
*   there's a lot of blood, for example, the toilet water turns red or you see large blood clots
*   you're vomiting blood or poo, or your sick looks like coffee grounds or soil

【12】Find your nearest A&E

【13】Treatment for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
----------------------------------------------

【14】Treatment for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) will depend on your symptoms. If you're very unwell, you may need to be treated in hospital.

【15】Treatments may include:

【16】*   medicines to help ease your symptoms, such as steroids, and other medicines that can help keep your symptoms under control
*   surgery to remove part of your bowel, if your symptoms are severe

【17】Causes of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
------------------------------------------

【18】It's not clear what causes inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It happens when your immune system attacks your bowel, which causes it to get inflamed.

【19】You're more likely to get IBD if one of your close relatives has it, for example, one of your parents, grandparents, or a sibling.

【20】Help and support
----------------

【21】*   Crohn's and Colitis UK - a charity that provides help and support for people living with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
*   IBD Registry - UK registry for IBD, which includes Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, IBD unclassified and other forms of IBD

【22】Page last reviewed: 05 May 2023  
Next review due: 05 May 2026

source_info.title: Shingles
source_info.text:
【0】Shingles
========

【1】**Shingles is an infection that causes a painful rash. Get advice from 111 as soon as possible if you think you have it.**

【2】Check if you have shingles
--------------------------

【3】The first signs of shingles can be:

【4】*   a tingling or painful feeling in an area of skin
*   a headache or feeling generally unwell

【5】A rash will usually appear a few days later. In rare cases shingles can cause pain without a rash.

【6】Usually you get the shingles rash on your chest and tummy, but it can appear anywhere on your body including on your face, eyes and genitals.

【7】The rash appears as blotches on your skin, on 1 side of your body only. A rash on both the left and right of your body is unlikely to be shingles.

【8】The blotches become itchy blisters that ooze fluid. A few days later, the blisters dry out and scab.

【9】Credit:

【10】Scott Camazine / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/herpes-zoster-shingles-rash-image3217474.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=04C48F81-4F80-4503-BEE8-E369C12FA659&p=9949&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dA02G43%26qt\_raw%3dA02G43%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【11】The rash can be red, but this can be harder to see on brown and black skin.

【12】Credit:

【13】Science Photo Library https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/877219/view

【14】The rash can form a cluster that only appears on 1 side of your body. The skin remains painful until after the rash has gone.

【15】Credit:

【16】DR M.A. ANSARY / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/262592/view

【17】The rash may be in and around your eye, making it sore and red. It can affect your sight or hearing and make it hard to move 1 side of your face.

【18】Credit:

【19】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/262644/view

【20】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【21】*   you think you might have shingles

【22】You might need medicine to help speed up your recovery and avoid longer-lasting problems.

【23】This works best if you start taking it within 3 days of the shingles rash appearing.

【24】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【25】Treatment from a GP for shingles
--------------------------------

【26】Treatment for shingles depends on how severe your symptoms are and whether you're at risk of complications.

【27】If you have a mild rash you may not need any treatment.

【28】You may be offered medicine (antiviral tablets) to help speed up your recovery from shingles if:

【29】*   you have a weakened immune system
*   your pain or your rash is moderate or severe
*   the rash is affecting other areas of your body apart from your chest, tummy and back

【30】You usually need to start taking the medicine within 3 days of your rash first appearing.

【31】Treatment for shingles can also include medicines to help relieve pain, such as painkillers, steroid tablets or medicines that help with nerve pain.

【32】How to treat shingles symptoms yourself
---------------------------------------

【33】If you have shingles there are things you can do to help with the symptoms.

【34】### Do

【35】*   take paracetamol to ease pain

【36】*   keep the rash clean and dry to reduce the risk of infection

【37】*   wear loose-fitting clothing

【38】*   use a cool compress (a bag of ice cubes or frozen vegetables wrapped in a towel, or a wet cloth) a few times a day

【39】### Don’t

【40】*   do not let dressings or plasters stick to the rash

【41】*   do not wear clothes with rough fibres that can irritate your skin

【42】How long shingles lasts
-----------------------

【43】It can take up to 4 weeks for the shingles rash to heal.

【44】Your skin can be painful for weeks after the rash has gone, but it usually gets better over time.

【45】Stay away from certain groups of people if you have shingles
------------------------------------------------------------

【46】You cannot spread shingles to others. But people could catch chickenpox from you if they have not had chickenpox before or have not had the chickenpox vaccine.

【47】This is because shingles is caused by the chickenpox virus.

【48】Try to avoid:

【49】*   anyone who is pregnant and has not had chickenpox before
*   people with a weakened immune system – like someone having chemotherapy
*   babies less than 1 month old

【50】### Important: Work and school

【51】Stay off work or school if the rash is still oozing fluid (weeping) and cannot be covered, or until the rash has dried out.

【52】You can only spread the infection to other people while the rash oozes fluid.

【53】You can cover the rash with loose clothing or a non-sticky dressing.

【54】Complications of shingles
-------------------------

【55】Most people recover from shingles without any problems. But it can sometimes cause complications, such as:

【56】*   post-herpetic neuralgia, where pain lasts for several months after the shingles rash has gone
*   the rash becoming infected, which may need to be treated with antibiotics
*   scarring or changes in skin colour after the rash has healed
*   muscle weakness
*   eye problems, which can lead to sight loss
*   Ramsay Hunt syndrome, a rare condition where shingles affects your facial nerve, causing weakness on one side of your face and sometimes hearing problems

【57】You can reduce the risk of complications by getting treatment as soon as possible after your symptoms start.

【58】### Shingles and pregnancy

【59】If you're pregnant and get shingles, it's mostly mild and there's usually no risk to you or your baby.

【60】But a GP should arrange for a specialist to advise on whether you need treatment.

【61】Causes of shingles
------------------

【62】You cannot get shingles from someone with shingles or chickenpox.

【63】But you can get chickenpox from someone with shingles if you have not had chickenpox before.

【64】When people get chickenpox, the virus stays in the body. It can be reactivated later and cause shingles if someone's immune system is weakened.

【65】This can be because of stress, certain conditions, or treatments like chemotherapy.

【66】Shingles vaccine
----------------

【67】A shingles vaccine is available on the NHS for:

【68】*   people who turned 65 on or after 1 September 2023
*   people aged 70 to 79 who have not yet been vaccinated
*   people aged 50 and over with a severely weakened immune system

【69】The vaccine helps reduce your risk of getting shingles.

【70】If you get shingles after being vaccinated, the symptoms can be much milder.

【71】You can get shingles more than once, so it's important to get vaccinated even if you've had shingles before.

【72】Ask your GP surgery if you can get the vaccine on the NHS.

text.content:
【0】Shingles
========

【1】**Shingles is an infection that causes a painful rash. Get advice from 111 as soon as possible if you think you have it.**

【2】Check if you have shingles
--------------------------

【3】The first signs of shingles can be:

【4】*   a tingling or painful feeling in an area of skin
*   a headache or feeling generally unwell

【5】A rash will usually appear a few days later. In rare cases shingles can cause pain without a rash.

【6】Usually you get the shingles rash on your chest and tummy, but it can appear anywhere on your body including on your face, eyes and genitals.

【7】The rash appears as blotches on your skin, on 1 side of your body only. A rash on both the left and right of your body is unlikely to be shingles.

【8】The blotches become itchy blisters that ooze fluid. A few days later, the blisters dry out and scab.

【9】Credit:

【10】Scott Camazine / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/herpes-zoster-shingles-rash-image3217474.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=04C48F81-4F80-4503-BEE8-E369C12FA659&p=9949&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dA02G43%26qt\_raw%3dA02G43%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【11】The rash can be red, but this can be harder to see on brown and black skin.

【12】Credit:

【13】Science Photo Library https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/877219/view

【14】The rash can form a cluster that only appears on 1 side of your body. The skin remains painful until after the rash has gone.

【15】Credit:

【16】DR M.A. ANSARY / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/262592/view

【17】The rash may be in and around your eye, making it sore and red. It can affect your sight or hearing and make it hard to move 1 side of your face.

【18】Credit:

【19】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/262644/view

【20】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【21】*   you think you might have shingles

【22】You might need medicine to help speed up your recovery and avoid longer-lasting problems.

【23】This works best if you start taking it within 3 days of the shingles rash appearing.

【24】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【25】Treatment from a GP for shingles
--------------------------------

【26】Treatment for shingles depends on how severe your symptoms are and whether you're at risk of complications.

【27】If you have a mild rash you may not need any treatment.

【28】You may be offered medicine (antiviral tablets) to help speed up your recovery from shingles if:

【29】*   you have a weakened immune system
*   your pain or your rash is moderate or severe
*   the rash is affecting other areas of your body apart from your chest, tummy and back

【30】You usually need to start taking the medicine within 3 days of your rash first appearing.

【31】Treatment for shingles can also include medicines to help relieve pain, such as painkillers, steroid tablets or medicines that help with nerve pain.

【32】How to treat shingles symptoms yourself
---------------------------------------

【33】If you have shingles there are things you can do to help with the symptoms.

【34】### Do

【35】*   take paracetamol to ease pain

【36】*   keep the rash clean and dry to reduce the risk of infection

【37】*   wear loose-fitting clothing

【38】*   use a cool compress (a bag of ice cubes or frozen vegetables wrapped in a towel, or a wet cloth) a few times a day

【39】### Don’t

【40】*   do not let dressings or plasters stick to the rash

【41】*   do not wear clothes with rough fibres that can irritate your skin

【42】How long shingles lasts
-----------------------

【43】It can take up to 4 weeks for the shingles rash to heal.

【44】Your skin can be painful for weeks after the rash has gone, but it usually gets better over time.

【45】Stay away from certain groups of people if you have shingles
------------------------------------------------------------

【46】You cannot spread shingles to others. But people could catch chickenpox from you if they have not had chickenpox before or have not had the chickenpox vaccine.

【47】This is because shingles is caused by the chickenpox virus.

【48】Try to avoid:

【49】*   anyone who is pregnant and has not had chickenpox before
*   people with a weakened immune system – like someone having chemotherapy
*   babies less than 1 month old

【50】### Important: Work and school

【51】Stay off work or school if the rash is still oozing fluid (weeping) and cannot be covered, or until the rash has dried out.

【52】You can only spread the infection to other people while the rash oozes fluid.

【53】You can cover the rash with loose clothing or a non-sticky dressing.

【54】Complications of shingles
-------------------------

【55】Most people recover from shingles without any problems. But it can sometimes cause complications, such as:

【56】*   post-herpetic neuralgia, where pain lasts for several months after the shingles rash has gone
*   the rash becoming infected, which may need to be treated with antibiotics
*   scarring or changes in skin colour after the rash has healed
*   muscle weakness
*   eye problems, which can lead to sight loss
*   Ramsay Hunt syndrome, a rare condition where shingles affects your facial nerve, causing weakness on one side of your face and sometimes hearing problems

【57】You can reduce the risk of complications by getting treatment as soon as possible after your symptoms start.

【58】### Shingles and pregnancy

【59】If you're pregnant and get shingles, it's mostly mild and there's usually no risk to you or your baby.

【60】But a GP should arrange for a specialist to advise on whether you need treatment.

【61】Causes of shingles
------------------

【62】You cannot get shingles from someone with shingles or chickenpox.

【63】But you can get chickenpox from someone with shingles if you have not had chickenpox before.

【64】When people get chickenpox, the virus stays in the body. It can be reactivated later and cause shingles if someone's immune system is weakened.

【65】This can be because of stress, certain conditions, or treatments like chemotherapy.

【66】Shingles vaccine
----------------

【67】A shingles vaccine is available on the NHS for:

【68】*   people who turned 65 on or after 1 September 2023
*   people aged 70 to 79 who have not yet been vaccinated
*   people aged 50 and over with a severely weakened immune system

【69】The vaccine helps reduce your risk of getting shingles.

【70】If you get shingles after being vaccinated, the symptoms can be much milder.

【71】You can get shingles more than once, so it's important to get vaccinated even if you've had shingles before.

【72】Ask your GP surgery if you can get the vaccine on the NHS.

【73】Page last reviewed: 23 November 2023  
Next review due: 23 November 2026

【62】You cannot get shingles from someone with shingles or chickenpox.

【63】But you can get chickenpox from someone with shingles if you have not had chickenpox before.

【64】When people get chickenpox, the virus stays in the body. It can be reactivated later and cause shingles if someone's immune system is weakened.

【65】This can be because of stress, certain conditions, or treatments like chemotherapy.

【66】Shingles vaccine
----------------

【67】A shingles vaccine is available on the NHS for:

【68】*   people who turned 65 on or after 1 September 2023
*   people aged 70 to 79 who have not yet been vaccinated
*   people aged 50 and over with a severely weakened immune system

【69】The vaccine helps reduce your risk of getting shingles.

【70】If you get shingles after being vaccinated, the symptoms can be much milder.

【71】You can get shingles more than once, so it's important to get vaccinated even if you've had shingles before.

【72】Ask your GP surgery if you can get the vaccine on the NHS.

Next review due: 23 November 2026

text.content:
【0】Shingles
========

【1】**Shingles is an infection that causes a painful rash. Get advice from 111 as soon as possible if you think you have it.**

【2】Check if you have shingles
--------------------------

【3】The first signs of shingles can be:

【4】*   a tingling or painful feeling in an area of skin
*   a headache or feeling generally unwell

【5】A rash will usually appear a few days later. In rare cases shingles can cause pain without a rash.

【6】Usually you get the shingles rash on your chest and tummy, but it can appear anywhere on your body including on your face, eyes and genitals.

【7】The rash appears as blotches on your skin, on 1 side of your body only. A rash on both the left and right of your body is unlikely to be shingles.

【8】The blotches become itchy blisters that ooze fluid. A few days later, the blisters dry out and scab.

<mark>【9】Credit:

【10】Scott Camazine / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/herpes-zoster-shingles-rash-image3217474.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=04C48F81-4F80-4503-BEE8-E369C12FA659&p=9949&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3Dbar%26st%3D0%26pn%3D1%26ps%3D100%26sortby%3D2%26resultview%3DsortbyPopular%26npgs%3D0%26qt%3DA02G43%26qt\_raw%3DA02G43%26lic%3D3%26mr%3D0%26pr%3D0%26ot%3D0%26creative%3D%26ag%3D0%26hc%3D0%26pc%3D%26blackwhite%3D%26cutout%3D%26tbar%3D1%26et%3D0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3D0%26loc%3D0%26imgt%3D0%26dtfr%3D%26dtto%3D%26size%3D0xFF%26archive%3D1%26groupid%3D%26pseudoid%3D%26a%3D%26cdid%3D%26cdsrt%3D%26name%3D%26qn%3D%26apalib%3D%26apalic%3D%26lightbox%3D%26gname%3D%26gtype%3D%26xstx%3D0%26simid%3D%26saveQry%3D%26editorial%3D1%26nu%3D%26t%3D%26edoptin%3D%26customgeoip%3D%26cap%3D1%26cbstore%3D1%26vd%3D0%26lb%3D%26fi%3D2%26edrf%3D0%26ispremium%3D1%26flip%3D0%26pl%3D</mark>

【11】The rash can be red, but this can be harder to see on brown and black skin.

<mark>【12】Credit:

【13】Science Photo Library https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/877219/view</mark>

【14】The rash can form a cluster that only appears on 1 side of your body. The skin remains painful until after the rash has gone.

<mark>【15】Credit:

【16】DR M.A. ANSARY / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/262592/view</mark>

【17】The rash may be in and around your eye, making it sore and red. It can affect your sight or hearing and make it hard to move 1 side of your face.

【18】Credit:

【19】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/262644/view

【20】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【21】*   you think you might have shingles

【22】You might need medicine to help speed up your recovery and avoid longer-lasting problems.

【23】This works best if you start taking it within 3 days of the shingles rash appearing.

【24】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【25】Treatment from a GP for shingles
--------------------------------

【26】Treatment for shingles depends on how severe your symptoms are and whether you're at risk of complications.

【27】If you have a mild rash you may not need any treatment.

【28】You may be offered medicine (antiviral tablets) to help speed up your recovery from shingles if:

【29】*   you have a weakened immune system
*   your pain or your rash is moderate or severe
*   the rash is affecting other areas of your body apart from your chest, tummy and back

【30】You usually need to start taking the medicine within 3 days of your rash first appearing.

【31】Treatment for shingles can also include medicines to help relieve pain, such as painkillers, steroid tablets or medicines that help with nerve pain.

【32】How to treat shingles symptoms yourself
---------------------------------------

【33】If you have shingles there are things you can do to help with the symptoms.

【34】### Do

【35】*   take paracetamol to ease pain

【36】*   keep the rash clean and dry to reduce the risk of infection

【37】*   wear loose-fitting clothing

【38】*   use a cool compress (a bag of ice cubes or frozen vegetables wrapped in a towel, or a wet cloth) a few times a day

【39】### Don’t

【40】*   do not let dressings or plasters stick to the rash

【41】*   do not wear clothes with rough fibres that can irritate your skin

【42】How long shingles lasts
-----------------------

【43】It can take up to 4 weeks for the shingles rash to heal.

【44】Your skin can be painful for weeks after the rash has gone, but it usually gets better over time.

【45】Stay away from certain groups of people if you have shingles
------------------------------------------------------------

【46】You cannot spread shingles to others. But people could catch chickenpox from you if they have not had chickenpox before or have not had the chickenpox vaccine.

【47】This is because shingles is caused by the chickenpox virus.

【48】Try to avoid:

【49】*   anyone who is pregnant and has not had chickenpox before
*   people with a weakened immune system – like someone having chemotherapy
*   babies less than 1 month old

【50】### Important: Work and school

【51】Stay off work or school if the rash is still oozing fluid (weeping) and cannot be covered, or until the rash has dried out.

【52】You can only spread the infection to other people while the rash oozes fluid.

【53】You can cover the rash with loose clothing or a non-sticky dressing.

【54】Complications of shingles
-------------------------

【55】Most people recover from shingles without any problems. But it can sometimes cause complications, such as:

【56】*   post-herpetic neuralgia, where pain lasts for several months after the shingles rash has gone
*   the rash becoming infected, which may need to be treated with antibiotics
*   scarring or changes in skin colour after the rash has healed
*   muscle weakness
*   eye problems, which can lead to sight loss
*   Ramsay Hunt syndrome, a rare condition where shingles affects your facial nerve, causing weakness on one side of your face and sometimes hearing problems

【57】You can reduce the risk of complications by getting treatment as soon as possible after your symptoms start.

【58】### Shingles and pregnancy

【59】If you're pregnant and get shingles, it's mostly mild and there's usually no risk to you or your baby.

【60】But a GP should arrange for a specialist to advise on whether you need treatment.

【61】Causes of shingles
------------------

【62】You cannot get shingles from someone with shingles or chickenpox.

【63】But you can get chickenpox from someone with shingles if you have not had chickenpox before.

【64】When people get chickenpox, the virus stays in the body. It can be reactivated later and cause shingles if someone's immune system is weakened.

【65】This can be because of stress, certain conditions, or treatments like chemotherapy.

【66】Shingles vaccine
----------------

【67】A shingles vaccine is available on the NHS for:

【68】*   people who turned 65 on or after 1 September 2023
*   people aged 70 to 79 who have not yet been vaccinated
*   people aged 50 and over with a severely weakened immune system

【69】The vaccine helps reduce your risk of getting shingles.

【70】If you get shingles after being vaccinated, the symptoms can be much milder.

【71】You can get shingles more than once, so it's important to get vaccinated even if you've had shingles before.

【72】Ask your GP surgery if you can get the vaccine on the NHS.

【73】Page last reviewed: 23 November 2023  
Next review due: 23 November 2026

source_info.title: Down's syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】How to help children and young people \- Down's syndrome
========================================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  What is Down's syndrome?
2.  Advice for new parents
3.  How to help children and young people
4.  Support for adults
5.  Support for families and carers
6.  Other health conditions

【3】Things you can do to help
-------------------------

【4】Children and young people with Down's syndrome have some level of learning disability. This means they may need help with daily life.

【5】What they need help with is different for each person. And this can change as they get older.

【6】You can try these things to help with their development.

【7】### Do

【8】*   praise them when they learn something new

【9】*   speak clearly and calmly so they can learn from you

【10】*   play, sing songs and read books together to help with sounds and words

【11】*   try showing them how to do something instead of just giving instructions – this can be easier to follow

【12】*   try ways to help them communicate such as Signalong, Makaton or PECS

【13】*   try to set routines so they feel more settled – for example, for getting up and at mealtimes

【14】*   encourage them to be healthy and active – find activities on the Down's Syndrome Association DSActive website

【15】*   look out for changes in mood or behaviour – they may not be able to tell you if something's wrong or they're unwell

【16】*   take them for regular hearing, eyesight and health checks

【17】### Don’t

【18】*   do not talk down to people with Down's syndrome – treat them like anyone their age

【19】*   do not just talk to parents or carers, talk directly to people with Down's syndrome

【20】*   do not use outdated and offensive language when talking to people with Down's syndrome – see the Down's Syndrome Association language guide

【21】Medical support
---------------

【22】Children with Down's syndrome should have regular check-ups with a children's doctor (paediatrician) or a GP.

【23】This is because there are conditions they may be more likely to have.

【24】It could help for them to see:

【25】*   a speech and language therapist – for help with speaking
*   a physiotherapist – for help walking if they have low muscle tone
*   an optometrist or hearing specialist – for help with vision and hearing
*   an occupational therapist – for help with their development

【26】Speak to a GP, health visitor or your local council to find out how your child can get these services.

【27】Support with education
----------------------

【28】### Choosing a school or college

【29】Lots of children with Down's syndrome go to mainstream schools.

【30】There are also special schools and colleges for children and young people who might need more help.

【31】Where your child goes depends on:

【32】*   the help your child needs
*   what's available where you live

【33】You can visit schools and colleges in your area and ask the staff how they can meet your child's needs.

【34】### Special educational needs support

【35】Children with Down's syndrome will get special educational needs support at their school or college.

【36】Special educational needs support might include things like:

【37】*   extra support from a teacher or assistant
*   help taking part in lessons
*   support with things like eating and getting around school

【38】Find out more about support children with special educational needs can get on the GOV.UK website

【39】If your child needs more support
--------------------------------

【40】You can apply for an education, health and care plan (EHC plan, or EHCP).

【41】This plan says what education and health needs your child has and what support they should get.

【42】Having an EHC plan can either help:

【43】*   the school get extra money to support your child
*   you apply for a place at a school that's better for your child

【44】Find out how to get an EHC plan on the GOV.UK website

【45】Having a child with Down's syndrome
-----------------------------------

【46】3 families share their experience of having a child with Down's syndrome

【47】Media last reviewed: 18 March 2022  
Media review due: 18 March 2025

【48】Page last reviewed: 17 February 2023  
Next review due: 17 February 2026

*   Next : Support for adults

5.  Support for families and carers

6.  Other health conditions</mark>tions

【3】Things you can do to help
-------------------------

【4】Children and young people with Down's syndrome have some level of learning disability. This means they may need help with daily life.

【5】What they need help with is different for each person. And this can change as they get older.

【6】You can try these things to help with their development.

【7】### Do

【8】*   praise them when they learn something new

【9】*   speak clearly and calmly so they can learn from you

【10】*   play, sing songs and read books together to help with sounds and words

【11】*   try showing them how to do something instead of just giving instructions – this can be easier to follow

【12】*   try ways to help them communicate such as Signalong, Makaton or PECS

【13】*   try to set routines so they feel more settled – for example, for getting up and at mealtimes

【14】*   encourage them to be healthy and active – find activities on the Down's Syndrome Association DSActive website

【15】*   look out for changes in mood or behaviour – they may not be able to tell you if something's wrong or they're unwell

【16】*   take them for regular hearing, eyesight and health checks

【17】### Don’t

【18】*   do not talk down to people with Down's syndrome – treat them like anyone their age

【19】*   do not just talk to parents or carers, talk directly to people with Down's syndrome

【20】*   do not use outdated and offensive language when talking to people with Down's syndrome – see the Down's Syndrome Association language guide

【21】Medical support
---------------

【22】Children with Down's syndrome should have regular check-ups with a children's doctor (paediatrician) or a GP.

【23】This is because there are conditions they may be more likely to have.

【24】It could help for them to see:

【25】*   a speech and language therapist – for help with speaking
*   a physiotherapist – for help walking if they have low muscle tone
*   an optometrist or hearing specialist – for help with vision and hearing
*   an occupational therapist – for help with their development

【26】Speak to a GP, health visitor or your local council to find out how your child can get these services.

【27】Support with education
----------------------

【28】### Choosing a school or college

【29】Lots of children with Down's syndrome go to mainstream schools.

【30】There are also special schools and colleges for children and young people who might need more help.

【31】Where your child goes depends on:

【32】*   the help your child needs
*   what's available where you live

【33】You can visit schools and colleges in your area and ask the staff how they can meet your child's needs.

【34】### Special educational needs support

【35】Children with Down's syndrome will get special educational needs support at their school or college.

【36】Special educational needs support might include things like:

【37】*   extra support from a teacher or assistant
*   help taking part in lessons
*   support with things like eating and getting around school

【38】Find out more about support children with special educational needs can get on the GOV.UK website

【39】If your child needs more support
--------------------------------

【40】You can apply for an education, health and care plan (EHC plan, or EHCP).

【41】This plan says what education and health needs your child has and what support they should get.

【42】Having an EHC plan can either help:

【43】*   the school get extra money to support your child
*   you apply for a place at a school that's better for your child

【44】Find out how to get an EHC plan on the GOV.UK website

【45】Having a child with Down's syndrome
-----------------------------------

【46】3 families share their experience of having a child with Down's syndrome

【47】Media last reviewed: 18 March 2022  
Media review due: 18 March 2025

【48】Page last reviewed: 17 February 2023  
Next review due: 17 February 2026

【49】*   Previous : Advice for new parents
*   Next : Support for adults

source_info.title: Spina bifida
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Spina bifida
======================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment

【3】**It's not known what causes spina bifida but a number of things can increase the risk of a baby developing the condition.**

【4】Lack of folic acid
------------------

【5】Not having enough folic acid during pregnancy is one of the most important factors that can increase your chances of having a child with spina bifida.

【6】Folic acid (also known as vitamin B9) occurs naturally in some foods, such as broccoli, peas and brown rice. It's also added to foods, such as some breakfast cereals. Folic acid tablets are available from pharmacies and supermarkets, or a GP may be able to prescribe them for you. 

【7】It's estimated that taking folic acid supplements before you conceive and while you're pregnant may prevent up to 7 out of 10 cases of neural tube defects, such as spina bifida.

【8】It's not clear how folic acid helps prevent spina bifida. It's likely that folic acid is needed for important biochemical reactions in the body.

【9】Read more about why you need folic acid in pregnancy.

【10】Family history
--------------

【11】Having a family member with a neural tube defect, such as spina bifida, increases your chances of having a baby with spina bifida.

【12】If you've previously had a child with spina bifida, your chance of having other children with the condition is increased.

【13】If you have a family history of spina bifida, it's very important that you take high-dose folic acid, prescribed by a GP before you become pregnant, and for at least the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.

【14】Medicine
--------

【15】Taking certain medicines during pregnancy has been linked to an increased risk of having a baby with spina bifida or other birth defects.

【16】Valproate and carbamazepine are medicines linked to spina bifida. They're often used to treat epilepsy, and some mental health conditions, such as bipolar disorder.

【17】Doctors will try to avoid prescribing these medicines if there's a chance you could get pregnant while taking them, but they may be needed if the alternatives are not effective.

【18】It's advisable to use a reliable form of contraception if you need to take one of these medicines and are not trying to get pregnant.

【19】Tell your doctor if you're thinking about trying for a baby and you need to take one of these medicines. They may be able to lower the dose and prescribe folic acid supplements at a higher than normal dose, to reduce the risk of problems.

【20】If you're not sure whether a medicine could affect your pregnancy, check with your doctor, midwife or pharmacist before taking it. Never stop taking a prescribed medicine unless a GP or another healthcare professional responsible for your care advises you to.

【21】Genetic conditions
------------------

【22】Very rarely a baby can have spina bifida alongside a genetic condition such as Patau's syndrome, Edwards' syndrome or Down's syndrome.

【23】If your baby is found to have spina bifida and it's thought they may also have one of these syndromes, you'll be offered a diagnostic test, such as amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling. These tests can confirm if your baby has one of these genetic conditions. 

【24】Other risk factors
------------------

【25】Other risk factors for spina bifida include:

【26】*   obesity – women who are obese (have a body mass index of 30 or more) are more likely to have a child with spina bifida than those of average weight
*   diabetes – women with diabetes may have an increased risk of having a child with spina bifida

【27】Page last reviewed: 20 April 2020  
Next review due: 20 April 2023

【28】*   Previous : Symptoms
*   Next : Treatment
