source_info.title: Heart failure
source_info.text:
【0】Living with \- Heart failure
============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with

【3】**If you have heart failure, it's important to look after your own health and wellbeing, with support from those involved in your care.**

【4】Looking after yourself
----------------------

【5】It's very important to take good care of yourself if you have heart failure.

【6】### Have a healthy diet

【7】A healthy, balanced diet can help improve your symptoms and general health.

【8】A balanced diet should include:

【9】*   plenty of fruit and vegetables – aim for at least 5 portions a day
*   meals based on starchy foods, such as potatoes, bread, rice or pasta
*   some dairy or dairy alternatives
*   some beans or pulses, fish, eggs, meat and other sources of protein
*   low levels of saturated fat, salt and sugar

【10】You may also be given advice about dietary changes that can specifically help with heart failure, such as limiting the amount of fluid you drink.

【11】### Exercise regularly

【12】Regular physical activity can also help improve your symptoms and general health.

【13】If you have heart failure, you should be offered an exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation programme.

【14】These programmes vary widely across the country, but most cover 1 or more of the following:

【15】*   exercise
*   education
*   emotional support

【16】They're usually run in hospitals or community clinics by teams that include nurses, physiotherapists, occupational therapists and exercise specialists.

【17】Before you start, you'll have an assessment to find out how much exercise you can safely do.

【18】A programme of exercise can then be tailored specifically for you.

【19】The education part of the programme will give you information on healthy eating and practical ways to reduce the risk of further damage to your heart.

【20】#### Want to know more?

【21】*   British Heart Foundation: cardiac rehabilitation

【22】### Stop smoking

【23】If you smoke, stopping smoking can improve your overall health and reduce your risk of many other health problems.

【24】Speak to your GP or an NHS stop smoking service if you think you'll need help quitting.

【25】They can provide support and, if necessary, prescribe stop smoking treatments.

【26】### Limit your alcohol consumption

【27】You can usually continue to drink alcohol if you have heart failure, but it's advisable not to exceed the recommended limits of more than 14 alcohol units a week.

【28】If your heart failure is directly related to drinking alcohol, you may be advised to stop entirely.

【29】Get some tips on cutting down on alcohol

【30】### Get vaccinated

【31】Heart failure can put a significant strain on your body and mean you're more vulnerable to infections.

【32】Everyone with heart failure should be offered the annual flu vaccine and the one-off pneumococcal vaccination.

【33】You can get these vaccinations at your GP surgery or a local pharmacy that offers a vaccination service.

【34】#### Want to know more?

【35】*   British Heart Foundation: living with heart failure
*   healthtalk.org: real stories about living with heart failure

【36】Regular reviews and monitoring
------------------------------

【37】You'll have regular contact with your GP or care team to monitor your condition at least every 6 months.

【38】These appointments may involve:

【39】*   talking about your symptoms, such as whether they're affecting your normal activities or are getting worse
*   a discussion about your medication, including any side effects
*   tests to monitor your health

【40】It's also a good opportunity to ask any questions you have or raise any other issues you'd like to discuss with your care team.

【41】You may be asked to help monitor your condition between appointments.

【42】For example, your care team may suggest weighing yourself regularly so any changes in your weight, which could be a sign of a problem, are picked up quickly.

【43】Contact your GP or care team if your symptoms are getting worse or you develop new symptoms.

【44】Your care team will advise you about when and where to seek advice if there's a potential problem.

【45】Travelling and driving
----------------------

【46】### Travelling

【47】Having heart failure shouldn't prevent you travelling or going on holiday, as long as you feel well enough and your condition is well controlled. But check with your doctor before you travel.

【48】It may be advisable to avoid travelling to high altitudes or hot, humid places because this may put extra strain on your heart.

【49】Flying won't usually cause problems, but if your heart failure is severe, your legs and ankles may swell and breathing may become more difficult.

【50】If you're flying, inform the airline of your condition. They may provide a wheelchair or electric car so you can avoid having to walk long distances at the airport.

【51】If you're travelling and sitting still for a long time, either in a car, coach or on a plane, you should do simple exercises to reduce the risk of blood clots. Wearing flight socks or compression stockings while flying should also help.

【52】It may be a good idea to take 2 sets of medication with you when you travel. Carry them in different places in case you lose one, and make a list of the medication you take and what it's for.

【53】Having heart failure shouldn't stop you getting travel insurance, but you may have to find a specialist company that'll insure you.

【54】### Driving

【55】You may need to tell the DVLA if you have heart failure.

【56】Read more about heart failure and driving on GOV.UK.

【57】Emotions, relationships and sex
-------------------------------

【58】Being diagnosed with heart failure can be a shock. Some people feel scared, anxious, depressed or angry. These feelings are completely normal.

【59】Some people also become depressed. Speak to your GP or care team if you feel unable to enjoy the things you used to or cope with everyday life.

【60】You may find your physical relationship with your partner changes after your diagnosis because of worries about having a heart attack, or because you lose interest in sex or are unable to get an erection, which can sometimes be caused by heart failure medicines.

【61】You can discuss any worries or problems you have with your GP or care team if you feel unable to talk to your family or friends. They'll be able to advise you and arrange support.

【62】You may also find it helpful to join a heart support group, where you can talk to other people with heart conditions whose circumstances are similar to yours.

【63】You can call the British Heart Foundation's heart helpline on 0300 330 3311 to find out about support groups in your area.

【64】Work and financial help
-----------------------

【65】### Can I continue working?

【66】If you're well enough, you can keep working for as long as you feel able. With the right support, staying in work can make you feel better and give you financial security. 

【67】Talk to your employer as soon as you feel your heart failure is affecting your ability to do your job so you can find a solution that suits both of you. For example, it may be possible for you to work part-time.

【68】The Disability Discrimination Act 1995 requires employers to make reasonable adjustments to working practices or premises to help a person with a disability.

【69】Where possible, this might include changing or modifying tasks, altering work patterns, installing special equipment, allowing time off to attend appointments, or helping with travel to work.

【70】### What happens if I can no longer work?

【71】If you can't continue working as a result of heart failure, you may be able to claim disability and sickness benefits.

【72】Find out more about benefits if you have a long-term illness or disability on GOV.UK

【73】### Help for carers

【74】Carers may also be entitled to some benefits.

【75】Read more about benefits for carers.

【76】Caring for someone with heart failure
-------------------------------------

【77】Looking after someone with heart failure can mean anything from helping with hospital or GP visits and collecting prescriptions, to full-time caring.

【78】There are many ways you can support someone with heart failure.

【79】Heart failure can be disabling and distressing, and many people with the condition find it a huge relief to share their concerns and fears with someone.

【80】As a carer, if you can attend GP and hospital appointments with the person with heart failure, you can encourage them to ask the right questions while you note down the answers.

【81】You could also provide the doctor with additional information or insights into the person's condition, which can be helpful for planning the right treatment.

【82】Another way you can help is by watching for warning signs that the person's heart failure is getting worse or they're not responding to treatment. 

【83】Contact the person's doctor if you notice a new symptom or their current symptoms are getting worse.

【84】Signs to look out for include:

【85】*   shortness of breath that isn't related to usual exercise or activity
*   increased swelling of the legs or ankles
*   significant weight gain over a few days
*   swelling or pain in their tummy
*   trouble sleeping or waking up short of breath
*   a dry, hacking cough
*   increasing tiredness or feeling tired all the time

【86】See the care and support guide for information about all aspects of caring for someone with a long-term condition.

【87】What will happen towards the end?
---------------------------------

【88】Heart failure usually gets gradually worse over time. It may eventually reach a point where it becomes very severe and it's unlikely the person will live much longer.

【89】Palliative care will usually begin when heart failure reaches this stage.

【90】This involves treatment to help you feel as comfortable as possible, as well as being offered psychological, spiritual and social support for both you and your family.

【91】You can choose whether you want palliative care and where you'd like it to be provided.

【92】Care can be provided:

【93】*   at home
*   in a hospice
*   in hospital

【94】### Plan in advance

【95】It's a good idea to plan for your care in advance, as you may not be able to make decisions about your treatment when you become severely ill.

【96】Find out more about planning ahead if you have a terminal illness

【97】Page last reviewed: 19 May 2022  
Next review due: 19 May 2025

【98】*   Previous : Treatment

text.text: See the care and support guide for information about all aspects of caring for someone with a long-term condition.
text.content:
【0】Living with \- Heart failure
============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with

【3】**If you have heart failure, it's important to look after your own health and wellbeing, with support from those involved in your care.**

【4】Looking after yourself
----------------------

【5】It's very important to take good care of yourself if you have heart failure.

【6】### Have a healthy diet

【7】A healthy, balanced diet can help improve your symptoms and general health.

【8】A balanced diet should include:

【9】*   plenty of fruit and vegetables – aim for at least 5 portions a day
*   meals based on starchy foods, such as potatoes, bread, rice or pasta
*   some dairy or dairy alternatives
*   some beans or pulses, fish, eggs, meat and other sources of protein
*   low levels of saturated fat, salt and sugar

【10】You may also be given advice about dietary changes that can specifically help with heart failure, such as limiting the amount of fluid you drink.

【11】### Exercise regularly

【12】Regular physical activity can also help improve your symptoms and general health.

【13】If you have heart failure, you should be offered an exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation programme.

【14】These programmes vary widely across the country, but most cover 1 or more of the following:

【15】*   exercise
*   education
*   emotional support

【16】They're usually run in hospitals or community clinics by teams that include nurses, physiotherapists, occupational therapists and exercise specialists.

【17】Before you start, you'll have an assessment to find out how much exercise you can safely do.

【18】A programme of exercise can then be tailored specifically for you.

【19】The education part of the programme will give you information on healthy eating and practical ways to reduce the risk of further damage to your heart.

【20】#### Want to know more?

【21】*   British Heart Foundation: cardiac rehabilitation

【22】### Stop smoking

【23】If you smoke, stopping smoking can improve your overall health and reduce your risk of many other health problems.

【24】Speak to your GP or an NHS stop smoking service if you think you'll need help quitting.

【25】They can provide support and, if necessary, prescribe stop smoking treatments.

【26】### Limit your alcohol consumption

【27】You can usually continue to drink alcohol if you have heart failure, but it's advisable not to exceed the recommended limits of more than 14 alcohol units a week.

【28】If your heart failure is directly related to drinking alcohol, you may be advised to stop entirely.

【29】Get some tips on cutting down on alcohol

【30】### Get vaccinated

【31】Heart failure can put a significant strain on your body and mean you're more vulnerable to infections.

【32】Everyone with heart failure should be offered the annual flu vaccine and the one-off pneumococcal vaccination.

【33】You can get these vaccinations at your GP surgery or a local pharmacy that offers a vaccination service.

【34】#### Want to know more?

【35】*   British Heart Foundation: living with heart failure
*   healthtalk.org: real stories about living with heart failure

【36】Regular reviews and monitoring
------------------------------

【37】You'll have regular contact with your GP or care team to monitor your condition at least every 6 months.

【38】These appointments may involve:

【39】*   talking about your symptoms, such as whether they're affecting your normal activities or are getting worse
*   a discussion about your medication, including any side effects
*   tests to monitor your health

【40】It's also a good opportunity to ask any questions you have or raise any other issues you'd like to discuss with your care team.

【41】You may be asked to help monitor your condition between appointments.

【42】For example, your care team may suggest weighing yourself regularly so any changes in your weight, which could be a sign of a problem, are picked up quickly.

【43】Contact your GP or care team if your symptoms are getting worse or you develop new symptoms.

【44】Your care team will advise you about when and where to seek advice if there's a potential problem.

【45】Travelling and driving
----------------------

【46】### Travelling

【47】Having heart failure shouldn't prevent you travelling or going on holiday, as long as you feel well enough and your condition is well controlled. But check with your doctor before you travel.

【48】It may be advisable to avoid travelling to high altitudes or hot, humid places because this may put extra strain on your heart.

【49】Flying won't usually cause problems, but if your heart failure is severe, your legs and ankles may swell and breathing may become more difficult.

【50】If you're flying, inform the airline of your condition. They may provide a wheelchair or electric car so you can avoid having to walk long distances at the airport.

【51】If you're travelling and sitting still for a long time, either in a car, coach or on a plane, you should do simple exercises to reduce the risk of blood clots. Wearing flight socks or compression stockings while flying should also help.

【52】It may be a good idea to take 2 sets of medication with you when you travel. Carry them in different places in case you lose one, and make a list of the medication you take and what it's for.

【53】Having heart failure shouldn't stop you getting travel insurance, but you may have to find a specialist company that'll insure you.

【54】### Driving

【55】You may need to tell the DVLA if you have heart failure.

【56】Read more about heart failure and driving on GOV.UK.

【57】Emotions, relationships and sex
-------------------------------

【58】Being diagnosed with heart failure can be a shock. Some people feel scared, anxious, depressed or angry. These feelings are completely normal.

【59】Some people also become depressed. Speak to your GP or care team if you feel unable to enjoy the things you used to or cope with everyday life.

【60】You may find your physical relationship with your partner changes after your diagnosis because of worries about having a heart attack, or because you lose interest in sex or are unable to get an erection, which can sometimes be caused by heart failure medicines.

【61】You can discuss any worries or problems you have with your GP or care team if you feel unable to talk to your family or friends. They'll be able to advise you and arrange support.

【62】You may also find it helpful to join a heart support group, where you can talk to other people with heart conditions whose circumstances are similar to yours.

【63】You can call the British Heart Foundation's heart helpline on 0300 330 3311 to find out about support groups in your area.

【64】Work and financial help
-----------------------

【65】### Can I continue working?

【66】If you're well enough, you can keep working for as long as you feel able. With the right support, staying in work can make you feel better and give you financial security. 

【67】Talk to your employer as soon as you feel your heart failure is affecting your ability to do your job so you can find a solution that suits both of you. For example, it may be possible for you to work part-time.

【68】The Disability Discrimination Act 1995 requires employers to make reasonable adjustments to working practices or premises to help a person with a disability.

【69】Where possible, this might include changing or modifying tasks, altering work patterns, installing special equipment, allowing time off to attend appointments, or helping with travel to work.

【70】### What happens if I can no longer work?

【71】If you can't continue working as a result of heart failure, you may be able to claim disability and sickness benefits.

【72】Find out more about benefits if you have a long-term illness or disability on GOV.UK

【73】### Help for carers

【74】Carers may also be entitled to some benefits.

【75】Read more about benefits for carers.

【76】Caring for someone with heart failure
-------------------------------------

【77】Looking after someone with heart failure can mean anything from helping with hospital or GP visits and collecting prescriptions, to full-time caring.

【78】There are many ways you can support someone with heart failure.

【79】Heart failure can be disabling and distressing, and many people with the condition find it a huge relief to share their concerns and fears with someone.

【80】As a carer, if you can attend GP and hospital appointments with the person with heart failure, you can encourage them to ask the right questions while you note down the answers.

【81】You could also provide the doctor with additional information or insights into the person's condition, which can be helpful for planning the right treatment.

【82】Another way you can help is by watching for warning signs that the person's heart failure is getting worse or they're not responding to treatment. 

【83】Contact the person's doctor if you notice a new symptom or their current symptoms are getting worse.

【84】Signs to look out for include:

【85】*   shortness of breath that isn't related to usual exercise or activity
*   increased swelling of the legs or ankles
*   significant weight gain over a few days
*   swelling or pain in their tummy
*   trouble sleeping or waking up short of breath
*   a dry, hacking cough
*   increasing tiredness or feeling tired all the time

【86】See the care and support guide for information about all aspects of caring for someone with a long-term condition.

【87】What will happen towards the end?
---------------------------------

【88】Heart failure usually gets gradually worse over time. It may eventually reach a point where it becomes very severe and it's unlikely the person will live much longer.

【89】Palliative care will usually begin when heart failure reaches this stage.

【90】This involves treatment to help you feel as comfortable as possible, as well as being offered psychological, spiritual and social support for both you and your family.

【91】You can choose whether you want palliative care and where you'd like it to be provided.

【92】Care can be provided:

【93】*   at home
*   in a hospice
*   in hospital

【94】### Plan in advance

【95】It's a good idea to plan for your care in advance, as you may not be able to make decisions about your treatment when you become severely ill.

【96】Find out more about planning ahead if you have a terminal illness

【97】Page last reviewed: 19 May 2022  
Next review due: 19 May 2025

【98】*   Previous : Treatment

source_info.title: Giving someone power of attorney
source_info.text:
【0】Giving someone power of attorney
================================

【1】Putting in place a power of attorney can give you peace of mind that someone you trust is in charge of your affairs.

【2】If you're aged 18 or older and have the mental ability to make financial, property and medical decisions for yourself, you can arrange for someone else to make these decisions for you in the future. This legal authority is called "lasting power of attorney".

【3】The person who is given power of attorney is known as the "attorney" and must be over 18 years old. You are known as the "donor".

【4】Appointing attorneys
--------------------

【5】You can appoint just 1 attorney, or more than 1 attorney, to act:

【6】*   "jointly" – they must always make decisions together
*   "jointly and severally" – they have to make some decisions together and some individually

【7】For example, you can appoint attorneys to act jointly when making decisions over your money, but state that only one attorney should decide where you should live.

【8】You have the right to say the attorneys must act jointly on all your affairs.

【9】Types of power of attorney
--------------------------

【10】There are 3 different types of power of attorney: lasting power of attorney (LPA), enduring power of attorney (EPA) and ordinary power of attorney.

【11】LPAs came into force in October 2007. Before that, people made EPAs. It's no longer possible to make an EPA, but an EPA made before October 2007 remains valid.

【12】An ordinary power of attorney allows someone to look after your financial affairs for a temporary period. It will end if you lose mental capacity to make decisions.

【13】### Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA)

【14】This includes:

【15】*   health and welfare LPA
*   property and financial affairs LPA

【16】### Health and welfare LPA

【17】A health and welfare LPA gives your attorney the power to make decisions about your daily routine (washing, dressing, eating), medical care, moving into a care home and life-sustaining medical treatment. It can only be used if you're unable to make your own decisions.

【18】### Property and financial affairs LPA

【19】A property and financial affairs LPA gives your attorney the power to make decisions about your money and property. This includes managing your bank or building society accounts, paying bills, collecting your pension or benefits and, if necessary, selling your home.

【20】Once registered with the Office of the Public Guardian, it can be used immediately or held in readiness until required.

【21】### Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA)

【22】An EPA deals only with property and financial affairs, not with personal welfare issues.

【23】Applying for power of attorney
------------------------------

【24】It's generally recommended that you set up both a health and welfare LPA and a property and financial affairs LPA at the same time.

【25】Many people do this while reviewing or revising their will, and you may be able to use the same solicitor.

【26】You can apply online for power of attorney on GOV.UK

【27】Alternatively, contact the Office of the Public Guardian for an application pack:

【28】*   by post at the Office of the Public Guardian, PO Box 16185, Birmingham B2 2WH
*   by phone on 0300 456 0300 – lines are open Monday to Friday, 9.30am to 5pm (Wednesday, 10am to 5pm)
*   by email – customerservices@publicguardian.gov.uk

【29】Talk to a solicitor if you have problems answering any of the questions or if you want them to check what you have done. You can find a solicitor on the Law Society online directory.

【30】You can call the Office of the Public Guardian on 0300 456 0300 or the Court of Protection on 0300 456 0300 first to see if they can help.

【31】Registering the power of attorney
---------------------------------

【32】A lasting power of attorney has to be registered before it comes into force.

【33】You can register a power of attorney on GOV.UK

【34】You'll need to pay an application fee. You may be exempt or pay a reduced fee if you receive certain benefits or you're on a low income.

【35】Either the person making the application for power of attorney (the donor) or the person who will have power of attorney (the attorney) can apply to register the application.

【36】There is a 4-week notice period for any objections to be raised.

【37】Once the power of attorney has been registered, the original document is returned to the applicant.

【38】The Office of the Public Guardian also gives notice to the donor that the LPA has been registered.

【39】Cancelling power of attorney
----------------------------

【40】You can cancel your lasting power of attorney at any time, even if the application has been registered.

【41】But you must have the mental capacity to make that decision, and you must tell your attorneys and the Office of the Public Guardian so they can remove the LPA from the register.

【42】Find out how to end a lasting power of attorney on GOV.UK

【43】Power of attorney automatically ends if:

【44】*   the attorney or donor dies
*   the attorney or donor becomes bankrupt, if it's a property and financial affairs LPA
*   a marriage or civil partnership between the donor and the attorney is dissolved or annulled
*   the attorneys lack the mental capacity to make decisions

【45】The Court of Protection can cancel an LPA if an attorney is not acting in a person's best interests and is making excessive "gifts" to themselves or others.

【46】### Cancelling enduring power of attorney (EPA)

【47】To cancel an unregistered EPA, you'll need to sign a formal document called a Deed of Revocation. You may wish to seek legal advice first.

【48】You can cancel an unregistered EPA at any time while you have the mental capacity to do so.

【49】If the EPA has been registered, you cannot cancel it except by permission of the Court of Protection.

【50】Advice for attorneys: health and welfare
----------------------------------------

【51】Having an LPA over someone's personal welfare may mean you need to make decisions about the healthcare and welfare of the person you're looking after.

【52】If you have this power, you may have to decide:

【53】*   where the person is to live
*   whether a care home or a nursing home is best for them, and which one
*   whether the person can continue to live at home with help from social services

【54】You'll be able to decide if the donor should:

【55】*   receive healthcare treatment
*   not receive a particular healthcare treatment
*   stop receiving a particular healthcare treatment

【56】Some people who have a progressive illness sometimes make a decision about whether they'd want a particular treatment in the future.

【57】They write down or tell others these wishes while they're mentally well, or have "mental capacity".

【58】If the donor made a decision to refuse future medical treatment (known as an advance decision) in advance of losing their mental capacity, you cannot override their decision unless the LPA was made later and specifies that you have the power to do so.

【59】### What health and welfare power of attorney cannot do

【60】A health and welfare LPA does not come into force until the donor has lost the capacity to make decisions for themselves.

【61】There are some decisions you as an attorney cannot make for another person.

【62】You cannot:

【63】*   refuse any medicine prescribed by a responsible clinician if the person has been sectioned or is on leave from hospital
*   make decisions about where they should live if the donor is under a guardianship order
*   make a decision about life-sustaining treatment without checking whether the person has made an advance decision about this

【64】### Health and welfare power of attorney and restraint

【65】If you have a health and welfare LPA, you may sometimes consider "restraining" (stopping or hindering) the person you're looking after from doing something you think will harm them or others.

【66】Under the law, you're considered to be restraining someone if you:

【67】*   physically force them to do, or stop doing, something
*   threaten to physically force them to do, or stop doing, something
*   prevent them going somewhere or doing something they want to
*   ask someone else to do any of the things listed above

【68】You should not restrain the person unless:

【69】*   you believe they do not have the mental ability or capacity to make a decision about that particular issue
*   you believe it's necessary to use restraint to prevent them harming themselves
*   it's a reasonable action to take because you believe they may suffer serious harm – for example, you could physically stop someone crossing the road if they were walking into traffic

【70】Advice for attorneys: property and financial affairs
----------------------------------------------------

【71】If you have lasting power of attorney over property and financial affairs, you're allowed to make decisions on the donor's behalf.

【72】These include:

【73】*   writing cheques and paying bills
*   selling or renting property
*   carrying out their trade or business
*   honouring any contractual obligations
*   conducting legal proceedings on their behalf

【74】You're also allowed to make gifts on behalf of the donor in certain circumstances.

【75】For example:

【76】*   on occasions such as birthdays or marriages to those related to or connected with the donor
*   to a charity the donor has supported in the past

【77】Acting as an attorney means you should maintain a duty of care to the donor, not to benefit yourself. It's important to avoid any potential conflicts of interest.

【78】Specifically, you must keep the donor's money and property separate from your own, and keep accurate accounts in all of your dealings as an attorney.

【79】Find out more about power of attorney on GOV.UK

【80】More in Making decisions for someone else
-----------------------------------------

【81】*   Mental Capacity Act
*   Giving someone power of attorney

【82】Page last reviewed: 15 April 2021  
Next review due: 15 April 2024

【27】Alternatively, contact the Office of the Public Guardian for an application pack:

【28】*   by post at the Office of the Public Guardian, PO Box 16185, Birmingham B2 2WH

by phone on 0300 456 0300 – lines are open Monday to Friday, 9.30am to 5pm (Wednesday, 10am to 5pm)
by email – customerservices@publicguardian.gov.uk

================================

【1】Putting in place a power of attorney can give you peace of mind that someone you trust is in charge of your affairs.

【2】If you're aged 18 or older and have the mental ability to make financial, property and medical decisions for yourself, you can arrange for someone else to make these decisions for you in the future. This legal authority is called "lasting power of attorney".

【3】The person who is given power of attorney is known as the "attorney" and must be over 18 years old. You are known as the "donor".

【4】Appointing attorneys
--------------------

【5】You can appoint just 1 attorney, or more than 1 attorney, to act:

【6】*   "jointly" – they must always make decisions together
*   "jointly and severally" – they have to make some decisions together and some individually

【7】For example, you can appoint attorneys to act jointly when making decisions over your money, but state that only one attorney should decide where you should live.

【8】You have the right to say the attorneys must act jointly on all your affairs.

【9】Types of power of attorney
--------------------------

【10】There are 3 different types of power of attorney: lasting power of attorney (LPA), enduring power of attorney (EPA) and ordinary power of attorney.

【11】LPAs came into force in October 2007. Before that, people made EPAs. It's no longer possible to make an EPA, but an EPA made before October 2007 remains valid.

【12】An ordinary power of attorney allows someone to look after your financial affairs for a temporary period. It will end if you lose mental capacity to make decisions.

【13】### Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA)

【14】This includes:

【15】*   health and welfare LPA
*   property and financial affairs LPA

【16】### Health and welfare LPA

【17】A health and welfare LPA gives your attorney the power to make decisions about your daily routine (washing, dressing, eating), medical care, moving into a care home and life-sustaining medical treatment. It can only be used if you're unable to make your own decisions.

【18】### Property and financial affairs LPA

【19】A property and financial affairs LPA gives your attorney the power to make decisions about your money and property. This includes managing your bank or building society accounts, paying bills, collecting your pension or benefits and, if necessary, selling your home.

【20】Once registered with the Office of the Public Guardian, it can be used immediately or held in readiness until required.

【21】### Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA)

【22】An EPA deals only with property and financial affairs, not with personal welfare issues.

【23】Applying for power of attorney
------------------------------

【24】It's generally recommended that you set up both a health and welfare LPA and a property and financial affairs LPA at the same time.

【25】Many people do this while reviewing or revising their will, and you may be able to use the same solicitor.

【26】You can apply online for power of attorney on GOV.UK

【27】Alternatively, contact the Office of the Public Guardian for an application pack:

【28】*   by post at the Office of the Public Guardian, PO Box 16185, Birmingham B2 2WH
*   by phone on 0300 456 0300 – lines are open Monday to Friday, 9.30am to 5pm (Wednesday, 10am to 5pm)
*   by email – customerservices@publicguardian.gov.uk

【29】Talk to a solicitor if you have problems answering any of the questions or if you want them to check what you have done. You can find a solicitor on the Law Society online directory.

【30】You can call the Office of the Public Guardian on 0300 456 0300 or the Court of Protection on 0300 456 0300 first to see if they can help.

【31】Registering the power of attorney
---------------------------------

【32】A lasting power of attorney has to be registered before it comes into force.

【33】You can register a power of attorney on GOV.UK

【34】You'll need to pay an application fee. You may be exempt or pay a reduced fee if you receive certain benefits or you're on a low income.

【35】Either the person making the application for power of attorney (the donor) or the person who will have power of attorney (the attorney) can apply to register the application.

【36】There is a 4-week notice period for any objections to be raised.

【37】Once the power of attorney has been registered, the original document is returned to the applicant.

【38】The Office of the Public Guardian also gives notice to the donor that the LPA has been registered.

【39】Cancelling power of attorney
----------------------------

【40】You can cancel your lasting power of attorney at any time, even if the application has been registered.

【41】But you must have the mental capacity to make that decision, and you must tell your attorneys and the Office of the Public Guardian so they can remove the LPA from the register.

【42】Find out how to end a lasting power of attorney on GOV.UK

【43】Power of attorney automatically ends if:

【44】*   the attorney or donor dies
*   the attorney or donor becomes bankrupt, if it's a property and financial affairs LPA
*   a marriage or civil partnership between the donor and the attorney is dissolved or annulled
*   the attorneys lack the mental capacity to make decisions

【45】The Court of Protection can cancel an LPA if an attorney is not acting in a person's best interests and is making excessive "gifts" to themselves or others.

【46】### Cancelling enduring power of attorney (EPA)

【47】To cancel an unregistered EPA, you'll need to sign a formal document called a Deed of Revocation. You may wish to seek legal advice first.

【48】You can cancel an unregistered EPA at any time while you have the mental capacity to do so.

【49】If the EPA has been registered, you cannot cancel it except by permission of the Court of Protection.

【50】Advice for attorneys: health and welfare
----------------------------------------

【51】Having an LPA over someone's personal welfare may mean you need to make decisions about the healthcare and welfare of the person you're looking after.

【52】If you have this power, you may have to decide:

【53】*   where the person is to live
*   whether a care home or a nursing home is best for them, and which one
*   whether the person can continue to live at home with help from social services

【54】You'll be able to decide if the donor should:

【55】*   receive healthcare treatment
*   not receive a particular healthcare treatment
*   stop receiving a particular healthcare treatment

【56】Some people who have a progressive illness sometimes make a decision about whether they'd want a particular treatment in the future.

【57】They write down or tell others these wishes while they're mentally well, or have "mental capacity".

【58】If the donor made a decision to refuse future medical treatment (known as an advance decision) in advance of losing their mental capacity, you cannot override their decision unless the LPA was made later and specifies that you have the power to do so.

【59】### What health and welfare power of attorney cannot do

【60】A health and welfare LPA does not come into force until the donor has lost the capacity to make decisions for themselves.

【61】There are some decisions you as an attorney cannot make for another person.

【62】You cannot:

【63】*   refuse any medicine prescribed by a responsible clinician if the person has been sectioned or is on leave from hospital
*   make decisions about where they should live if the donor is under a guardianship order
*   make a decision about life-sustaining treatment without checking whether the person has made an advance decision about this

【64】### Health and welfare power of attorney and restraint

【65】If you have a health and welfare LPA, you may sometimes consider "restraining" (stopping or hindering) the person you're looking after from doing something you think will harm them or others.

【66】Under the law, you're considered to be restraining someone if you:

【67】*   physically force them to do, or stop doing, something
*   threaten to physically force them to do, or stop doing, something
*   prevent them going somewhere or doing something they want to
*   ask someone else to do any of the things listed above

【68】You should not restrain the person unless:

【69】*   you believe they do not have the mental ability or capacity to make a decision about that particular issue
*   you believe it's necessary to use restraint to prevent them harming themselves
*   it's a reasonable action to take because you believe they may suffer serious harm – for example, you could physically stop someone crossing the road if they were walking into traffic

【70】Advice for attorneys: property and financial affairs
----------------------------------------------------

【71】If you have lasting power of attorney over property and financial affairs, you're allowed to make decisions on the donor's behalf.

【72】These include:

【73】*   writing cheques and paying bills
*   selling or renting property
*   carrying out their trade or business
*   honouring any contractual obligations
*   conducting legal proceedings on their behalf

【74】You're also allowed to make gifts on behalf of the donor in certain circumstances.

【75】For example:

【76】*   on occasions such as birthdays or marriages to those related to or connected with the donor
*   to a charity the donor has supported in the past

【77】Acting as an attorney means you should maintain a duty of care to the donor, not to benefit yourself. It's important to avoid any potential conflicts of interest.

【78】Specifically, you must keep the donor's money and property separate from your own, and keep accurate accounts in all of your dealings as an attorney.

【79】Find out more about power of attorney on GOV.UK

【80】More in Making decisions for someone else
-----------------------------------------

【81】*   Mental Capacity Act
*   Giving someone power of attorney

【82】Page last reviewed: 15 April 2021  
Next review due: 15 April 2024

source_info.title: Domperidone
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking domperidone \- Brand name: Motilium
=======================================================================================

【1】Domperidone and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Domperidone can be taken in pregnancy if other anti-sickness medicines have not worked.

【3】Domperidone and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【4】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take domperidone while breastfeeding but it's best to only take it for a short time.

【5】There is not much information about how much domperidone passes into breast milk, but it's only a tiny amount. It's been used during breastfeeding for many years without babies having side effects.

【6】Domperidone can also be used to help increase your breast milk supply. Although it's not made for this purpose, a specialist may offer this to you, if other things have not worked.

【7】If you notice your baby has diarrhoea, or you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to a midwife, health visitor, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【8】Domperidone and fertility
-------------------------

【9】There's no evidence to suggest that taking domperidone affects fertility in either men or women.

【10】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【11】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【12】Find out how anti-sickness medicines such as domperidone can affect you and your baby on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.

【13】More in Domperidone
-------------------

【14】*   About domperidone
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【15】Page last reviewed: 6 April 2023  
Next review due: 6 April 2026

source_info.title: Co-amoxiclav
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking co-amoxiclav \- Brand name: Augmentin
=========================================================================================

【1】Co-amoxiclav and pregnancy
--------------------------

【2】Co-amoxiclav can be taken during pregnancy, although it is not recommended in certain circumstances (for example if your waters break early).

【3】Check with your doctor, midwife or pharmacist to make sure that co-amoxiclav is suitable for you.

【4】Co-amoxiclav and breastfeeding
------------------------------

【5】It's OK to take co-amoxiclav while breastfeeding.

【6】Co-amoxiclav passes into breast milk in tiny amounts and is very unlikely to cause side effects in your baby. However, mild side effects have been reported in a small number of babies.

【7】If your baby is not feeding as well as usual, is being sick or has diarrhoea, has oral thrush (mouth thrush), a skin rash, or seems restless, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife.

【8】Co-amoxiclav and fertility
--------------------------

【9】There's no evidence to suggest that taking co-amoxiclav will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【10】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【11】*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【12】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how penicillin antibiotics such as co-amoxiclav can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>

【13】More in Co-amoxiclav
--------------------

【14】*   About co-amoxiclav
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【15】Page last reviewed: 21 September 2022  
Next review due: 21 September 2025

source_info.title: Hydroxychloroquine
source_info.text:
【0】Taking hydroxychloroquine with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Quinoric
=============================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Hydroxychloroquine can affect the way some medicines work. Other medicines can also affect the way hydroxychloroquine works or increase the chance of you getting side effects.

【3】If you take antacids, leave a gap of at least 4 hours between taking them and hydroxychloroquine.

【4】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including:

【5】*   azithromycin, erythromycin or clarithromycin, antibiotics
*   amiodarone or digoxin, medicines for heart problems
*   medicines for epilepsy
*   medicines for diabetes, such as insulin or metformin
*   cimetidine, a medicine for stomach ulcers

【6】Mixing hydroxychloroquine with herbal remedies and supplements
--------------------------------------------------------------

【7】There's not enough information to say that herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with hydroxychloroquine. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【10】More in Hydroxychloroquine
--------------------------

【11】*   About hydroxychloroquine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking hydroxychloroquine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【12】Page last reviewed: 8 June 2022  
Next review due: 8 June 2025

Next review due: 8 June 2025
text.content:
【0】Taking hydroxychloroquine with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Quinoric
=============================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Hydroxychloroquine can affect the way some medicines work. Other medicines can also affect the way hydroxychloroquine works or increase the chance of you getting side effects.

【3】If you take antacids, leave a gap of at least 4 hours between taking them and hydroxychloroquine.

【4】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including:

【5】*   azithromycin, erythromycin or clarithromycin, antibiotics
*   amiodarone or digoxin, medicines for heart problems
*   medicines for epilepsy
*   medicines for diabetes, such as insulin or metformin
*   cimetidine, a medicine for stomach ulcers

【6】Mixing hydroxychloroquine with herbal remedies and supplements
--------------------------------------------------------------

【7】There's not enough information to say that herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with hydroxychloroquine. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【10】More in Hydroxychloroquine
--------------------------

【11】*   About hydroxychloroquine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking hydroxychloroquine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Frostbite
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Frostbite
=====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment

【3】**Frostbite is damage to skin and tissue caused by exposure to freezing temperatures – typically any temperature below -0.55C (31F).**

【4】Frostbite can affect any part of your body, but the extremities, such as the hands, feet, ears, nose and lips, are most likely to be affected.

【5】The symptoms of frostbite usually begin with the affected parts feeling cold and painful.

【6】If exposure to the cold continues, you may feel pins and needles before the area becomes numb as the tissues freeze.

【7】When to get medical attention
-----------------------------

【8】If you think you or someone else may have frostbite, call your GP or NHS 111 for advice.

【9】If the symptoms are more severe or there are signs of hypothermia, such as constant shivering or fast breathing (hyperventilation), go immediately to your nearest A&E.

【10】A doctor will examine the affected area, check your vital signs, and ask how you got frostbite.

【11】You may need a follow-up appointment or referral to a specialist, as the full extent of a frostbite injury often isn't apparent until a few days later.

【12】Treating frostbite
------------------

【13】A person with frostbite should be taken to a warm environment as soon as possible. This is to limit the effects of the injury and because it's also likely they'll have hypothermia. Don't put pressure on the affected area.

【14】The frostbitten area should be warmed up by a healthcare professional. This is usually done by immersing the affected area in warm – but not hot – water. 

【15】A bath of water at 37C to 39C (98.6F to 102.2F) is recommended for rewarming. The rewarming process is often painful, and regular strong painkillers may be needed.

【16】It's important not to rewarm the affected area if there's a chance of it freezing again, as this can lead to further tissue damage.

【17】If frostbite is severe, the loss of blood supply to the tissue may cause it to die (gangrene). A type of surgery called debridement may be needed to remove the dead tissue. Amputation may be needed if frostbite is severe.

【18】Read more about treating frostbite.

【19】What causes frostbite?
----------------------

【20】The body responds to cold temperatures by narrowing the blood vessels. Blood flow to the extremities slows down so flow to the vital organs can be increased.

【21】As the blood is redirected away from the extremities, these parts of the body get colder, and fluid in the tissue can freeze into ice crystals.

【22】The ice crystals can cause severe cell and tissue damage in the affected area. The low blood flow also deprives the tissues of oxygen. If blood flow can't be restored, the tissue will eventually die.

【23】### At-risk groups

【24】Certain groups of people are at greater risk of getting frostbite.

【25】They include:

【26】*   people who take part in winter and high-altitude sports, such as mountaineers and skiers
*   anyone stranded in extreme cold weather conditions
*   anyone who works outdoors in harsh conditions for long periods of time, such as soldiers, sailors and rescue workers
*   homeless people
*   the very young and very old, as their bodies are less able to regulate body temperature
*   people with conditions that cause blood vessel damage or circulation problems, such as diabetes and Raynaud's phenomenon
*   anyone taking medicine that constricts the blood vessels, including beta blockers – smoking can also constrict the blood vessels

【27】People who've taken drugs or drunk alcohol are also vulnerable to frostbite. Taking drugs or being drunk can lead to risky behaviour, not responding normally to cold, or falling asleep outside in cold weather.

【28】As you'd expect, cases of frostbite in England often rise during particularly cold winters. For example, during the very cold winter of 2010-11, there were 111 hospital admissions for frostbite. In most years, there are around 30 to 60 cases every winter.

【29】Preventing frostbite
--------------------

【30】Most of the time frostbite can be prevented by taking precautions during cold weather.

【31】Avoid unnecessary exposure to cold temperatures. The combination of wind and cold temperatures (wind chill) can also cause a rapid drop in temperature, so avoid going out when it's cold and windy, if possible. 

【32】It's also important to know what the early symptoms of frostbite are, particularly the tingling sensation of frostnip.

【33】Wear appropriate clothing that protects your extremities, such as:

【34】*   well-insulated boots and a thick pair of well-fitting socks
*   mittens – they provide better protection against very cold weather than gloves
*   a warm, weatherproof hat that covers your ears – it's important to protect your head from the cold
*   multiple thin layers of warm, loose-fitting clothing – these act as insulation

【35】You should also try to keep dry and remove any wet clothing as soon as you can. 

【36】If you're travelling during cold weather, plan for emergencies. For example, if you're driving in icy conditions, make sure you keep a warm blanket and some spare clothes in the boot of your car in case you break down. 

【37】If you're travelling by foot, always let others know where you're going and what time you'll be back. Take a fully charged mobile phone with you so you can call for help if you have an accident, such as a fall.

【38】Be careful when drinking alcohol during very cold weather. Drinking too much increases your risk of falling asleep in the cold, a common cause of frostbite. Alcohol also causes you to lose heat at a faster rate.

【39】Smoking also makes you more vulnerable to the effects of the cold because nicotine can narrow your blood vessels.

【40】Complications of frostbite
--------------------------

【41】If some of your tissue dies, the dead tissue will no longer have a blood supply. This can make the affected body part very vulnerable to infection because your body relies on white blood cells to ward off infections.

【42】People with frostbite are at risk of bacterial wound infections, such as tetanus. More seriously, this infection can spread into the blood (sepsis), which requires treatment with antibiotics. Both conditions require hospital admission. 

【43】Read more about treating tetanus and treating sepsis.

【44】### Hypothermia

【45】Severe frostbite is often associated with hypothermia, which is a dangerous drop in body temperature below 35C (95F).

【46】Initial symptoms can include:

【47】*   constant shivering
*   tiredness
*   low energy
*   cold or pale skin
*   fast breathing (hyperventilation)

【48】Someone with severe hypothermia may be unconscious and have shallow breathing and a weak pulse. 

【49】Read more about how hypothermia is treated.

【50】Help us improve our website
---------------------------

【51】Can you answer some questions about your visit today?

【52】Take our survey

【53】Page last reviewed: 24 August 2021  
Next review due: 24 August 2024

【54】*   Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: Colecalciferol
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take colecalciferol \- Brand names: Lamberts, Hux D3, Solgar, SunVit D3
=======================================================================================

【1】Colecalciferol comes in different strengths.

【2】A loading dose is a high strength course of vitamin D treatment that is usually taken for a short time (usually, a few weeks). It is prescribed to raise low levels of vitamin D quickly.

【3】Lower doses of colecalciferol are usually taken to maintain your vitamin D levels or prevent you from getting vitamin D deficiency.

【4】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【5】Colecalciferol doses are measured in international units (IU). 1 microgram of vitamin D is the same as 40IU.

【6】### Adult loading doses

【7】If you have severe vitamin D deficiency, your doctor may prescribe a loading dose of up to 300,000IU. This can be taken as:

【8】*   50,000IU once a week for 6 weeks
*   40,000IU once a week for 7 weeks
*   1,000IU four times a day for 10 weeks
*   800IU five times a day for 10 weeks

【9】### Maintenance dose

【10】If you've had a loading dose but need to maintain your vitamin D levels, your doctor may prescribe a maintenance dose of 800IU to 2,000IU a day.

【11】### Lower colecalciferol doses

【12】Colecalciferol is also available in lower doses. You can take 400IU a day if you're an adult maintaining your vitamin D levels.

【13】### Doses for children

【14】Your child's dose will depend on their age and how severe their vitamin D deficiency is.

【15】The usual loading dose for children is:

【16】*   age 1 to 5 months – 3,000IU daily for 8 to 12 weeks
*   age 6 months to 11 years – 6,000IU daily for 8 to 12 weeks
*   age 12 to 17 years – 10,000IU daily for 8 to 12 weeks

【17】#### Maintenance dose for children

【18】Your child's doctor may recommend changes to your child's diet to improve their vitamin D levels. If changes to their diet still do not provide enough vitamin D then the doctor may prescribe a maintenance dose of 400IU to 600IU for them to take daily long term.

【19】#### Prevention doses for children

【20】To help your child grow healthy bones and prevent rickets, you can give them:

【21】*   340IU to 400IU a day – from birth to 1 year
*   400IU a day – from 1 year to 4 years

【22】How to take it
--------------

【23】If you're unsure how to take colecalciferol, ask your doctor or your pharmacist. Take your medicine exactly as they advise you to.

【24】### Capsules and tablets

【25】If you're taking colecalciferol capsules or tablets, swallow them whole with some water. Take them with your main meal of the day.

【26】### Chewable tablets

【27】If you're taking chewable tablets, chew them. Do not swallow them whole.

【28】### Syrup (oral solution)

【29】Your colecalciferol liquid should come with a plastic syringe. If you do not have one, ask your pharmacist for one.

【30】Follow the instructions included with your medicine about how to take the syrup with a syringe.

【31】1.  Measure the amount prescribed by your doctor into the syringe.
2.  Squirt the medicine straight into your mouth until the syringe is empty.
3.  Wash the syringe and allow to dry.

【32】### Colecalciferol oral drops

【33】If you're using colecalciferol drops, you can either drop them straight into your mouth or onto a spoon before you take it.

【34】### Colecalciferol dissolvable tablets

【35】Drop 1 tablet into a glass of water and as soon as it dissolves drink straight away. Do not chew or swallow the tablets whole.

【36】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【37】For adults, if you're taking a loading dose for severe vitamin D deficiency you'll usually take it daily or weekly for 6 to 10 weeks.

【38】To maintain your vitamin D levels or prevent deficiency you'll usually take colecalciferol long term.

【39】Children with severe vitamin D deficiency usually take a loading dose for 8 to 12 weeks. They may then take a lower, maintenance dose of vitamin D long term.

【40】If you or your child's vitamin D levels are OK, your doctor may recommend safely increasing your exposure to sunlight and adding more foods that are high in vitamin D to your diet.

【41】If you stop taking colecalciferol, your symptoms may come back and your bone health may be affected. Stopping colecalciferol could cause the calcium levels in your body to fall. This can cause problems like bone pain or muscle weakness.

【42】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【43】If you forget to take your daily or weekly dose of colecalciferol, take it as soon as you remember, unless it's nearly time for your next dose. In this case, leave out the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【44】Never take 2 doses at the same time and do not take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【45】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm or make a note in your diary to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【46】If you take too much
--------------------

【47】Unless you're taking a loading dose of vitamin D, as prescribed by your doctor, taking an extra dose is unlikely to harm you.

【48】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【49】*   you have taken more than 4,000IU of colecalciferol in 1 day
*   your child is between 1 and 10 years of age and has had more than 2,000IU in 1 day
*   your child is under 12 months and has had more than 1,000IU in 1 day

【50】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111. Call 111 if you are asking about a child under the age of 5 years.

【51】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【52】Take the colecalciferol packet, or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine with you.

【53】If you have taken too much colecalciferol, tell your doctor or contact 111 straight away if you (or your child):

【54】*   feel weak or have pain in your muscles or bones
*   need to pee more often
*   feel thirsty
*   feel tired
*   are sick (vomit) or feel sick
*   have constipation, or lose your appetite
*   are sweating a lot
*   have headaches
*   feel confused
*   feel drowsy
*   feel pain in the abdomen – this could be a sign of kidney stones

【55】More in Colecalciferol
----------------------

【56】*   About colecalciferol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【57】Page last reviewed: 10 January 2023  
Next review due: 10 January 2026

source_info.title: Behçet's disease
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Behçet's disease
============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment

【3】**Behçet's disease can cause a wide range of symptoms, but it's rare for someone with the condition to have all of them at once.**

【4】Most people experience times when the symptoms improve (remission) and times when they get worse (flare-ups or relapses).

【5】Mouth ulcers
------------

【6】Almost everyone with Behçet's disease develops mouth ulcers. The ulcers may look the same as normal mouth ulcers, but can be more numerous and painful. They most often develop on the tongue, lips, gums and the insides of the cheeks.

【7】The ulcers usually heal within a couple of weeks without leaving any scarring, although they'll often return.

【8】Genital ulcers
--------------

【9】Like mouth ulcers, recurrent genital ulcers are also a common symptom of Behçet's disease.

【10】In men, the ulcers usually appear on the scrotum. In women, they usually appear on the cervix (neck of the womb), vulva or vagina. However, genital ulcers can appear anywhere in the groin area, including on the penis, but this is rare.

【11】The genital ulcers are usually painful and may leave scarring. Men may also experience inflammation (swelling) of the testicles and women may find the ulcers make having sex painful.

【12】Genital ulcers caused by Behçet's disease are not contagious and cannot be spread through sexual intercourse.

【13】Skin lesions
------------

【14】Many people with Behçet's disease also develop skin lesions. A lesion is any type of unusual growth or abnormality that develops on your skin, such as a bump or a discoloured area of skin.

【15】Skin lesions that can occur in Behçet's disease include red, tender swellings on the legs called erythema nodosum and more widespread acne\-like spots called pseudofolliculitis.

【16】Skin lesions often heal within 14 days, although they may come back frequently. Erythema nodosum lesions may leave permanently discoloured areas of skin.

【17】Behçet's disease may also cause another skin condition called superficial thrombophlebitis. which causes tender red lumps that appear in a line.

【18】Inflammation of the joints
--------------------------

【19】Behçet's disease affects the joints in around 1 in 2 people with the condition, causing arthritis\-like symptoms such as pain, stiffness, swelling, warmth and tenderness.

【20】The joints most often affected include the knees, ankles, wrists and small joints in the hands.

【21】Unlike some conditions affecting the joints, permanent joint damage is rare in Behçet's disease and symptoms can usually be controlled successfully.

【22】Inflammation of the eyes
------------------------

【23】Inflammation of the eyes is another common symptom of Behçet's disease, occurring in around 7 out of 10 cases. It often develops very suddenly.

【24】Inflammation often affects the uveal tract, which is a group of connected structures inside the eye. Sometimes both eyes may be affected at the same time.

【25】Inflammation of the uveal tract is known as uveitis and it can cause symptoms that include:

【26】*   painful red eyes
*   sensitivity to light
*   floaters (dots that move across the field of vision)
*   blurred vision
*   sudden loss of vision

【27】Call 999 or go to A&E if you have sudden blurred vision or sudden loss of vision.

【28】In the most severe cases of Behçet's disease, inflammation of the eyes can lead to permanent loss of vision. However, this is far less likely with early and appropriate treatment.

【29】Sensitive skin
--------------

【30】In some people with Behçet's disease, the skin is particularly sensitive to injury or irritation. This is known as pathergy.

【31】For example, if a needle is used to prick the skin of someone who has pathergy, a large red bump may develop within 1 to 2 days that appears out of proportion to the original needle prick.

【32】Not everyone with Behçet's disease has pathergy, so this reaction alone cannot diagnose the condition.

【33】Gastrointestinal symptoms
-------------------------

【34】Behçet's disease can cause inflammation of the stomach and bowel, which can lead to symptoms such as:

【35】*   feeling and being sick
*   tummy pain
*   indigestion
*   loss of appetite
*   diarrhoea with bleeding

【36】Occasionally, the inflammation can cause the bowel to become damaged and bleed. Having blood in your poo is a possible symptom of inflammation of the internal lining of the bowel.

【37】Blood clots
-----------

【38】The inflammation of the lining of the blood vessels associated with Behçet's disease can sometimes cause blood clots to form.

【39】One of the most common types of blood clot to affect people with Behçet's disease is deep vein thrombosis (DVT), where a blood clot develops in 1 of the deep veins of the body, usually in the legs.

【40】Symptoms of DVT include:

【41】*   pain, swelling and tenderness in one of your legs (usually in the calf)
*   a heavy ache in the affected area
*   warm skin in the area of the clot
*   redness of your skin, particularly at the back of your leg below the knee

【42】DVT requires immediate medical treatment. If you suspect DVT,  go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department immediately.

【43】In people with Behçet's disease, careful assessment is needed to determine if it's safe to use blood thinning treatment for this complication. Treatment to control inflammation is usually more effective.

【44】### Cerebral venous thrombosis

【45】A less common type of blood clot associated with Behçet's disease is cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT). This occurs when a blood clot develops inside the blood vessels that run through channels located between the outer and inner layer of your brain.

【46】The blood clot can increase the pressure inside your skull and also lead to an interruption of the blood supply to the brain (stroke).

【47】Symptoms of a CVT include:

【48】*   a severe headache – this has been described as a throbbing, piercing, band of pain, or as a very severe pain that suddenly appears out of nowhere
*   slurred speech
*   seizures (fits)
*   hearing loss
*   double vision
*   stroke-like symptoms, such as muscle weakness or paralysis – but, unlike most strokes, both sides of the body can be affected

【49】CVT is as a medical emergency. If you suspect a CVT, dial 999 immediately to request an ambulance.

【50】Aneurysms
---------

【51】Inflammation of the blood vessels can cause the walls of your blood vessels to weaken. This causes the walls to bulge outwards as a result of blood pressure. The bulge is known as an aneurysm.

【52】Aneurysms do not usually cause any noticeable symptoms unless the wall of the blood vessel becomes so weak that it enlarges or ruptures. This can place pressure on nearby areas and can sometimes lead to internal bleeding or organ dysfunction.

【53】The symptoms of a ruptured aneurysm can vary depending on where in the body the aneurysm developed. Possible symptoms include:

【54】*   sudden severe pain in the body, such as the limb, chest, back, or tummy
*   a sudden agonising headache
*   dizziness
*   breathlessness
*   coughing up blood
*   confusion
*   loss of consciousness

【55】Call 999 if you or someone else suddenly gets these symptoms.

【56】Inflammation of the nervous system
----------------------------------

【57】Inflammation of the central nervous system (CNS) causes the most serious symptoms associated with Behçet's disease.

【58】The symptoms of CNS inflammation usually develop quickly over the space of a few days, and can include:

【59】*   headache
*   double vision
*   loss of balance
*   seizures (fits)
*   partial paralysis on 1 side of the body
*   behavioural or personality changes

【60】Call 999 or go to A&E if you or someone else suddenly develops these symptoms.

【61】General symptoms
----------------

【62】It's also common for people with Behçet's disease to experience more general symptoms as a result of the condition, including periods of extreme physical or mental tiredness (fatigue). This can affect a person's ability to perform any sort of activity.

【63】Page last reviewed: 06 April 2023  
Next review due: 06 April 2026

【64】*   Previous : Behçet's disease
*   Next : Treatment

source_info.title: Hip replacement
source_info.text:
【0】Metal implant advice \- Hip replacement
=======================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  How it is performed
3.  Risks
4.  Recovery
5.  Metal implant advice

【3】**Patients with a common type of metal hip implant should have regular annual health checks.**

【4】Most people who have a metal-on-metal (MoM) implant have well-functioning hips and are thought to be at low risk of developing any serious problems.

【5】But compared with other hip replacements, some metal-on-metal hip devices have been found to wear down more quickly in some patients.

【6】This potentially causes damage and deterioration in the bone and tissue around the hip, which medical checks will monitor.

【7】In 2017, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) published updated guidelines on monitoring patients with all types of metal-on-metal hip implants.

【8】Check-ups are a precautionary measure to reduce the small risk of complications and monitor patients who have had the devices implanted for a long time.

【9】What should I do if I have this type of hip implant?
----------------------------------------------------

【10】Metal-on-metal (MoM) implants have only been used in a minority of all hip replacement surgeries. They are done on very few people now, so this may not affect you.

【11】If you're not sure what type of implant you have or you have any concerns about your hip, you can consult your doctor for advice.

【12】If you do have a metal-on-metal implant, make sure you attend any follow-up appointments you're invited to.

【13】You should also be aware of the warning signs that could show there's a problem.

【14】What are the warning signs?
---------------------------

【15】You should contact your doctor if you have:

【16】*   pain in your groin, hip or leg
*   swelling at or near your hip joint
*   a limp or problems walking
*   grinding or clunking from the joint

【17】These symptoms do not necessarily mean your device is failing, but they do need to be investigated.

【18】Any changes in your general health should also be reported, including:

【19】*   chest pain or shortness of breath
*   numbness or weakness
*   changes in vision or hearing
*   fatigue
*   feeling cold
*   weight gain

【20】What are metal-on-metal implants?
---------------------------------

【21】As the name implies, metal-on-metal implants are a joint made of two metal surfaces:

【22】*   a metal "ball" that replaces the ball at the top of the thigh bone (femur)
*   a metal "cup" that acts like the socket in the pelvis

【23】What does monitoring involve?
-----------------------------

【24】Patients who have metal-on-metal implants should be monitored regularly for the life of the implant and have tests to measure levels of metal particles (ions) in their blood.

【25】Patients with these types of implant who have symptoms may be investigated with MRI or ultrasound scans, and patients without symptoms should have a scan if the level of metal ions in their blood is rising.

【26】What is the problem with metal-on-metal implants?
-------------------------------------------------

【27】### Wear and tear

【28】All hip implants wear down over time as the ball and cup slide against each other during movements, including walking and running.

【29】Although many people live the rest of their lives without needing a replacement implant, some people may eventually need surgery to remove or replace its components.

【30】Evidence suggests that certain types of metal-on-metal implant wear down at a faster rate than other types.

【31】As friction acts upon their surfaces, it can cause tiny metal particles to break off and enter the space around the implant.

【32】People are thought to react differently to the presence of these metal particles, but they can trigger inflammation and discomfort in the area around the implant in some people.

【33】If not caught early, this can cause damage and deterioration in the bone and tissue surrounding the implant and joint over time. This in turn may cause the implant to become loose and cause painful symptoms, meaning further surgery is required.

【34】The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) guidance is designed to detect and treat any complications like this.

【35】### Metal ions in the blood

【36】Some news coverage has focused on the MHRA's recommendation to check for the presence of metal ions in the blood.

【37】Ions are electrically charged molecules. Levels of ions in the blood, particularly of cobalt and chromium used in the surface of the implants, may therefore indicate how much wear there is to the artificial hip.

【38】These ions in the blood are not blood poisoning and do not lead to sepsis, which is an entirely different type of illness. Talk of this in some news reports is very misleading and completely wrong.

【39】There has been no definitive link between ions from metal-on-metal implants and illness, although there has been a small number of cases in which high levels of metal ions in the blood have been associated with symptoms or illnesses elsewhere in the body, including effects on the heart, nervous system and thyroid gland.

【40】How many people are affected?
-----------------------------

【41】Approximately 71,000 UK patients have had a metal-on-metal hip device implanted or had metal-on-metal resurfacing.

【42】The majority of these patients have well-functioning hips and a low risk of complications.

【43】Because of the problems with this type of implant, they are rarely used now.

【44】How are medical devices regulated?
----------------------------------

【45】In the UK, the MHRA is the government agency responsible for ensuring medical devices work and are safe. MHRA audits the performance of private sector organisations that assess and approve medical devices.

【46】Once a product is on the market and in use, MHRA has a system for receiving reports of problems with these products and will issue warnings if these problems are confirmed through its investigations.

【47】It also inspects companies that manufacture products to ensure they comply with regulations.

【48】Further information
-------------------

【49】National Joint Registry: metal-on-metal hip implants

【50】Page last reviewed: 23 December 2019  
Next review due: 23 December 2022

【51】*   Previous : Recovery
