【4】Most people who have a metal-on-metal (MoM) implant have well-functioning hips and are thought to be at low risk of developing any serious problems.

【5】But compared with other hip replacements, some metal-on-metal hip devices have been found to wear down more quickly in some patients.

【6】This potentially causes damage and deterioration in the bone and tissue around the hip, which medical checks will monitor.

【7】In 2017, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) published updated guidelines on monitoring patients with all types of metal-on-metal hip implants.

【8】Check-ups are a precautionary measure to reduce the small risk of complications and monitor patients who have had the devices implanted for a long time.

【9】What should I do if I have this type of hip implant?
----------------------------------------------------

【10】Metal-on-metal (MoM) implants have only been used in a minority of all hip replacement surgeries. They are done on very few people now, so this may not affect you.

【11】If you're not sure what type of implant you have or you have any concerns about your hip, you can consult your doctor for advice.

【12】If you do have a metal-on-metal implant, make sure you attend any follow-up appointments you're invited to.

【13】You should also be aware of the warning signs that could show there's a problem.

【14】What are the warning signs?
---------------------------

【15】You should contact your doctor if you have:

【16】*   pain in your groin, hip or leg
*   swelling at or near your hip joint
*   a limp or problems walking
*   grinding or clunking from the joint

【17】These symptoms do not necessarily mean your device is failing, but they do need to be investigated.

【18】Any changes in your general health should also be reported, including:

【19】*   chest pain or shortness of breath
*   numbness or weakness
*   changes in vision or hearing
*   fatigue
*   feeling cold
*   weight gain

【20】What are metal-on-metal implants?
---------------------------------

【21】As the name implies, metal-on-metal implants are a joint made of two metal surfaces:

【22】*   a metal "ball" that replaces the ball at the top of the thigh bone (femur)
*   a metal "cup" that acts like the socket in the pelvis

【23】What does monitoring involve?
-----------------------------

【24】Patients who have metal-on-metal implants should be monitored regularly for the life of the implant and have tests to measure levels of metal particles (ions) in their blood.

【25】Patients with these types of implant who have symptoms may be investigated with MRI or ultrasound scans, and patients without symptoms should have a scan if the level of metal ions in their blood is rising.

【26】What is the problem with metal-on-metal implants?
-------------------------------------------------

【27】### Wear and tear

【28】All hip implants wear down over time as the ball and cup slide against each other during movements, including walking and running.

【29】Although many people live the rest of their lives without needing a replacement implant, some people may eventually need surgery to remove or replace its components.

【30】Evidence suggests that certain types of metal-on-metal implant wear down at a faster rate than other types.

【31】As friction acts upon their surfaces, it can cause tiny metal particles to break off and enter the space around the implant.

【32】People are thought to react differently to the presence of these metal particles, but they can trigger inflammation and discomfort in the area around the implant in some people.

【33】If not caught early, this can cause damage and deterioration in the bone and tissue surrounding the implant and joint over time. This in turn may cause the implant to become loose and cause painful symptoms, meaning further surgery is required.

【34】The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) guidance is designed to detect and treat any complications like this.

【35】### Metal ions in the blood

【36】Some news coverage has focused on the MHRA's recommendation to check for the presence of metal ions in the blood.

【37】Ions are electrically charged molecules. Levels of ions in the blood, particularly of cobalt and chromium used in the surface of the implants, may therefore indicate how much wear there is to the artificial hip.

【38】These ions in the blood are not blood poisoning and do not lead to sepsis, which is an entirely different type of illness. Talk of this in some news reports is very misleading and completely wrong.

【39】There has been no definitive link between ions from metal-on-metal implants and illness, although there has been a small number of cases in which high levels of metal ions in the blood have been associated with symptoms or illnesses elsewhere in the body, including effects on the heart, nervous system and thyroid gland.

【40】How many people are affected?
-----------------------------

【41】Approximately 71,000 UK patients have had a metal-on-metal hip device implanted or had metal-on-metal resurfacing.

【42】The majority of these patients have well-functioning hips and a low risk of complications.

【43】Because of the problems with this type of implant, they are rarely used now.

【44】How are medical devices regulated?
----------------------------------

【45】In the UK, the MHRA is the government agency responsible for ensuring medical devices work and are safe. MHRA audits the performance of private sector organisations that assess and approve medical devices.

【46】Once a product is on the market and in use, MHRA has a system for receiving reports of problems with these products and will issue warnings if these problems are confirmed through its investigations.

【47】It also inspects companies that manufacture products to ensure they comply with regulations.

【48】Further information
-------------------

【49】National Joint Registry: metal-on-metal hip implants

【50】Page last reviewed: 23 December 2019  
Next review due: 23 December 2022

【51】*   Previous : Recovery

source_info.title: Perindopril
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking perindopril
===============================================================

【1】Perindopril and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Perindopril is not recommended in pregnancy. It can affect your baby's kidneys, particularly if it's taken in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. This can result in long term damage to your baby's kidneys.

【3】If you're already pregnant, stop taking perindopril and talk to your doctor straight away. Usually your doctor will be able to prescribe a different medicine that is safe to take in pregnancy. Perindopril should be stopped by the time you're 12 weeks pregnant at the latest.

【4】Use contraception if you're taking perindopril and carefully plan any pregnancy with your doctor, pregnancy specialist (obstetrician) or hospital doctor. They will want to review your medical condition and medicine before you get pregnant.

【5】Most women come off perindopril before getting pregnant, but some may continue up until they have a positive pregnancy test and then stop. Your doctor will discuss what's best for you, based on your medical condition and the risks and benefits of perindopril.

【6】Perindopril and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【7】It might be OK to take perindopril while breastfeeding, but talk to your doctor or pharmacist first. It is best not to take perindopril if your baby was born prematurely, but your doctor will help you decide.

【8】Only small amounts of perindopril pass into breast milk, which is unlikely to cause side effects in your baby. However, there is a very small risk that it could also lower your baby's blood pressure. Your doctor might recommend a different medicine for you to take while breastfeeding.

【9】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, seems unusually sleepy, seems much paler than usual, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your health visitor, midwife or doctor as soon as possible.

【10】Perindopril and fertility
-------------------------

【11】There's no clear evidence to suggest that taking perindopril reduces fertility in either men or women.

【12】But if you're trying to get pregnant, talk to your doctor as this medicine is not recommended in pregnancy.

【13】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【14】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【15】More in Perindopril
-------------------

【16】*   About perindopril
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking perindopril with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【17】Page last reviewed: 8 December 2021  
Next review due: 8 December 2024

source_info.title: Spina bifida
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Spina bifida
========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment

【3】**Spina bifida is when a baby's spine and spinal cord does not develop properly in the womb, causing a gap in the spine.**

【4】Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect. The neural tube is the structure that eventually develops into the baby's brain and spinal cord.

【5】The neural tube starts to form in early pregnancy and closes about 4 weeks after conception.

【6】In spina bifida, part of the neural tube does not develop or close properly, leading to defects in the spinal cord and bones of the spine (vertebrae).

【7】It's not known what causes spina bifida, but a lack of folic acid before and in the early stages of pregnancy is a significant risk factor.

【8】Types of spina bifida
---------------------

【9】There are several different types of spina bifida, including:

【10】*   myelomeningocele – the most severe type of spina bifida; the baby's spinal canal remains open along several vertebrae in the back, allowing the spinal cord and protective membranes around it to push out and form a sac in the baby's back
*   meningocele – another serious type of spina bifida where the protective membranes around the spinal cord (meninges) push out through the spine; the spinal cord usually develops normally so surgery can often be used to remove the membranes without damaging the nerves
*   spina bifida occulta – the most common and mildest type of spina bifida; 1 or more vertebrae does not form properly, but the gap in the spine is very small; spina bifida occulta does not usually cause any problems and most people are unaware they have it

【11】These pages focus on myelomeningocele, the most severe type of spina bifida, and this is the type usually referred to whenever the term spina bifida is used.

【12】Shine is a charity that provides help and support for people affected by spina bifida. 

【13】Their website has more information about the other types of spina bifida.

【14】Symptoms of spina bifida
------------------------

【15】Most people with spina bifida are able to have surgery to close the opening in the spine.

【16】But the nervous system will usually already have been damaged, which can lead to problems such as:

【17】*   weakness or total paralysis of the legs
*   bowel incontinence and urinary incontinence
*   loss of skin sensation in the legs and around the bottom – the child is unable to feel hot or cold, which can lead to accidental injury

【18】Many babies will have or develop hydrocephalus (a build-up of fluid on the brain), which can further damage the brain.

【19】Most people with spina bifida have normal intelligence, but some have learning difficulties.

【20】Read more about the symptoms of spina bifida.

【21】Causes of spina bifida
----------------------

【22】The cause of spina bifida is unknown, but a number of factors can increase the risk of a baby developing the condition.

【23】These include: 

【24】*   low folic acid intake during pregnancy
*   having a family history of spina bifida
*   medicines – taking certain medicines such as valproic acid (used to prevent seizures) during pregnancy has been linked to an increased risk of having a baby with spina bifida

【25】Read more about the causes of spina bifida.

【26】Diagnosing spina bifida
-----------------------

【27】Spina bifida is often detected during the mid-pregnancy anomaly scan, which is offered to all pregnant women between 18 and 21 weeks of pregnancy.

【28】If tests confirm that your baby has spina bifida, the implications will be discussed with you.

【29】This will include a discussion about the possible problems associated with the condition, the treatment and support your child may need if you decide to continue with the pregnancy, and what your options are regarding ending the pregnancy, if that's your choice.

【30】### Tests after birth

【31】Once the baby is born, a number of tests may be carried out to find out how bad the condition is and help decide which treatments are likely to be the best option.

【32】Tests may include:

【33】*   monitoring your child's head growth and carrying out a brain scan, using an ultrasound scan, CT scan or MRI scan, to check for hydrocephalus (excess fluid on the brain)
*   ultrasound scans of the bladder and kidneys to check whether your baby stores their pee normally
*   an assessment of your baby's movements to check for paralysis

【34】Surgery to repair the spine will usually be recommended soon after your baby is born.

【35】Treating spina bifida
---------------------

【36】Treatments for the symptoms or conditions associated with spina bifida include:

【37】*   surgery soon after birth to close the opening in the spine and treat hydrocephalus
*   therapies to help make day-to-day life easier and improve independence, such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy
*   assistive devices and mobility equipment, such as a wheelchair, or walking aids
*   treatments for bowel and urinary problems

【38】With the right treatment and support, many children with spina bifida survive well into adulthood.

【39】It can be a challenging condition to live with, but many adults with spina bifida are able to lead independent and fulfilling lives.

【40】Read more about treating spina bifida.

【41】Preventing spina bifida with folic acid
---------------------------------------

【42】The best way to prevent spina bifida is to take folic acid supplements before and during pregnancy.

【43】### Folic acid recommendations

【44】You should take a 400 microgram folic acid tablet every day while you're trying to get pregnant and until you're 12 weeks pregnant.

【45】If you did not take folic acid before you conceived, you should start as soon as you find out you're pregnant.

【46】Folic acid tablets are available from pharmacies and supermarkets, or a GP may be able to prescribe them for you.

【47】You should also try to eat foods that contain folate (the natural form of folic acid), such as broccoli, spinach and chickpeas.

【48】Read more about folic acid, including folic acid supplements and foods containing folate.

【49】### Recommendations for women at higher risk of spina bifida

【50】Women thought to be at higher risk of having a child with spina bifida need to be prescribed a higher (5 milligram) dose of folic acid by a GP.

【51】Women at higher risk include those:

【52】*   with a family history of neural tube defects
*   with a partner with a family history of neural tube defects
*   who have had a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect
*   with diabetes

【53】A GP can advise you further about this.

【54】If you're taking medicine to treat epilepsy, you should ask your GP for advice. You may also need to take a higher dose of folic acid.

【55】Help and support
----------------

【56】If you have a child with spina bifida or you've been diagnosed with the condition yourself, you may find it helpful to speak to other people affected by it.

【57】Shine, the spina bifida and hydrocephalus charity, can provide you with details about local support groups and organisations.

【58】You can find and contact your regional Shine team or read about support for carers on the Shine website.

【59】National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【60】If you or your child has spina bifida, your clinical team will pass information about you or your child on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【61】The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【62】Page last reviewed: 20 April 2020  
Next review due: 20 April 2023

【63】*   Next : Symptoms

【28】If tests confirm that your baby has spina bifida, the implications will be discussed with you.

【29】This will include a discussion about the possible problems associated with the condition, the treatment and support your child may need if you decide to continue with the pregnancy, and what your options are regarding ending the pregnancy, if that's your choice.

【30】### Tests after birth

【31】Once the baby is born, a number of tests may be carried out to find out how bad the condition is and help decide which treatments are likely to be the best option.

【32】Tests may include:

【33】*   monitoring your child's head growth and carrying out a brain scan, using an ultrasound scan, CT scan or MRI scan, to check for hydrocephalus (excess fluid on the brain)
*   ultrasound scans of the bladder and kidneys to check whether your baby stores their pee normally
*   an assessment of your baby's movements to check for paralysis

【34】Surgery to repair the spine will usually be recommended soon after your baby is born.

【35】Treating spina bifida
---------------------

【36】Treatments for the symptoms or conditions associated with spina bifida include:

【37】*   surgery soon after birth to close the opening in the spine and treat hydrocephalus
*   therapies to help make day-to-day life easier and improve independence, such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy
*   assistive devices and mobility equipment, such as a wheelchair, or walking aids
*   treatments for bowel and urinary problems

【38】With the right treatment and support, many children with spina bifida survive well into adulthood.

【39】It can be a challenging condition to live with, but many adults with spina bifida are able to lead independent and fulfilling lives.

【40】Read more about treating spina bifida.

【41】Preventing spina bifida with folic acid
---------------------------------------

【42】The best way to prevent spina bifida is to take folic acid supplements before and during pregnancy.

【43】### Folic acid recommendations

【44】You should take a 400 microgram folic acid tablet every day while you're trying to get pregnant and until you're 12 weeks pregnant.

【45】If you did not take folic acid before you conceived, you should start as soon as you find out you're pregnant.

【46】Folic acid tablets are available from pharmacies and supermarkets, or a GP may be able to prescribe them for you.

【47】You should also try to eat foods that contain folate (the natural form of folic acid), such as broccoli, spinach and chickpeas.

【48】Read more about folic acid, including folic acid supplements and foods containing folate.

【49】### Recommendations for women at higher risk of spina bifida

【50】Women thought to be at higher risk of having a child with spina bifida need to be prescribed a higher (5 milligram) dose of folic acid by a GP.

【51】Women at higher risk include those:

【52】*   with a family history of neural tube defects
*   with a partner with a family history of neural tube defects
*   who have had a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect
*   with diabetes

【53】A GP can advise you further about this.

【54】If you're taking medicine to treat epilepsy, you should ask your GP for advice. You may also need to take a higher dose of folic acid.

【55】Help and support
----------------

【56】If you have a child with spina bifida or you've been diagnosed with the condition yourself, you may find it helpful to speak to other people affected by it.

【57】Shine, the spina bifida and hydrocephalus charity, can provide you with details about local support groups and organisations.

【58】You can find and contact your regional Shine team or read about support for carers on the Shine website.

【59】National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【60】If you or your child has spina bifida, your clinical team will pass information about you or your child on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【61】The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【62】Page last reviewed: 20 April 2020  
Next review due: 20 April 2023

【0】Overview \- Spina bifida
========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment

【3】**Spina bifida is when a baby's spine and spinal cord does not develop properly in the womb, causing a gap in the spine.**

【4】Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect. The neural tube is the structure that eventually develops into the baby's brain and spinal cord.

【5】The neural tube starts to form in early pregnancy and closes about 4 weeks after conception.

【6】In spina bifida, part of the neural tube does not develop or close properly, leading to defects in the spinal cord and bones of the spine (vertebrae).

【7】It's not known what causes spina bifida, but a lack of folic acid before and in the early stages of pregnancy is a significant risk factor.

【8】Types of spina bifida
---------------------

【9】There are several different types of spina bifida, including:

【10】*   myelomeningocele – the most severe type of spina bifida; the baby's spinal canal remains open along several vertebrae in the back, allowing the spinal cord and protective membranes around it to push out and form a sac in the baby's back
*   meningocele – another serious type of spina bifida where the protective membranes around the spinal cord (meninges) push out through the spine; the spinal cord usually develops normally so surgery can often be used to remove the membranes without damaging the nerves
*   spina bifida occulta – the most common and mildest type of spina bifida; 1 or more vertebrae does not form properly, but the gap in the spine is very small; spina bifida occulta does not usually cause any problems and most people are unaware they have it

【11】These pages focus on myelomeningocele, the most severe type of spina bifida, and this is the type usually referred to whenever the term spina bifida is used.

【12】Shine is a charity that provides help and support for people affected by spina bifida. 

【13】Their website has more information about the other types of spina bifida.

【14】Symptoms of spina bifida
------------------------

【15】Most people with spina bifida are able to have surgery to close the opening in the spine.

【16】But the nervous system will usually already have been damaged, which can lead to problems such as:

【17】*   weakness or total paralysis of the legs
*   bowel incontinence and urinary incontinence
*   loss of skin sensation in the legs and around the bottom – the child is unable to feel hot or cold, which can lead to accidental injury

【18】Many babies will have or develop hydrocephalus (a build-up of fluid on the brain), which can further damage the brain.

【19】Most people with spina bifida have normal intelligence, but some have learning difficulties.

<mark>【20】Read more about the symptoms of spina bifida.</mark>

【21】Causes of spina bifida
----------------------

【22】The cause of spina bifida is unknown, but a number of factors can increase the risk of a baby developing the condition.

【23】These include: 

【24】*   low folic acid intake during pregnancy
*   having a family history of spina bifida
*   medicines – taking certain medicines such as valproic acid (used to prevent seizures) during pregnancy has been linked to an increased risk of having a baby with spina bifida

<mark>【25】Read more about the causes of spina bifida.</mark>

-----------------------

【27】Spina bifida is often detected during the mid-pregnancy anomaly scan, which is offered to all pregnant women between 18 and 21 weeks of pregnancy.

【28】If tests confirm that your baby has spina bifida, the implications will be discussed with you.

【29】This will include a discussion about the possible problems associated with the condition, the treatment and support your child may need if you decide to continue with the pregnancy, and what your options are regarding ending the pregnancy, if that's your choice.

【30】### Tests after birth

【31】Once the baby is born, a number of tests may be carried out to find out how bad the condition is and help decide which treatments are likely to be the best option.

【32】Tests may include:

【33】*   monitoring your child's head growth and carrying out a brain scan, using an ultrasound scan, CT scan or MRI scan, to check for hydrocephalus (excess fluid on the brain)
*   ultrasound scans of the bladder and kidneys to check whether your baby stores their pee normally
*   an assessment of your baby's movements to check for paralysis

【34】Surgery to repair the spine will usually be recommended soon after your baby is born.

【35】Treating spina bifida
---------------------

【36】Treatments for the symptoms or conditions associated with spina bifida include:

【37】*   surgery soon after birth to close the opening in the spine and treat hydrocephalus
*   therapies to help make day-to-day life easier and improve independence, such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy
*   assistive devices and mobility equipment, such as a wheelchair, or walking aids
*   treatments for bowel and urinary problems

【38】With the right treatment and support, many children with spina bifida survive well into adulthood.

【39】It can be a challenging condition to live with, but many adults with spina bifida are able to lead independent and fulfilling lives.

【40】Read more about treating spina bifida.

【41】Preventing spina bifida with folic acid
---------------------------------------

【42】The best way to prevent spina bifida is to take folic acid supplements before and during pregnancy.

【43】### Folic acid recommendations

【44】You should take a 400 microgram folic acid tablet every day while you're trying to get pregnant and until you're 12 weeks pregnant.

【45】If you did not take folic acid before you conceived, you should start as soon as you find out you're pregnant.

【46】Folic acid tablets are available from pharmacies and supermarkets, or a GP may be able to prescribe them for you.

【47】You should also try to eat foods that contain folate (the natural form of folic acid), such as broccoli, spinach and chickpeas.

【48】Read more about folic acid, including folic acid supplements and foods containing folate.

【49】### Recommendations for women at higher risk of spina bifida

【50】Women thought to be at higher risk of having a child with spina bifida need to be prescribed a higher (5 milligram) dose of folic acid by a GP.

【51】Women at higher risk include those:

【52】*   with a family history of neural tube defects
*   with a partner with a family history of neural tube defects
*   who have had a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect
*   with diabetes

【53】A GP can advise you further about this.

【54】If you're taking medicine to treat epilepsy, you should ask your GP for advice. You may also need to take a higher dose of folic acid.

【55】Help and support
----------------

【56】If you have a child with spina bifida or you've been diagnosed with the condition yourself, you may find it helpful to speak to other people affected by it.

【57】Shine, the spina bifida and hydrocephalus charity, can provide you with details about local support groups and organisations.

【58】You can find and contact your regional Shine team or read about support for carers on the Shine website.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

source_info.title: Lipoma
source_info.text:
【0】Lipoma
======

【1】**Lipomas are soft, fatty lumps that grow under your skin. They're harmless and do not usually need any treatment, but it's important to get any lumps checked by a GP.**

【2】Check if you have a lipoma
--------------------------

【3】Lipomas are common.

【4】They:

【5】*   feel soft and squishy
*   can be anything from the size of a pea to a few centimetres across
*   may move slightly under your skin if you press them
*   are not usually painful
*   grow slowly
*   can appear anywhere on your body

【6】Lipomas often appear on your shoulders, chest, arms, back, bottom or thighs.

【7】Credit:

【8】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/106645/view

【9】You can also get a lipoma in other places, such as your forehead.

【10】Credit:

【11】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/259388/view

【12】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【13】*   you get a lump anywhere on your body
*   a lump is painful, red or hot to touch
*   a lump is hard and does not move
*   a lump increases in size

【14】A GP will usually be able to tell if the lump is a lipoma.

【15】If there's any doubt, they may refer you for a scan to check it.

【16】In rare cases, lumps under your skin can be a sign of something more serious.

【17】Getting a lipoma removed
------------------------

【18】Lipomas are harmless and do not usually need to be removed. They would only be removed on the NHS if it was growing or causing symptoms because of where it is.

【19】If you have it removed it may be sent to a laboratory to check it is a lipoma.

【20】You can pay to have a lipoma removed at a private clinic, but it may be expensive.

【21】A GP can give you advice about where to get treatment.

【22】Page last reviewed: 25 July 2023  
Next review due: 25 July 2026

text.text:
Credit:

【8】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/106645/view

【9】You can also get a lipoma in other places, such as your forehead.

【10】Credit:

【11】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/259388/view
text.content:
【0】Lipoma
======

【1】**Lipomas are soft, fatty lumps that grow under your skin. They're harmless and do not usually need any treatment, but it's important to get any lumps checked by a GP.**

【2】Check if you have a lipoma
--------------------------

【3】Lipomas are common.

【4】They:

【5】*   feel soft and squishy
*   can be anything from the size of a pea to a few centimetres across
*   may move slightly under your skin if you press them
*   are not usually painful
*   grow slowly
*   can appear anywhere on your body

【6】Lipomas often appear on your shoulders, chest, arms, back, bottom or thighs.

【7】Credit:

【8】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/106645/view

【9】You can also get a lipoma in other places, such as your forehead.

【10】Credit:

【11】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/259388/view

【12】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【13】*   you get a lump anywhere on your body
*   a lump is painful, red or hot to touch
*   a lump is hard and does not move
*   a lump increases in size

【14】A GP will usually be able to tell if the lump is a lipoma.

【15】If there's any doubt, they may refer you for a scan to check it.

【16】In rare cases, lumps under your skin can be a sign of something more serious.

【17】Getting a lipoma removed
------------------------

【18】Lipomas are harmless and do not usually need to be removed. They would only be removed on the NHS if it was growing or causing symptoms because of where it is.

【19】If you have it removed it may be sent to a laboratory to check it is a lipoma.

【20】You can pay to have a lipoma removed at a private clinic, but it may be expensive.

【21】A GP can give you advice about where to get treatment.

【22】Page last reviewed: 25 July 2023  
Next review due: 25 July 2026

source_info.title: Montelukast
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about montelukast \- Brand name: Singulair
===========================================================

【1】How does montelukast work?

【2】Montelukast is from a group of medicines called leukotriene receptor antagonists (LTRAs). LTRAs work by stopping the chemicals in your body that narrow your airways. These chemicals are called leukotrienes.

【3】Montelukast helps stop your airways from narrowing (caused by inflammation). This makes breathing easier and prevents asthma attacks.

【4】Leukotrienes are also released in your body when you have an allergic reaction to something like dust or pollen and when you exercise. Montelukast helps to reduce the level of leukotrienes and stops you getting symptoms.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】Montelukast starts to work immediately and takes about a day to start to help asthma symptoms.

【7】If montelukast has had no effect after you've been taking it for 4 to 8 weeks, see your doctor to talk about other treatment options.

【8】If you're taking montelukast to prevent exercise-induced asthma, take it 2 hours before you exercise. This will mean that the level of medicine in your body is highest when you start exercising.

【9】Are there any long-term side effects?

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that taking montelukast will cause any problems if you take it for a long time.

【11】Are there any other medicines for asthma?

【12】Montelukast is one medicine used to prevent asthma symptoms.

【13】Most people with asthma will be given an inhaler, such as beclometasone or fluticasone. Montelukast may be given as an extra medicine if your doctor thinks you need it.

【14】Other medicines which may help prevent asthma attacks are inhalers like salmeterol or sodium cromoglicate, or medicines like theophylline.

【15】Medicines used to relieve asthma symptoms quickly when they come on include salbutamol or terbutaline inhalers.

【16】Will it affect my contraception?

【17】Montelukast does not affect any type of contraception including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【18】However, if montelukast makes you vomit or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.

【19】Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.

【20】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【21】Montelukast does not usually cause any problems with driving or riding a bike.

【22】However, do not drive a car or ride a bike if montelukast makes you see things which are not there (hallucinate), if you get shaking or tremors in any part of your body or you're unable to concentrate or make decisions.

【23】It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【24】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking montelukast. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【25】Can I drink alcohol while taking montelukast?

【26】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking montelukast.

【27】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【28】You do not need to avoid any food or drink while taking montelukast.

【29】More in Montelukast
-------------------

【30】*   About montelukast
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【31】Page last reviewed: 14 March 2023  
Next review due: 14 March 2026

source_info.title: Venlafaxine
source_info.text:
【0】Taking venlafaxine with other medicines and herbal supplements
==============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines can affect the way venlafaxine works and increase the chances of you having side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking these medicines before you start venlafaxine:

【4】*   any medicines that affect your heartbeat – as venlafaxine can make your heart beat faster or cause an irregular heartbeat
*   any other medicines for depression – some rarely used antidepressants can affect venlafaxine and cause very high blood pressure even if they have not been taken few weeks

【5】Mixing venlafaxine with herbal remedies and supplements
-------------------------------------------------------

【6】Do not take St John's wort, a herbal remedy for depression, while you are being treated with venlafaxine because it increases your risk of side effects.

【7】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with venlafaxine. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【10】More in Venlafaxine
-------------------

【11】*   About venlafaxine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking venlafaxine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【12】Page last reviewed: 10 February 2022  
Next review due: 10 February 2025

source_info.title: Budesonide rectal foam and enemas
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to use budesonide rectal foam and enemas \- Brand names: Budenofalk, Entocort
==========================================================================================

【1】Always use budesonide rectal foam and enemas as a doctor or pharmacist has told you.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】The usual dose of budesonide rectal foam or budesonide enema is 2mg, used once a day for up to 8 weeks.

【4】Budesonide rectal foam
----------------------

【5】Budesonide rectal foam comes in a can with single-use plastic tubes (applicators) that you use to insert the foam.

【6】Each application gives a 2mg dose of budesonide.

【7】Try to use it at about the same time of day, either in the morning or in the evening before bed.

【8】Use the rectal foam after doing a poo. This is because the medicine works best when your bowels are empty.

【9】After you use the foam, try not to poo again for at least a few hours. For the medicine to work properly it needs to stay inside your bowel as long as possible.

【10】### How to use it

【11】1.  Read the instruction leaflet. The pictures show you exactly how to use the foam.
2.  If you're using it for the first time, remove the plastic flap (or safety lock) from underneath the dome-shaped pump at the top of the can.
3.  Wash your hands before and after using the foam.
4.  Push a new applicator onto the nozzle. This nozzle sticks out beneath the dome at the top of the can.
5.  Shake the can for about 15 seconds.
6.  Twist the rounded dome at the bottom.
7.  Put your index finger on top of the dome and turn the can upside down. It's important to keep the can as straight (vertical) as possible.
8.  Stand with one leg raised on a chair – or lie down on your side if you prefer. Gently put the applicator into your bottom as far as possible.
9.  Push the dome down fully once.
10.  Then release the dome slowly. The foam comes out of the spray can when you do this.
11.  Wait 10 to 15 seconds before removing the applicator from your bottom. This is important to make sure you get the full dose and to stop any foam spilling out.
12.  Twist the dome at the base and remove the applicator from the nozzle. This stops any foam coming out when you're not using it. Put the applicator in the plastic bag provided and throw the bag away.

【12】**Budesonide enemas**
---------------------

【13】This medicine comes as liquid and tablets that you mix together. Once made up, it contains a 2mg dose of budesonide.

【14】It's best to use budesonide enemas at night, just before going to bed.

【15】It's best to go to the toilet before using the enema. This is because it's more comfortable if you empty your bowels and bladder before using it.

【16】You may want to sleep on a towel or similar covering. This is to protect your bedding from stains.

【17】### How to use a budesonide enema

【18】You should have 1 bottle of liquid, 1 nozzle and enema tablets.

【19】1.  Check the instruction leaflet first. The pictures show you exactly how to prepare and use the enema.
2.  Take a bottle of the liquid and unscrew the cap.
3.  Remove 1 tablet from the foil strip and drop it into the bottle of liquid.
4.  Replace the cap and screw firmly back onto the bottle.
5.  Shake the bottle well for at least 15 seconds, or until the tablet has dissolved in the liquid.
6.  Remove the cap and screw the nozzle tightly onto the top of the bottle.
7.  The enema is now ready and should be used immediately.
8.  Wash your hands before and after using the enema.
9.  Lie on your side, with your bottom slightly higher than the rest of your body. You can use a pillow to lift your bottom up. You may want to lie on a towel.
10.  Put one of the disposable plastic bags provided over your hand (like a glove) and pick up the bottle.
11.  Shake the bottle and remove only the protective cap that covers the nozzle (do not unscrew the nozzle itself).
12.  Gently push the nozzle into your bottom as far as is comfortable. You can use a lubricant if you find this uncomfortable.
13.  Squeeze the bottle to push the liquid into your bottom. It's normal for some liquid to be left in the bottle afterwards.
14.  Remove the nozzle from your bottom.
15.  Put the bottle into the disposable plastic bag by rolling the bag off your hand and over the bottle, ready to throw away.
16.  Roll onto your front and wait for 5 minutes. This will stop any liquid coming out of your bottom.
17.  For sleeping, find a comfortable position that keeps the liquid in your bottom for as long as possible. The longer it stays there, the better it will work.

【20】How long to use it for
----------------------

【21】Your doctor will tell you how long to use budesonide rectal foam or enemas for. This will usually be for no longer than 8 weeks. Do not use budesonide rectal foam or enemas for more than 8 weeks without speaking to a doctor.

【22】If you forget to use it
-----------------------

【23】If you forget to use your budesonide rectal foam or enema, use it as soon as you remember unless it's nearly time for the next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take the next one at the usual time.

【24】Never use 2 doses to make up for a missed dose.

【25】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to use this medicine.

【26】If you use too much
-------------------

【27】Using too much budesonide is unlikely to harm you.

【28】If you're worried, talk to your doctor or a pharmacist.

【29】More in Budesonide rectal foam and enemas
-----------------------------------------

【30】*   About budesonide rectal foam and enemas
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【31】Page last reviewed: 16 August 2023  
Next review due: 16 August 2026

source_info.title: Do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation (DNACPR) decisions
source_info.text:
【0】Do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation (DNACPR) decisions
===============================================================

【1】CPR stands for cardiopulmonary resuscitation. It's a treatment that can be given when you stop breathing (respiratory arrest) or your heart stops beating (cardiac arrest).

【2】CPR tries to get your breathing and heart going again.

【3】It can involve:

【4】*   pressing down hard on your chest repeatedly (chest compressions)
*   a machine to stimulate your heart using electrical shocks (sometimes more than once)
*   equipment that helps move oxygen around your body (artificial ventilation)
*   giving medicine by injection

【5】How successful is CPR?
----------------------

【6】CPR can sometimes get the heart and breathing going again. The actions used in CPR, such as chest compressions, can cause bruising, break ribs and puncture lungs.

【7】Overall, CPR restarts the heart and/or breathing for between 1 and 2 in 10 people whose heart or breathing have stopped.

【8】You have the best chance of CPR restarting your heart or breathing if:

【9】*   your lungs, heart or other organs are healthy and working well before your heart or breathing stops
*   you are near a person trained in CPR
*   any equipment that is needed, such as a defibrillator, is nearby

【10】The chances of CPR starting your heart and/or breathing are lower if your lungs, heart or other organs are struggling to work before CPR is needed. Your organs might be struggling because you:

【11】*   have previous organ damage (for example, your lungs have been damaged by smoking)
*   have a serious long-term condition (this is not the same as a disability)
*   have current severe illness
*   are frail
*   are approaching the end of your life

【12】Only a few people make a full recovery even if their heart or breathing can be restarted with CPR.

【13】You may still be very unwell and need more treatment and you may never get back to the health you had before.

【14】Your heart and/or brain may be permanently damaged. This is why DNACPR forms are written. They mean you do not receive a treatment that may prolong or cause suffering at the end of your life.

【15】What does DNACPR mean and how is it recorded?
---------------------------------------------

【16】DNACPR stands for do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation. It's sometimes called DNAR (do not attempt resuscitation) or DNR (do not resuscitate) but they all refer to the same thing.

【17】DNACPR means if your heart or breathing stops your healthcare team will not try to restart it.

【18】A DNACPR decision is made by you and/or your doctor or healthcare team. This is explained in more detail in the following section "When is a DNACPR decision made and a form written and who is involved?".

【19】A DNACPR decision is usually recorded on a special form. Different doctors or hospitals might use different forms, but they all serve the same purpose. Some examples are a DNACPR form, a treatment escalation plan, or a recommended summary plan for emergency care and treatment (ReSPECT) process.

【20】All these forms are easily recognised by doctors, nurses and healthcare workers, so they know what to do in an emergency.

【21】This form is kept in your medical records. It may also be printed and kept with you if you are at home or in a care home.

【22】You and the people important to you should know that a DNACPR form has been put in your medical records.

【23】The form says that if your heart or breathing stop, CPR should not be tried. This means medical staff will not try to restart your heart or breathing.

【24】### Important

【25】DNACPR is about CPR only. It does not mean that you will not get care and treatment. You will continue to have all the other appropriate care, treatment and support you need.

【26】When is a DNACPR decision made and a form written and who is involved?
----------------------------------------------------------------------

【27】There are different situations when a DNACPR decision might be made.

【28】### You decide – deciding in advance to refuse CPR

【29】Everyone who has capacity to do so can refuse CPR if they wish.

【30】This is a choice you can make at any time, for example when you are healthy or when you are approaching the end of your life.

【31】You can make it clear to your doctor or medical team that you do not want CPR if your heart or breathing stops.

【32】Your doctor may complete a DNACPR form to indicate this and put it in your medical records.

【33】*   If you wish to make your refusal of CPR legally binding for when in the future you are unable to make this decision, then you should write an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT). An ADRT explains to a doctor or medical team when you want to refuse CPR (or other treatments).
*   You can change your mind about your DNACPR decision at any time. If you do, you need to tell your doctors and nurses so that the DNACPR form is marked as no longer valid. The fact that you once had a DNACPR form will still be recorded on your records so that doctors and nurses can see your full medical history and know about conversations that happened in the past.

【34】### A doctor decides in advance

【35】*   DNACPR is a medical treatment decision that can be made by your doctor even if you do not agree.
*   You must be told that a DNACPR form will be/has been completed for you, but a doctor does not need your consent. Doctors can only not tell you that a DNACPR form has been completed for you if they think doing so would cause you physical or psychological harm.
*   You should be given the chance to understand what a DNACPR is, how the decision is made and why they think CPR would not be suitable for you. For example, your doctor may think that CPR will not help you live longer or that giving you CPR could cause you more harm. This may be because your organs are already too damaged because of another illness or you are approaching the end of your life.
*   You should then be consulted, and doctors should ask about your wishes and preferences. Your doctor makes the final decision.
*   Doctors do not have to give you treatment if they think it will not work.
*   A DNACPR decision must be made on an individual (person by person) basis. This means it must be based on your health, needs and priorities as an individual. The judgement about whether the discussion or decision would cause you harm should also be made on an individual basis.
*   DNACPR decisions should not be made for a group of people at once. For example, DNACPR decisions should not be made for everyone living in a care home or for a group of people over a certain age. This is unlawful, irrespective of medical condition, age, disability, race or language.
*   Learning disability, autism or dementia are not reasons to put a DNACPR on someone's record.
*   If you disagree with a DNACPR decision that a doctor has made, you can ask for a second opinion and a review. You cannot demand CPR. The law does not require your consent to a DNACPR. The law does provide you with the right to be involved in, and informed of, a doctor's DNACPR decision.

【36】What happens if you are unable to make or discuss a DNACPR decision in advance of your heart stopping?
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【37】Some people cannot make decisions about CPR for themselves. If you have been assessed as unable to make a specific decision for yourself, you will be referred to as "lacking capacity".

【38】If you lack capacity to decide about CPR, doctors should first check to see if you have an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT) that says that you do not want CPR. They should also check to see if you have a Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) for health and care decisions.

【39】An LPA is a document that explains who you have chosen to help you make decisions or who can make decisions for you. Your chosen person(s) are known as "attorneys". If you would like your LPA to make decisions about CPR, then you must complete and sign the section on life-sustaining treatment in the LPA document.

【40】An LPA (with the right to make decisions on life-sustaining treatment) means if you lack the relevant capacity, your attorney can make the decision relating to CPR in your best interests. Your attorney cannot insist on CPR being given.

【41】If you do not have an ADRT (which says that you do not want CPR) or an LPA (with life-sustaining treatment decision-making powers) then a best interest's decision is made by the senior doctor.

【42】This doctor must ask the people who are important to you about your wishes and preferences. This includes anyone with the legal power to represent you, such as a personal welfare deputy, special guardian or – for children and young people under 16 – a parent.

【43】If you do not have family or friends appropriate to ask, then the doctor should ask an independent mental capacity advocate (IMCA) to represent you in the decision-making process. The doctor should also ask members of your healthcare (multidisciplinary) team for their views.

【44】Information:

【45】### Further information

【46】*   GOV.UK: Deputies - make decisions for someone who lacks capacity
*   GOV.UK: Become a special guardian

【47】How long does a DNACPR form last?
---------------------------------

【48】A DNACPR form can be written for a short period – for example, if you have been admitted to hospital. Or it can be written with no end date – for example, if you have a long-term condition that has damaged your heart, lungs or other organs – only being reviewed if your situation changes.

【49】When the DNACPR decision is made you should be told when it will be reviewed, and this is usually recorded on the form. It's recommended that a DNACPR is reviewed each time your situation changes – for example, when you leave hospital. If a DNACPR form is placed on your medical records while in hospital, this will be included in your discharge summary and shared with your GP.

【50】Is a DNACPR form legally binding?
---------------------------------

【51】A DNACPR form is not legally binding. It's a tool to tell doctors, nurses or paramedics not to attempt CPR.

【52】If you wish to make your DNACPR decision legally binding, you should write an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT). An ADRT explains when you want to refuse CPR (or other treatment).

【53】Talking about a DNACPR
----------------------

【54】You do not have to talk about DNACPR if you do not want to. If you would prefer not to talk about it, you can let your doctors and nurses know. You could ask your doctors and nurses to make it clear on your record. If you change your mind and want to talk about it, you can.

【55】If a decision needs to be made about CPR, your doctors can still decide to complete a form even if you ask not to talk about it. Your doctor will do this if they believe that CPR would not prolong your life or would do you more harm than good.

【56】Even if you ask not to be involved in the decision, you should be told if a DNACPR form is written and placed on your medical records. Doctors can only not tell you that a DNACPR form has been completed for you if they think doing so would cause you physical or psychological harm.

【57】What should you do if you are concerned about a DNACPR form in your medical record or on somebody else's (such as a relative)?
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【58】If you are concerned about a DNACPR form, you should first raise those concerns with your doctor.

【59】If you are still not happy, then you can ask for another doctor's opinion.

【60】If you are not the patient and the patient has capacity to make their own decisions, they will need to agree to it being discussed with you. If you do not have capacity, your family, friends or those with the legal power to represent you (such as a Lasting Power of Attorney) can raise concerns on your behalf.

【61】It's important to understand that nobody has the right to demand CPR, so the decision may not change if there was a good clinical reason for it (for example, your heart, lungs or other organs are struggling to work). The doctor should explain their reasons and ask about your wishes and preferences.

【62】If the DNACPR form was made by a GP, and you are not happy with their response, you should follow the practice's complaints procedure. If you are still concerned, or you wish to make a complaint, contact NHS England and NHS Improvement.

【63】If the DNACPR form was made by a doctor in a hospital, and you are not happy with their response, you can ask to speak to the senior doctor on duty or the consultant responsible for your care. The hospital should have its own complaints procedure. This will tell you how to make a complaint.

【64】If your DNACPR form was made by a GP or doctor in a hospital, you can contact your local Healthwatch to find out about how to get help making a complaint. You can also have support from an advocate if you want help to make a complaint about your GP or a doctor in the hospital.

【65】If you are still not happy with the response you can contact the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman.

【66】Page last reviewed: 14 December 2023  
Next review due: 14 December 2026

source_info.title: Low sperm count
source_info.text:
【0】Low sperm count
===============

【1】**A low sperm count, also called oligozoospermia, is where a man has fewer than 15 million sperm per millilitre of semen.**

【2】Having a low sperm count can make it more difficult to conceive naturally, although successful pregnancies can still occur.

【3】Problems with sperm, including a low sperm count and problems with sperm quality, are quite common. They're a factor in around 1 in 3 couples who are struggling to get pregnant.

【4】There are treatments available on the NHS or privately that can help you become a dad if you have a low sperm count.

【5】Getting your sperm count checked
--------------------------------

【6】See your GP if you have not managed to conceive after 1 year of trying for a baby.

【7】It's a good idea for both you and your partner to get advice, as fertility problems can affect men and women and often it's a combination of both. It's important to understand what the exact issue is before you decide on your next steps.

【8】One of the tests your GP can arrange is a semen analysis.

【9】This is where a sample of semen is analysed to check the quality and quantity of the sperm. The results are usually available within a week.

【10】If the results are not normal, the test should be repeated to ensure it was accurate. This will normally be performed after 3 months.

【11】Your GP can refer you to a specialist in male infertility at your local hospital or fertility clinic if any problems are found.

【12】Home sperm count testing kits
-----------------------------

【13】There are several male fertility home-testing kits available to buy from pharmacies. These tests claim to indicate whether your sperm count is low.

【14】It may be tempting to try one of the tests if you would rather not see your GP, but you should be aware that:

【15】*   although research by the manufacturers suggests these tests can give an accurate indication of sperm count, they have not been extensively studied
*   some home-testing kits classify a low sperm count as under 20 million sperm per millilitre of semen, but more recent international guidelines state that anything above 15 million sperm per millilitre of semen is normal
*   some kits only check the number of sperm, not other things that can affect fertility such as how well the sperm are able to move (motility) – it's best to use a kit that measures both these things

【16】While these tests might sometimes give a useful indication of your sperm count, they may also give you false reassurance or may suggest your sperm count is low when it's actually perfectly normal.

【17】It's better to see your GP for a proper semen analysis at an accredited laboratory if you're concerned about your fertility. See how to use self-test kits safely for more about the issues of home-testing.

【18】Causes of a low sperm count
---------------------------

【19】In many cases, it's not obvious what causes a low sperm count.

【20】Sometimes problems with sperm count and quality are associated with:

【21】*   a hormone imbalance, such as hypogonadism (reduced hormone production)
*   a genetic problem such as Klinefelter syndrome
*   having had undescended testicles as a baby
*   a structural problem – for example, the tubes that carry sperm being damaged and blocked by illness or injury, or being absent from birth
*   a genital infection such as chlamydia, gonorrhoea or prostatitis (infection of the prostate gland)
*   varicoceles (enlarged veins in the testicles)
*   previous surgery to the testicles or hernia repairs
*   the testicles becoming overheated
*   excessive alcohol consumption, smoking and using drugs such as marijuana or cocaine
*   certain medications, including testosterone replacement therapy, long-term anabolic steroid use, cancer medications (chemotherapy), some antibiotics and some antidepressants
*   being overweight or obese

【22】Treatments for low sperm count
------------------------------

【23】If you or your partner has been diagnosed with a low sperm count, there are several options available.

【24】### Keep trying

【25】Your doctor may initially suggest trying to conceive naturally for a little longer. Many couples conceive within the second year of trying.

【26】You can help maximise your chances of conceiving by:

【27】*   having sex every 2 or 3 days
*   moderating your alcohol consumption and stopping smoking
*   staying in good shape, exercising regularly and having a healthy, balanced diet

【28】Read more about how to improve your chances of becoming a dad.

【29】### IVF

【30】In vitro fertilisation (IVF) may be an option if you have a slightly low sperm count and you've been trying to conceive naturally with your partner for at least 2 years.

【31】During IVF, an egg is removed from the woman's ovaries and fertilised with sperm in a laboratory. The fertilised egg is then returned to the woman's womb to grow and develop.

【32】Read more about IVF.

【33】### Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)

【34】Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is a type of IVF technique, in which a single sperm is injected directly into an egg to fertilise it. The fertilised egg is then transferred to the woman's womb.

【35】ICSI may be offered if you've been trying to conceive naturally with your partner for at least 2 years and you have either few or no sperm in your semen or poor quality sperm.

【36】Before having ICSI, you and your partner will need to have an assessment to ensure the treatment is appropriate.

【37】This will involve questions about your medical and sexual history, and screening tests to check for infections or genetic problems that could affect your baby and the chances of ICSI working.

【38】The Human Fertilisation & Embryo Authority (HFEA) has more information about ICSI.

【39】### Donor insemination

【40】Donor insemination means using sperm donated by another man.

【41】You may wish to consider using donor insemination as an alternative to ICSI, particularly if you have a genetic disorder that could be passed on to any children. It can be used as part of IVF if necessary.

【42】If you're considering donor insemination, you should be offered counselling as a couple about the implications for you and your children.

【43】Read more about what you need to know about using a sperm donor.

【44】### Gonadotrophin medicine

【45】If you have very low levels of gonadotrophin hormones (that stimulate the production of sperm), you should be offered treatment with gonadotrophin medicine to improve your fertility.

【46】But if no cause has been found for your abnormal sperm count, you will not be offered hormone-based medicines as they are not known to improve fertility in these cases.

【47】Page last reviewed: 07 August 2019  
Next review due: 07 August 2022

text.text: 【28】Read more about how to improve your chances of becoming a dad.
text.content:
【0】Low sperm count
===============

【1】**A low sperm count, also called oligozoospermia, is where a man has fewer than 15 million sperm per millilitre of semen.**

【2】Having a low sperm count can make it more difficult to conceive naturally, although successful pregnancies can still occur.

【3】Problems with sperm, including a low sperm count and problems with sperm quality, are quite common. They're a factor in around 1 in 3 couples who are struggling to get pregnant.

【4】There are treatments available on the NHS or privately that can help you become a dad if you have a low sperm count.

【5】Getting your sperm count checked
--------------------------------

【6】See your GP if you have not managed to conceive after 1 year of trying for a baby.

【7】It's a good idea for both you and your partner to get advice, as fertility problems can affect men and women and often it's a combination of both. It's important to understand what the exact issue is before you decide on your next steps.

【8】One of the tests your GP can arrange is a semen analysis.

【9】This is where a sample of semen is analysed to check the quality and quantity of the sperm. The results are usually available within a week.

【10】If the results are not normal, the test should be repeated to ensure it was accurate. This will normally be performed after 3 months.

【11】Your GP can refer you to a specialist in male infertility at your local hospital or fertility clinic if any problems are found.

【12】Home sperm count testing kits
-----------------------------

【13】There are several male fertility home-testing kits available to buy from pharmacies. These tests claim to indicate whether your sperm count is low.

【14】It may be tempting to try one of the tests if you would rather not see your GP, but you should be aware that:

【15】*   although research by the manufacturers suggests these tests can give an accurate indication of sperm count, they have not been extensively studied
*   some home-testing kits classify a low sperm count as under 20 million sperm per millilitre of semen, but more recent international guidelines state that anything above 15 million sperm per millilitre of semen is normal
*   some kits only check the number of sperm, not other things that can affect fertility such as how well the sperm are able to move (motility) – it's best to use a kit that measures both these things

【16】While these tests might sometimes give a useful indication of your sperm count, they may also give you false reassurance or may suggest your sperm count is low when it's actually perfectly normal.

【17】It's better to see your GP for a proper semen analysis at an accredited laboratory if you're concerned about your fertility. See how to use self-test kits safely for more about the issues of home-testing.

【18】Causes of a low sperm count
---------------------------

【19】In many cases, it's not obvious what causes a low sperm count.

【20】Sometimes problems with sperm count and quality are associated with:

【21】*   a hormone imbalance, such as hypogonadism (reduced hormone production)
*   a genetic problem such as Klinefelter syndrome
*   having had undescended testicles as a baby
*   a structural problem – for example, the tubes that carry sperm being damaged and blocked by illness or injury, or being absent from birth
*   a genital infection such as chlamydia, gonorrhoea or prostatitis (infection of the prostate gland)
*   varicoceles (enlarged veins in the testicles)
*   previous surgery to the testicles or hernia repairs
*   the testicles becoming overheated
*   excessive alcohol consumption, smoking and using drugs such as marijuana or cocaine
*   certain medications, including testosterone replacement therapy, long-term anabolic steroid use, cancer medications (chemotherapy), some antibiotics and some antidepressants
*   being overweight or obese

【22】Treatments for low sperm count
------------------------------

【23】If you or your partner has been diagnosed with a low sperm count, there are several options available.

【24】### Keep trying

【25】Your doctor may initially suggest trying to conceive naturally for a little longer. Many couples conceive within the second year of trying.

【26】You can help maximise your chances of conceiving by:

【27】*   having sex every 2 or 3 days
*   moderating your alcohol consumption and stopping smoking
*   staying in good shape, exercising regularly and having a healthy, balanced diet

【28】Read more about how to improve your chances of becoming a dad.

【29】### IVF

【30】In vitro fertilisation (IVF) may be an option if you have a slightly low sperm count and you've been trying to conceive naturally with your partner for at least 2 years.

【31】During IVF, an egg is removed from the woman's ovaries and fertilised with sperm in a laboratory. The fertilised egg is then returned to the woman's womb to grow and develop.

【32】Read more about IVF.

【33】### Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)

【34】Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is a type of IVF technique, in which a single sperm is injected directly into an egg to fertilise it. The fertilised egg is then transferred to the woman's womb.

【35】ICSI may be offered if you've been trying to conceive naturally with your partner for at least 2 years and you have either few or no sperm in your semen or poor quality sperm.

【36】Before having ICSI, you and your partner will need to have an assessment to ensure the treatment is appropriate.

【37】This will involve questions about your medical and sexual history, and screening tests to check for infections or genetic problems that could affect your baby and the chances of ICSI working.

【38】The Human Fertilisation & Embryo Authority (HFEA) has more information about ICSI.

【39】### Donor insemination

【40】Donor insemination means using sperm donated by another man.

【41】You may wish to consider using donor insemination as an alternative to ICSI, particularly if you have a genetic disorder that could be passed on to any children. It can be used as part of IVF if necessary.

【42】If you're considering donor insemination, you should be offered counselling as a couple about the implications for you and your children.

【43】Read more about what you need to know about using a sperm donor.

【44】### Gonadotrophin medicine

【45】If you have very low levels of gonadotrophin hormones (that stimulate the production of sperm), you should be offered treatment with gonadotrophin medicine to improve your fertility.

【46】But if no cause has been found for your abnormal sperm count, you will not be offered hormone-based medicines as they are not known to improve fertility in these cases.

【47】Page last reviewed: 07 August 2019  
Next review due: 07 August 2022

source_info.title: Hernia
source_info.text:
【0】Hernia
======

【1】**A hernia occurs when an internal part of the body pushes through a weakness in the muscle or surrounding tissue wall.**

【2】A hernia usually develops between your chest and hips. In many cases, it causes no or very few symptoms, although you may notice a swelling or lump in your tummy (abdomen) or groin.

【3】The lump can often be pushed back in or disappears when you lie down. Coughing or straining may make the lump appear.

【4】Types of hernia
---------------

【5】### Inguinal hernias

【6】Inguinal hernias occur when fatty tissue or a part of your bowel pokes through into your groin at the top of your inner thigh.

【7】This is the most common type of hernia and it mainly affects men. It's often associated with ageing and repeated strain on the tummy.

【8】### Femoral hernias

【9】Femoral hernias also happen when fatty tissue or part of your bowel pokes through into your groin at the top of your inner thigh.

【10】They're much less common than inguinal hernias and tend to affect more women than men.

【11】Like inguinal hernias, femoral hernias are also associated with ageing and repeated strain on the tummy.

【12】### Umbilical hernias

【13】Umbilical hernias occur when fatty tissue or part of your bowel pokes through your tummy near your belly button.

【14】This type of hernia can occur in babies if the opening in the tummy that the umbilical cord passes through does not seal properly after birth.

【15】Adults can also be affected, possibly as a result of repeated strain on the tummy.

【16】### Hiatus hernias

【17】Hiatus hernias occur when part of the stomach pushes up into your chest by squeezing through an opening in the diaphragm, the thin sheet of muscle that separates the chest from the tummy.

【18】This type of hernia may not have any noticeable symptoms, although it can cause heartburn in some people.

【19】It's not exactly clear what causes hiatus hernias, but it may be the result of the diaphragm becoming weak with age or pressure on the tummy.

【20】### Other types of hernia

【21】Other types of hernia that can affect the tummy include:

【22】*   incisional hernias – where tissue pokes through a surgical wound in your tummy that has not fully healed
*   epigastric hernias – where fatty tissue pokes through your tummy, between your belly button and the lower part of your breastbone
*   spigelian hernias – where part of your bowel pokes through your tummy at the side of your abdominal muscle, usually below your belly button
*   diaphragmatic hernias – where organs in your tummy move into your chest through an opening in the diaphragm; this can also affect babies if their diaphragm does not develop properly in the womb
*   muscle hernias – where part of the muscle pokes through the tissue; they commonly occur in leg muscles as a result of a sports injury

【23】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【24】See a GP if you think you have a hernia. They may refer you to hospital for surgical treatment, if necessary.

【25】You should go to your nearest A&E straight away if you have a hernia and you develop any of the following symptoms:

【26】*   sudden, severe pain
*   being sick
*   difficulty pooing or passing wind
*   the hernia becomes firm or tender, or cannot be pushed back in

【27】These symptoms could mean that either: 

【28】*   the blood supply to a section of organ or tissue trapped in the hernia has become cut off (strangulation)
*   a piece of bowel has entered the hernia and become blocked (obstruction)

【29】A strangulated hernia and obstructed bowel are medical emergencies and need to be treated as soon as possible.

【30】Assessing a hernia
------------------

【31】A GP will usually be able to identify a hernia by examining the affected area.

【32】In some cases, they may refer you to a nearby hospital for an ultrasound scan to confirm the diagnosis or assess the extent of the problem.

【33】This is a painless scan where high-frequency sound waves are used to create an image of part of the inside of the body.

【34】Once a diagnosis has been confirmed, a GP or hospital doctor will determine whether surgery to repair the hernia is necessary.

【35】A number of factors will be considered when deciding whether surgery is appropriate, including:

【36】*   the type of hernia – some types of hernia are more likely to become strangulated or cause a bowel obstruction than others
*   the content of your hernia – if the hernia contains a part of your bowel, muscle or other tissue, there may be a risk of strangulation or obstruction
*   your symptoms and the impact on your daily life – surgery may be recommended if your symptoms are severe or getting worse, or if the hernia is affecting your ability to carry out your normal activities
*   your general health – surgery may be too much of a risk if your general health is poor

【37】Although most hernias will not get better without surgery, they will not necessarily get worse.

【38】In some cases, the risks of surgery outweigh the potential benefits.

【39】Surgery for a hernia
--------------------

【40】There are 2 main ways surgery for hernias can be carried out:

【41】*   open surgery – where a cut is made to allow the surgeon to push the lump back into the tummy
*   laparoscopy (keyhole surgery) – this is a less invasive, but more difficult, technique where several smaller cuts are made, allowing the surgeon to use various special instruments to repair the hernia

【42】Most people are able to go home the same day or the day after surgery and make a full recovery within a few weeks.

【43】If your doctor recommends having surgery, it's important to be aware of the potential risks, as well as the possibility of the hernia coming back.

【44】Make sure you discuss the benefits and risks of the procedure with your surgeon in detail before having the operation.

【45】### More information

【46】To find out more about some common types of hernia surgery, see:

【47】*   how inguinal hernias are repaired
*   how femoral hernias are repaired
*   how umbilical hernias are repaired
*   how hiatus hernias are treated
