source_info.title: Sodium valproate
source_info.text:
【0】Sodium valproate \- Brand names: Dyzantil, Epilim, Episenta, Epival
===================================================================

【1】On this page
------------

【2】1.  About sodium valproate
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take sodium valproate
4.  How and when to take sodium valproate
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of sodium valproate
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about sodium valproate

【3】1\. About sodium valproate
--------------------------

【4】Sodium valproate is used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder.

【5】It's occasionally used to prevent migraine headaches.

【6】This medicine is only available on prescription. It comes as capsules, tablets and a liquid that you swallow. It also comes as granules that you mix with food or drink.

【7】Sodium valproate can also be given by injection, but this is usually only done in hospital.

【8】If taken during pregnancy, sodium valproate can cause problems for a baby's development, including birth defects and long term learning difficulties. For this reason, sodium valproate is not recommended if there's a chance that you could become pregnant.

【9】For women and girls of childbearing age, if you do need to take sodium valproate then your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【10】### Important: Valproate pregnancy prevention programme

【11】The valproate pregnancy prevention programme is very important.

【12】You should be reviewed every year by your doctor or nurse. They will assess whether you need to continue taking sodium valproate or whether it is possible to change your medicine.

【13】If you do need to continue sodium valproate then you must be using reliable contraception, even if you are not currently sexually active. Your doctor or nurse can advise you about reliable contraception. You will be asked to sign a form to say that you are using contraception and understand the risks of becoming pregnant while taking sodium valproate.

【14】It's important to get advice as soon as possible if you think you are pregnant or might become pregnant while taking sodium valproate. However, do not stop taking your medicine suddenly without talking to your doctor first.

【15】Updated: 18 October 2022

【16】2\. Key facts
-------------

【17】*   You'll usually take sodium valproate once or twice a day. You can take it with or without food.
*   You'll usually start on a low dose. Your dose will gradually increase over a few days or weeks.
*   Valproic acid and semisodium valproate are similar to sodium valproate and work in the same way. However these medicines are used to treat different conditions and doses will vary.
*   There are also brands such as Epilim Chrono, Epilim Chronosphere and Dyzantil which contain mostly sodium valproate, with some valproic acid.
*   If you're pregnant, or there's a chance you could become pregnant, sodium valproate is not recommended for treating migraine. For epilepsy and bipolar disorder, your doctor will only prescribe sodium valproate for you if there are no other suitable treatments.

【18】3\. Who can and cannot take sodium valproate
--------------------------------------------

【19】Sodium valproate can be taken by adults and children to treat epilepsy or bipolar disorder.

【20】It can be taken by adults (aged 18 and above) to help prevent migraine.

【21】Sodium valproate is not suitable for girls or women who could become pregnant. However, in some cases it may be the only treatment option available, for example for epilepsy where other treatments have not worked. Girls and women who need to take sodium valproate must be on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【22】To make sure sodium valproate is safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【23】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to sodium valproate or any other medicine
*   have liver problems
*   have a rare metabolic or genetic illness such as porphyria, urea cycle disorder or mitochondrial disorder

【24】4\. How and when to take sodium valproate
-----------------------------------------

【25】Sodium valproate is a prescription medicine. It's important to take it as your doctor tells you.

【26】### Dosage

【27】The usual dose for treating epilepsy in:

【28】*   adults and older children (aged 12 years and over) – 600mg to 2,000mg a day, as 1 dose or split into 2 doses. Some people take a higher dose of 2,500mg a day
*   younger children (aged 1 month to 11 years) – the doctor will use your child's weight to work out the right dose for them

【29】The usual dose for treating bipolar disorder in:

【30】*   adults – 750mg to 2,000mg a day, as 1 dose or split into 2 doses
*   children – the doctor will work out the right dose for your child

【31】The usual dose for preventing migraine in:

【32】*   adults – daily doses vary from a single dose of 400mg to 1,500mg split into 2 doses

【33】If your doctor tells you to take sodium valproate twice a day, you'll usually take half the dose in the morning and half in the evening (to make up your full daily dose).

【34】If you're taking sodium valproate and have kidney problems, your doctor may prescribe a lower dose.

【35】### How to take it

【36】Sodium valproate comes as slow release (prolonged or sustained release) tablets, capsules and granules, gastro-resistant tablets, crushable tablets, and as a liquid.

【37】Slow release medicine passes into your body gradually.

【38】Gastro-resistant tablets release the medicine as soon as it passes through your stomach. This means the sodium valproate is less likely to upset your stomach.

【39】You can take sodium valproate with or without food, but it's best to stick to the same way each time. Do not take it with food some days and without food on other days.

【40】#### How to take slow release tablets and capsules

【41】Swallow these whole with a drink of water or juice. Do not chew them.

【42】You'll usually take them once a day, unless you're on a high dose and your doctor tells you to take your medicine twice a day.

【43】#### How to take slow release granules

【44】Add the granules to a small drink, then stir and swallow it. If you prefer, sprinkle the granules onto any soft food that you can swallow whole. Do not chew the granules.

【45】Your doctor will tell you to take these either once or twice a day.

【46】#### How to take gastro-resistant tablets

【47】Swallow these whole with a drink of water or juice. Do not chew them.

【48】You'll usually take these twice a day.

【49】#### How to take crushable tablets

【50】Crush the tablets using the back of a spoon and mix the powder with some soft food that you can swallow whole. If you prefer, add the powder to a small drink, then stir and swallow it.

【51】You'll usually take this medicine twice a day.

【52】#### How to take liquid

【53】Use the plastic syringe or spoon that comes with your medicine to measure the correct dose. If you do not have one, ask your pharmacist. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as you will not get the right amount.

【54】You'll usually take the liquid twice a day.

【55】### When to take sodium valproate

【56】If you're taking sodium valproate once a day, you can choose a time that suits you. Just try to keep to the same time every day.

【57】If you're taking sodium valproate twice a day, try to leave a gap of 10 to 12 hours between doses. For example you could take your first dose in the morning (between 7am and 8am) and your second dose in the evening (between 7pm and 8pm).

【58】### Will my dose go up or down?

【59】To reduce the chance of side effects, your doctor will start you off on a low dose of sodium valproate. They will increase it gradually over a few days or weeks.

【60】Once you find a dose that suits you, it will usually stay the same, unless your condition changes, or your doctor starts you on a new medicine that may affect sodium valproate.

【61】### What if I forget to take it?

【62】If you've missed a dose, what you do next depends on whether you usually take your medicine once or twice a day.

【63】If you take sodium valproate:

【64】*   **once a day** – take the forgotten dose as soon as you remember unless it's within a few hours of the next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time
*   **twice a day** – take the forgotten dose as soon as you remember unless it's within 2 hours of the next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time

【65】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【66】If you have epilepsy, it's important to take this medicine regularly. Missing doses can trigger a seizure.

【67】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【68】### What if I take too much?

【69】Taking too much sodium valproate can lead to symptoms such as:

【70】*   feeling or being sick (nausea or vomiting)
*   headaches or feeling dizzy
*   muscle weakness
*   breathing problems
*   feeling confused, or changes to your normal behaviour
*   passing out

【71】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【72】*   you take too much sodium valproate and feel unwell

【73】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

【74】If you need to go to A&E, take the sodium valproate packet or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.

【75】5\. Side effects
----------------

【76】Like all medicines, sodium valproate can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【77】### Common side effects

【78】These common side effects may happen in more than 1 in 100 people. They're usually mild and go away by themselves.

【79】Keep taking the medicine but talk to your doctor if these side effects bother you or do not go away:

【80】*   stomach pain, feeling or being sick
*   diarrhoea
*   dry or sore mouth, or swollen gums
*   shakes (tremors) in a part of your body, or unusual eye movements
*   feeling tired or sleepy
*   headache
*   weight gain
*   thinning hair, or changes to the colour or texture of your hair
*   irregular or delayed periods

【81】### Serious side effects

【82】It's unusual to have serious side effects after taking sodium valproate. Tell a doctor straight away if you have:

【83】*   thoughts of harming or killing yourself – a small number of people taking sodium valproate have had suicidal thoughts
*   yellowing of the whites of your eyes or your skin, although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin, and dark pee – these may be signs of liver problems
*   long-lasting and severe nausea, vomiting or stomach pain – these may be signs of acute pancreatitis (an inflamed pancreas)
*   unusual bruises or bleeding – these may be signs of a blood disorder

【84】#### Serious allergic reaction

【85】In rare cases, sodium valproate may cause a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).

【86】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【87】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【88】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【89】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【90】These are not all the side effects of sodium valproate. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【91】Information:

【92】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【93】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【94】6\. How to cope with side effects of sodium valproate
-----------------------------------------------------

【95】**What to do about:**

【96】*   **stomach pain, feeling or being sick** – take sodium valproate with or after a meal or snack. It may also help if you avoid rich or spicy food. Take small, frequent sips of water if you're being sick to avoid dehydration.
*   **diarrhoea** – drink plenty of fluids such as water or squash to avoid dehydration. Speak to a pharmacist if you have signs of dehydration, such as peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.
*   **dry or sore mouth, or swollen gums** – for a dry mouth try sugar-free gum or sweets, or sipping cold drinks. If this does not help, or you have mouth ulcers, talk to your pharmacist or doctor. If you're bothered by swollen gums or this symptom does not go away, talk to your doctor or dentist.
*   **shakes (tremors) in a part of your body, or unusual eye movements** – talk to your doctor if this is bothering you. These symptoms can be a sign that your dose is too high. Talk to your doctor as they may want to change your dose or suggest you take it at a different time.
*   **feeling tired or sleepy** – as your body gets used to sodium valproate, these side effects should wear off. If these symptoms do not get better within a week or two, your doctor may either reduce your dose or increase it more slowly. If that does not work, talk to your doctor as they may want to switch you to a different medicine.
*   **headaches** – make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Talk to your doctor if your headaches last longer than a week or are severe.
*   **weight gain** – if you find you're putting on weight after taking sodium valproate, try to have a healthy balanced diet. Regular exercise will also help you keep your weight stable. Your doctor will usually monitor your weight while you're taking this medicine. Speak to them if you have any concerns.
*   **thinning hair, or changes to the colour or texture of your hair** – if these symptoms bother you, ask your doctor whether it's possible to lower your dose. Your hair may regrow after either reducing your dose or switching to a different medicine.
*   **irregular or delayed periods** – if you usually have regular periods, take a pregnancy test if your period is late, and speak to your doctor if the result is positive. As well as being a side effect of sodium valproate, a late period is a sign that you could be pregnant, and sodium valproate can be harmful for an unborn baby. Changes to your periods can also be a symptom of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), a rare side effect of sodium valproate. Your doctor will be able to do some tests to check whether you have PCOS.

【97】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【98】### Sodium valproate and pregnancy

【99】Sodium valproate is not recommended in pregnancy, as it can cause birth defects and problems with your baby's learning and behaviour.

【100】If there's a chance you could become pregnant while taking this medicine, your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【101】If you think you might already be pregnant, contact your doctor or nurse as soon as possible.

【102】If you're taking sodium valproate for epilepsy or bipolar disorder and you become pregnant, do not stop taking your medicine without talking to your doctor first. This is because your symptoms may get worse.

【103】Your doctor may continue to prescribe sodium valproate, but only if there's no other suitable treatment for your epilepsy or bipolar disorder.

【104】For pregnant women with recurrent migraine your doctor should offer you an alternative treatment to sodium valproate.

【105】Information:

【106】You must have a review of your treatment every year. Contact your doctor or specialist now if you have not had one.

【107】### Sodium valproate and breastfeeding

【108】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy you can take sodium valproate while breastfeeding.

【109】Sodium valproate passes into breast milk in small amounts but it's unlikely to harm your baby so you can continue breastfeeding if your doctor says you need to take it.

【110】If there's a chance you could become pregnant while taking this medicine, your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme. Your doctor may still recommend sodium valproate if it is the only medicine that works for you.

【111】Do not stop taking your medicine without talking to your doctor first as your symptoms may get worse. Breastfeeding will also benefit both you and your baby.

【112】Talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible if:

【113】*   your baby is not feeding as well as usual
*   your baby is bruising more easily than usual
*   the whites of your baby's eyes turn yellow or your baby's skin turns yellow (this may be less obvious on brown or black skin), or your baby has dark pee or pale poo – these can be signs of jaundice

【114】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【115】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【116】### More information

【117】*   Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website – information about how sodium valproate can affect you and your baby during pregnancy
*   NHS England letter to all women and girls aged 12 to 55 taking sodium valproate, available in different languages
*   valproate pregnancy prevention programme patient guide: what women and girls need to know about valproate (PDF, 341kb)

【118】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【119】There are some medicines that may affect how sodium valproate works. Sodium valproate can also affect the way other medicines work.

【120】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines:

【121】*   any other medicines for epilepsy such as carbamazepine
*   medicines for preventing blood clots such as warfarin
*   aspirin for pain relief or low-dose aspirin
*   cimetidine, a medicine for stomach ulcers
*   medicines to treat HIV and AIDS such as ritonavir
*   antibiotics such as erythromycin
*   medicines for depression or other mental health problems such as venlafaxine, quetiapine or diazepam
*   cholesterol-lowering medicines such as cholestyramine
*   medicines to prevent malaria such as mefloquine or chloroquine

【122】### Mixing sodium valproate with herbal remedies or supplements

【123】It's not possible to say whether complementary medicines and herbal supplements are safe to take with sodium valproate.

【124】They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【125】### Important: Medicine safety

【126】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【127】9\. Common questions about sodium valproate
-------------------------------------------

【128】How does sodium valproate work?

【129】Sodium valproate is an anticonvulsant (or anti-epileptic) medicine. It prevents epileptic seizures by reducing excessive electrical activity in your brain.

【130】It's not fully understood how this medicine works for treating bipolar disorder. However, sodium valproate is thought to reduce or prevent manic episodes by increasing the amount of a chemical called gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain. GABA blocks transmission across nerves in the brain and has a calming effect.

【131】It's not clear how sodium valproate prevents migraine. It may limit how your nerves transmit pain signals in the brain.

【132】When will I feel better?

【133】It takes a few weeks for sodium valproate to work properly. You may still have symptoms during this time.

【134】How long will I take it for?

【135】Once your condition is under control, you'll usually need to keep taking sodium valproate for many years.

【136】Can I get addicted to sodium valproate?

【137】Sodium valproate is not known to be addictive.

【138】Is it safe to take it for a long time?

【139】Many people can take sodium valproate safely for many months or years.

【140】However, there are potential side effects that can happen over a long time. Long-term treatment with sodium valproate can cause osteoporosis and osteopenia (increasing your risk of breaking a bone).

【141】Your doctor can arrange for tests to check the strength of your bones. Regular exercise and a good diet can also help to keep your bones strong.

【142】Can I get epilepsy medicines for free?

【143】If you have epilepsy, you're entitled to free prescriptions for all of your medicines (not just your epilepsy ones).

【144】To claim your free prescriptions you'll need a medical exemption certificate.

【145】The application form for the medical exemption certificate is called FP92A. You can get this from your doctor's surgery. You will need to fill in the form, then your doctor will sign it and send it off.

【146】Are there similar medicines to sodium valproate?

【147】Valproic acid and semisodium valproate are very similar to sodium valproate. They work in the same way but these medicines are sometimes given at different doses for different conditions.

【148】If you decide to try valproic acid or semisodium valproate instead, your doctor will explain how to come off sodium valproate safely.

【149】How does it compare with other medicines for epilepsy?

【150】There are many different medicines for treating epilepsy. It's not possible to say that one works better than the others. It varies from person to person and depends on the type of seizures and how often you have them.

【151】Before prescribing a medicine, your doctor will also take into account your age and sex, the medicines you're already taking and any other health problems you have.

【152】It's usual to try to treat epilepsy using a single medicine. If this medicine is not working well, or you're getting side effects, your doctor will try you on a different one.

【153】If a single medicine is not preventing your seizures, then your doctor may recommend taking 2 or more anti-epileptic medicines at the same time.

【154】Sodium valproate works for several different types of epilepsy. If it's giving you side effects, or you're worried it is not suitable for you, ask your doctor or specialist to recommend a different medicine.

【155】Other anti-epileptic medicines include:

【156】*   carbamazepine
*   clobazam
*   ethosuximide
*   gabapentin
*   lamotrigine
*   levetiracetam
*   phenytoin
*   pregabalin
*   topiramate

【157】How does it compare with other medicines for migraine?

【158】For many people topiramate, propranolol and amitriptyline work better than sodium valproate at preventing migraines. These medicines are likely to cause fewer side effects, so your doctor or specialist will usually prescribe one of these first.

【159】Sodium valproate is not used as often for preventing migraine. However, your doctor may recommend it if these other medicines are causing side effects or are not working for you.

【160】Your doctor may also prescribe sodium valproate if you have a health problem that means you cannot take other migraine medicines.

【161】How does sodium valproate compare with other medicines for treating bipolar disorder?

【162】If you have bipolar disorder, there are several types of medicine to prevent mood swings and treat mania. It's not possible to say that one works better than another and it varies from person to person.

【163】Lithium is commonly used for bipolar disorder, as well as anti-epileptic medicines like sodium valproate and antipsychotic medicines like olanzapine. You can take sodium valproate instead of lithium, or together with lithium, depending on what your doctor recommends.

【164】Your doctor or specialist will find the medicines that work best for you. It depends on your mood swings, how often they happen, how severe they are and how well you cope with a medicine.

【165】Do I need to stick to the same brand of sodium valproate?

【166】Once you're on a dose of sodium valproate that suits you, you're likely to keep taking the same type or brand. This is because it can be a problem to swap from modified release to gastro-resistant tablets.

【167】Some people may change brands to try a different type of sodium valproate. For example they may want to try the granules instead of the tablets. If you need to change brand your doctor or pharmacist will explain how to do so safely.

【168】However, if your epilepsy has been difficult to control in the past and the brand you're taking is working well for you, your doctor may recommend staying on the same one.

【169】What will happen when I come off it?

【170】Do not stop taking sodium valproate suddenly, unless your doctor tells you to.

【171】You're unlikely to get any extra symptoms when you stop taking this medicine. However, if you're taking sodium valproate for epilepsy, it's possible that you'll get seizures again once you stop taking it. You can prevent these withdrawal seizures by reducing your dose of sodium valproate gradually.

【172】If you're taking it for bipolar disorder or to prevent migraine, your condition could get worse for a short time after you stop taking the medicine.

【173】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【174】Sodium valproate can affect recreational drugs like cannabis and heroin.

【175】If you use recreational drugs alongside sodium valproate, you may be more likely to have side effects like panic attacks, anxiety and memory loss.

【176】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【177】Drinking alcohol while taking sodium valproate may make you feel sleepy or tired. It's best to stop drinking alcohol during the first few days, until you see how the medicine affects you.

【178】Will it affect my fertility?

【179】Sodium valproate can reduce fertility in both men and women. Once you stop taking this medicine, your fertility will return.

【180】In men sodium valproate has been reported to cause infertility. However, this is rare.

【181】In women it can change your menstrual cycle, causing delayed or missed periods. Sodium valproate has also been reported to cause polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), though this happens rarely.

【182】Talk to your doctor if you're concerned about how sodium valproate may affect your fertility.

【183】Sodium valproate is not recommended if there's a chance you could become pregnant. If you're taking sodium valproate and want to start a family, it's important to talk your doctor as soon as possible. This is because taking sodium valproate while pregnant can harm your baby.

【184】Will it affect my contraception?

【185】Sodium valproate does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【186】If there's a chance you could become pregnant while taking sodium valproate you must use contraception. Your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【187】Speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you have any questions about this programme.

【188】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【189】You may feel sleepy, tired or dizzy when you first start taking sodium valproate. This may also happen if your dose has increased. If you're affected, do not drive or ride a bike until you feel more alert.

【190】If you have epilepsy, you're not allowed to drive until you've had no seizures for 1 year (or only have seizures while you're asleep).

【191】If you change your epilepsy medicine, your doctor will tell you whether you need to stop driving and for how long.

【192】Information:

【193】Driving rules if you change or withdraw your medicine, Epilepsy Action

【194】Epilepsy and driving information, GOV.UK

【195】Related conditions
------------------

【196】*   Bipolar disorder
*   Epilepsy
*   Migraine

【197】Useful resources
----------------

【198】*   NHS England letter to all women and girls of taking sodium valproate. Available in different languages
*   HealthUnlocked: sodium valproate forum
*   Bipolar UK: charity
*   Epilepsy Action: charity
*   Migraine Trust: charity
*   Mind: mental health charity
*   Healthtalk: videos of personal stories about epilepsy
*   Healthtalk: videos of personal stories about epilepsy in young people

【199】Page last reviewed: 24 August 2021  
Next review due: 24 August 2024

text.content:
【0】Sodium valproate \- Brand names: Dyzantil, Epilim, Episenta, Epival
===================================================================

【1】On this page
------------

【2】1.  About sodium valproate
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take sodium valproate
4.  How and when to take sodium valproate
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of sodium valproate
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about sodium valproate

【3】1\. About sodium valproate
--------------------------

【4】Sodium valproate is used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder.

【5】It's occasionally used to prevent migraine headaches.

【6】This medicine is only available on prescription. It comes as capsules, tablets and a liquid that you swallow. It also comes as granules that you mix with food or drink.

【7】Sodium valproate can also be given by injection, but this is usually only done in hospital.

【8】If taken during pregnancy, sodium valproate can cause problems for a baby's development, including birth defects and long term learning difficulties. For this reason, sodium valproate is not recommended if there's a chance that you could become pregnant.

【9】For women and girls of childbearing age, if you do need to take sodium valproate then your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【10】### Important: Valproate pregnancy prevention programme

【11】The valproate pregnancy prevention programme is very important.

【12】You should be reviewed every year by your doctor or nurse. They will assess whether you need to continue taking sodium valproate or whether it is possible to change your medicine.

【13】If you do need to continue sodium valproate then you must be using reliable contraception, even if you are not currently sexually active. Your doctor or nurse can advise you about reliable contraception. You will be asked to sign a form to say that you are using contraception and understand the risks of becoming pregnant while taking sodium valproate.

【14】It's important to get advice as soon as possible if you think you are pregnant or might become pregnant while taking sodium valproate. However, do not stop taking your medicine suddenly without talking to your doctor first.

【15】Updated: 18 October 2022

【16】2\. Key facts
-------------

【17】*   You'll usually take sodium valproate once or twice a day. You can take it with or without food.
*   You'll usually start on a low dose. Your dose will gradually increase over a few days or weeks.
*   Valproic acid and semisodium valproate are similar to sodium valproate and work in the same way. However these medicines are used to treat different conditions and doses will vary.
*   There are also brands such as Epilim Chrono, Epilim Chronosphere and Dyzantil which contain mostly sodium valproate, with some valproic acid.
*   If you're pregnant, or there's a chance you could become pregnant, sodium valproate is not recommended for treating migraine. For epilepsy and bipolar disorder, your doctor will only prescribe sodium valproate for you if there are no other suitable treatments.

【18】3\. Who can and cannot take sodium valproate
--------------------------------------------

【19】Sodium valproate can be taken by adults and children to treat epilepsy or bipolar disorder.

【20】It can be taken by adults (aged 18 and above) to help prevent migraine.

【21】Sodium valproate is not suitable for girls or women who could become pregnant. However, in some cases it may be the only treatment option available, for example for epilepsy where other treatments have not worked. Girls and women who need to take sodium valproate must be on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【22】To make sure sodium valproate is safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【23】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to sodium valproate or any other medicine
*   have liver problems
*   have a rare metabolic or genetic illness such as porphyria, urea cycle disorder or mitochondrial disorder

【24】4\. How and when to take sodium valproate
-----------------------------------------

【25】Sodium valproate is a prescription medicine. It's important to take it as your doctor tells you.

【26】### Dosage

【27】The usual dose for treating epilepsy in:

【28】*   adults and older children (aged 12 years and over) – 600mg to 2,000mg a day, as 1 dose or split into 2 doses. Some people take a higher dose of 2,500mg a day
*   younger children (aged 1 month to 11 years) – the doctor will use your child's weight to work out the right dose for them

【29】The usual dose for treating bipolar disorder in:

【30】*   adults – 750mg to 2,000mg a day, as 1 dose or split into 2 doses
*   children – the doctor will work out the right dose for your child

【31】The usual dose for preventing migraine in:

【32】*   adults – daily doses vary from a single dose of 400mg to 1,500mg split into 2 doses

【33】If your doctor tells you to take sodium valproate twice a day, you'll usually take half the dose in the morning and half in the evening (to make up your full daily dose).

【34】If you're taking sodium valproate and have kidney problems, your doctor may prescribe a lower dose.

【35】### How to take it

【36】Sodium valproate comes as slow release (prolonged or sustained release) tablets, capsules and granules, gastro-resistant tablets, crushable tablets, and as a liquid.

【37】Slow release medicine passes into your body gradually.

【38】Gastro-resistant tablets release the medicine as soon as it passes through your stomach. This means the sodium valproate is less likely to upset your stomach.

【39】You can take sodium valproate with or without food, but it's best to stick to the same way each time. Do not take it with food some days and without food on other days.

【40】#### How to take slow release tablets and capsules

【41】Swallow these whole with a drink of water or juice. Do not chew them.

【42】You'll usually take them once a day, unless you're on a high dose and your doctor tells you to take your medicine twice a day.

【43】#### How to take slow release granules

【44】Add the granules to a small drink, then stir and swallow it. If you prefer, sprinkle the granules onto any soft food that you can swallow whole. Do not chew the granules.

【45】Your doctor will tell you to take these either once or twice a day.

【46】#### How to take gastro-resistant tablets

【47】Swallow these whole with a drink of water or juice. Do not chew them.

【48】You'll usually take these twice a day.

【49】#### How to take crushable tablets

【50】Crush the tablets using the back of a spoon and mix the powder with some soft food that you can swallow whole. If you prefer, add the powder to a small drink, then stir and swallow it.

【51】You'll usually take this medicine twice a day.

【52】#### How to take liquid

【53】Use the plastic syringe or spoon that comes with your medicine to measure the correct dose. If you do not have one, ask your pharmacist. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as you will not get the right amount.

【54】You'll usually take the liquid twice a day.

【55】### When to take sodium valproate

【56】If you're taking sodium valproate once a day, you can choose a time that suits you. Just try to keep to the same time every day.

【57】If you're taking sodium valproate twice a day, try to leave a gap of 10 to 12 hours between doses. For example you could take your first dose in the morning (between 7am and 8am) and your second dose in the evening (between 7pm and 8pm).

【58】### Will my dose go up or down?

【59】To reduce the chance of side effects, your doctor will start you off on a low dose of sodium valproate. They will increase it gradually over a few days or weeks.

【60】Once you find a dose that suits you, it will usually stay the same, unless your condition changes, or your doctor starts you on a new medicine that may affect sodium valproate.

【61】### What if I forget to take it?

【62】If you've missed a dose, what you do next depends on whether you usually take your medicine once or twice a day.

【63】If you take sodium valproate:

【64】*   **once a day** – take the forgotten dose as soon as you remember unless it's within a few hours of the next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time
*   **twice a day** – take the forgotten dose as soon as you remember unless it's within 2 hours of the next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time

【65】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【66】If you have epilepsy, it's important to take this medicine regularly. Missing doses can trigger a seizure.

【67】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【68】### What if I take too much?

【69】Taking too much sodium valproate can lead to symptoms such as:

【70】*   feeling or being sick (nausea or vomiting)
*   headaches or feeling dizzy
*   muscle weakness
*   breathing problems
*   feeling confused, or changes to your normal behaviour
*   passing out

【71】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【72】*   you take too much sodium valproate and feel unwell

【73】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

【74】If you need to go to A&E, take the sodium valproate packet or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.

【75】5\. Side effects
----------------

【76】Like all medicines, sodium valproate can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【77】### Common side effects

【78】These common side effects may happen in more than 1 in 100 people. They're usually mild and go away by themselves.

【79】Keep taking the medicine but talk to your doctor if these side effects bother you or do not go away:

【80】*   stomach pain, feeling or being sick
*   diarrhoea
*   dry or sore mouth, or swollen gums
*   shakes (tremors) in a part of your body, or unusual eye movements
*   feeling tired or sleepy
*   headache
*   weight gain
*   thinning hair, or changes to the colour or texture of your hair
*   irregular or delayed periods

【81】### Serious side effects

【82】It's unusual to have serious side effects after taking sodium valproate. Tell a doctor straight away if you have:

【83】*   thoughts of harming or killing yourself – a small number of people taking sodium valproate have had suicidal thoughts
*   yellowing of the whites of your eyes or your skin, although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin, and dark pee – these may be signs of liver problems
*   long-lasting and severe nausea, vomiting or stomach pain – these may be signs of acute pancreatitis (an inflamed pancreas)
*   unusual bruises or bleeding – these may be signs of a blood disorder

【84】#### Serious allergic reaction

【85】In rare cases, sodium valproate may cause a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).

【86】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【87】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【88】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【89】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【90】These are not all the side effects of sodium valproate. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【91】Information:

【92】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【93】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【94】6\. How to cope with side effects of sodium valproate
-----------------------------------------------------

【95】**What to do about:**

【96】*   **stomach pain, feeling or being sick** – take sodium valproate with or after a meal or snack. It may also help if you avoid rich or spicy food. Take small, frequent sips of water if you're being sick to avoid dehydration.
*   **diarrhoea** – drink plenty of fluids such as water or squash to avoid dehydration. Speak to a pharmacist if you have signs of dehydration, such as peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.
*   **dry or sore mouth, or swollen gums** – for a dry mouth try sugar-free gum or sweets, or sipping cold drinks. If this does not help, or you have mouth ulcers, talk to your pharmacist or doctor. If you're bothered by swollen gums or this symptom does not go away, talk to your doctor or dentist.
*   **shakes (tremors) in a part of your body, or unusual eye movements** – talk to your doctor if this is bothering you. These symptoms can be a sign that your dose is too high. Talk to your doctor as they may want to change your dose or suggest you take it at a different time.
*   **feeling tired or sleepy** – as your body gets used to sodium valproate, these side effects should wear off. If these symptoms do not get better within a week or two, your doctor may either reduce your dose or increase it more slowly. If that does not work, talk to your doctor as they may want to switch you to a different medicine.
*   **headaches** – make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Talk to your doctor if your headaches last longer than a week or are severe.
*   **weight gain** – if you find you're putting on weight after taking sodium valproate, try to have a healthy balanced diet. Regular exercise will also help you keep your weight stable. Your doctor will usually monitor your weight while you're taking this medicine. Speak to them if you have any concerns.
*   **thinning hair, or changes to the colour or texture of your hair** – if these symptoms bother you, ask your doctor whether it's possible to lower your dose. Your hair may regrow after either reducing your dose or switching to a different medicine.
*   **irregular or delayed periods** – if you usually have regular periods, take a pregnancy test if your period is late, and speak to your doctor if the result is positive. As well as being a side effect of sodium valproate, a late period is a sign that you could be pregnant, and sodium valproate can be harmful for an unborn baby. Changes to your periods can also be a symptom of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), a rare side effect of sodium valproate. Your doctor will be able to do some tests to check whether you have PCOS.

【97】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【98】### Sodium valproate and pregnancy

【99】Sodium valproate is not recommended in pregnancy, as it can cause birth defects and problems with your baby's learning and behaviour.

【100】If there's a chance you could become pregnant while taking this medicine, your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【101】If you think you might already be pregnant, contact your doctor or nurse as soon as possible.

【102】If you're taking sodium valproate for epilepsy or bipolar disorder and you become pregnant, do not stop taking your medicine without talking to your doctor first. This is because your symptoms may get worse.

【103】Your doctor may continue to prescribe sodium valproate, but only if there's no other suitable treatment for your epilepsy or bipolar disorder.

【104】For pregnant women with recurrent migraine your doctor should offer you an alternative treatment to sodium valproate.

【105】Information:

【106】You must have a review of your treatment every year. Contact your doctor or specialist now if you have not had one.

【107】### Sodium valproate and breastfeeding

【108】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy you can take sodium valproate while breastfeeding.

【109】Sodium valproate passes into breast milk in small amounts but it's unlikely to harm your baby so you can continue breastfeeding if your doctor says you need to take it.

【110】If there's a chance you could become pregnant while taking this medicine, your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme. Your doctor may still recommend sodium valproate if it is the only medicine that works for you.

【111】Do not stop taking your medicine without talking to your doctor first as your symptoms may get worse. Breastfeeding will also benefit both you and your baby.

【112】Talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible if:

【113】*   your baby is not feeding as well as usual
*   your baby is bruising more easily than usual
*   the whites of your baby's eyes turn yellow or your baby's skin turns yellow (this may be less obvious on brown or black skin), or your baby has dark pee or pale poo – these can be signs of jaundice

【114】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【115】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【116】### More information

【117】*   Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website – information about how sodium valproate can affect you and your baby during pregnancy
*   NHS England letter to all women and girls aged 12 to 55 taking sodium valproate, available in different languages
*   valproate pregnancy prevention programme patient guide: what women and girls need to know about valproate (PDF, 341kb)

【118】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【119】There are some medicines that may affect how sodium valproate works. Sodium valproate can also affect the way other medicines work.

【120】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines:

【121】*   any other medicines for epilepsy such as carbamazepine
*   medicines for preventing blood clots such as warfarin
*   aspirin for pain relief or low-dose aspirin
*   cimetidine, a medicine for stomach ulcers
*   medicines to treat HIV and AIDS such as ritonavir
*   antibiotics such as erythromycin
*   medicines for depression or other mental health problems such as venlafaxine, quetiapine or diazepam
*   cholesterol-lowering medicines such as cholestyramine
*   medicines to prevent malaria such as mefloquine or chloroquine

【122】### Mixing sodium valproate with herbal remedies or supplements

【123】It's not possible to say whether complementary medicines and herbal supplements are safe to take with sodium valproate.

【124】They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【125】### Important: Medicine safety

【126】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【127】9\. Common questions about sodium valproate
-------------------------------------------

【128】How does sodium valproate work?

【129】Sodium valproate is an anticonvulsant (or anti-epileptic) medicine. It prevents epileptic seizures by reducing excessive electrical activity in your brain.

【130】It's not fully understood how this medicine works for treating bipolar disorder. However, sodium valproate is thought to reduce or prevent manic episodes by increasing the amount of a chemical called gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain. GABA blocks transmission across nerves in the brain and has a calming effect.

【131】It's not clear how sodium valproate prevents migraine. It may limit how your nerves transmit pain signals in the brain.

【132】When will I feel better?

【133】It takes a few weeks for sodium valproate to work properly. You may still have symptoms during this time.

【134】How long will I take it for?

【135】Once your condition is under control, you'll usually need to keep taking sodium valproate for many years.

【136】Can I get addicted to sodium valproate?

【137】Sodium valproate is not known to be addictive.

【138】Is it safe to take it for a long time?

【139】Many people can take sodium valproate safely for many months or years.

【140】However, there are potential side effects that can happen over a long time. Long-term treatment with sodium valproate can cause osteoporosis and osteopenia (increasing your risk of breaking a bone).

【141】Your doctor can arrange for tests to check the strength of your bones. Regular exercise and a good diet can also help to keep your bones strong.

【142】Can I get epilepsy medicines for free?

【143】If you have epilepsy, you're entitled to free prescriptions for all of your medicines (not just your epilepsy ones).

【144】To claim your free prescriptions you'll need a medical exemption certificate.

【145】The application form for the medical exemption certificate is called FP92A. You can get this from your doctor's surgery. You will need to fill in the form, then your doctor will sign it and send it off.

【146】Are there similar medicines to sodium valproate?

【147】Valproic acid and semisodium valproate are very similar to sodium valproate. They work in the same way but these medicines are sometimes given at different doses for different conditions.

【148】If you decide to try valproic acid or semisodium valproate instead, your doctor will explain how to come off sodium valproate safely.

【149】How does it compare with other medicines for epilepsy?

【150】There are many different medicines for treating epilepsy. It's not possible to say that one works better than the others. It varies from person to person and depends on the type of seizures and how often you have them.

【151】Before prescribing a medicine, your doctor will also take into account your age and sex, the medicines you're already taking and any other health problems you have.

【152】It's usual to try to treat epilepsy using a single medicine. If this medicine is not working well, or you're getting side effects, your doctor will try you on a different one.

【153】If a single medicine is not preventing your seizures, then your doctor may recommend taking 2 or more anti-epileptic medicines at the same time.

【154】Sodium valproate works for several different types of epilepsy. If it's giving you side effects, or you're worried it is not suitable for you, ask your doctor or specialist to recommend a different medicine.

【155】Other anti-epileptic medicines include:

【156】*   carbamazepine
*   clobazam
*   ethosuximide
*   gabapentin
*   lamotrigine
*   levetiracetam
*   phenytoin
*   pregabalin
*   topiramate

【157】How does it compare with other medicines for migraine?

【158】For many people topiramate, propranolol and amitriptyline work better than sodium valproate at preventing migraines. These medicines are likely to cause fewer side effects, so your doctor or specialist will usually prescribe one of these first.

【159】Sodium valproate is not used as often for preventing migraine. However, your doctor may recommend it if these other medicines are causing side effects or are not working for you.

【160】Your doctor may also prescribe sodium valproate if you have a health problem that means you cannot take other migraine medicines.

【161】How does sodium valproate compare with other medicines for treating bipolar disorder?

【162】If you have bipolar disorder, there are several types of medicine to prevent mood swings and treat mania. It's not possible to say that one works better than another and it varies from person to person.

【163】Lithium is commonly used for bipolar disorder, as well as anti-epileptic medicines like sodium valproate and antipsychotic medicines like olanzapine. You can take sodium valproate instead of lithium, or together with lithium, depending on what your doctor recommends.

【164】Your doctor or specialist will find the medicines that work best for you. It depends on your mood swings, how often they happen, how severe they are and how well you cope with a medicine.

【165】Do I need to stick to the same brand of sodium valproate?

【166】Once you're on a dose of sodium valproate that suits you, you're likely to keep taking the same type or brand. This is because it can be a problem to swap from modified release to gastro-resistant tablets.

【167】Some people may change brands to try a different type of sodium valproate. For example they may want to try the granules instead of the tablets. If you need to change brand your doctor or pharmacist will explain how to do so safely.

【168】However, if your epilepsy has been difficult to control in the past and the brand you're taking is working well for you, your doctor may recommend staying on the same one.

【169】What will happen when I come off it?

【170】Do not stop taking sodium valproate suddenly, unless your doctor tells you to.

【171】You're unlikely to get any extra symptoms when you stop taking this medicine. However, if you're taking sodium valproate for epilepsy, it's possible that you'll get seizures again once you stop taking it. You can prevent these withdrawal seizures by reducing your dose of sodium valproate gradually.

【172】If you're taking it for bipolar disorder or to prevent migraine, your condition could get worse for a short time after you stop taking the medicine.

【173】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【174】Sodium valproate can affect recreational drugs like cannabis and heroin.

【175】If you use recreational drugs alongside sodium valproate, you may be more likely to have side effects like panic attacks, anxiety and memory loss.

【176】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【177】Drinking alcohol while taking sodium valproate may make you feel sleepy or tired. It's best to stop drinking alcohol during the first few days, until you see how the medicine affects you.

【178】Will it affect my fertility?

【179】Sodium valproate can reduce fertility in both men and women. Once you stop taking this medicine, your fertility will return.

【180】In men sodium valproate has been reported to cause infertility. However, this is rare.

【181】In women it can change your menstrual cycle, causing delayed or missed periods. Sodium valproate has also been reported to cause polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), though this happens rarely.

【182】Talk to your doctor if you're concerned about how sodium valproate may affect your fertility.

【183】Sodium valproate is not recommended if there's a chance you could become pregnant. If you're taking sodium valproate and want to start a family, it's important to talk your doctor as soon as possible. This is because taking sodium valproate while pregnant can harm your baby.

【184】Will it affect my contraception?

【185】Sodium valproate does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【186】If there's a chance you could become pregnant while taking sodium valproate you must use contraception. Your doctor will put you on Prevent, the valproate pregnancy prevention programme.

【187】Speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you have any questions about this programme.

【188】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【189】You may feel sleepy, tired or dizzy when you first start taking sodium valproate. This may also happen if your dose has increased. If you're affected, do not drive or ride a bike until you feel more alert.

【190】If you have epilepsy, you're not allowed to drive until you've had no seizures for 1 year (or only have seizures while you're asleep).

【191】If you change your epilepsy medicine, your doctor will tell you whether you need to stop driving and for how long.

【192】Information:

【193】Driving rules if you change or withdraw your medicine, Epilepsy Action

【194】Epilepsy and driving information, GOV.UK

【195】Related conditions
------------------

【196】*   Bipolar disorder
*   Epilepsy
*   Migraine

【197】Useful resources
----------------

【198】*   NHS England letter to all women and girls of taking sodium valproate. Available in different languages
*   HealthUnlocked: sodium valproate forum
*   Bipolar UK: charity
*   Epilepsy Action: charity
*   Migraine Trust: charity
*   Mind: mental health charity
*   Healthtalk: videos of personal stories about epilepsy
*   Healthtalk: videos of personal stories about epilepsy in young people

【199】Page last reviewed: 24 August 2021  
Next review due: 24 August 2024

source_info.title: Skin picking disorder
source_info.text:
【0】Skin picking disorder
=====================

【1】**Also called dermatillomania or excoriation disorder, skin picking disorder is where you cannot stop picking at your skin. There are things you can try to help yourself, but some people may need professional treatment.**

【2】Check if you have skin picking disorder
---------------------------------------

【3】Most people pick at their skin from time to time, but you may have skin picking disorder if you:

【4】*   cannot stop picking your skin
*   cause cuts, bleeding or bruising by picking your skin
*   pick moles, freckles, spots or scars to try to "smooth" or "perfect" them
*   do not always realise you're picking your skin or do it when you're asleep
*   pick your skin when you feel anxious or stressed

【5】You may pick your skin with your fingers, fingernails, teeth or with tools like tweezers, pins or scissors.

【6】Things you can try if you have skin picking disorder
----------------------------------------------------

【7】### Do

【8】*   keep your hands busy – try squeezing a soft ball or putting on gloves

【9】*   identify when and where you most commonly pick your skin and try to avoid these triggers

【10】*   try to resist for longer and longer each time you feel the urge to pick

【11】*   care for your skin when you get the urge to pick it – for example, by applying moisturiser

【12】*   tell other people – they can help you recognise when you're picking

【13】*   keep your skin clean to avoid infection

【14】### Don’t

【15】*   do not let your nails grow long – keep them trimmed

【16】*   do not keep things like tweezers and pins where you can easily get at them

【17】### Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:

【18】*   you cannot stop picking your skin
*   you're causing serious damage to your skin by picking it, like cuts that do not heal within a few days
*   picking your skin is causing you emotional distress or affecting your daily life

【19】### What happens at your appointment

【20】A GP will ask you about your skin picking behaviour and look at your skin.

【21】If they think you have skin picking disorder, they may refer you to a specialist for diagnosis and possible treatment.

【22】This could be with a type of talking therapy or medicine.

【23】They may also refer you to a skin specialist (dermatologist) if your skin is badly damaged or you have any underlying skin conditions that may be triggering your skin picking, like acne or eczema.

【24】Treatment for skin picking disorder
-----------------------------------

【25】### Talking therapy for skin picking disorder

【26】Talking therapy is currently thought to be an effective treatment to help change skin picking behaviour.

【27】If you're offered this, it'll usually be given through community mental health services.

【28】The most common type of talking therapy offered for skin picking disorder is cognitive behavioural therapy, and may include a technique called habit reversal training.

【29】Habit reversal training works by helping you:

【30】*   recognise and be more aware of your skin picking and what's triggering it
*   replace skin picking with a less harmful behaviour

【31】### Medicines for skin picking disorder

【32】Your doctors may recommend some types of medicine to help you control your skin picking behaviour.

【33】This may be prescribed by a GP, but more often it'll be prescribed by a specialist (psychiatrist).

【34】Causes of skin picking disorder
-------------------------------

【35】Skin picking disorder is related to obsessive compulsive disorder, where the person cannot stop themselves carrying out a particular action.

【36】It can be triggered by:

【37】*   boredom
*   stress or anxiety
*   negative emotions, such as guilt or shame
*   skin conditions, such as acne or eczema
*   other blemishes that the person wants to get rid of (these may not be noticeable to other people)

【38】It's sometimes called a body-focused repetitive behaviour and is similar to repetitive hair pulling disorder (trichotillomania).

【39】It's also related to other obsessive compulsive disorders, such as body dysmorphic disorder, where the person is excessively preoccupied with their appearance.

【40】People with skin picking disorder often also have other obsessive compulsive disorders. These may require their own assessment and treatment.

【41】Page last reviewed: 24 March 2021  
Next review due: 24 March 2024

-----------------------------------

【25】### Talking therapy for skin picking disorder

【26】Talking therapy is currently thought to be an effective treatment to help change skin picking behaviour.

【27】If you're offered this, it'll usually be given through community mental health services.

【28】The most common type of talking therapy offered for skin picking disorder is cognitive behavioural therapy, and may include a technique called habit reversal training.

【29】Habit reversal training works by helping you:

【30】*   recognise and be more aware of your skin picking and what's triggering it
*   replace skin picking with a less harmful behaviour

【31】### Medicines for skin picking disorder

【32】Your doctors may recommend some types of medicine to help you control your skin picking behaviour.

【33】This may be prescribed by a GP, but more often it'll be prescribed by a specialist (psychiatrist).

【34】Causes of skin picking disorder
-------------------------------

【35】Skin picking disorder is related to obsessive compulsive disorder, where the person cannot stop themselves carrying out a particular action.

【36】It can be triggered by:

【37】*   boredom
*   stress or anxiety
*   negative emotions, such as guilt or shame
*   skin conditions, such as acne or eczema
*   other blemishes that the person wants to get rid of (these may not be noticeable to other people)

【38】It's sometimes called a body-focused repetitive behaviour and is similar to repetitive hair pulling disorder (trichotillomania).

【39】It's also related to other obsessive compulsive disorders, such as body dysmorphic disorder, where the person is excessively preoccupied with their appearance.

【40】People with skin picking disorder often also have other obsessive compulsive disorders. These may require their own assessment and treatment.

【41】Page last reviewed: 24 March 2021  
Next review due: 24 March 2024

source_info.title: Contraceptive injections (medroxyprogesterone)
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections \- Brand names: Depo-Provera, Sayana Press
=======================================================================================================

【1】Like all medicines, medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections can cause side effects although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Headaches

【5】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【6】Talk to your doctor if headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【7】Stomach pain

【8】Try to rest and relax. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Putting a heat pad or covered hot water bottle on your stomach may also help. If you're in a lot of pain, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【9】Feeling bloated

【10】Try not to eat foods that cause wind (like lentils, peas, beans and onions). Eat smaller meals, eat and drink slowly, and exercise regularly. There are pharmacy medicines that can also help, such as charcoal tablets or simeticone. Speak to a pharmacist for advice.

【11】Feeling sick (nausea)

【12】It may help if you avoid rich or spicy food.

【13】If it does not go away or it's severe, tell your doctor. They may be able to prescribe an extra medicine to help with this side effect.

【14】Feeling nervous or depressed

【15】Talk to your doctor if you have problems with mood changes and it does not improve.

【16】Changes to your periods

【17】Talk to your doctor if you have irregular bleeding, or bleeding after you have not had a period for a while. They may be able to prescribe medicine to help, or arrange for extra tests if you need them.

【18】Weight gain or weight loss

【19】You may lose weight when having medroxyprogesterone injections, but it's more common to gain weight. This is often a small amount.

【20】Eating a healthy, balanced diet and regular exercise will help you keep to a healthy weight.

【21】Lower sex drive

【22】Speak to your doctor if you have problems with your sex drive (loss of libido). You may need to consider using a different contraceptive.

【23】Feeling dizzy

【24】Stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Do not drive, cycle or use tools or machinery if you're feeling dizzy.

【25】Breast tenderness

【26】Try to wear a well-fitting and comfortable bra.

【27】Back pain

【28】Try taking a painkiller, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen.

【29】Feeling tired or weak

【30】Try to get plenty of rest. Do not drive, cycle or use tools or machinery if you're feeling tired. Do not drink alcohol as it will make you feel worse.

【31】Itchy skin

【32】It may help to take an antihistamine which you can buy from a pharmacy. Check with the pharmacist to see what type is suitable for you.

【33】Acne

【34】Wash with a mild soap or cleanser and lukewarm water. Avoid using too much make-up and cosmetics. Speak to a pharmacist for advice about treating acne.

【35】Hair loss

【36】Thinning hair or mild hair loss can be stressful but it is not usually a sign of anything to worry about. Talk to your pharmacist or doctor if you're concerned. Some hair loss treatments are available.

【37】Fluid retention such as swollen ankles

【38】Raise your legs when you're sitting down. Try not to stand for a long time.

【39】If it does not improve or you're also short of breath, talk to your doctor.

【40】Changes to vaginal discharge

【41】Changes including an increase in vaginal discharge are common and are not usually anything to worry about. Talk to your doctor if your discharge changes in smell, colour or texture, as it might be a sign of an infection.

【42】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【43】Serious side effects
--------------------

【44】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【45】Call your doctor or call 111 now if:

【46】*   you have a high temperature or feel cold and shivery, get a burning feeling when peeing, have pain in your back or side, or blood in your pee – these can be signs of a urinary tract infection (UTI)
*   you get pain, swelling, redness and warmth in a leg or arm – this could be a sign of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
*   you get a red painful lump or swelling where you had the injection – this could be a sign of an injection site abscess or infection and it will need to be treated straight away before the infection gets worse
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin, or if you have pale poo and dark pee – these can be signs of liver problems
*   you get blurred vision or double vision – this could be a sign of a build-up of fluid in your eye (oedema)

【47】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【48】*   you're suddenly short of breath or get a sharp pain in your chest and a cough, or you're coughing up blood – these may be signs of a blood clot in your lungs
*   you lose vision suddenly in one or both eyes – this could be a sign of a blood clot

【49】Find your nearest A&E

【50】### Serious allergic reaction

【51】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to a medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injection.

【52】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【53】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【54】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【55】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【56】Long-term side effects
----------------------

【57】If you have medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections for a long time, your bones may become weaker or more fragile (osteoporosis).

【58】To help prevent this, try exercising regularly, and make sure you get enough calcium in your diet to help strengthen your bones. Milk, cheese and leafy greens contain lots of calcium.

【59】Other side effects
------------------

【60】These are not all the side effects of medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【61】Information:

【62】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【63】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【64】More in Contraceptive injections (medroxyprogesterone)
------------------------------------------------------

【65】*   About medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections
*   Who can and cannot have them
*   How and when to have them
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy and breastfeeding
*   Having them with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【66】Page last reviewed: 20 April 2023  
Next review due: 20 April 2026

source_info.title: Rivaroxaban
source_info.text:
【0】Taking rivaroxaban with other medicines and herbal supplements
==============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines can affect how rivaroxaban works. This can lead to serious side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start taking rivaroxaban:

【4】*   any other anticoagulant, such as warfarin or enoxaparin
*   medicines to treat fungal or bacterial infections, such as fluconazole, erythromycin, clarithromycin or rifampicin
*   medicines to treat HIV, such as ritonavir
*   medicines to treat epilepsy, such as carbamazepine, phenytoin or phenobarbital
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen or aspirin

【5】Taking rivaroxaban with everyday painkillers
--------------------------------------------

【6】You can take paracetamol while you're taking rivaroxaban.

【7】Do not take aspirin or ibuprofen while you're taking rivaroxaban unless a doctor has said it's OK. They increase the chance of bleeding.

【8】Mixing rivaroxaban with herbal remedies and supplements
-------------------------------------------------------

【9】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're taking rivaroxaban. It can increase your risk of side effects.

【10】There's not enough information to say that other herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with rivaroxaban. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines.

【11】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【12】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【13】More in Rivaroxaban
-------------------

【14】*   About rivaroxaban
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking rivaroxaban with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【15】Page last reviewed: 15 March 2022  
Next review due: 15 March 2025

source_info.title: Molar pregnancy
source_info.text:
【0】Molar pregnancy
===============

【1】**A molar pregnancy is when there's a problem with a fertilised egg, which means a baby and a placenta do not develop the way they should after conception. A molar pregnancy will not be able to survive. It happens by chance and is rare.**

【2】Finding out you have a molar pregnancy
--------------------------------------

【3】A molar pregnancy may not have any symptoms, or you may have some symptoms of pregnancy.

【4】You may find out about a molar pregnancy during your 1st pregnancy ultrasound scan at around 8 to 14 weeks.

【5】Some people find out after their pregnancy ends with a miscarriage.

【6】Urgent advice: Call a midwife or GP if:
---------------------------------------

【7】You're pregnant and:

【8】*   you have any bleeding or a dark discharge from your vagina
*   you're feeling or being sick often (severe morning sickness)
*   you think your bump looks bigger than it should for your stage of pregnancy
*   you have any other symptoms you're worried about

【9】Tests for a molar pregnancy
---------------------------

【10】If a midwife or doctor thinks you have a molar pregnancy, you'll need:

【11】*   blood tests to check your level of the pregnancy hormone hCG, which is usually higher than normal in a molar pregnancy
*   an ultrasound scan
*   an appointment with a specialist (gynaecologist) or at an early pregnancy assessment unit

【12】Finding out you have a molar pregnancy can be very difficult. A doctor or midwife can give you advice about the support that's available.

【13】Treatment for a molar pregnancy
-------------------------------

【14】A molar pregnancy will not be able to survive.

【15】It may end on its own, with a miscarriage.

【16】If this does not happen, it's usually treated with a procedure to remove the pregnancy.

【17】You'll usually be given a general anaesthetic before the procedure, so you'll be asleep.

【18】Sometimes you might be able to take medicine to end a molar pregnancy.

【19】### Follow-up care

【20】After treatment for a molar pregnancy you'll have regular blood and urine tests to check your hCG hormone level is returning to normal.

【21】If your hormone level does not return to normal you'll need further treatment.

【22】Sex, contraception, and trying for a baby after a molar pregnancy
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【23】You can have sex as soon as you feel ready, but it's important to use contraception while you're getting follow-up care. Talk to a GP about what type of contraception is right for you.

【24】Having a molar pregnancy does not affect your chances of getting pregnant again. But it's important to wait until your doctor tells you it's safe before you start trying for a baby.

【25】Causes of a molar pregnancy
---------------------------

【26】A molar pregnancy happens by chance. It's not caused by either parent doing something wrong.

【27】You may be more likely to have a molar pregnancy if:

【28】*   you're a young teenager or over 45 years old when you get pregnant
*   you've had a molar pregnancy before
*   you have an Asian background

【29】Types of molar pregnancy
------------------------

【30】A molar pregnancy is sometimes called a hydatidiform mole.

【31】There are 2 types of molar pregnancy:

【32】*   a complete molar pregnancy – this is where abnormal cells grow in the womb after conception and there's no sign of a baby
*   a partial molar pregnancy – this is where there may be early signs of a baby, but it cannot fully develop or survive

【33】Where to find help and support for a molar pregnancy
----------------------------------------------------

【34】It can take time to recover after a molar pregnancy, both physically and emotionally.

【35】The specialists looking after you can give you advice if you need support. They may be able to recommend support services in your area.

【36】You can also get more information and support from:

【37】*   Molar Pregnancy Support & Information
*   Miscarriage Association
*   Tommy's: molar pregnancy – information and support
*   Charing Cross Hospital Trophoblast Disease Service

【38】Page last reviewed: 19 June 2023  
Next review due: 19 June 2026

text.text:

【32】*   a complete molar pregnancy – this is where abnormal cells grow in the womb after conception and there's no sign of a baby
*   a partial molar pregnancy – this is where there may be early signs of a baby, but it cannot fully develop or survive

【33】Where to find help and support for a molar pregnancy
----------------------------------------------------

【34】It can take time to recover after a molar pregnancy, both physically and emotionally.

【35】The specialists looking after you can give you advice if you need support. They may be able to recommend support services in your area.

【36】You can also get more information and support from:

【37】*   Molar Pregnancy Support & Information
*   Miscarriage Association
*   Tommy's: molar pregnancy – information and support
*   Charing Cross Hospital Trophoblast Disease Service
