source_info.title: Kyphosis
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Kyphosis
====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment

【3】**Kyphosis is curvature of the spine that causes the top of the back to appear more rounded than normal.**

【4】Everyone has some degree of curvature in their spine. However, a curve of more than 45 degrees is considered excessive.

【5】Sometimes kyphosis doesn't cause any symptoms other than the back appearing abnormally curved or hunched. However, in some cases the condition causes:

【6】*   back pain and stiffness
*   tenderness of the spine
*   tiredness

【7】Back pain can be particularly problematic in adults with kyphosis because the body has to compensate for the spinal abnormality.

【8】If you have severe kyphosis, your symptoms may get worse over time. You may also have difficulty breathing and eating.

【9】What causes kyphosis?
---------------------

【10】In kyphosis, the normal curve in the middle section of vertebral column (the thoracic vertebrae) is more curved than normal. There are a number of reasons why this might happen, including:

【11】*   poor posture (postural kyphosis) – slouching, leaning back in chairs and carrying heavy bags can stretch supporting muscles and ligaments, which can increase spinal curvature
*   abnormally shaped vertebrae (Scheuermann's kyphosis) – if the vertebrae don't develop properly, they can end up being out of position
*   abnormal development of the spine in the womb (congenital kyphosis) – if something disrupts the spine's normal development, two or more vertebrae sometimes fuse together
*   age – as people get older, their spinal curvature can increase

【12】Kyphosis can also develop as a result of a spinal injury.

【13】Read more about the causes of kyphosis.

【14】Treating kyphosis
-----------------

【15】If you have kyphosis, your treatment depends on how curved your spine is, whether you have any additional symptoms such as back pain, and the underlying causes.

【16】Children with kyphosis may be able to be treated using non-surgical methods, such as bracing, to limit the progression of kyphosis as they grow. Treatment for mild kyphosis may not be necessary.

【17】Kyphosis rarely requires surgical treatment. It's only needed in some severe cases to correct the curvature of the spine.

【18】Read more about treatment for kyphosis.

【19】Emotional issues
----------------

【20】Older children with kyphosis may become concerned or embarrassed about the effect the condition has on their appearance, or having to wear a back brace.

【21】These concerns can affect different children in different ways. Some children can become socially withdrawn and may be reluctant to take part in activities, such as PE, where their condition may be exposed.

【22】There are no easy answers to these problems, but it can sometimes help to reassure your child that their feelings will improve with time.

【23】Complications
-------------

【24】Complications of kyphosis usually only occur in more severe cases. They include:

【25】*   persistent pain
*   breathing difficulties caused by the spine compressing the lungs and airways

【26】Occasionally, people with kyphosis can have difficulties when the nerves running through the spine become compressed or pinched. This can disrupt nerve signals and cause symptoms such as:

【27】*   numbness or weakness in the arms and legs
*   problems with sense of balance
*   loss of normal bladder or bowel control

【28】These serious complications require urgent medical attention and surgery would usually be recommended.

【29】Can kyphosis be prevented?
--------------------------

【30】Postural kyphosis can be prevented by being aware of your posture and by taking care of your back. You should encourage your child to:

【31】*   avoid slouching
*   sit correctly – sit upright, ensuring that all of the back is supported
*   avoid carrying heavy schoolbags and if using backpacks ensure they are well designed and used properly
*   take regular exercise to help strengthen the back and keep it flexible; activities such as swimming, running, walking and yoga are ideal for helping to prevent back problems

【32】**Further information:**

【33】*   Physical activity guidelines for children under 5 years of age
*   Physical activity guidelines for children and young people

【34】Page last reviewed: 12 May 2022  
Next review due: 12 May 2025

【35】*   Next : Causes

source_info.title: Bumetanide
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take bumetanide
===============================

【1】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【2】Bumetanide is available as 1mg and 5mg tablets and a liquid containing 1mg in 5ml.

【3】The usual dose for adults to treat heart failure or a build up of fluid in the body (oedema) is 1mg to 10mg a day.

【4】If you are over 65 your doctor may give you a lower dose.

【5】For babies and children, your doctor will use your child's weight or age to work out the right dose.

【6】How to take it
--------------

【7】You'll usually take bumetanide once a day in the morning or afternoon. If your doctor prescribes it twice a day, take it once in the morning and again in the afternoon.

【8】You do not need to take bumetanide at the same time every day. You can occasionally take it at a different time if it's more convenient for you. For example, you could take it later if you need to go out for a few hours in the morning and will not be near a toilet.

【9】Do not take bumetanide too late in the day (after 4pm) or at night, otherwise you may have to wake up to go to the toilet. Your pharmacist or doctor will advise the best times for you to take your medicine.

【10】You can take bumetanide with or without food. Swallow the tablets whole with a drink of water.

【11】If you're taking bumetanide as a liquid, it will come with a plastic spoon or syringe to help you measure the correct amount. If you do not have one, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not measure the right amount.

【12】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【13】Depending on the reason why you're taking bumetanide, you may have to take it for a long time, even for the rest of your life.

【14】**If you get ill while taking it**
----------------------------------

【15】Contact your doctor if:

【16】*   you're ill with a a high temperature
*   you're sweating and shaking
*   you're being sick (vomiting) or have severe diarrhoea

【17】Your doctor may recommend you stop taking bumetanide for 1 to 2 days until you are better. You can start taking it again when you're eating and drinking normally.

【18】If you take bumetanide when you have an illness that makes you dehydrated, it can make the dehydration worse.

【19】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【20】Take your forgotten dose as soon as you remember, unless it is after 4pm. If this happens, leave out the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【21】Do not take 2 doses to make up for a forgotten dose.

【22】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicines.

【23】Stopping bumetanide
-------------------

【24】Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking bumetanide. Stopping it may cause fluid to build up in your body.

【25】If you're bothered by side effects, your doctor may be able to prescribe you a different medicine.

【26】If you take too much
--------------------

【27】Taking too much bumetanide can cause headaches, make you feel dizzy, give you a pounding or irregular heartbeat, make you faint, and make you feel thirsty.

【28】The amount of bumetanide that can lead to an overdose varies from person to person.

【29】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【30】you take more than your prescribed dose of bumetanide. This is very important if you:

【31】*   feel unwell
*   are over 65 (even if you feel well)
*   have liver, kidney or heart problems (even if you feel well)

【32】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

【33】If you need advice for a child under the age of 5, call 111.

【34】If you have to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you. Take the bumetanide packet, and the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine with you.

【35】More in Bumetanide
------------------

【36】*   About bumetanide
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking bumetanide with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【37】Page last reviewed: 7 February 2022  
Next review due: 7 February 2025

source_info.title: Long QT syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Long QT syndrome
================

【1】**Long QT syndrome is an inherited heart problem that affects how your heart beats. In some people, this can cause fainting or fits (seizures).**

【2】Symptoms of long QT syndrome
----------------------------

【3】Some people with long QT syndrome do not have any symptoms. They may only become aware of their condition after having an electrocardiogram (ECG) for another reason.

【4】Those who do have symptoms usually have:

【5】*   **blackouts or** **fainting**, because the heart has stopped pumping blood properly and the brain is temporarily starved of oxygen – the heart's rhythm returns to normal within a few minutes and the person regains consciousness
*   **seizures**, which sometimes happen instead of a blackout when the brain is starved of oxygen
*   **heart palpitations**, when the heart is beating in a fast or unpredictable way

【6】These symptoms can start unexpectedly and may be triggered by:

【7】*   stress
*   a sudden noise – such as an alarm
*   strenuous exercise – particularly swimming
*   a slow heart rate during sleep

【8】### Risk of death

【9】The heart usually returns to its normal rhythm after it's been beating abnormally.

【10】But if it continues to beat abnormally and is not treated in time with a defibrillator, the heart will stop pumping and the person will die. This is called cardiac arrest, and the heart rarely returns to normal if it is not electrically corrected with shock.

【11】**Call 999 for an ambulance if someone with long QT syndrome suddenly collapses and does not regain consciousness. If you're able to, perform** **cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)** **until medical help arrives.**

【12】Long QT syndrome is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young, otherwise healthy, people. It can also be an underlying cause of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

【13】Causes of long QT syndrome
--------------------------

【14】Long QT syndrome is usually caused by a faulty gene inherited from a parent. The abnormal gene affects the heart's electrical activity.

【15】Certain medicines can also trigger long QT syndrome, including some types of:

【16】*   antibiotics
*   antihistamines
*   antidepressants
*   antipsychotics
*   diuretics
*   heart medicines

【17】But drug-induced long QT syndrome tends to only affect people who already have a tendency to develop the condition.

【18】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information, see Cardiac Risk in the Young: medicines people with long QT syndrome should avoid.</u>

【19】Diagnosing long QT syndrome
---------------------------

【20】A GP may recommend you have an ECG and refer you to a heart specialist (cardiologist) if:

【21】*   you have long QT syndrome
*   you have blackouts during exercise
*   you have a family history of unexpected and unexplained sudden death

【22】An ECG records your heart's rhythm and electrical activity. If you have long QT syndrome, the trace of the QT section (showing part of the heartbeat) will be longer than normal. Sometimes an exercise ECG will be needed to confirm the diagnosis.

【23】Genetic testing may be needed to identify the faulty gene causing long QT syndrome. It can also help identify other family members who may have inherited the faulty gene and need clinical assessment.

【24】Treating long QT syndrome 
--------------------------

【25】Most people with inherited long QT syndrome will need treatment with medicines. Beta blockers, such as propranolol or nadolol, may be prescribed to help control irregular heartbeats and slow down your heart rate.

【26】If your symptoms are frequent or severe, and you have a high risk of having a life-threatening arrhythmia, you may need to have a pacemaker or implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) fitted.

【27】In some cases of long QT syndrome, surgery may be needed to control the flow of chemicals into the heart. This is known as a sympathectomy.

【28】If medicines are causing long QT syndrome, your medicines will be reviewed and an alternative may be prescribed.

【29】Living with long QT syndrome
----------------------------

【30】With the right treatment, it's possible to avoid long QT syndrome having a major impact on your day-to-day life. However, you may need to make some lifestyle adjustments to reduce your risk of having blackouts.

【31】For example, you may not be able to exercise strenuously or play competitive sports, and may need to try to avoid startling noises, such as alarm clocks. Avoiding stressful situations may also be recommended.

【32】Rehydrating properly after a tummy upset is also essential, usually with supplements containing salt and sugar.

【33】Your doctor may prescribe potassium supplements or suggest increasing the amount of potassium-rich foods in your diet. Good sources of potassium include:

【34】*   bananas
*   vegetables
*   pulses
*   nuts and seeds
*   milk
*   fish
*   shellfish
*   beef
*   chicken
*   turkey
*   bread

【35】Always tell medical staff that you have long QT syndrome. Any new medicine, whether prescription or over the counter, will need to be carefully checked to see if it's suitable for you.

【36】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information you can get a booklet about life with inherited abnormal heart rhythms from the British Heart Foundation.</u>

【37】Page last reviewed: 26 October 2020  
Next review due: 26 October 2023

source_info.title: Spironolactone
source_info.text:
【0】Taking spironolactone with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Aldactone
==========================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines affect spironolactone and stop it working properly or increase the chances of you having side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines:

【4】*   eplerenone, a medicine used to treat high blood pressure which works in a similar way to spironolactone
*   other diuretics – do not take diuretics that increase potassium levels (such as amiloride) with spironolactone. You can take other diuretics (such as furosemide) with spironolactone if your doctor recommends it
*   other medicines that increase your potassium levels. Examples include some medicines that help to prevent blood clots, such as enoxaparin, and some antibiotics, such as trimethoprim
*   ACE inhibitors, used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure, such as ramipril, lisinopril, perindopril or enalapril
*   digoxin, a medicine used to treat an irregular heartbeat
*   painkillers known as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), including diclofenac, ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

【5】Mixing spironolactone with medicines that you buy from a pharmacy or shop
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

【6】Do not take NSAIDs such as ibuprofen with spironolactone unless your doctor says it's OK.

【7】Some products to help symptoms of indigestion and urinary tract infections (UTIs) contain potassium, and may not be suitable while you're taking spironolactone. Speak to a pharmacist or doctor to see if these medicines are safe to take with spironolactone.

【8】Mixing spironolactone with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------------

【9】Do not take supplements that are high in potassium, such as Sando K tablets or Kay-Cee-L syrup. Taking these with spironolactone can cause your potassium levels to become too high.

【10】There's very little information about taking other herbal remedies and supplements with spironolactone. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【11】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【12】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【13】More in Spironolactone
----------------------

【14】*   About spironolactone
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking spironolactone with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【15】Page last reviewed: 6 July 2022  
Next review due: 6 July 2025

source_info.title: Edoxaban
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take edoxaban
=============================

【1】It's important to take edoxaban as your doctor has told you.

【2】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【3】Edoxaban comes as 15mg, 30mg and 60mg tablets.

【4】The usual dose of edoxaban is 60mg, taken once a day. Your doctor may prescribe a lower dose of 30mg a day if you:

【5】*   have kidney disease
*   have a low body weight
*   are taking ciclosporin
*   are taking dronedarone (to treat atrial fibrillation)
*   are taking erythromycin or ketoconazole

【6】If you're unsure what dose you need to take, check with your pharmacist or doctor.

【7】How to take it
--------------

【8】Swallow the tablet with a drink of water.

【9】You can take edoxaban with or without food but try to take it at the same time every day.

【10】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【11】How long you need to take edoxaban will depend on why you're taking it.

【12】If you've had a blood clot (deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism) you'll normally take edoxaban for at least 3 months. Depending on what caused the blood clot, you might need to take it for longer.

【13】If you have atrial fibrillation you might need to take edoxaban long term or even for the rest of your life.

【14】Do not stop taking edoxaban without talking to your doctor. If you stop taking it you may be at increased risk of serious health problems caused by blood clots.

【15】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【16】If you forget a dose of edoxaban, take your tablet as soon as you remember. If you only remember the following day, leave out the forgotten dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【17】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【18】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to remember to take your medicines.

【19】If you take too much
--------------------

【20】Taking too much edoxaban puts you at risk of bleeding.

【21】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【22】*   you take more than your prescribed dose of edoxaban

【23】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【24】Anticoagulant alert card
------------------------

【25】Your doctor or pharmacist will give you an anticoagulant alert card. Carry this with you all the time. It tells healthcare professionals that you're taking an anticoagulant. This can be useful for them to know in case of a medical emergency.

【26】If you need any medical or dental treatment, show your anticoagulant alert card to the nurse, doctor or dentist. This includes before you have vaccinations and routine sessions with the dental hygienist.

【27】Your doctor may advise you to stop taking edoxaban or reduce your dose for a short time.

【28】Switching from warfarin to edoxaban
-----------------------------------

【29】If you need to switch from warfarin to edoxaban, your doctor will advise you when to stop taking warfarin. This will probably be a few days before you start edoxaban.

【30】Your doctor or anticoagulant clinic will do a blood test called the international normalised ratio (INR) to check how quickly your blood's clotting. This is to help decide exactly when you should start taking edoxaban.

【31】Switching from edoxaban to warfarin
-----------------------------------

【32】If you need to switch from edoxaban to warfarin, you may need to take both medicines together for a few days.

【33】Your doctor or anticoagulant clinic will do a blood test called the international normalised ratio (INR) to check how quickly your blood's clotting. This is to help decide exactly when you should stop taking edoxaban.

【34】More in Edoxaban
----------------

【35】*   About edoxaban
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking edoxaban with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【36】Page last reviewed: 15 March 2022  
Next review due: 15 March 2025

source_info.title: Esomeprazole
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take esomeprazole
====================================

【1】Who can take esomeprazole
-------------------------

【2】Esomeprazole can be taken by most adults. Children should only have esomeprazole if a doctor prescribes it.

【3】Who may not be able to take esomeprazole
----------------------------------------

【4】Esomeprazole is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to esomeprazole or any other medicine
*   have liver problems
*   are due to have an endoscopy

【6】If you're going to have an endoscopy, ask your doctor if you should stop taking esomeprazole a few weeks before your procedure. This is because esomeprazole may hide some of the problems that would usually be spotted during an endoscopy.

【7】More in Esomeprazole
--------------------

【8】*   About esomeprazole
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking esomeprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【9】Page last reviewed: 7 January 2022  
Next review due: 7 January 2025

source_info.title: Naproxen
source_info.text:
【0】About naproxen
==============

【1】Naproxen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It reduces swelling (inflammation) and pain in joints and muscles.

【2】It's used to treat:

【3】*   rheumatoid arthritis
*   osteoarthritis
*   gout
*   period pain
*   muscle and bone disorders, such as back pain and sprains and strains

【4】Naproxen is available on prescription as tablets or as a liquid that you swallow.

【5】Key facts
---------

【6】*   Take naproxen with or just after a meal or snack.
*   Take the lowest dose of naproxen for the shortest time to control your symptoms.
*   The most common side effects of naproxen are confusion, headache, ringing in the ears, changes in vision, tiredness, drowsiness, dizziness and rashes.
*   For strains and sprains, some doctors recommend waiting 48 hours before taking naproxen because it may slow down healing. If you're unsure, speak to a doctor.
*   If you're taking naproxen for a long time or at risk of getting a stomach ulcer, your doctor may prescribe a medicine, such as omeprazole or lansoprazole, to protect your stomach.

【7】More in Naproxen
----------------

【8】*   About naproxen
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking naproxen with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【9】Page last reviewed: 20 January 2022  
Next review due: 20 January 2025

source_info.title: Benign brain tumour (non-cancerous)
source_info.text:
【0】Recovery \- Benign brain tumour (non-cancerous)
===============================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Recovery

【3】**After being treated for a benign (non-cancerous) brain tumour, you may need additional care to monitor and treat any further problems.**

【4】Follow-up appointments
----------------------

【5】Non-cancerous brain tumours can sometimes grow back after treatment, so you'll have regular follow-up appointments to check for signs of this.

【6】Your appointments may include a discussion of any new symptoms you experience, a physical examination, and, occasionally, a brain scan.

【7】It's likely you'll have follow-up appointments at least every few months to start with, but they'll probably be needed less frequently if no problems develop.

【8】Side effects of treatment
-------------------------

【9】Some people who have had a brain tumour can develop side effects of treatment months or years later, such as:

【10】*   cataracts
*   problems with thinking, memory, language or judgement
*   epilepsy
*   hearing loss
*   infertility
*   migraine attacks
*   a tumour developing somewhere else
*   numbness, pain, weakness or loss of vision resulting from nerve damage (but these complications are rare)
*   a stroke (this is rare)

【11】If you or someone you care for has any worrying symptoms that develop after brain tumour treatment, see your doctor.

【12】If you think it's a stroke, dial 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance.

【13】Supportive treatment
--------------------

【14】Problems caused by a brain tumour do not always resolve as soon as the tumour is removed or treated.

【15】For example, some people have persistent weakness, epileptic fits (seizures), difficulty walking and speech problems.

【16】Extra support may be needed to help you overcome or adapt to any problems you have.

【17】This may include therapies such as:

【18】*   **physiotherapy** to help with any movement problems you have
*   **occupational therapy** to identify any problems you're having with daily activities, and arrange for any equipment or alterations to your home that may help
*   **speech and language therapy** to help you with communication or swallowing problems

【19】Some people may also need to continue taking medicine for seizures for a few months or more after their tumour has been treated or removed.

【20】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has made recommendations about the standards of care people with brain tumours should receive.

【21】See the NICE guidance about improving outcomes for people with brain and other central nervous system tumours.

【22】Driving and travelling
----------------------

【23】You may not be allowed to drive for a while after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.

【24】How long you'll be unable to drive will depend on factors such as:

【25】*   whether you have had epileptic fits (seizures)
*   the type of brain tumour you have
*   where it is in your brain
*   what symptoms you have
*   what type of surgery you have had

【26】If you're unsure whether or not you should be driving, do not drive until you have had clarification from the DVLA, your GP or specialist. 

【27】Driving against medical advice is both dangerous and against the law.

【28】If you need to give up your driving licence, the DVLA will speak to your GP or specialist to determine when you can drive again.

【29】With up-to-date scans and advice from your medical team, you may be allowed to drive after an agreed period.

【30】This is usually after you have successfully completed medical tests to determine your ability to control a vehicle, and when the risk of having seizures is low.

【31】The Cancer Research UK website has more information about brain tumours and driving.

【32】Flying is usually possible when you have recovered from surgery, but you should let your travel insurance company know about your condition.

【33】Lifestyle advice
----------------

【34】If you have had radiotherapy, it's important to follow a healthy lifestyle to lower your risk of stroke.

【35】This means stopping smoking if you smoke, eating a balanced diet and doing regular exercise.

【36】However, there are limits to the exercise you should do.

【37】### Sports and activities

【38】After being treated for a brain tumour, you might be advised to permanently avoid contact sports, such as rugby and boxing.

【39】You can start other activities again, with the agreement of your doctor, once you have recovered.

【40】Swimming unsupervised is not recommended for about a year after treatment because there's a risk you could have a seizure while in the water.

【41】Sex and pregnancy
-----------------

【42】It's safe to have sex after treatment for a non-cancerous brain tumour.

【43】Women may be advised to avoid becoming pregnant for 6 months or more after treatment. 

【44】If you're planning to become pregnant, you should discuss this with your medical team.

【45】Going back to work
------------------

【46】Tiredness is a common symptom after receiving treatment for a brain tumour. This often restricts your ability to return to work.

【47】Although you may want to return to work and normal life as soon as possible, it's probably a good idea to work part time to begin with and only go back full time when you feel ready.

【48】If you have had seizures, you should not work with machinery or at heights.

【49】Help and support
----------------

【50】A brain tumour is often life changing. You may feel angry, frightened and emotionally drained.

【51】Your doctor or specialist may be able to refer you to a social worker or counsellor for help with the practical and emotional aspects of your diagnosis.

【52】There are also a number of organisations that can provide help and support, such as The Brain Tumour Charity and Brain Tumour Research.

【53】Page last reviewed: 21 April 2020  
Next review due: 21 April 2023

【54】*   Previous : Treatment

【4】Follow-up appointments
----------------------

【5】Non-cancerous brain tumours can sometimes grow back after treatment, so you'll have regular follow-up appointments to check for signs of this.

【6】Your appointments may include a discussion of any new symptoms you experience, a physical examination, and, occasionally, a brain scan.

【7】It's likely you'll have follow-up appointments at least every few months to start with, but they'll probably be needed less frequently if no problems develop.

【8】Side effects of treatment
-------------------------

【9】Some people who have had a brain tumour can develop side effects of treatment months or years later, such as:

【10】*   cataracts
*   problems with thinking, memory, language or judgement
*   epilepsy
*   hearing loss
*   infertility
*   migraine attacks
*   a tumour developing somewhere else
*   numbness, pain, weakness or loss of vision resulting from nerve damage (but these complications are rare)
*   a stroke (this is rare)

【11】If you or someone you care for has any worrying symptoms that develop after brain tumour treatment, see your doctor.

【12】If you think it's a stroke, dial 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance.

【13】Supportive treatment
--------------------

【14】Problems caused by a brain tumour do not always resolve as soon as the tumour is removed or treated.

【15】For example, some people have persistent weakness, epileptic fits (seizures), difficulty walking and speech problems.

【16】Extra support may be needed to help you overcome or adapt to any problems you have.

【17】This may include therapies such as:

【18】*   **physiotherapy** to help with any movement problems you have
*   **occupational therapy** to identify any problems you're having with daily activities, and arrange for any equipment or alterations to your home that may help
*   **speech and language therapy** to help you with communication or swallowing problems

【19】Some people may also need to continue taking medicine for seizures for a few months or more after their tumour has been treated or removed.

【20】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has made recommendations about the standards of care people with brain tumours should receive.

【21】See the NICE guidance about improving outcomes for people with brain and other central nervous system tumours.

【22】Driving and travelling
----------------------

【23】You may not be allowed to drive for a while after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.

【24】How long you'll be unable to drive will depend on factors such as:

【25】*   whether you have had epileptic fits (seizures)
*   the type of brain tumour you have
*   where it is in your brain
*   what symptoms you have
*   what type of surgery you have had

【26】If you're unsure whether or not you should be driving, do not drive until you have had clarification from the DVLA, your GP or specialist. 

【27】Driving against medical advice is both dangerous and against the law.

【28】If you need to give up your driving licence, the DVLA will speak to your GP or specialist to determine when you can drive again.

【29】With up-to-date scans and advice from your medical team, you may be allowed to drive after an agreed period.

【30】This is usually after you have successfully completed medical tests to determine your ability to control a vehicle, and when the risk of having seizures is low.

【31】The Cancer Research UK website has more information about brain tumours and driving.

【32】Flying is usually possible when you have recovered from surgery, but you should let your travel insurance company know about your condition.

【33】Lifestyle advice
----------------

【34】If you have had radiotherapy, it's important to follow a healthy lifestyle to lower your risk of stroke.

【35】This means stopping smoking if you smoke, eating a balanced diet and doing regular exercise.

【36】However, there are limits to the exercise you should do.

【37】### Sports and activities

【38】After being treated for a brain tumour, you might be advised to permanently avoid contact sports, such as rugby and boxing.

【39】You can start other activities again, with the agreement of your doctor, once you have recovered.

【40】Swimming unsupervised is not recommended for about a year after treatment because there's a risk you could have a seizure while in the water.

【41】Sex and pregnancy
-----------------

【42】It's safe to have sex after treatment for a non-cancerous brain tumour.

【43】Women may be advised to avoid becoming pregnant for 6 months or more after treatment. 

【44】If you're planning to become pregnant, you should discuss this with your medical team.

【45】Going back to work
------------------

【46】Tiredness is a common symptom after receiving treatment for a brain tumour. This often restricts your ability to return to work.

【47】Although you may want to return to work and normal life as soon as possible, it's probably a good idea to work part time to begin with and only go back full time when you feel ready.

【48】If you have had seizures, you should not work with machinery or at heights.

【49】Help and support
----------------

【50】A brain tumour is often life changing. You may feel angry, frightened and emotionally drained.

【51】Your doctor or specialist may be able to refer you to a social worker or counsellor for help with the practical and emotional aspects of your diagnosis.

【52】There are also a number of organisations that can provide help and support, such as The Brain Tumour Charity and Brain Tumour Research.

【53】Page last reviewed: 21 April 2020  
Next review due: 21 April 2023

【54】*   Previous : Treatment

source_info.title: Oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking or using oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray \- Brand names: Oestrogel, Evorel, Sandrena, Lenzetto, Estradot, Progynova
=================================================================================================================================================================================

【1】Oestrogen tablets, patches gel and spray and pregnancy
------------------------------------------------------

【2】Oestrogen tablets, patches gel and spray are not known to be harmful in pregnancy, but if you get pregnant while taking HRT then stop taking it and speak to your doctor.

【3】Levels of oestrogen and progesterone are naturally high during pregnancy, so you will not need HRT.

【4】Oestrogen tablets, patches gel and spray and breastfeeding
----------------------------------------------------------

【5】There is not much information on taking oestrogen for HRT while breastfeeding. Most of the information comes from the use of other types of oestrogen as a contraceptive.

【6】If you're breastfeeding and need to use HRT, oestrogen tablets, patches, gel or spray are not usually prescribed, unless a specialist recommends it.

【7】Oestrogen tablets, patches gel and spray and fertility
------------------------------------------------------

【8】Taking oestrogen as HRT is unlikely to affect your fertility.

【9】Oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray do not act as a contraceptive.

【10】Even if you think that you've gone through the menopause, unless you've had a hysterectomy there's a small chance that you could become pregnant.

【11】You're advised to use contraception for at least 1 year from your last period if you're over 50 years old and for 2 years if you're under 50 years old. Discuss this with your doctor or family planning practitioner.

【12】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【13】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【14】More in Oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray
-------------------------------------------------

【15】*   About oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray
*   Who can and cannot take or use it
*   How and when to take or use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking or using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【16】Page last reviewed: 5 January 2023  
Next review due: 5 January 2026

source_info.title: Spinal muscular atrophy
source_info.text:
【0】Types \- Spinal muscular atrophy
================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Types
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment

【3】**There are several different types of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), which start at different ages.**

【4】They can all cause weakness and difficulty moving, but how bad these problems are varies.

【5】Intelligence and learning ability are not affected by any type of SMA.

【6】Type 1 SMA (young babies)
-------------------------

【7】Children with type 1 SMA show symptoms in the first 6 months of life.

【8】Babies with the condition:

【9】*   have very weak and floppy arms and legs (hypotonia)
*   have problems moving, eating, breathing, and swallowing
*   are unable to raise their head or sit without support

【10】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 1 SMA.

【11】Type 2 SMA (older babies and toddlers)
--------------------------------------

【12】Children with type 2 SMA usually show symptoms when they're 7 to 18 months old. The symptoms are less severe than type 1.

【13】Children with the condition may:

【14】*   be able to sit up without help, but not stand or walk
*   have weak arms or legs
*   have shaking (tremors) in their fingers and hands
*   later develop problems with their joints, such as an unusually curved spine (scoliosis)
*   have weak breathing muscles and difficulty coughing – this can put them at risk of chest infections

【15】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 2 SMA.

【16】Type 3 SMA (children and young adults)
--------------------------------------

【17】People with type 3 SMA usually develop symptoms after 18 months of age, but this is very variable and sometimes it may not appear until late childhood or early adulthood.

【18】People with the condition:

【19】*   are able to stand and walk without help, although they may find walking or getting up from a sitting position difficult
*   may have balance problems, difficulty running or climbing steps, and a slight shaking in their fingers
*   may find walking gets gradually harder over time, and they may eventually lose the ability to walk when they're older

【20】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 3 SMA.

【21】Type 4 SMA (adults)
-------------------

【22】Type 4 SMA, also called adult-onset SMA, usually begins in early adulthood.

【23】Someone with the condition may have:

【24】*   weakness in the hands and feet
*   difficulty walking
*   shaking and twitching muscles

【25】Type 4 SMA gets slowly worse over time, but does not normally cause problems with breathing or swallowing.

【26】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 4 SMA.

【27】Other types of SMA
------------------

【28】There are several other types of SMA, including:

【29】*   **spinal muscular atrophy with respiratory distress (SMARD)** – a type of SMA that's usually diagnosed during a baby's first year of life and can cause serious breathing problems
*   **Kennedy's disease, or spinobulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA)** – a rare type of SMA that only affects men and usually starts in middle age; it does not usually affect life expectancy
*   **distal spinal muscular atrophy (DSMA)** – a type of SMA that mainly affects the hands, feet, lower arms, and lower legs

【30】Page last reviewed: 04 May 2020  
Next review due: 04 May 2023

【31】*   Previous : Spinal muscular atrophy
*   Next : Diagnosis

-------------------------

【7】Children with type 1 SMA show symptoms in the first 6 months of life.

【8】Babies with the condition:

【9】*   have very weak and floppy arms and legs (hypotonia)
*   have problems moving, eating, breathing, and swallowing
*   are unable to raise their head or sit without support

<mark>【10】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 1 SMA.</mark>

【11】Type 2 SMA (older babies and toddlers)
--------------------------------------

【12】Children with type 2 SMA usually show symptoms when they're 7 to 18 months old. The symptoms are less severe than type 1.

【13】Children with the condition may:

【14】*   be able to sit up without help, but not stand or walk
*   have weak arms or legs
*   have shaking (tremors) in their fingers and hands
*   later develop problems with their joints, such as an unusually curved spine (scoliosis)
*   have weak breathing muscles and difficulty coughing – this can put them at risk of chest infections

【15】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 2 SMA.

【16】Type 3 SMA (children and young adults)
--------------------------------------

【17】People with type 3 SMA usually develop symptoms after 18 months of age, but this is very variable and sometimes it may not appear until late childhood or early adulthood.

【18】People with the condition:

【19】*   are able to stand and walk without help, although they may find walking or getting up from a sitting position difficult
*   may have balance problems, difficulty running or climbing steps, and a slight shaking in their fingers
*   may find walking gets gradually harder over time, and they may eventually lose the ability to walk when they're older

【20】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 3 SMA.

【21】Type 4 SMA (adults)
-------------------

【22】Type 4 SMA, also called adult-onset SMA, usually begins in early adulthood.

【23】Someone with the condition may have:

【24】*   weakness in the hands and feet
*   difficulty walking
*   shaking and twitching muscles

【25】Type 4 SMA gets slowly worse over time, but does not normally cause problems with breathing or swallowing.

【26】Spinal Muscular Atrophy UK has more information about type 4 SMA.

【27】Other types of SMA
------------------

【28】There are several other types of SMA, including:

【29】*   **spinal muscular atrophy with respiratory distress (SMARD)** – a type of SMA that's usually diagnosed during a baby's first year of life and can cause serious breathing problems
*   **Kennedy's disease, or spinobulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA)** – a rare type of SMA that only affects men and usually starts in middle age; it does not usually affect life expectancy
*   **distal spinal muscular atrophy (DSMA)** – a type of SMA that mainly affects the hands, feet, lower arms, and lower legs

【30】Page last reviewed: 04 May 2020  
Next review due: 04 May 2023

source_info.title: Lumbar decompression surgery
source_info.text:
【0】Recovery \- Lumbar decompression surgery
========================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  When it's used
3.  How it's performed
4.  Recovery
5.  Risks

【3】**Recovery after lumbar decompression surgery will depend on your fitness and level of activity prior to surgery. This is why a course of physiotherapy before the operation may be recommended.**

【4】You'll be encouraged to walk and move around the day after surgery and it's likely you'll be discharged 1 to 4 days afterwards.

【5】It will take about 4 to 6 weeks for you to reach your expected level of mobility and function (this will depend on the severity of your condition and symptoms before the operation).

【6】When you wake up after lumbar decompression surgery, your back may feel sore and you'll probably be attached to 1 or more tubes.

【7】These may include a:

【8】*   drip supplying fluids into a vein (intravenous drip), to make sure you don't get dehydrated
*   drain to take away any fluid from your wound
*   thin, flexible tube inserted into your bladder (urinary catheter), in case you have difficulty urinating
*   pump to deliver painkillers directly into your veins

【9】The tubes are usually only attached for a short time after your operation.

【10】Pain
----

【11】Immediately after surgery, you'll have some pain in and around the area where the operation was carried out. You'll be given pain relief to ensure you're comfortable and to help you move. The original leg pain you had before surgery usually improves immediately, but you should tell the nurses and your doctor if it doesn't.

【12】A very small number of people have difficulty urinating after the operation. This is usually temporary, but in rare cases complications, such as nerve damage, may cause the legs or bladder to stop working properly. It's important to tell your doctor and nurses immediately if you have problems.

【13】It can take up to 6 weeks for the general pain and tiredness after your operation to disappear completely.

【14】Stitches
--------

【15】You'll have stitches or staples to close any cuts or incisions made during your operation. Deep stitches beneath the skin will dissolve and don't need to be removed. If dissolvable stiches are used, they don't need to be removed.

【16】Non-dissolvable stitches or staples will be removed 5 to 10 days after your operation. Before you leave hospital, you'll be given an appointment to have them removed.

【17】Your stitches may be covered by a simple adhesive dressing, like a large plaster. Be careful not to get your dressing wet when you wash. After having your stitches removed, you won't need a dressing and will be able to bath and shower as normal.

【18】Rehabilitation
--------------

【19】Your medical team will want you to get up and moving about as soon as possible, usually from the day after the operation. This is because inactivity can increase your risk of developing a blood clot in the leg (DVT), and movement can speed up the recovery process.

【20】After your operation, a physiotherapist will help you safely regain strength and movement. They'll teach you some simple exercises you can do at home to help your recovery.

【21】Read more about physiotherapy.

【22】Getting home
------------

【23】You'll usually be able to go home about 1 to 4 days after your operation. How long you need to stay in hospital will depend on the specific type of surgery you had and your general health.

【24】When you get home, it's important to take things easy at first, gradually increasing your level of activity every day. Some help at home is usually needed for at least the first week after surgery.

【25】Being active will speed up your recovery. Make sure you do the exercises recommended by your physiotherapist, and try not to sit or stand in the same position for more than 15-20 minutes at a time, because this can make you feel stiff and sore.

【26】Walking is a good way to keep active, but you should avoid heavy lifting, awkward twisting and leaning when you do everyday tasks until you're feeling better.

【27】You may be asked to return to hospital for one or more follow-up appointments in the weeks after your operation to check how you're doing.

【28】Work
----

【29】When you can go back to work will depend on how quickly you heal after surgery and the type of job you do. Most people return to work after 4 to 8 weeks, if their job isn't too strenuous.

【30】If your job involves a lot of driving, lifting heavy items or other strenuous activities, you may need to be off work for up to 3 to 6 months.

【31】Driving
-------

【32】Before starting to drive again, you should be free from the effects of any painkillers that may make you drowsy.

【33】You should be comfortable in the driving position and be able to do an emergency stop without experiencing any pain (you can practise this without starting your car).

【34】Most people feel ready to drive after 2 to 6 weeks, depending on the size of the operation.

【35】Some insurance companies don't insure drivers for a number of weeks after surgery, so check what your policy says before you start to drive.

【36】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【37】Call the hospital where you had your operation, or your GP, for advice if:

【38】*   there's leaking fluid or redness at the site of your wound
*   your stitches come out
*   your dressing becomes soaked with blood
*   you have a high temperature (fever) of 38C (100.4F) or above
*   you have increasing pain, numbness or weakness in your legs, back or buttocks
*   you can't move your legs
*   you can't pee or control your bladder
*   you have a severe headache
*   you experience a sudden shortness of breath (this could be a sign of pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, or other heart and lung problems)

【39】Page last reviewed: 28 April 2022  
Next review due: 28 April 2025

【40】*   Previous : How it's performed
*   Next : Risks

【28】Work
----

【29】When you can go back to work will depend on how quickly you heal after surgery and the type of job you do. Most people return to work after 4 to 8 weeks, if their job isn't too strenuous.

【30】If your job involves a lot of driving, lifting heavy items or other strenuous activities, you may need to be off work for up to 3 to 6 months.

【31】Driving
-------

【32】Before starting to drive again, you should be free from the effects of any painkillers that may make you drowsy.

【33】You should be comfortable in the driving position and be able to do an emergency stop without experiencing any pain (you can practise this without starting your car).

【34】Most people feel ready to drive after 2 to 6 weeks, depending on the size of the operation.

【35】Some insurance companies don't insure drivers for a number of weeks after surgery, so check what your policy says before you start to drive.

【36】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【37】Call the hospital where you had your operation, or your GP, for advice if:

【38】*   there's leaking fluid or redness at the site of your wound
*   your stitches come out
*   your dressing becomes soaked with blood
*   you have a high temperature (fever) of 38C (100.4F) or above
*   you have increasing pain, numbness or weakness in your legs, back or buttocks
*   you can't move your legs
*   you can't pee or control your bladder
*   you have a severe headache
*   you experience a sudden shortness of breath (this could be a sign of pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, or other heart and lung problems)

【39】Page last reviewed: 28 April 2022  
Next review due: 28 April 2025

【40】*   Previous : How it's performed
*   Next : Risks

source_info.title: Genital warts
source_info.text:
【0】Genital warts
=============

【1】**Genital warts are small, rough lumps that can appear around the vagina, penis or anus. They're a common sexually transmitted infection (STI). Treatment from a sexual health clinic can help.**

【2】Check if you have genital warts
-------------------------------

【3】It can take a few weeks or months for genital warts to appear after having sex with someone who is infected.

【4】Genital warts are usually small, rough lumps on the skin.

【5】They can appear:

【6】*   around the vagina and on the penis
*   around the anus
*   on the skin between the genitals and anus (perineum)

【7】Genital warts may:

【8】*   appear on their own or in a group (groups of warts can look like a cauliflower)
*   feel soft or firm
*   be white, red, skin-coloured, or darker than the surrounding skin

【9】They do not usually cause symptoms but sometimes they may be painful, itchy or bleed.

【10】You may also have:

【11】*   pain or discomfort during sex
*   problems peeing (there may be blood in your pee, you may find it hard to pee, or you may stop and start a lot)

【12】See pictures of genital warts

【13】Credit:

【14】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/295848/view

【15】Credit:

【16】DR HAROUT TANIELIAN/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/88265/view

【17】Credit:

【18】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/295869/view

【19】Credit:

【20】Clinical Photography/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/861668/view

【21】Non-urgent advice: Go to a sexual health clinic if you have:
------------------------------------------------------------

【22】*   1 or more painless lumps or growths around your vagina, penis or anus
*   itching or bleeding from your genitals or anus
*   a change to your normal flow of pee (for example, it's begun to flow sideways) that does not go away
*   a sexual partner who has genital warts, even if you do not know if you have them

【23】You may have genital warts. Go to a sexual health clinic to be checked.

【24】Sexual health clinics are sometimes called genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinics, or sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services.

【25】Treatment can help remove the warts and stop the infection being passed on.

【26】Information:

【27】### Why you should go to a sexual health clinic

【28】A GP will probably refer you to a sexual health clinic if they think you might have genital warts.

【29】Sexual health clinics specialise in treating problems with the genitals and urine system.

【30】Many sexual health clinics offer a walk-in service where you do not need an appointment.

【31】Sexual health clinics often get test results quicker than GP surgeries. You also do not have to pay a prescription charge for medicines prescribed by a sexual health clinic.

【32】Find a sexual health clinic

【33】What happens at a sexual health clinic
--------------------------------------

【34】A doctor or nurse at a sexual health clinic will usually be able to diagnose genital warts by looking at them.

【35】They may:

【36】*   ask you about your symptoms and sexual partners
*   look at the lumps around your genitals and anus, sometimes using a magnifying lens
*   possibly need to look inside your vagina, anus or urethra (tube where pee comes out), depending on where the warts are

【37】It may not be possible to find out who you got genital warts from, or how long you've had the infection.

【38】Treatments for genital warts
----------------------------

【39】Treatment for genital warts is not always needed. They sometimes disappear on their own within 6 months.

【40】If treatment is recommended, it will need to be prescribed by a doctor.

【41】The type of treatment you'll be offered depends on what the warts look like and where they are. The doctor or nurse will discuss this with you.

【42】Treatments for genital warts include:

【43】*   cream, liquid or ointment – you can usually apply these yourself, but if the area is large, a doctor or nurse will need to apply it (these treatments can cause pain, irritation or a burning sensation)
*   freezing (cryotherapy) – this treatment may need to be repeated several times and can be painful
*   surgery – the warts are cut out after numbing the affected area with local anaesthetic, or they may be removed using heat or a laser (these treatments can cause pain, irritation or scarring)

【44】It may take weeks or months for genital wart treatment to work and the warts may come back. Sometimes the treatment does not work.

【45】Tell the doctor or nurse if you're pregnant or thinking about becoming pregnant, as some treatments will not be suitable for you.

【46】Some creams can weaken condoms and vaginal diaphragms if it comes into contact with them. Ask the doctor or nurse about this.

【47】Things you can do while having treatment for genital warts
----------------------------------------------------------

【48】There are some things you can do while having treatment for genital warts.

【49】### Do

【50】*   follow the instructions about how to apply creams, liquids and ointments carefully – some creams should only be left on for a certain amount of time before being washed off

【51】*   avoid getting any treatment you apply to genital warts on normal skin or in open wounds

【52】### Don’t

【53】*   do not use wart treatment from a pharmacy because they're not made for genital warts

【54】*   do not smoke – many treatments for genital warts work better if you do not smoke

【55】*   do not have vaginal, anal or oral sex until the warts have gone (but if you do have sex, always use a condom)

【56】How genital warts are passed on
-------------------------------

【57】Genital warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). The virus can be passed on even when there are no visible warts.

【58】Many people with the virus do not have symptoms but can still pass it on.

【59】If you have genital warts, your current sexual partners should consider getting checked because they may have warts and not know it.

【60】After you get the infection, it can take weeks to many months before symptoms appear.

【61】You can get genital warts from:

【62】*   skin-to-skin contact, including vaginal and anal sex
*   sharing sex toys
*   oral sex, but this is rare

【63】The virus can also be passed to a baby from its mother during birth, but this is rare.

【64】Genital warts can be spread if you touch an infected area and then touch another part of your body.

【65】You cannot get genital warts from kissing or from sharing things like towels, cutlery, cups or toilet seats.

【66】Stopping genital warts being passed on
--------------------------------------

【67】You can stop genital warts being passed on by:

【68】*   using a condom every time you have vaginal, anal or oral sex – but if the virus is in any skin that's not protected by a condom, it can still be passed on
*   not having sex while you're having treatment for genital warts
*   not sharing sex toys – if you do share them, wash them or cover them with a new condom before anyone else uses them

【69】### HPV vaccine

【70】The HPV vaccine offered to 12 to 13 year-old girls and boys in England protects against genital warts and some cancers (such as cervical cancer and anal cancer).

【71】The HPV vaccine is also offered to men (up to and including 45 years old) who have sex with men, some trans men and trans women, sex workers and people living with HIV.

【72】Find out more about the HPV vaccine

【73】Genital warts and pregnancy
---------------------------

【74】Genital warts are not usually harmful during pregnancy.

【75】But you'll usually be referred to a sexual health specialist if you have genital warts and you’re pregnant.

【76】During pregnancy, genital warts may:

【77】*   multiply and get bigger (they may be removed if they're very big)
*   become more easily irritated
*   be passed on to the baby during birth, but this is rare (the HPV virus can cause infection in the baby’s throat or genitals)

【78】Most creams, liquids and ointments used to treat genital warts are not recommended during pregnancy.

【79】Genital warts often disappear on their own within 6 weeks after the baby is born, so treatment is often delayed until after the birth.

【80】Page last reviewed: 10 July 2023  
Next review due: 10 July 2026

source_info.title: Risedronate
source_info.text:
【0】Taking risedronate with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Actonel, Actonel Once a Week
===========================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】When taking risedronate, it's important to not take any other medicines at the same time. This is because other medicines can affect how well your body absorbs risedronate and may stop it working properly.

【3】If you take risedronate first thing in the morning, when you get up, wait for at least 30 minutes before taking your other medicines.

【4】If you take risedronate between meals or in the evening, wait at least 2 hours before taking your other medicines.

【5】Tell your doctor if you're taking:

【6】*   antacids to relieve indigestion or heartburn such as Maalox, Mucogel or Milk of Magnesia
*   laxatives containing magnesium such as Milk of Magnesia
*   cancer medicines such as bevacizumab or thalidomide, or if you're having chemotherapy or taking steroids such as prednisolone or dexamethasone – these may increase the risk of damage to your jawbone
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen, which can increase the risk of irritating your food pipe, stomach or gut – taking low-dose aspirin is OK
*   antibiotics such as gentamicin, amikacin, streptomycin or tobramycin – these can lower the calcium in your blood
*   deferasirox, a medicine used to remove excess iron from the body – this may increase the risk of bleeding from your gut
*   parathyroid hormone, a medicine used to treat hypoparathyroidism

【7】Mixing risedronate with herbal remedies or supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【8】Tell your doctor if you're taking supplements or multivitamins containing calcium, iron, magnesium or zinc. These supplements can reduce the amount of risedronate absorbed from your stomach if you take them at the same time.

【9】If you take your risedronate in the morning, consider taking your calcium, iron, magnesium or zinc supplement in the evening.

【10】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with risedronate. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the affect they have on other medicines.

【11】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【12】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【13】More in Risedronate
-------------------

【14】*   About risedronate
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【15】Page last reviewed: 25 October 2022  
Next review due: 25 October 2025

【0】Taking risedronate with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Actonel, Actonel Once a Week
===========================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】When taking risedronate, it's important to not take any other medicines at the same time. This is because other medicines can affect how well your body absorbs risedronate and may stop it working properly.

【3】If you take risedronate first thing in the morning, when you get up, wait for at least 30 minutes before taking your other medicines.

【4】If you take risedronate between meals or in the evening, wait at least 2 hours before taking your other medicines.

【5】Tell your doctor if you're taking:

【6】*   antacids to relieve indigestion or heartburn such as Maalox, Mucogel or Milk of Magnesia

*   antibiotics such as gentamicin, amikacin, streptomycin or tobramycin – these can lower the calcium in your blood

source_info.title: Dentures (false teeth)
source_info.text:
【0】Dentures (false teeth)
======================

【1】**Dentures are removable false teeth made of acrylic (plastic), nylon or metal. They fit snugly over the gums to replace missing teeth and eliminate potential problems caused by gaps.**

【2】Gaps left by missing teeth can cause problems with eating and speech, and teeth either side of the gap may grow into the space at an angle.

【3】Sometimes all the teeth need to be removed and replaced.

【4】You may therefore need either:

【5】*   **complete dentures** (a full set) – which replace all your upper or lower teeth, or
*   **partial dentures** – which replace just 1 tooth or a few missing teeth

【6】Dentures may help prevent problems with eating and speech. If you need complete dentures, they may also improve the appearance of your smile and give you confidence.

【7】It's also possible that dentures might not give you the result you hope for. Discuss plans openly with your dentist before you agree to go ahead.

【8】How dentures are fitted
-----------------------

【9】### Complete dentures

【10】A full denture will be fitted if all your upper or lower teeth need to be removed or you're having an old complete denture replaced.

【11】The denture will usually be fitted as soon as your teeth are removed, which means you won't be without teeth. The denture will fit snugly over your gums and jawbone.

【12】But if you have dentures fitted immediately after the removal of several teeth, the gums and bone will alter in shape fairly quickly and the dentures will probably need relining or remaking after a few months.

【13】Occasionally, your gums may need to be left to heal and alter in shape for several months before dentures can be fitted.

【14】You can either see a dentist or a qualified clinical dental technician to have your dentures made and fitted.

【15】The difference between them is that a:

【16】*   dentist will take measurements and impressions (moulds) of your mouth, and then order your full or partial dentures from a dental technician
*   clinical dental technician will provide a full set of dentures directly without you having to see your dentist (although you should still have regular dental check-ups with your dentist)

【17】A trial denture will be created from the impressions taken of your mouth.

【18】The dentist or clinical dental technician will try this in your mouth to assess the fit and for you to assess the appearance.

【19】The shape and colour may be adjusted before the final denture is produced.

【20】### Partial dentures

【21】A partial denture is designed to fill in the gaps left by one or more missing teeth. It's a plastic, nylon or metal plate with a number of false teeth attached to it.

【22】It usually clips onto some of your natural teeth via metal clasps, which hold it securely in place in your mouth. It can easily be unclipped and removed.

【23】Occasionally, the clips can be made of a tooth- or gum-coloured material, although this type of clip isn't always suitable because it tends to be more brittle than metal.

【24】Your dentist can measure your mouth and order a partial denture for you, or you can see a qualified clinical dental technician, who can provide a partial denture for you directly after you have first seen your dentist for a treatment plan and certificate of oral health.

【25】The Oral Health Foundation website has more information and advice about bridges and partial dentures, including which type of denture (metal or plastic) is best for you.

【26】A fixed bridge is an alternative to a partial denture and may be suitable for some people.

【27】Crowns are put on the teeth either side of the gap and joined together by a false tooth that's put in the gap.

【28】Looking after your dentures
---------------------------

【29】Dentures may feel a bit strange to begin with, but you'll soon get used to wearing them.

【30】At first, you may need to wear your dentures all the time, including while sleeping.

【31】Your dentist or clinical dental technician will advise you on whether you should remove your dentures before you go to sleep.

【32】It isn't always necessary to remove your dentures at night, but doing so can allow your gums to rest as you sleep. 

【33】If you remove your dentures, they should be kept moist – for example, in water or a polythene bag with some dampened cotton wool in it, or in a suitable overnight denture-cleaning solution.

【34】This will stop the denture material drying out and changing shape.

【35】### Dental hygiene

【36】Keeping your mouth clean is just as important when you wear dentures.

【37】You should brush your remaining teeth, gums and tongue every morning and evening with fluoride toothpaste to prevent tooth decay, gum disease and other dental problems.

【38】Read more about how to keep your teeth clean.

【39】### Cleaning dentures

【40】It's important to regularly remove plaque and food deposits from your dentures.

【41】This is because unclean dentures can also lead to problems, such as bad breath, gum disease, tooth decay and oral thrush.

【42】Clean your dentures as often as you would normal teeth (at least twice a day: every morning and night).

【43】You should:

【44】*   brush your dentures with toothpaste or soap and water before soaking them to remove food particles
*   soak them in a fizzy solution of denture-cleaning tablets to remove stains and bacteria (follow the manufacturer's instructions)
*   brush them again as you would your normal teeth (but don't scrub them too hard)

【45】Dentures may break if you drop them, so you should clean them over a bowl or sink filled with water, or something soft like a folded towel.

【46】Find more information on denture cleaning, on the Oral Health Foundation website.

【47】### Eating with dentures

【48】When you first start wearing dentures, you should eat soft foods cut into small pieces and chew slowly, using both sides of your mouth.

【49】Avoid chewing gum and any food that's sticky, hard or has sharp edges.

【50】You can gradually start to eat other types of food until you're back to your old diet. Never use toothpicks.

【51】### Denture adhesive

【52】If your dentures fit properly, you shouldn't necessarily need to use denture fixative (adhesive).

【53】But if your jawbone has shrunk significantly, adhesive may be the only way to help retain your dentures. 

【54】Your dentist or clinical dental technician will advise you if this is the case.

【55】At first, some people feel more confident with their dentures if they use adhesive. Follow the manufacturer's instructions and avoid using excessive amounts.

【56】Adhesive can be removed from the denture by brushing with soap and water. 

【57】Remnants of adhesive left in the mouth may need to be removed with some damp kitchen roll or a clean damp flannel.

【58】When to see your dentist
------------------------

【59】You should continue to see your dentist regularly if you have dentures (even if you have complete dentures) so they can check for any problems.

【60】Your dentures should last several years if you take good care of them.

【61】But your gums and jawbone will eventually shrink, which means the dentures may not fit as well as they used to and can become loose, or they may become worn.

【62】See your dentist as soon as possible if:

【63】*   your dentures click when you're talking
*   your dentures tend to slip, or you feel they no longer fit properly
*   your dentures feel uncomfortable
*   your dentures are visibly worn
*   you have signs of gum disease or tooth decay, such as bleeding gums or bad breath

【64】If poorly fitting or worn dentures aren't replaced, they can cause great discomfort and lead to mouth sores, infections or problems eating and speaking.

【65】How much dentures cost on the NHS
---------------------------------

【66】Having dentures fitted is a band 3 treatment.

【67】Read about understanding NHS dental charges for the different bands and how to get help with dental costs.

【68】Page last reviewed: 08 September 2021  
Next review due: 08 September 2024
