-----------------------

【9】### Complete dentures

【10】A full denture will be fitted if all your upper or lower teeth need to be removed or you're having an old complete denture replaced.

【11】The denture will usually be fitted as soon as your teeth are removed, which means you won't be without teeth. The denture will fit snugly over your gums and jawbone.

【12】But if you have dentures fitted immediately after the removal of several teeth, the gums and bone will alter in shape fairly quickly and the dentures will probably need relining or remaking after a few months.

【13】Occasionally, your gums may need to be left to heal and alter in shape for several months before dentures can be fitted.

【14】You can either see a dentist or a qualified clinical dental technician to have your dentures made and fitted.

【15】The difference between them is that a:

【16】*   dentist will take measurements and impressions (moulds) of your mouth, and then order your full or partial dentures from a dental technician
*   clinical dental technician will provide a full set of dentures directly without you having to see your dentist (although you should still have regular dental check-ups with your dentist)

【17】A trial denture will be created from the impressions taken of your mouth.

【18】The dentist or clinical dental technician will try this in your mouth to assess the fit and for you to assess the appearance.

【19】The shape and colour may be adjusted before the final denture is produced.

【20】### Partial dentures

【21】A partial denture is designed to fill in the gaps left by one or more missing teeth. It's a plastic, nylon or metal plate with a number of false teeth attached to it.

【22】It usually clips onto some of your natural teeth via metal clasps, which hold it securely in place in your mouth. It can easily be unclipped and removed.

【23】Occasionally, the clips can be made of a tooth- or gum-coloured material, although this type of clip isn't always suitable because it tends to be more brittle than metal.

【24】Your dentist can measure your mouth and order a partial denture for you, or you can see a qualified clinical dental technician, who can provide a partial denture for you directly after you have first seen your dentist for a treatment plan and certificate of oral health.

【25】The Oral Health Foundation website has more information and advice about bridges and partial dentures, including which type of denture (metal or plastic) is best for you.

【26】A fixed bridge is an alternative to a partial denture and may be suitable for some people.

【27】Crowns are put on the teeth either side of the gap and joined together by a false tooth that's put in the gap.

【28】Looking after your dentures
---------------------------

【29】Dentures may feel a bit strange to begin with, but you'll soon get used to wearing them.

【30】At first, you may need to wear your dentures all the time, including while sleeping.

【31】Your dentist or clinical dental technician will advise you on whether you should remove your dentures before you go to sleep.

【32】It isn't always necessary to remove your dentures at night, but doing so can allow your gums to rest as you sleep. 

【33】If you remove your dentures, they should be kept moist – for example, in water or a polythene bag with some dampened cotton wool in it, or in a suitable overnight denture-cleaning solution.

【34】This will stop the denture material drying out and changing shape.

【35】### Dental hygiene

【36】Keeping your mouth clean is just as important when you wear dentures.

【37】You should brush your remaining teeth, gums and tongue every morning and evening with fluoride toothpaste to prevent tooth decay, gum disease and other dental problems.

<mark>【38】Read more about how to keep your teeth clean.</mark>

【39】### Cleaning dentures

【40】It's important to regularly remove plaque and food deposits from your dentures.

【41】This is because unclean dentures can also lead to problems, such as bad breath, gum disease, tooth decay and oral thrush.

【42】Clean your dentures as often as you would normal teeth (at least twice a day: every morning and night).

【43】You should:

【44】*   brush your dentures with toothpaste or soap and water before soaking them to remove food particles
*   soak them in a fizzy solution of denture-cleaning tablets to remove stains and bacteria (follow the manufacturer's instructions)
*   brush them again as you would your normal teeth (but don't scrub them too hard)

【45】Dentures may break if you drop them, so you should clean them over a bowl or sink filled with water, or something soft like a folded towel.

<mark>【46】Find more information on denture cleaning, on the Oral Health Foundation website.</mark>

【47】### Eating with dentures

【48】When you first start wearing dentures, you should eat soft foods cut into small pieces and chew slowly, using both sides of your mouth.

【49】Avoid chewing gum and any food that's sticky, hard or has sharp edges.

【50】You can gradually start to eat other types of food until you're back to your old diet. Never use toothpicks.

【51】### Denture adhesive

【52】If your dentures fit properly, you shouldn't necessarily need to use denture fixative (adhesive).

【53】But if your jawbone has shrunk significantly, adhesive may be the only way to help retain your dentures. 

【54】Your dentist or clinical dental technician will advise you if this is the case.

【55】At first, some people feel more confident with their dentures if they use adhesive. Follow the manufacturer's instructions and avoid using excessive amounts.

【56】Adhesive can be removed from the denture by brushing with soap and water. 

【57】Remnants of adhesive left in the mouth may need to be removed with some damp kitchen roll or a clean damp flannel.

【58】When to see your dentist
------------------------

【59】You should continue to see your dentist regularly if you have dentures (even if you have complete dentures) so they can check for any problems.

【60】Your dentures should last several years if you take good care of them.

【61】But your gums and jawbone will eventually shrink, which means the dentures may not fit as well as they used to and can become loose, or they may become worn.

【62】See your dentist as soon as possible if:

【63】*   your dentures click when you're talking
*   your dentures tend to slip, or you feel they no longer fit properly
*   your dentures feel uncomfortable
*   your dentures are visibly worn
*   you have signs of gum disease or tooth decay, such as bleeding gums or bad breath

【64】If poorly fitting or worn dentures aren't replaced, they can cause great discomfort and lead to mouth sores, infections or problems eating and speaking.

【65】How much dentures cost on the NHS
---------------------------------

【66】Having dentures fitted is a band 3 treatment.

【67】Read about understanding NHS dental charges for the different bands and how to get help with dental costs.

【68】Page last reviewed: 08 September 2021  
Next review due: 08 September 2024

source_info.title: Timolol eye drops
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot use timolol eye drops \- Brand names: Eysano, Timoptol, Timoptol LA, Tiopex
==============================================================================================

【1】Who can use timolol eye drops
-----------------------------

【2】Most adults and children, including babies, can use timolol eye drops.

【3】Who may not be able to use timolol eye drops
--------------------------------------------

【4】Timolol eye drops are not suitable for everyone. To make sure they're safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to timolol or any other medicine
*   are due to have, or have had eye surgery (including cataract surgery)
*   have eye problems such as eye pain, irritation, inflammation, blurred vision, or dry eyes
*   wear contact lenses – you can still use timolol, but you will need to remove your contact lenses before using the drops. You’ll also need to wait 15 minutes after using the drops to put your contact lenses back in
*   have lung disease or asthma
*   have heart problems, including a slow heart rate
*   have low blood pressure (hypotension)

【6】More in Timolol eye drops
-------------------------

【7】*   About timolol eye drops
*   Who can and cannot use them
*   How and when to use them
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using timolol eye drops with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【8】Page last reviewed: 25 August 2022  
Next review due: 25 August 2025

source_info.title: Sitagliptin
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take sitagliptin
===================================

【1】Who can take sitagliptin
------------------------

【2】Most adults aged 18 years and older can take sitagliptin.

【3】Who may not be able to take sitagliptin
---------------------------------------

【4】This medicine is not used to treat type 1 diabetes (when your body does not produce insulin).

【5】Sitagliptin is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【6】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to sitagliptin or any other medicine
*   have problems with your pancreas
*   have gallstones or very high levels of triglycerides (a type of fat) in your blood
*   are a heavy drinker or dependent on alcohol
*   have ever had any problems with your kidneys
*   are pregnant or breastfeeding, or trying to get pregnant

【7】More in Sitagliptin
-------------------

【8】*   About sitagliptin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking sitagliptin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Blood poisoning, see Sepsis
source_info.text:
【0】Blood poisoning, see Sepsis
Treatment and recovery \- Sepsis
================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Symptoms
2.  Who can get it
3.  Treatment and recovery

【3】Treatment for sepsis
--------------------

【4】Sepsis needs treatment in hospital straight away because it can get worse quickly.

【5】You should get antibiotics within 1 hour of arriving at hospital.

【6】If sepsis is not treated early, it can turn into septic shock and cause your organs to fail. This is life threatening.

【7】You may need other tests or treatments depending on your symptoms, including:

【8】*   treatment in an intensive care unit
*   a machine to help you breathe (ventilator)
*   surgery to remove areas of infection

【9】You may need to stay in hospital for several weeks.

【10】Recovering from sepsis
----------------------

【11】Most people make a full recovery from sepsis. But it can take time.

【12】You might continue to have physical and emotional symptoms. These can last for months, or even years, after you had sepsis.

【13】These long-term effects are sometimes called post-sepsis syndrome, and can include:

【14】*   feeling very tired and weak, and difficulty sleeping
*   lack of appetite
*   getting ill more often
*   changes in your mood, or anxiety or depression
*   nightmares or flashbacks
*   post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)

【15】### Treatment for post-sepsis syndrome

【16】Most symptoms of post-sepsis syndrome should get better on their own. But it can take time.

【17】There are things you can do to help with some long-term effects.

【18】#### Do

【19】*   ask your work about changes to your working hours or conditions while you're recovering

【20】*   do some gentle, easy exercises to build your strength

【21】*   get regular sleep

【22】*   try to prevent infections – for example, by washing your hands regularly

【23】*   try to eat little and often if you have a small appetite

【24】#### Don’t

【25】*   do not try to rush your recovery – give yourself time

【26】### Non-urgent advice: See a GP about:

【27】*   treatment for physical side effects
*   treatment and support for emotional symptoms

【28】Information:

【29】### Find out more:

【30】*   UK Sepsis Trust: support for sepsis survivors
*   UK Sepsis Trust: post-sepsis syndrome
*   UK Sepsis Trust: going back to work after sepsis
*   UK Sepsis Trust: support for relatives and friends

【31】Page last reviewed: 05 September 2022  
Next review due: 05 September 2025

【32】*   Previous : Who can get it

source_info.title: Mebendazole
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of mebendazole \- Brand names: Ovex, Vermox
========================================================

【1】Like all medicines, mebendazole can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of mebendazole happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Stomach pain

【5】Try to rest. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Placing a heat pad or covered hot water bottle on your stomach may also help.

【6】If you're in a lot of pain, speak to a doctor or pharmacist.

【7】Stomach discomfort including bloating and wind

【8】Stick to simple meals and avoid rich or spicy food. It might help to take mebendazole after you've eaten to see if that helps ease the symptoms.

【9】Diarrhoea

【10】Drink plenty of water or other fluids to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【11】Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor first.

【12】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【13】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【14】Serious side effects
--------------------

【15】Stop taking mebendazole and call a doctor or call 111 straight away if the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin. These can be signs of liver problems.

【16】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【17】*   you or your child has a fit or seizure

【18】Find your nearest A&E

【19】### Serious allergic reaction

【20】It happens rarely but it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to mebendazole.

【21】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【22】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【23】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【24】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【25】Other side effects
------------------

【26】These are not all the side effects of mebendazole. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【27】Information:

【28】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【29】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【30】More in Mebendazole
-------------------

【31】*   About mebendazole
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking mebendazole with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【32】Page last reviewed: 4 August 2022  
Next review due: 4 August 2025

source_info.title: Moles
source_info.text:
【0】Moles
=====

【1】**Moles are small, coloured spots on the skin. Most people have them and they're usually nothing to worry about unless they change size, shape or colour.**

【2】Check if your mole could be cancerous
-------------------------------------

【3】### Signs of harmless moles

【4】Most harmless moles are round or oval-shaped, with a smooth edge.

【5】Credit:

【6】SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/259903/view

【7】They can be flat or raised and may feel smooth or rough.

【8】Credit:

【9】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/259947/view

【10】Sometimes they have hair growing from them.

【11】Credit:

【12】Contributor: BSIP SA / Alamy Stock Photo Image ID: MME7MB https://www.alamy.com/nevus-image184710187.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=B33AEE40-FD41-4DE2-BF16-72B8A18E1C94&p=165781&n=0&orientation=0&pn=2&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d2%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d3%26resultview%3dsortbyRelevant%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dmole%2520hair%26qt\_raw%3dmole%2520hair%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26bespoke%3d4%26customgeoip%3dGB%26apaid%3d%7b18B189B6-6A83-41BD-8442-2448A6B7E281%7d%26custspecid%3d14369B5F-24B7-4344-B743-D5DE569A1F46%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【13】They are usually darker on brown and black skin.

【14】Credit:

【15】Contributor: EyeEm / Alamy Stock Photo Image ID: WBFD4C https://www.alamy.com/portrait-of-woman-with-headscarf-image265256332.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=50740171-D814-439F-8F04-115BCA386F9F&p=914525&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d3%26resultview%3dsortbyRelevant%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dmole%2520african%2520skin%26qt\_raw%3dmole%2520african%2520skin%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26bespoke%3d4%26customgeoip%3dGB%26apaid%3d%7b18B189B6-6A83-41BD-8442-2448A6B7E281%7d%26custspecid%3d14369B5F-24B7-4344-B743-D5DE569A1F46%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【16】It's normal for:

【17】*   babies to be born with moles
*   new moles to appear – especially in children and teenagers
*   moles to fade or disappear as you get older
*   moles to get slightly darker during pregnancy

【18】### Signs a mole could be cancerous

【19】Some moles can be a sign of melanoma, a type of skin cancer.

【20】Melanomas may change colour over time or have more than 2 colours.

【21】Credit:

【22】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/253324/view

【23】They often have uneven edges.

【24】Credit:

【25】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/108472/view

【26】Sometimes they may bleed, itch, or be crusty or raised.

【27】Credit:

【28】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/97260/view

【29】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【30】*   you have a mole that's changed size, shape or colour
*   you have a mole that's painful or itchy
*   you have a mole that's inflamed, bleeding or crusty
*   you have a new or unusual mark on your skin that has not gone away after a few weeks

【31】Finding a melanoma as early as possible can mean it's easier to treat

【32】Treatments for moles
--------------------

【33】Moles only need treating if they're a sign of melanoma.

【34】If the GP thinks your mole is melanoma, you'll be referred to a specialist in hospital. You should get an appointment within 2 weeks.

【35】The main treatment for melanoma is surgery to remove the mole.

【36】### Cosmetic mole removal

【37】Most moles are harmless. Harmless moles are not usually treated on the NHS.

【38】You can pay a private clinic to remove a mole, but it may be expensive.

【39】How to prevent cancerous moles
------------------------------

【40】UV light from the sun can increase the chance of a mole becoming cancerous. If you have lots of moles, you need to be extra careful in the sun.

【41】It's important to check your moles regularly for any changes.

【42】There are some things you can do to protect your moles from sun damage, especially during hot weather.

【43】### Do

【44】*   stay in the shade between 11am and 3pm, when sunlight is strongest

【45】*   cover skin with clothes – wear a hat and sunglasses if you have moles on your face

【46】*   regularly apply a high-factor sunscreen (minimum SPF30) and apply it again after swimming

【47】### Don’t

【48】*   do not use sunlamps or sunbeds – they use UV light

【49】Information:

【50】Find out more about sunscreen and sun safety

【51】Page last reviewed: 04 July 2023  
Next review due: 04 July 2026

【12】Contributor: BSIP SA / Alamy Stock Photo Image ID: MME7MB https://www.alamy.com/nevus-image184710187.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=B33AEE40-FD41-4DE2-BF16-72B8A18E1C94&p=165781&n=0&orientation=0&pn=2&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d2%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d3%26resultview%3dsortbyRelevant%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dmole%2520hair%26qt\_raw%3dmole%2520hair%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26bespoke%3d4%26customgeoip%3dGB%26apaid%3d%7b18B189B6-6A83-41BD-8442-2448A6B7E281%7d%26custspecid%3d14369B5F-24B7-4344-B743-D5DE569A1F46%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【13】They are usually darker on brown and black skin.

【14】Credit:

【15】Contributor: EyeEm / Alamy Stock Photo Image ID: WBFD4C https://www.alamy.com/portrait-of-woman-with-headscarf-image265256332.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=50740171-D814-439F-8F04-115BCA386F9F&p=914525&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d3%26resultview%3dsortbyRelevant%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dmole%2520african%2520skin%26qt\_raw%3dmole%2520african%2520skin%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26bespoke%3d4%26customgeoip%3dGB%26apaid%3d%7b18B189B6-6A83-41BD-8442-2448A6B7E281%7d%26custspecid%3d14369B5F-24B7-4344-B743-D5DE569A1F46%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【16】It's normal for:

【17】*   babies to be born with moles
*   new moles to appear – especially in children and teenagers
*   moles to fade or disappear as you get older
*   moles to get slightly darker during pregnancy

【18】### Signs a mole could be cancerous

【19】Some moles can be a sign of melanoma, a type of skin cancer.

【20】Melanomas may change colour over time or have more than 2 colours.

【21】Credit:

【22】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/253324/view

【23】They often have uneven edges.

【24】Credit:

【25】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/108472/view

【26】Sometimes they may bleed, itch, or be crusty or raised.

【27】Credit:

【28】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/97260/view

【29】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【30】*   you have a mole that's changed size, shape or colour
*   you have a mole that's painful or itchy
*   you have a mole that's inflamed, bleeding or crusty
*   you have a new or unusual mark on your skin that has not gone away after a few weeks

【31】Finding a melanoma as early as possible can mean it's easier to treat

【32】Treatments for moles
--------------------

【33】Moles only need treating if they're a sign of melanoma.

【34】If the GP thinks your mole is melanoma, you'll be referred to a specialist in hospital. You should get an appointment within 2 weeks.

【35】The main treatment for melanoma is surgery to remove the mole.

【36】### Cosmetic mole removal

【37】Most moles are harmless. Harmless moles are not usually treated on the NHS.

【38】You can pay a private clinic to remove a mole, but it may be expensive.

【39】How to prevent cancerous moles
------------------------------

【40】UV light from the sun can increase the chance of a mole becoming cancerous. If you have lots of moles, you need to be extra careful in the sun.

【41】It's important to check your moles regularly for any changes.

【42】There are some things you can do to protect your moles from sun damage, especially during hot weather.

【43】### Do

【44】*   stay in the shade between 11am and 3pm, when sunlight is strongest

【45】*   cover skin with clothes – wear a hat and sunglasses if you have moles on your face

【46】*   regularly apply a high-factor sunscreen (minimum SPF30) and apply it again after swimming

【47】### Don’t

【48】*   do not use sunlamps or sunbeds – they use UV light

【49】Information:

【50】Find out more about sunscreen and sun safety

【12】Contributor: BSIP SA / Alamy Stock Photo Image ID: MME7MB https://www.alamy.com/nevus-image184710187.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=B33AEE40-FD41-4DE2-BF16-72B8A18E1C94&p=165781&n=0&orientation=0&pn=2&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3Dbar%26st%3D0%26pn%3D2%26ps%3D100%26sortby%3D3%26resultview%3DsortbyRelevant%26npgs%3D0%26qt%3Dmole%2520hair%26qt\_raw%3Dmole%2520hair%26lic%3D3%26mr%3D0%26pr%3D0%26ot%3D0%26creative%3D%26ag%3D0%26hc%3D0%26pc%3D%26blackwhite%3D%26cutout%3D%26tbar%3D1%26et%3D0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3D0%26loc%3D0%26imgt%3D0%26dtfr%3D%26dtto%3D%26size%3D0xFF%26archive%3D1%26groupid%3D%26pseudoid%3D%26a%3D%26cdid%3D%26cdsrt%3D%26name%3D%26qn%3D%26apalib%3D%26apalic%3D%26lightbox%3D%26gname%3D%26gtype%3D%26xstx%3D0%26simid%3D%26saveQry%3D%26editorial%3D%26nu%3D%26t%3D%26edoptin%3D%26bespoke%3D4%26customgeoip%3DGB%26apaid%3D{18B189B6-6A83-41BD-8442-2448A6B7E281}%26custspecid%3D14369B5F-24B7-4344-B743-D5DE569A1F46%26cap%3D1%26cbstore%3D1%26vd%3D0%26lb%3D%26fi%3D2%26edrf%3D0%26ispremium%3D1%26flip%3D0%26pl%3D</mark>l%3d

【13】They are usually darker on brown and black skin.

<mark>【14】Credit:

【15】Contributor: EyeEm / Alamy Stock Photo Image ID: WBFD4C https://www.alamy.com/portrait-of-woman-with-headscarf-image265256332.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=50740171-D814-439F-8F04-115BCA386F9F&p=914525&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3Dbar%26st%3D0%26pn%3D1%26ps%3D100%26sortby%3D3%26resultview%3DsortbyRelevant%26npgs%3D0%26qt%3Dmole%2520african%2520skin%26qt\_raw%3Dmole%2520african%2520skin%26lic%3D3%26mr%3D0%26pr%3D0%26ot%3D0%26creative%3D%26ag%3D0%26hc%3D0%26pc%3D%26blackwhite%3D%26cutout%3D%26tbar%3D1%26et%3D0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3D0%26loc%3D0%26imgt%3D0%26dtfr%3D%26dtto%3D%26size%3D0xFF%26archive%3D1%26groupid%3D%26pseudoid%3D%26a%3D%26cdid%3D%26cdsrt%3D%26name%3D%26qn%3D%26apalib%3D%26apalic%3D%26lightbox%3D%26gname%3D%26gtype%3D%26xstx%3D0%26simid%3D%26saveQry%3D%26editorial%3D%26nu%3D%26t%3D%26edoptin%3D%26bespoke%3D4%26customgeoip%3DGB%26apaid%3D{18B189B6-6A83-41BD-8442-2448A6B7E281}%26custspecid%3D14369B5F-24B7-4344-B743-D5DE569A1F46%26cap%3D1%26cbstore%3D1%26vd%3D0%26lb%3D%26fi%3D2%26edrf%3D0%26ispremium%3D1%26flip%3D0%26pl%3D</mark>l%3d

【16】It's normal for:

【17】*   babies to be born with moles
*   new moles to appear – especially in children and teenagers
*   moles to fade or disappear as you get older
*   moles to get slightly darker during pregnancy

【18】### Signs a mole could be cancerous

【19】Some moles can be a sign of melanoma, a type of skin cancer.

【20】Melanomas may change colour over time or have more than 2 colours.

<mark>【21】Credit:

【22】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/253324/view

【23】They often have uneven edges.

【24】Credit:

【25】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/108472/view

【26】Sometimes they may bleed, itch, or be crusty or raised.

【27】Credit:

【28】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/97260/view</mark>

【29】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【30】*   you have a mole that's changed size, shape or colour
*   you have a mole that's painful or itchy
*   you have a mole that's inflamed, bleeding or crusty
*   you have a new or unusual mark on your skin that has not gone away after a few weeks

【31】Finding a melanoma as early as possible can mean it's easier to treat

【32】Treatments for moles
--------------------

【33】Moles only need treating if they're a sign of melanoma.

【34】If the GP thinks your mole is melanoma, you'll be referred to a specialist in hospital. You should get an appointment within 2 weeks.

【35】The main treatment for melanoma is surgery to remove the mole.

【36】### Cosmetic mole removal

【37】Most moles are harmless. Harmless moles are not usually treated on the NHS.

【38】You can pay a private clinic to remove a mole, but it may be expensive.

【39】How to prevent cancerous moles
------------------------------

【40】UV light from the sun can increase the chance of a mole becoming cancerous. If you have lots of moles, you need to be extra careful in the sun.

【41】It's important to check your moles regularly for any changes.

【42】There are some things you can do to protect your moles from sun damage, especially during hot weather.

【43】### Do

【44】*   stay in the shade between 11am and 3pm, when sunlight is strongest

【45】*   cover skin with clothes – wear a hat and sunglasses if you have moles on your face

【46】*   regularly apply a high-factor sunscreen (minimum SPF30) and apply it again after swimming

【47】### Don’t

【48】*   do not use sunlamps or sunbeds – they use UV light

【49】Information:

【50】Find out more about sunscreen and sun safety

【51】Page last reviewed: 04 July 2023  
Next review due: 04 July 2026

source_info.title: Vitamins and minerals
source_info.text:
【0】Vitamin E \- Vitamins and minerals
==================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Vitamin A
3.  B vitamins and folic acid
4.  Vitamin C
5.  Vitamin D
6.  Vitamin E
7.  Vitamin K
8.  Calcium
9.  Iodine
10.  Iron
11.  Others

【3】**Vitamin E helps maintain healthy skin and eyes, and strengthen the body's natural defence against illness and infection (the immune system).**

【4】Good sources of vitamin E
-------------------------

【5】Vitamin E is a group of compounds found in a wide variety of foods.

【6】Good sources include:

【7】*   plant oils – such as rapeseed (vegetable oil), sunflower, soya, corn and olive oil
*   nuts and seeds
*   wheatgerm – found in cereals and cereal product

【8】How much vitamin E do I need?
-----------------------------

【9】The amount of vitamin E you need is:

【10】*   4mg a day for men
*   3mg a day for women

【11】You should be able to get all the vitamin E you need from your diet.

【12】Any vitamin E your body does not need immediately is stored for future use, so you do not need it in your diet every day.

【13】What happens if I take too much vitamin E?
------------------------------------------

【14】There is not enough evidence to know what the effects might be of taking high doses of vitamin E supplements each day.

【15】What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?
----------------------------------------------------------

【16】You should be able to get the amount of vitamin E you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【17】If you take vitamin E supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

【18】Taking 540mg (800 IU) or less a day of vitamin E supplements is unlikely to cause any harm.

【19】Page last reviewed: 03 August 2020  
Next review due: 03 August 2023

【20】*   Previous : Vitamin D
*   Next : Vitamin K

source_info.title: Angina
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Angina
==================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with

【3】**Angina is chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscles. It's not usually life threatening, but it's a warning sign that you could be at risk of a heart attack or stroke.**

【4】With treatment and healthy lifestyle changes, it's possible to control angina and reduce the risk of these more serious problems.

【5】Symptoms of angina
------------------

【6】The main symptom of angina is chest pain.

【7】Chest pain caused by angina usually:

【8】*   feels tight, dull or heavy – it may spread to your arms, neck, jaw or back
*   is triggered by physical exertion or stress
*   stops within a few minutes of resting

【9】Sometimes there might be other symptoms, like feeling sick or breathless.

【10】When to get medical help
------------------------

【11】If you have not been diagnosed with angina, get an urgent GP appointment if you have an attack of chest pain that stops within a few minutes of resting.

【12】They can check if it might be a heart problem and refer you to a hospital for tests.

【13】Find out more about how angina is diagnosed

【14】Call 999 for an ambulance if you have chest pain that does not stop after a few minutes. This could be a heart attack.

【15】Types
-----

【16】There are 2 main types of angina you can be diagnosed with:

【17】*   stable angina (more common) – attacks have a trigger (such as stress or exercise) and stop within a few minutes of resting
*   unstable angina (more serious) – attacks are more unpredictable (they may not have a trigger) and can continue despite resting

【18】Some people develop unstable angina after having stable angina.

【19】Treatment for angina
--------------------

【20】You'll probably need to take several different medicines for the rest of your life.

【21】You may be given medicine to:

【22】*   treat attacks when they happen (only taken when needed)
*   prevent further attacks
*   reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes

【23】If medicines are not suitable or do not help, an operation to improve blood flow to your heart muscles may be recommended.

【24】Living with angina
------------------

【25】If it's well controlled, there's no reason why you cannot have a largely normal life with angina.

【26】You can usually continue to do most of your normal activities.

【27】You'll probably need to make healthy lifestyle changes, such as:

【28】*   having a balanced diet
*   cutting down on alcohol
*   stopping smoking if you smoke
*   losing weight if you're overweight
*   exercising regularly – gentle exercises are usually safe

【29】This can help reduce your risk of heart attacks and strokes.

【30】Causes of angina
----------------

【31】Angina is usually caused by the arteries supplying blood to the heart muscles becoming narrowed by a build-up of fatty substances.

【32】This is called atherosclerosis.

【33】Things that can increase your risk of atherosclerosis include:

【34】*   an unhealthy diet
*   a lack of exercise
*   smoking
*   increasing age
*   a family history of atherosclerosis or heart problems

【35】Angina can also be caused by other conditions affecting the heart and arteries.

【36】Video: Angina
-------------

【37】In this video an expert describes the symptoms, stages and treatment of angina.

【38】Media last reviewed: 1 September 2021  
Media review due: 1 September 2024

【39】Page last reviewed: 22 April 2021  
Next review due: 22 April 2024

【40】*   Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: Sitagliptin
source_info.text:
【0】Taking sitagliptin with other medicines and herbal supplements
==============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines and sitagliptin can affect each other. Taking them at the same time as sitagliptin can cause low blood sugar or increase your risk of getting side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking:

【4】*   insulin or any other diabetes medicine – your doctor may want to lower the dose of these medicines when you start sitagliptin to reduce the risk of low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia)
*   ketoconazole or itraconazole, medicines for fungal infections
*   ritonavir, a medicine used to treat HIV and AIDS
*   clarithromycin, an antibiotic for treating pneumonia and ear infections
*   digoxin, a medicine for heart conditions, including heart failure

【5】Make sure that your doctor and pharmacist know you're taking sitagliptin before starting or stopping any other medicine.

【6】Mixing sitagliptin with herbal remedies and supplements
-------------------------------------------------------

【7】There's very little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements with sitagliptin. However, taking them at the same time as sitagliptin can cause low blood sugar.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【10】More in Sitagliptin
-------------------

【11】*   About sitagliptin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking sitagliptin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【12】Page last reviewed: 11 February 2022  
Next review due: 11 February 2025

source_info.title: Warfarin
source_info.text:
【0】Taking warfarin with other medicines and herbal supplements
===========================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Many medicines and supplements can affect warfarin. This can make you more likely to bleed.

【3】You might need a blood test to check the other medicine is not affecting how your blood clots.

【4】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start taking warfarin:

【5】*   medicines for heart problems, such as amiodarone, quinidine or propafenone
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or aspirin
*   cholesterol-lowering medicines, such as bezafibrate, gemfibrozil, clofibrate or cholestyramine
*   antibiotics, such as erythromycin, co-trimoxazole or norfloxacin
*   miconazole gel for fungal infections like thrush

【6】Taking warfarin with everyday painkillers
-----------------------------------------

【7】It's safe to take paracetamol while you're on warfarin. But take the lowest dose that controls your pain. Taking more than four, 500mg tablets over 24 hours for longer than a few days may make your blood clot more slowly. This puts you at risk of bleeding.

【8】If you're still in pain after taking paracetamol for 3 or 4 days, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【9】Do not take aspirin or ibuprofen while you're taking warfarin unless a doctor has said it's OK. They increase the chance of bleeding.

【10】Mixing warfarin with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------

【11】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're taking warfarin. It can increase your risk of side effects.

【12】Tell your doctor if you're taking vitamin K supplements before you start taking warfarin. Do not start taking vitamin K supplements while you are taking warfarin without checking with your doctor first.

【13】There's not enough information to say that other herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with warfarin. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines.

【14】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【15】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【16】More in Warfarin
----------------

【17】*   About warfarin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Advice about food and drink
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking warfarin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【18】Page last reviewed: 22 April 2022  
Next review due: 22 April 2025

source_info.title: Staying in hospital as an inpatient
source_info.text:
【0】Staying in hospital as an inpatient
===================================

【1】If you have been referred to hospital for an operation or test and you need to stay overnight, it means you're being treated as an inpatient.

【2】The hospital should contact you with more information before you come in. Details of what you need to do will vary depending on the hospital.

【3】They might ask you to wear a face covering over your nose and mouth, test to check if you have COVID-19 or self-isolate before you go into hospital.

【4】Check the hospital's website for more information.

【5】Find the contact details of a hospital

【6】When you arrive at the hospital, you'll be welcomed by a member of staff, who will explain the processes to you and what to expect.

【7】You'll be given an identity bracelet to wear at all times while you're in the hospital.

【8】While you're in hospital, you should be involved in all decisions about your treatment.

【9】If you wish, staff will keep members of your family or friends informed about your progress.

【10】Find out more about hospital admissions

【11】Find out more about having an operation

【12】Will I be offered same-sex hospital accommodation?
--------------------------------------------------

【13】Being in mixed-sex hospital accommodation can be difficult for some patients for a variety of personal and cultural reasons.

【14】All providers of NHS-funded care are expected to eliminate mixed-sex accommodation, except where it's in the overall best interests of the patient or reflects their personal choice.

【15】While there are some circumstances where mixing can be justified, these are mainly confined to patients who need highly specialised care, such as that given in critical care units.

【16】Find out about being detained under the Mental Health Act to learn more about this.

【17】Since April 2011, hospitals have had to provide a monthly report of the number of times they breach the Department of Health's same-sex accommodation guidance.

【18】Mixed-sex accommodation data is published on the NHS England website, and you can use this information to help you choose a hospital.

【19】Hospitals can face fines of up to £250 for breaching the same-sex accommodation guidance.

【20】While this central reporting concentrates on sleeping accommodation, mixing in bathrooms and WCs is still unacceptable.

【21】Will the hospital address possible mental health needs?
-------------------------------------------------------

【22】If you're physically ill and have to go to hospital for treatment, the team looking after you should also consider your mental health needs.

【23】Your hospital should have a liaison psychiatry service, also known as a psychological medicine service.

【24】The service aims to bridge the gap between physical and mental healthcare.

【25】In discussion with you, your healthcare team should refer you to the liaison psychiatry service where appropriate to ensure your mental health needs are met.

【26】Consent to treatment
--------------------

【27】For some procedures, including operations, you'll be asked to sign a consent form.

【28】It's up to you whether you give your consent for a treatment.

【29】You should ask as much about the treatment as possible before giving your consent so you can give an informed decision.

【30】Find out what questions to ask your doctor

【31】You can change your mind after the consent form has been signed, at any time, including during the procedure.

【32】Find out about consent to treatment

【33】You may wish to plan ahead for a time when you cannot give consent.

【34】You can pre-arrange a legally binding advance decision to refuse treatment (living will), previously known as an advance directive.

【35】Healthcare professionals must follow the advance decision, provided it's valid and applicable.

【36】You can also make broader statements about how you wish to be treated, such as receiving terminal care at home rather than in hospital.

【37】These are not legally binding, but will be taken into consideration by health professionals.

【38】### What if I'm not able to give consent?

【39】If you clearly lack the capacity to make decisions when you're admitted to hospital, health professionals will make what's called a "best interests decision" about whether a specific treatment is in your best interests.

【40】Doctors and nurses will weigh up the benefits and risks, including whether you're likely to regain the ability to give or withhold consent.

【41】Find out more about how capacity to consent is assessed

【42】### Consent under the Mental Health Act

【43】If you're held under the Mental Health Act, you can be treated against your will.

【44】This is because it's felt you do not have sufficient capacity to make an informed decision about your treatment at the time.

【45】This is also the case if you refuse treatment but the team treating you believe you should have it.

【46】The Care Quality Commission (CQC) provides detailed guidance about your rights in relation to consent to medication and electroconvulsive therapy if you're detained in hospital or placed on a community treatment order.

【47】Read more about your rights around treatment when you are restricted under the Mental Health Act on the CQC website.

【48】Find out more about the Mental Health Act

【49】Download easy read factsheets that explain your rights

【50】### Consent for children and young people

【51】Before a doctor, nurse or therapist can examine or treat your child, they must have consent or agreement.

【52】As a parent, you'll make your decisions based on what you feel is in your child's best interests.

【53】But it's advisable to involve children as much as possible in these decisions.

【54】This will give them a sense of control, and they're more likely to respond positively to their treatment.

【55】People aged 16 or over are entitled to consent to their own treatment. This can only be overruled in exceptional circumstances.

【56】Children under the age of 16 can consent to their own treatment if they're believed to have enough intelligence, competence and understanding to fully appreciate what's involved in their treatment. This is known as being Gillick competent.

【57】Find out more about consent from children and young people

【58】Advice for parents with children
--------------------------------

【59】Children can find going to hospital a daunting experience.

【60】This is partly to do with their treatment, but also because the hospital is a new and strange environment, full of new sights, smells, noises and people.

【61】If possible, talk to your child before leaving for hospital and explain what they should expect.

【62】### Stay with your child as much as you can

【63】Children often adapt better to a hospital if their parents stay with them for as long as possible.

【64】Reassure your child that you'll be staying by their side and let them know the hospital is a safe place to be.

【65】But if you have to leave the hospital at any time, inform your child how long you'll be gone for and make sure you're back on time.

【66】If you're able to stay with your child overnight, the hospital may arrange for an extra bed in your child's room or ward.

【67】### Stick to a routine

【68】Keeping a routine can help your child feel more at home.

【69】It may help if, for example, you stick to your child's usual bedtime routine, or bring in their favourite toy or comforter.

【70】### Take time for yourself

【71】While it's important to reassure children about their stay in hospital, it's just as important to look after yourself.

【72】You'll be better able to care for your child and give support if you're coping well yourself.

【73】Remember, it's fine to take breaks. Go for a walk, or get a cup of tea or coffee.

【74】Talk things through with your partner, friends or family. They'll be able to give support, and talking can be a great stress reliever.

【75】Find out more about special care for ill or premature babies

【76】Staying mobile
--------------

【77】Staying mobile in hospital can help you recover more quickly.

【78】Being immobile can lead to additional health problems, such as infections and pressure sores. It can also increase your risk of blood clots.

【79】To avoid venous thromboembolism (VTE), you'll be encouraged to move about the ward regularly. You'll be given as much assistance as you need to move about.

【80】If you're at an increased risk of VTE, you'll be given compression stockings to improve your circulation.

【81】Find out how long you should wear compression stockings after surgery

【82】Death in hospital
-----------------

【83】If someone you know dies while in hospital, the staff will advise you about what to do.

【84】If you're their next of kin, you may need to give permission for a post-mortem to be carried out.

【85】Find more information about what to do after someone dies on the GOV.UK website.

【86】General tips on hospital etiquette
----------------------------------

【87】Things to remember while you're in hospital:

【88】*   Tell staff if you're going out of the ward or unit.
*   Listen carefully to information about your treatment and medication.
*   Ask staff to explain something to you again if you do not understand.
*   Tell the doctor about any treatments you're already receiving or any allergies you have.
*   Bring any medication you're currently using with you.
*   Treat staff, fellow patients and visitors politely and with respect. Verbal abuse, harassment and physical violence are unacceptable and may lead to prosecution.
*   Follow the rules for your ward.

【89】Hospital safety and security
----------------------------

【90】### Accidents

【91】Accidents, particularly falls, occur frequently in hospitals, but many can be prevented.

【92】If you see something that could cause an accident or witness an incident, alert a member of staff immediately.

【93】To help avoid accidents in hospital:

【94】*   Ask for help if you want to get in or out of bed and feel dizzy or unwell.
*   Ensure you know where the call bell is and you can reach it easily.
*   Be aware of obstacles on the ward, wet floors and other people around you.
*   If you have glasses, wear them. If you have left them at home, ask someone to bring them in for you.
*   Wear close-fitting non-slip slippers.
*   If you use a walking aid, such as a stick or frame, keep it near to you. Make sure it's labelled with your name and contact details.
*   If your bed is too high or too low, ask the nursing staff to adjust it for you.

【95】### Fire safety

【96】Each hospital has its own fire safety procedure. Make sure you're familiar with what to do in case of a fire.

【97】Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS)
-----------------------------------------

【98】If you need help and advice about your treatment in hospital, contact the Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS).

【99】Most hospitals have their own PALS contact you can approach.

【100】To contact your local PALS:

【101】*   phone your local clinic, GP surgery, health centre or hospital and ask for details of PALS
*   search for your local PALS

【102】More in Going into hospital
---------------------------

【103】*   Outpatients and day patients
*   Going into hospital as a patient
*   Staying in hospital as an inpatient
*   Visiting someone in hospital
*   Being discharged from hospital
*   How to organise transport to and from hospital
*   Staying with my child in hospital

【104】Page last reviewed: 24 April 2023  
Next review due: 24 April 2026

source_info.title: Fluoxetine (Prozac)
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of fluoxetine
==========================

【1】Like all medicines, fluoxetine can cause side effects in some people, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Some of the common side effects will gradually improve as your body gets used to it.

【3】Common side effects
-------------------

【4】These common side effects of fluoxetine happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【5】Feeling sick (nausea)

【6】Try taking fluoxetine with or after food. It may also help to stick to simple meals and avoid rich or spicy food.

【7】Headaches

【8】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【9】Headaches usually go away after the first week of taking fluoxetine. Talk to your doctor if they last longer than a week or are severe.

【10】Being unable to sleep

【11】Take fluoxetine first thing in the morning.

【12】Diarrhoea

【13】Drink plenty of water or other fluids to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【14】Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【15】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【16】Feeling tired or weak

【17】If fluoxetine makes you feel tired or weak, stop what you’re doing and sit or lie down until you feel better.

【18】Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you’re feeling tired. It’s best not to drink alcohol as it will make you feel worse.

【19】If these symptoms do not go away after a week or two, ask your doctor for advice.

【20】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】It happens rarely (in less than 1 in 100 people), but some people may have serious side effects when taking fluoxetine.

【23】Book an appointment with your doctor if you:

【24】*   gain weight or lose weight without trying
*   get changes in your periods such as heavy bleeding, spotting, or bleeding between periods

【25】Call a doctor or call 111 straight away if you:

【26】*   get feelings of overwhelming happiness (euphoria), excessive enthusiasm or excitement, or a feeling of restlessness that means you cannot sit or stand still
*   are bleeding from the gums or get bruises that appear without a reason or that get bigger
*   are coughing up blood, or have blood in your pee
*   have black or red poo, or blood in your vomit – these can be signs of bleeding in your stomach

【27】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【28】*   you get chest pain or pressure, or shortness of breath
*   you get severe dizziness or pass out
*   you get painful erections that last longer than 2 hours – this may happen even when you are not having sex
*   you have a fit or seizure
*   you get headaches, have trouble focusing, have memory problems, cannot think clearly, have a seizure or fit, or lose your balance – these can be signs of low sodium levels
*   you have thoughts about harming yourself or ending your life
*   you get any severe bleeding, or bleeding that you cannot stop, such as cuts or nosebleeds that do not stop within 10 minutes

【29】### Serious allergic reaction

【30】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to fluoxetine.

【31】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【32】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【33】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【34】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【35】Long-term side effects
----------------------

【36】Sexual side effects, such as problems getting an erection or a lower sex drive, have been reported after taking fluoxetine. In some cases, these can continue even after stopping the medicine.

【37】Other side effects
------------------

【38】These are not all the side effects of fluoxetine. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【39】Information:

【40】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【41】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【42】More in Fluoxetine (Prozac)
---------------------------

【43】*   About fluoxetine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking fluoxetine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【44】Page last reviewed: 10 February 2022  
Next review due: 10 February 2025

【12】Diarrhoea

【13】Drink plenty of water or other fluids to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【14】Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【15】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【16】Feeling tired or weak

【17】If fluoxetine makes you feel tired or weak, stop what you’re doing and sit or lie down until you feel better.

【18】Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you’re feeling tired. It’s best not to drink alcohol as it will make you feel worse.

【19】If these symptoms do not go away after a week or two, ask your doctor for advice.

【20】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】It happens rarely (in less than 1 in 100 people), but some people may have serious side effects when taking fluoxetine.

【23】Book an appointment with your doctor if you:

【24】*   gain weight or lose weight without trying
*   get changes in your periods such as heavy bleeding, spotting, or bleeding between periods

【25】Call a doctor or call 111 straight away if you:

【26】*   get feelings of overwhelming happiness (euphoria), excessive enthusiasm or excitement, or a feeling of restlessness that means you cannot sit or stand still
*   are bleeding from the gums or get bruises that appear without a reason or that get bigger
*   are coughing up blood, or have blood in your pee
*   have black or red poo, or blood in your vomit – these can be signs of bleeding in your stomach

【27】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【28】*   you get chest pain or pressure, or shortness of breath
*   you get severe dizziness or pass out
*   you get painful erections that last longer than 2 hours – this may happen even when you are not having sex
*   you have a fit or seizure
*   you get headaches, have trouble focusing, have memory problems, cannot think clearly, have a seizure or fit, or lose your balance – these can be signs of low sodium levels
*   you have thoughts about harming yourself or ending your life
*   you get any severe bleeding, or bleeding that you cannot stop, such as cuts or nosebleeds that do not stop within 10 minutes

【29】### Serious allergic reaction

【30】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to fluoxetine.

【31】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【32】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【33】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【34】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【35】Long-term side effects
----------------------

【36】Sexual side effects, such as problems getting an erection or a lower sex drive, have been reported after taking fluoxetine. In some cases, these can continue even after stopping the medicine.

【37】Other side effects
------------------

【38】These are not all the side effects of fluoxetine. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【39】Information:

【40】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【41】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【42】More in Fluoxetine (Prozac)
---------------------------

【43】*   About fluoxetine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking fluoxetine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【44】Page last reviewed: 10 February 2022  
Next review due: 10 February 2025

source_info.title: Trazodone
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take trazodone
=================================

【1】Who can take trazodone
----------------------

【2】Most adults aged 18 years and over can take trazodone.

【3】If you have diabetes, trazodone can make it more difficult to keep your blood sugar stable. Your doctor may advise that you monitor your blood sugar more often for the first few weeks of treatment with trazodone, and adjust your diabetes treatment if necessary.

【4】Speak to your doctor if your blood sugar levels are causing you concern.

【5】Who may not be able to take trazodone
-------------------------------------

【6】Trazodone is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, check with your doctor before starting to take it if you:

【7】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to trazodone or any other medicine
*   have ever had thoughts of self-harming or ending your life
*   have recently had a heart attack or have heart, kidney or liver problems
*   have epilepsy or are having electroconvulsive treatment – trazodone may increase your risk of having a seizure
*   are pregnant, trying to get pregnant or breastfeeding
*   have porphyria, a rare disorder
*   have phaeochromocytoma, a condition that affects the adrenal glands

【8】More in Trazodone
-----------------

【9】*   About trazodone
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking trazodone with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【10】Page last reviewed: 9 March 2022  
Next review due: 9 March 2025

source_info.title: Heart attack
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Heart attack
========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery
7.  Complications
8.  Prevention

【3】**Call 999 immediately if you think someone might be having a heart attack. The faster you act, the better their chances.**

【4】Symptoms of a heart attack
--------------------------

【5】Symptoms of a heart attack can include:

【6】*   chest pain – a feeling of pressure, heaviness, tightness or squeezing across your chest
*   pain in other parts of the body – it can feel as if the pain is spreading from your chest to your arms (usually the left arm, but it can affect both arms), jaw, neck, back and tummy
*   feeling lightheaded or dizzy
*   sweating
*   shortness of breath
*   feeling sick (nausea) or being sick (vomiting)
*   an overwhelming feeling of anxiety (similar to a panic attack)
*   coughing or wheezing

【7】The chest pain is often severe, but some people may only experience minor pain, similar to indigestion.

【8】While the most common symptom is chest pain, symptoms can vary from person to person. Some people may have other symptoms such as shortness of breath, feeling or being sick and back or jaw pain without any chest pain.

【9】Waiting for an ambulance
------------------------

【10】If you have had a heart attack, it's important that you rest while you wait for an ambulance, to avoid unnecessary strain on your heart.

【11】If aspirin is available and you are not allergic to it, slowly chew and then swallow an adult-size tablet (300mg) while you wait for the ambulance.

【12】Aspirin helps to thin your blood and improve blood flow to your heart.

【13】Cardiac arrest 
---------------

【14】In some cases, a complication called ventricular arrhythmia can cause the heart to stop beating. This is known as sudden cardiac arrest.

【15】Signs and symptoms that suggest a person has gone into cardiac arrest include:

【16】*   they appear not to be breathing
*   they're not moving
*   they don't respond to any stimulation, such as being touched or spoken to

【17】If you think somebody has gone into cardiac arrest, call 999 immediately and start doing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

【18】If there is someone with you, ask them to find an automated external defibrillator (AED) and use it as soon as you can.

【19】### Hands-only CPR (chest compressions)

【20】To do chest compressions on an adult:

【21】1.  Place the heel of your hand on the breastbone at the centre of the person's chest. Place your other hand on top of your first hand and interlock your fingers.
2.  Using your body weight (not just your arms), press straight down by 5 to 6cm on their chest.
3.  Repeat this until an ambulance arrives.

【22】Aim to do 100 to 120 compressions a minute. Watch CPR training videos on the British Heart Foundation website.

【23】Find out about how to resuscitate a child.

【24】### Automated external defibrillator (AED)

【25】If you have access to an AED, you should use it. An AED is a safe, portable electrical device that most large organisations keep as part of first aid equipment.

【26】It helps to establish a regular heartbeat during a cardiac arrest by monitoring the person's heartbeat and giving them an electric shock if necessary.

【27】Find out more about automated external defibrillators (AED) on the Arrhythmia Alliance website

【28】Angina and heart attacks
------------------------

【29】Angina is chest pain caused by the supply of oxygen-rich blood to the heart becoming restricted.

【30】People with angina can experience similar symptoms to a heart attack, but they usually happen during exercise and pass within a few minutes.

【31】However, occasionally, people with angina can have a heart attack. It's important to recognise the difference between the symptoms of angina and those of a heart attack. The best way to do this is to remember that the symptoms of angina can be controlled with medicine, but symptoms of a heart attack cannot.

【32】If you have angina, you may have been prescribed medicine (glyceryl trinitrate) that improves your symptoms within 5 minutes. If the first dose does not work, a second dose can be taken after 5 minutes.

【33】Call 999 if the second dose does not work after 5 minutes.

【34】Call 999 sooner if the pain gets worse or you feel unwell, for example feeling sick, dizzy or short of breath.

【35】Page last reviewed: 13 July 2023  
Next review due: 13 July 2026

【36】*   Previous : Heart attack
*   Next : Causes

source_info.title: Clarithromycin
source_info.text:
【0】Taking clarithromycin with other medicines and herbal supplements
=================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that do not mix well with clarithromycin.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start clarithromycin:

【4】*   ergotamine or dihydroergotamine, used to treat migraines
*   medicines for epilepsy, such as carbamazepine or phenytoin
*   theophylline for asthma
*   colchicine for gout
*   digoxin, for some heart problems
*   warfarin, used to help prevent blood clots (sometimes called a blood thinner)
*   a statin medicine to lower your cholesterol, such as simvastatin or atorvastatin

【5】Mixing clarithromycin with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------------

【6】Clarithromycin may not mix well with some complementary and herbal remedies.

【7】It's best to check with your doctor or a pharmacist before taking any herbal remedies or supplements while taking clarithromycin.

【8】There's not enough information to say that complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with clarithromycin. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【9】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【10】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【11】More in Clarithromycin
----------------------

【12】*   About clarithromycin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking clarithromycin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【13】Page last reviewed: 26 January 2022  
Next review due: 26 January 2025

source_info.title: Colposcopy
source_info.text:
【0】Getting ready \- Colposcopy
===========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  What is a colposcopy?
2.  Why it's done
3.  Getting ready
4.  What happens on the day
5.  Results

【3】If your cervical screening results show that abnormal cervical cells linked with human papillomavirus (HPV) were found, you will get a letter inviting you for a colposcopy.

【4】You will be given your appointment time in your letter. You may have to wait 8 weeks or more.

【5】The procedure will usually take place at a colposcopy unit at a local hospital or clinic.

【6】Contact the hospital or clinic before your appointment if:

【7】*   you think you will be having your period at the time of your appointment as your appointment may need to be rescheduled
*   you’re pregnant or think you may be pregnant – it is safe to have a colposcopy when pregnant, but you need to tell the hospital or clinic before you attend your appointment
*   you’d like someone to be in the room with you (a chaperone), for example someone you know, a nurse or member of staff
*   you need an interpreter

【8】Getting ready for a colposcopy
------------------------------

【9】For the 24 hours before your colposcopy:

【10】*   do not have penetrative vaginal sex
*   do not use any products that you place inside your vagina, such as tampons, vaginal creams or medicines

【11】You might have some minor bleeding after the colposcopy, so it’s a good idea to bring a sanitary pad or panty liner to the appointment.

【12】If you have a coil (IUD, or Mirena coil) it does not usually need to be taken out, but tell the person doing the colposcopy that you have one.

【13】Page last reviewed: 24 May 2022  
Next review due: 24 May 2025

【14】*   Previous : Why it's done
*   Next : What happens on the day

【6】Contact the hospital or clinic before your appointment if:

【7】*   you think you will be having your period at the time of your appointment as your appointment may need to be rescheduled
*   you’re pregnant or think you may be pregnant – it is safe to have a colposcopy when pregnant, but you need to tell the hospital or clinic before you attend your appointment
*   you’d like someone to be in the room with you (a chaperone), for example someone you know, a nurse or member of staff
*   you need an interpreter

【8】Getting ready for a colposcopy
------------------------------

【9】For the 24 hours before your colposcopy:

【10】*   do not have penetrative vaginal sex
*   do not use any products that you place inside your vagina, such as tampons, vaginal creams or medicines

【11】You might have some minor bleeding after the colposcopy, so it’s a good idea to bring a sanitary pad or panty liner to the appointment.

【12】If you have a coil (IUD, or Mirena coil) it does not usually need to be taken out, but tell the person doing the colposcopy that you have one.

source_info.title: Tranexamic acid
source_info.text:
【0】Taking tranexamic acid with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Cyklokapron
=============================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Tranexamic acid can be taken with most other medicines.

【3】However, talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking the combined contraceptive pill. There could be a very small increased risk of getting a blood clot if you take tranexamic acid as well.

【4】Mixing tranexamic acid with herbal remedies or supplements
----------------------------------------------------------

【5】There's not enough information to say that complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with tranexamic acid. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【6】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【7】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【8】More in Tranexamic acid
-----------------------

【9】*   About tranexamic acid
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking tranexamic acid with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Pulmonary hypertension
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Pulmonary hypertension
================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment

【3】**Pulmonary hypertension is caused by changes to the pulmonary arteries, the blood vessels that carry blood from the heart to the lungs.**

【4】There are 5 main types of pulmonary hypertension.

【5】Pulmonary arterial hypertension
-------------------------------

【6】Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) covers several conditions that cause changes in the smaller branches of the pulmonary arteries.

【7】The walls of the arteries become thick and stiff, narrowing the space for blood to pass through and increasing blood pressure.

【8】PAH can be caused by conditions including:

【9】*   **connective tissue diseases** – such as scleroderma, a condition that causes thickened areas of skin and problems with blood vessels
*   **congenital heart problems** – such as a hole in the heart
*   **portal hypertension** – abnormally high blood pressure in the vein that takes blood to the liver, usually caused by a problem with the liver
*   **HIV**

【10】It can also be caused by certain medicines or drugs.

【11】A small number of people develop PAH without having any other medical condition. This is called idiopathic PAH. In very rare cases, PAH can be inherited. 

【12】### Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

【13】In rare cases, newborn babies can have high pressure inside their blood vessels, which means their heart cannot pump enough oxygenated blood around their body. This is known as persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).

【14】Treatment in an intensive care unit may be needed if simple measures such as keeping the baby warm and giving oxygen do not increase oxygen levels to normal.

【15】The Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children website has more information about persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.

【16】Pulmonary hypertension linked to left heart disease
---------------------------------------------------

【17】If there are problems with the left side of the heart, the right side has to work harder to pump blood through the lungs. This increases blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries.

【18】Problems with the left side of the heart are thought to be one of the most common causes of pulmonary hypertension. These include mitral valve problems, left ventricle problems and aortic valve conditions.

【19】Pulmonary hypertension linked with lung disease or lack of oxygen
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【20】Pulmonary hypertension is also sometimes linked with lung diseases or lack of oxygen (hypoxia), including:

【21】*   **chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)** – a number of lung conditions that affect breathing
*   **interstitial lung disease** – a group of lung disorders that cause scarring of the lung tissue, which makes it difficult to get enough oxygen into your body
*   **conditions that affect breathing while you're in a deep sleep** – such as sleep apnoea

【22】Low levels of oxygen in the blood make the pulmonary arteries narrow. This squeezes the blood into a smaller space, which increases blood pressure, causing pulmonary hypertension.

【23】Pulmonary hypertension caused by blood clots
--------------------------------------------

【24】Pulmonary hypertension can sometimes be caused by scars from previous blood clots that narrow or block the pulmonary arteries. This is called chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.

【25】A blood clot that blocks one of the blood vessels that supply your lungs is called a pulmonary embolism.

【26】Pulmonary hypertension caused by other conditions
-------------------------------------------------

【27】Other, less common, causes of pulmonary hypertension include: 

【28】*   conditions that cause inflammation, including sarcoidosis and vasculitis
*   metabolic conditions such as thyroid disease and glycogen storage disease
*   blood disorders such as sickle cell disease and thalassaemia
*   chronic kidney disease
*   compression of the blood vessels in the lungs – for example, as the result of a tumour

【29】Read about how pulmonary hypertension is diagnosed.

【30】Page last reviewed: 02 May 2023  
Next review due: 02 May 2026

【31】*   Previous : Pulmonary hypertension
*   Next : Diagnosis
