source_info.title: Thalassaemia
source_info.text:
【0】Thalassaemia carriers \- Thalassaemia
=====================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Thalassaemia carriers

【3】**If you're a carrier of thalassaemia, it means you carry one of the faulty genes that cause thalassaemia, but you do not have thalassaemia yourself.**

【4】Being a carrier of the trait is sometimes known as having the thalassaemia trait or having thalassaemia minor.

【5】If you carry thalassaemia, you will not ever develop thalassaemia, but you may sometimes experience mild anaemia. This is because your red blood cells are smaller than usual.

【6】This type of anaemia is different from iron deficiency anaemia and does not need any treatment.

【7】You can find out if you're a carrier of thalassaemia by having a simple blood test.

【8】GOV.UK also has more information to help you understand what it means to be a beta thalassaemia or delta beta thalassaemia carrier if you're pregnant.

【9】*   GOV.UK: beta thalassaemia carrier
*   GOV.UK: delta beta thalassaemia carrier

【10】Who can carry thalassaemia?
---------------------------

【11】Anyone can be a carrier of thalassaemia, but it's much more common in people from certain ethnic backgrounds.

【12】Thalassaemia mainly affects people who are from, or who have family members originally from:

【13】*   around the Mediterranean, including Italy, Greece and Cyprus
*   India, Pakistan and Bangladesh
*   the Middle East
*   China and southeast Asia

【14】You can have a blood test to see if you're a carrier if you think you may be at risk.

【15】Testing for the thalassaemia trait
----------------------------------

【16】Screening for thalassaemia is offered to all pregnant women in England.

【17】Find out more about screening for thalassaemia in pregnancy

【18】Alternatively, anyone can ask to have a free test to find out if they're a carrier at any point.

【19】This can be particularly useful if:

【20】*   you have a family history of thalassaemia or the thalassaemia trait
*   you're sexually active and want to find out if you're at risk of having a child with thalassaemia
*   your partner is known to have the thalassaemia trait

【21】You can request the test from your GP surgery. A genetic counsellor will discuss the result and implications with you if you're found to have the trait.

【22】Having children
---------------

【23】If you have the thalassaemia trait, you're at risk of having children with thalassaemia if your partner is also a carrier or has thalassaemia themselves.

【24】If you're planning to have a child and you know you're a carrier, it's a good idea for your partner to be tested as well.

【25】If you and your partner both have the trait for the main type of thalassaemia (beta thalassaemia), there's a:

【26】*   1 in 4 chance each child you have will not have thalassaemia or carry the thalassaemia trait
*   1 in 2 chance each child you have will be a carrier of thalassaemia, but will not have the condition themselves
*   1 in 4 chance each child you have will be born with thalassaemia

【27】If both of you are carriers and you're planning to have a baby, talk to your GP about getting a referral to a genetic counsellor, who can explain the risks to your children and what your options are.

【28】These include:

【29】*   having tests during pregnancy to see if your baby has thalassaemia
*   adopting a child
*   trying in vitro fertilisation (IVF) with a donor egg or sperm
*   trying preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-M, which used to be called PGD), although this is not widely available in the UK

【30】PGT-M is similar to IVF, but the resulting embryos are tested to check they do not have thalassaemia before they're implanted in the womb. 

【31】The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) has more information about PGT-M

【32】Possible health problems
------------------------

【33】You will not develop thalassaemia at any point if you're a carrier of it.

【34】You can live a normal life and generally will not have any health problems as a result of being a carrier.

【35】But you may develop mild anaemia, which is where there are low levels of haemoglobin (a substance that transports oxygen) in the blood.

【36】This can cause symptoms such as tiredness and pale skin, but may only be picked up with a blood test.

【37】This type of anaemia is different from iron deficiency anaemia and does not need any treatment.

【38】If you have anaemia, it's important not to take iron supplements for it unless you're diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia.

【39】Taking iron supplements when you already have enough iron in your body could be harmful.

【40】Carriers of other blood disorders
---------------------------------

【41】People who are carriers of thalassaemia are also at risk of having a child with a blood condition if their partner is a carrier of a different type of blood condition.

【42】You can find more detailed information about some of the other types of carrier in the following leaflets:

【43】*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin O Arab carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin C carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin D carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin E carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin Lepore carrier
*   GOV.UK: sickle cell carrier

【44】Page last reviewed: 17 October 2022  
Next review due: 17 October 2025

【45】*   Previous : Living with

7.  Thalassaemia carriers</mark>iers

【3】**If you're a carrier of thalassaemia, it means you carry one of the faulty genes that cause thalassaemia, but you do not have thalassaemia yourself.**

【4】Being a carrier of the trait is sometimes known as having the thalassaemia trait or having thalassaemia minor.

【5】If you carry thalassaemia, you will not ever develop thalassaemia, but you may sometimes experience mild anaemia. This is because your red blood cells are smaller than usual.

【6】This type of anaemia is different from iron deficiency anaemia and does not need any treatment.

【7】You can find out if you're a carrier of thalassaemia by having a simple blood test.

【8】GOV.UK also has more information to help you understand what it means to be a beta thalassaemia or delta beta thalassaemia carrier if you're pregnant.

<mark>【9】*   GOV.UK: beta thalassaemia carrier

GOV.UK: delta beta thalassaemia carrier</mark>ier

【10】Who can carry thalassaemia?
---------------------------

【11】Anyone can be a carrier of thalassaemia, but it's much more common in people from certain ethnic backgrounds.

【12】Thalassaemia mainly affects people who are from, or who have family members originally from:

【13】*   around the Mediterranean, including Italy, Greece and Cyprus
*   India, Pakistan and Bangladesh
*   the Middle East
*   China and southeast Asia

【14】You can have a blood test to see if you're a carrier if you think you may be at risk.

【15】Testing for the thalassaemia trait
----------------------------------

【16】Screening for thalassaemia is offered to all pregnant women in England.

【17】Find out more about screening for thalassaemia in pregnancy

【18】Alternatively, anyone can ask to have a free test to find out if they're a carrier at any point.

【19】This can be particularly useful if:

【20】*   you have a family history of thalassaemia or the thalassaemia trait
*   you're sexually active and want to find out if you're at risk of having a child with thalassaemia
*   your partner is known to have the thalassaemia trait

【21】You can request the test from your GP surgery. A genetic counsellor will discuss the result and implications with you if you're found to have the trait.

【22】Having children
---------------

【23】If you have the thalassaemia trait, you're at risk of having children with thalassaemia if your partner is also a carrier or has thalassaemia themselves.

【24】If you're planning to have a child and you know you're a carrier, it's a good idea for your partner to be tested as well.

【25】If you and your partner both have the trait for the main type of thalassaemia (beta thalassaemia), there's a:

【26】*   1 in 4 chance each child you have will not have thalassaemia or carry the thalassaemia trait
*   1 in 2 chance each child you have will be a carrier of thalassaemia, but will not have the condition themselves
*   1 in 4 chance each child you have will be born with thalassaemia

【27】If both of you are carriers and you're planning to have a baby, talk to your GP about getting a referral to a genetic counsellor, who can explain the risks to your children and what your options are.

【28】These include:

【29】*   having tests during pregnancy to see if your baby has thalassaemia
*   adopting a child
*   trying in vitro fertilisation (IVF) with a donor egg or sperm
*   trying preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-M, which used to be called PGD), although this is not widely available in the UK

【30】PGT-M is similar to IVF, but the resulting embryos are tested to check they do not have thalassaemia before they're implanted in the womb. 

【31】The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) has more information about PGT-M

【32】Possible health problems
------------------------

【33】You will not develop thalassaemia at any point if you're a carrier of it.

【34】You can live a normal life and generally will not have any health problems as a result of being a carrier.

【35】But you may develop mild anaemia, which is where there are low levels of haemoglobin (a substance that transports oxygen) in the blood.

【36】This can cause symptoms such as tiredness and pale skin, but may only be picked up with a blood test.

【37】This type of anaemia is different from iron deficiency anaemia and does not need any treatment.

【38】If you have anaemia, it's important not to take iron supplements for it unless you're diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia.

【39】Taking iron supplements when you already have enough iron in your body could be harmful.

【40】Carriers of other blood disorders
---------------------------------

【41】People who are carriers of thalassaemia are also at risk of having a child with a blood condition if their partner is a carrier of a different type of blood condition.

【42】You can find more detailed information about some of the other types of carrier in the following leaflets:

【43】*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin O Arab carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin C carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin D carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin E carrier
*   GOV.UK: haemoglobin Lepore carrier
*   GOV.UK: sickle cell carrier

【44】Page last reviewed: 17 October 2022  
Next review due: 17 October 2025

【45】*   Previous : Living with

source_info.title: Sotrovimab (Xevudy)
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about sotrovimab
=================================

【1】How does sotrovimab work?

【2】Sotrovimab helps to treat COVID-19 by sticking to a protein on the surface of the virus called the spike protein. This stops the virus from getting into your lungs and causing an infection.

【3】This can also help your body fight the virus and help you get better faster.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】Sotrovimab works best when it's taken as soon as possible after you've had a positive COVID-19 test and within 5 days of your symptoms starting.

【6】Everyone has a different experience of COVID-19, especially if you have risks for getting severe disease. Sotrovimab will increase the chances of you having a milder infection and help your body recover more quickly.

【7】How effective is sotrovimab?

【8】If you have mild or moderate COVID-19, evidence shows that sotrovimab is very effective at reducing your risk of severe symptoms and you may not need hospital treatment.

【9】How do other medicines for COVID-19 compare?

【10】Sotrovimab is a neutralising monoclonal antibody (nMAb).

【11】There are other treatments for COVID-19 which work in a different way. There are 3 antiviral medicines which stop the COVID-19 virus from growing and spreading:

【12】*   nirmatrelvir and ritonavir (Paxlovid) comes as tablets
*   remdesivir (Veklury) is given as a drip, usually into your arm (infusion)
*   molnupiravir comes as capsules. It treats mild to moderate COVID-19 but it has not been tested in people with severe symptoms who need treatment with oxygen

【13】None of these medicines are a substitute for COVID-19 vaccines. It's very important you still have these.

【14】Find out more about treatments for COVID-19

【15】Will it affect my contraception?

【16】It's important not to have sex or close contact with anyone while you have COVID-19 as you may pass the infection on to them.

【17】Sotrovimab is not known to stop any contraception from working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【18】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【19】If you're being treated for COVID-19, you must stay at home to avoid passing the infection on to other people.

【20】Some people feel dizzy after having sotrovimab. This may make it more difficult to concentrate and react.

【21】If you feel dizzy after your treatment, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery.

【22】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【23】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while having sotrovimab. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【24】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【25】It's not yet known if alcohol affects sotrovimab.

【26】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【27】There is no food or drink you need to avoid before or after having sotrovimab.

【28】It's important to drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated if you have COVID-19.

【29】More in Sotrovimab (Xevudy)
---------------------------

【30】*   About sotrovimab
*   Who can and cannot have it
*   How and when to have it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Having sotrovimab with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【31】Page last reviewed: 20 December 2021  
Next review due: 20 December 2024

source_info.title: Hyoscine hydrobromide (Kwells and Joy-Rides)
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking hyoscine hydrobromide \- Brand names: Kwells, Joy-Rides, Kwells Kids, Travel Calm, Scopoderm
================================================================================================================================================

【1】Hyoscine hydrobromide and pregnancy
-----------------------------------

【2】Hyoscine hydrobromide is not recommended during pregnancy because not enough is known about its effects.

【3】However, your doctor may offer you hyoscine hydrobromide if you have severe travel sickness that cannot be treated any other way.

【4】Hyoscine hydrobromide and breastfeeding
---------------------------------------

【5】It is not known how much hyoscine hydrobromide gets into breast milk, but it's likely to be a very small amount.

【6】If you are only taking occasional doses of hyoscine hydrobromide for a short time, for example for travel sickness, it's OK to use while breastfeeding and your baby does not need to be monitored for side effects.

【7】If you need to take hyoscine hydrobromide more regularly, this is still OK while breastfeeding, but monitor your baby for possible side effects, such as sleepiness, constipation, and peeing less than usual.

【8】If your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or you have any other concerns about your baby while you're breastfeeding, talk to your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife.

【9】Hyoscine hydrobromide and fertility
-----------------------------------

【10】There's no good evidence to suggest that taking hyoscine hydrobromide reduces fertility in either men or women.

【11】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【12】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【13】Find out more about how hyoscine hydrobromide can affect you and your baby on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.

【14】More in Hyoscine hydrobromide (Kwells and Joy-Rides)
----------------------------------------------------

【15】*   About hyoscine hydrobromide
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【16】Page last reviewed: 5 October 2022  
Next review due: 5 October 2025

source_info.title: Budesonide rectal foam and enemas
source_info.text:
【0】Using budesonide rectal foam and enemas with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Budenofalk, Entocort
========================================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines can affect the way budesonide rectal foam and enemas work and increase your chance of getting side effects.

【3】Speak to a doctor or a pharmacist before starting to use budesonide rectal foam or enemas if you take any of these:

【4】*   medicines used to treat HIV, such as ritonavir or cobicistat
*   antifungal medicines, such as itraconazole
*   other medicines that contain steroids, such as eczema creams, steroid tablets, injections, inhalers, nasal sprays, or eye or nose drops

【5】Mixing budesonide with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【6】There's not enough information to say whether complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with budesonide rectal foam and enemas. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【7】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【8】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【9】More in Budesonide rectal foam and enemas
-----------------------------------------

【10】*   About budesonide rectal foam and enemas
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【11】Page last reviewed: 16 August 2023  
Next review due: 16 August 2026

text.content:
【0】Using budesonide rectal foam and enemas with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Budenofalk, Entocort
========================================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines can affect the way budesonide rectal foam and enemas work and increase your chance of getting side effects.

【3】Speak to a doctor or a pharmacist before starting to use budesonide rectal foam or enemas if you take any of these:

【4】*   medicines used to treat HIV, such as ritonavir or cobicistat
*   antifungal medicines, such as itraconazole
*   other medicines that contain steroids, such as eczema creams, steroid tablets, injections, inhalers, nasal sprays, or eye or nose drops

【5】Mixing budesonide with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【6】There's not enough information to say whether complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with budesonide rectal foam and enemas. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【7】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【8】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【9】More in Budesonide rectal foam and enemas
-----------------------------------------

source_info.title: Slipped disc
source_info.text:
【0】Slipped disc
============

【1】A slipped disc is when a soft cushion of tissue between the bones in your spine pushes out. It's painful if it presses on nerves. It usually gets better slowly with rest, gentle exercise and painkillers.

【2】Check if it's a slipped disc
----------------------------

【3】A slipped disc (also called a prolapsed or herniated disc) can cause:

【4】*   lower back pain
*   numbness or tingling in your shoulders, back, arms, hands, legs or feet
*   neck pain
*   problems bending or straightening your back
*   muscle weakness
*   pain in the buttocks, hips or legs if the disc is pressing on the sciatic nerve (sciatica)

【5】Not all slipped discs cause symptoms. Many people will never know they have slipped a disc.

【6】### Other causes of back pain

【7】Sometimes the pain may be a result of an injury such as a sprain or strain, but often there's no obvious reason.

【8】Back pain is rarely caused by anything serious.

【9】How you can ease the pain from a slipped disc yourself
------------------------------------------------------

【10】### Keep active

【11】If the pain is very bad, you may need to rest at first. But start gentle exercise as soon as you can – it'll help you get better faster.

【12】The type of exercise is not important, just gradually increase your activity level.

【13】### Take painkillers

【14】Alternate painkillers such as ibuprofen and paracetamol. Paracetamol on its own is not recommended for back pain.

【15】Take them regularly (up to the recommended daily amount) rather than just when the pain is particularly bad. This will help you to keep moving.

【16】A pharmacist can help with a slipped disc
-----------------------------------------

【17】Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen are not suitable for everyone. Speak to a pharmacist if you're not sure.

【18】Stronger painkillers containing codeine may help for pain that's just started.

【19】But these types of painkillers can cause addiction and should only be used for a few days.

【20】Find a pharmacy

【21】### Non-urgent advice: See a GP if you have back pain and:

【22】*   painkillers are not helping
*   the pain is no better after a month
*   a very high temperature or you feel hot and shivery
*   unexplained weight loss
*   a swelling in your back
*   the pain is worse at night

【23】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if you have back pain and:

【24】*   numbness around your bottom or genitals
*   cannot pee
*   lose feeling in 1 or both legs
*   cannot control when you pee or poo
*   got it after a serious accident, such as a car accident

【25】### What happens at your appointment

【26】Your GP will usually be able to tell if you have a slipped disc from your symptoms.

【27】You may also have a physical examination. Your GP might ask you to raise your arms or do simple leg exercises to find out where the slipped disc is.

【28】Treatment for a slipped disc from a GP
--------------------------------------

【29】A GP might prescribe a stronger painkiller, a steroid injection or a muscle relaxant to use in the short term.

【30】If your symptoms do not get better, a GP might recommend further tests, like an MRI scan.

【31】They might also refer you to a physiotherapist. Physiotherapy from the NHS might not be available everywhere and waiting times can be long. You can also get it privately.

【32】Find a physiotherapist

【33】Surgery for a slipped disc
--------------------------

【34】Surgery is not usually needed, but a GP might refer to you a specialist to discuss surgery if your symptoms:

【35】*   have not improved using other treatments
*   include worsening muscle weakness, or numbness

【36】Alternative treatments for a slipped disc
-----------------------------------------

【37】There's some evidence that manual therapies, like osteopathy, can help ease lower back pain.

【38】You'll usually have to pay for this treatment privately.

【39】What causes a slipped disc
--------------------------

【40】They can happen because of:

【41】*   ageing
*   exercising too hard
*   lifting heavy objects the wrong way
*   vibration from driving or operating machinery
*   being inactive or overweight

【42】To help prevent a slipped disc
------------------------------

【43】### Do

【44】*   keep active – take regular exercise

【45】*   use a safe technique when lifting heavy objects

【46】### Don’t

【47】*   do not smoke – nicotine weakens the disc tissue

【48】Page last reviewed: 22 March 2021  
Next review due: 22 March 2024

source_info.title: Malnutrition
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Malnutrition
======================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment

【3】**Malnutrition (undernutrition) is caused by a lack of nutrients, either as a result of a poor diet or problems absorbing nutrients from food.**

【4】Certain things can increase your risk of becoming malnourished.

【5】Health conditions
-----------------

【6】Some health conditions that can lead to malnutrition include:

【7】*   long-term conditions that cause loss of appetite, feeling sick (nausea) and/or changes in bowel habit (such as diarrhoea and vomiting – these include cancer, liver disease and some lung conditions (such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease)
*   mental health conditions, such as depression or schizophrenia, which may affect your mood and desire to eat
*   conditions that disrupt your ability to digest food or absorb nutrients, such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis
*   dementia, which can cause a person to neglect their wellbeing and forget to eat
*   an eating disorder, such as anorexia

【8】You can also become malnourished if your body needs an increased amount of energy – for example, if you're healing after surgery or a serious injury such as a burn, or if you have involuntary movements such as a tremor or shaking hands.

【9】Medicines
---------

【10】Some types of medicine may also increase your risk of developing malnutrition.

【11】Some medicines have unpleasant side effects, such as making you feel sick, losing your appetite, or having diarrhoea, which could mean you eat less or do not absorb as many nutrients from food.

【12】Physical and social factors
---------------------------

【13】The following factors can also contribute to malnutrition:

【14】*   teeth that are in poor condition, or dentures (false teeth) that do not fit properly, which can make eating difficult or painful
*   a physical disability or other impairment that makes it difficult to move around, cook or shop for food
*   living alone and being socially isolated
*   having limited knowledge about nutrition or cooking
*   alcohol or drug dependency
*   low income or poverty

【15】Causes of malnutrition in children
----------------------------------

【16】In the UK, malnutrition in children is often caused by long-term health conditions that:

【17】*   lead to a lack of appetite
*   disrupt digestion
*   increase the body's demand for energy

【18】Examples of these types of conditions include childhood cancers, congenital heart disease, cystic fibrosis and cerebral palsy.

【19】Some children may become malnourished because of an eating disorder or a behavioural or psychological condition that means they avoid or refuse food.

【20】Malnutrition caused by a poor diet is rare in the UK, but it can happen if a child is neglected, living in poverty or being abused.

【21】Call the NSPCC helpline on 0808 800 5000 if you're concerned about a child.

【22】Page last reviewed: 23 May 2023  
Next review due: 23 May 2026

【23】*   Previous : Symptoms
*   Next : Treatment

source_info.title: Mirabegron
source_info.text:
【0】Taking mirabegron with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Betmiga
====================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Mirabegron may affect the way other medicines work, and other medicines may affect how mirabegron works.

【3】Tell your pharmacist or doctor if you're taking:

【4】*   digoxin, a medicine for heart failure or abnormal heart rhythm
*   imipramine, a medicine for depression
*   dabigatran, a medicine to help prevent blood clots (anticoagulant)
*   clarithromycin, an antibiotic
*   ketoconazole or itraconazole, medicines used to treat fungal infections
*   medicines used to treat HIV, such as ritonavir

【5】Taking mirabegron with painkillers
----------------------------------

【6】It's safe to take mirabegron with everyday painkillers like paracetamol and ibuprofen.

【7】Taking mirabegron with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【8】There's not enough information to say that complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with mirabegron. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【9】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【10】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【11】More in Mirabegron
------------------

【12】*   About mirabegron
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【13】Page last reviewed: 21 July 2023  
Next review due: 21 July 2026

source_info.title: Montelukast
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of montelukast \- Brand name: Singulair
====================================================

【1】Like all medicines, montelukast can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of montelukast happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Diarrhoea

【5】Drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【6】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【7】High temperature

【8】Paracetamol will help to bring the temperature down. Drink plenty of fluids. See your doctor if it lasts for more than a few days.

【9】Headaches

【10】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【11】Headaches should usually go away after the first week of taking montelukast. Talk to your doctor if headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【12】Stomach pain

【13】Try to rest and relax. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Putting a heat pad or covered hot water bottle on your stomach may also help.

【14】If you're in a lot of pain, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【15】Feeling or being sick

【16】Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food. If you're being sick, try small frequent sips of water to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark strong-smelling pee.

【17】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【18】A mild rash

【19】It may help to take an antihistamine, which you can buy from a pharmacy. Check with the pharmacist to see what type is right for you.

【20】If the rash gets worse, speak to your doctor.

【21】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【22】Serious side effects
--------------------

【23】Call your doctor or call 111 immediately if:

【24】*   you notice mood changes and you become depressed, aggressive or you're thinking of harming yourself
*   you see things which are not there (hallucinations)
*   you're finding it harder than usual to concentrate or remember things
*   your speech changes or you start stuttering
*   you have shaking or trembling in any part of your body
*   you have an unusual or fast heartbeat
*   you develop a combination of symptoms such as a flu-like illness, pins and needles or numbness of arms or legs, worsening of asthma symptoms, or a rash
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin – this can be a sign of liver problems

【25】### Serious allergic reaction

【26】It is possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to montelukast.

【27】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【28】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【29】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【30】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【31】Other side effects
------------------

【32】These are not all the side effects of montelukast. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【33】Information:

【34】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【35】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【36】More in Montelukast
-------------------

【37】*   About montelukast
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【38】Page last reviewed: 14 March 2023  
Next review due: 14 March 2026

【24】*   you notice mood changes and you become depressed, aggressive or you're thinking of harming yourself
*   you see things which are not there (hallucinations)
*   you're finding it harder than usual to concentrate or remember things
*   your speech changes or you start stuttering
*   you have shaking or trembling in any part of your body
*   you have an unusual or fast heartbeat
*   you develop a combination of symptoms such as a flu-like illness, pins and needles or numbness of arms or legs, worsening of asthma symptoms, or a rash
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin – this can be a sign of liver problems

【25】### Serious allergic reaction

【26】It is possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to montelukast.

【27】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【28】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【29】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【30】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【31】Other side effects
------------------

【32】These are not all the side effects of montelukast. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【33】Information:

【34】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【35】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【36】More in Montelukast
-------------------

【37】*   About montelukast
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【38】Page last reviewed: 14 March 2023  
Next review due: 14 March 2026

source_info.title: Prochlorperazine
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about prochlorperazine \- Brand names: Stemetil, Buccastem
===========================================================================

【1】How does prochlorperazine work?

【2】Prochlorperazine belongs to a group of medicines called phenothiazines.

【3】Phenothiazines are thought to work by blocking the action of a chemical called dopamine in the brain. This stops nausea messages from being sent to a part of your brain called the vomiting centre.

【4】The vomiting centre controls when you feel sick or vomit.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】Prochlorperazine starts to work in around 30 to 60 minutes.

【7】If you're taking it for Ménière's disease, it will take a few days before it reaches its full effect.

【8】Is prochlorperazine addictive?

【9】Prochlorperazine is not usually addictive. However, if you stop taking it suddenly after taking it for a long time, it can cause withdrawal symptoms such as feeling or being sick and problems sleeping.

【10】Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking prochlorperazine after taking it for a long time. They'll probably want to reduce your dose gradually to stop you having any of these withdrawal symptoms.

【11】How does prochlorperazine compare with other anti-sickness medicines?

【12】Prochlorperazine belongs to a group of medicines known as anti-sickness (anti-emetic) medicines.

【13】There's not enough information available to say whether one is better than another for helping with sickness. You may need to try a few different medicines to find out what works best for you.

【14】There are also other medicines that can help with different types of sickness, such as metoclopramide, ondansetron, domperidone and cyclizine.

【15】Will it affect my contraception?

【16】Prochlorperazine does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【17】But if prochlorperazine is not working for you and you're being sick, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look at your pill packet to find out what to do.

【18】Find out what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick.

【19】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【20】Do not drive a car or ride a bike if prochlorperazine makes you sleepy or gives you an irregular heartbeat.

【21】This may be more likely when you first start taking prochlorperazine, but could happen at any time, for example, when starting another medicine.

【22】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【23】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking prochlorperazine. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【24】Can I drink alcohol while taking prochlorperazine?

【25】It's best not to drink alcohol when taking prochlorperazine.

【26】Drinking alcohol can make side effects worse, such as feeling sleepy or an irregular heartbeat.

【27】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【28】Apart from avoiding alcohol, you can eat and drink normally while taking prochlorperazine.

【29】It's best to take buccal tablets after food so you do not accidentally swallow them before they dissolve.

【30】More in Prochlorperazine
------------------------

【31】*   About prochlorperazine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【32】Page last reviewed: 7 September 2023  
Next review due: 7 September 2026

source_info.title: You and your baby at 26 weeks pregnant
source_info.text:
【0】You and your baby at 26 weeks pregnant
======================================

【1】Your baby at 26 weeks
---------------------

【2】The baby's eyelids open for the first time around now and they will soon start blinking. It's not until some weeks after the birth that your baby's eyes become the colour they will stay.

【3】You at 26 weeks
---------------

【4】Pregnancy and birth can weaken the muscles of the pelvic floor and you may notice you leak pee when you cough, sneeze or strain your stomach muscles.

【5】Your pelvic floor is made up of layers of muscles inside your body that stretch like a hammock from the pubic bone (in front) to the end of the spine.

【6】Pelvic floor exercises can help strengthen the muscles so they work better.

【7】Things to think about at 26 weeks
---------------------------------

【8】Find out if you're getting all the vitamins and minerals you need.

【9】You can download a birth plan template to fill in and save, stating your preferences for labour and birth, such as pain relief, and the positions you would like to be in.

【10】You will be advised to have the whooping cough vaccination between 16 and 32 weeks of pregnancy – ask your midwife or GP if you have not had yours yet.

【11】Read about travelling safely in pregnancy.

【12】Massaging your perineum (the area between your vagina and anus) from 35 weeks of pregnancy can reduce the chance of tearing, needing a cut (episiotomy), and postnatal perineal pain in those having their first vaginal birth.

【13】Varicose veins are common in pregnancy – find out about common health problems in pregnancy.

【14】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 26 weeks pregnant

【15】You can sign up for Start4Life's weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.

【16】Video: What can I do during pregnancy to help make giving birth easier?
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

【17】In this video, a midwife describes things women can do during pregnancy to help make giving birth easier.

【18】Media last reviewed: 3 February 2023  
Media review due: 3 February 2026

source_info.title: Clobetasol
source_info.text:
【0】Using clobetasol with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Dermovate, ClobaDerm, Etrivex
==========================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Most medicines do not affect the way clobetasol works, but tell a pharmacist or doctor if you're taking:

【3】*   ritonavir (for HIV infection)
*   itraconazole (for a fungal infection)

【4】These medicines can increase the levels of clobetasol in your body and increase the chances of side effects.

【5】Mixing clobetasol with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【6】There's not enough information to say whether complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with clobetasol. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【7】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【8】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

【9】More in Clobetasol
------------------

【10】*   About clobetasol
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【11】Page last reviewed: 21 October 2022  
Next review due: 21 October 2025

source_info.title: Rabeprazole
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking rabeprazole
===============================================================

【1】Rabeprazole and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Rabeprazole is not usually recommended because there is little information about its use during pregnancy.

【3】A similar medicine, calledomeprazole, may be recommended instead as there is more safety information available.

【4】If you want to treat your symptoms without taking medicine, there are things you can do. You could try eating smaller meals more often, avoiding fatty and spicy food and sitting up straight when you eat - this will take the pressure off your stomach. If you have symptoms when you go to bed at night, propping your head and shoulders up can stop stomach acid coming up while you sleep

【5】Rabeprazole and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【6】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, it’s OK to take rabeprazole while you’re breastfeeding. However, they might recommend a similar medicine we know more about.

【7】It’s not known how much rabeprazole gets into breast milk, but it’s likely to be a small amount. Your baby will not take in a lot from the breast milk.

【8】It’s unlikely that rabeprazole will cause any side effects in your baby

【9】Rabeprazole and fertility
-------------------------

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that taking rabeprazole reduces fertility in either men or women. However, speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant. They may want to review your treatment.

【11】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【12】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【13】More in Rabeprazole
-------------------

【14】*   About rabeprazole
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking rabeprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

Next review due: 19 January 2025

【9】Rabeprazole and fertility
-------------------------

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that taking rabeprazole reduces fertility in either men or women. However, speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant. They may want to review your treatment.

【11】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【12】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【13】More in Rabeprazole
-------------------

【14】*   About rabeprazole
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking rabeprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

Next review due: 19 January 2025

source_info.title: Heart attack
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Heart attack
========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery
7.  Complications
8.  Prevention

【3】**A heart attack (myocardial infarction or MI) is a serious medical emergency in which the supply of blood to the heart is suddenly blocked, usually by a blood clot.**

【4】A heart attack is a medical emergency. Call 999 and ask for an ambulance if you suspect a heart attack.

【5】A lack of blood to the heart may seriously damage the heart muscle and can be life threatening.

【6】Symptoms of a heart attack
--------------------------

【7】Symptoms of a heart attack can include:

【8】*   chest pain – a feeling of pressure, heaviness, tightness or squeezing across your chest
*   pain in other parts of the body – it can feel as if the pain is spreading from your chest to your arms (usually the left arm, but it can affect both arms), jaw, neck, back and tummy
*   feeling lightheaded or dizzy
*   sweating
*   shortness of breath
*   feeling sick (nausea) or being sick (vomiting)
*   an overwhelming feeling of anxiety (similar to a panic attack)
*   coughing or wheezing

【9】The chest pain is often severe, but some people may only experience minor pain, similar to indigestion.

【10】While the most common symptom is chest pain, symptoms can vary from person to person. Some people may have other symptoms such as shortness of breath, feeling or being sick and back or jaw pain without any chest pain.

【11】Call 999 immediately if you think someone might be having a heart attack. The faster you act, the better their chances.

【12】Treating heart attacks
----------------------

【13】While waiting for an ambulance, it may help to chew and then swallow a tablet of aspirin (ideally 300mg), as long as the person having a heart attack is not allergic to aspirin.

【14】Aspirin helps to thin the blood and improves blood flow to the heart.

【15】In hospital, treatment for a heart attack depends on the type of heart attack, and how serious it is.

【16】The 2 main treatments are:

【17】*   using medicines to dissolve blood clots
*   surgery to help restore blood to the heart

【18】Causes of a heart attack
------------------------

【19】Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of heart attacks.

【20】CHD is a condition in which the major blood vessels (coronary arteries) that supply the heart muscle become clogged by a build-up of deposits of fatty substances, known as plaques.

【21】Before a heart attack, 1 of the plaques bursts (ruptures), causing a blood clot to develop at the site of the rupture.

【22】The clot may block the supply of blood to the heart, triggering a heart attack.

【23】Recovering from a heart attack
------------------------------

【24】The time it takes to recover from a heart attack will depend on the amount of damage to your heart muscle.

【25】Most people can return to work after having a heart attack. How quickly you can go back to work depends on your health, the state of your heart and the type of work you do.

【26】The recovery process aims to:

【27】*   reduce your risk of another heart attack through a combination of lifestyle changes (such as eating a healthy diet), and medicines (such as statins), which help to lower blood cholesterol levels
*   gradually restore your physical fitness so you can resume normal activities (cardiac rehabilitation)

【28】Find out more about recovering from a heart attack

【29】Complications of a heart attack
-------------------------------

【30】Complications of a heart attack can be serious and possibly life threatening.

【31】These include:

【32】*   arrhythmias – these are abnormal heartbeats. Some types can stop the heart beating
*   cardiogenic shock – where the heart's muscles are severely damaged and can no longer contract properly to supply enough blood to maintain many body functions
*   heart rupture – where the heart's muscles, walls or valves split apart (rupture)

【33】These complications can happen quickly after a heart attack and are a leading cause of death.

【34】Some people die suddenly from a complication of a heart attack before reaching hospital or within the 1st month after a heart attack. But with treatment many people survive a heart attack.

【35】The outlook often depends on:

【36】*   age – serious complications are more likely as you get older
*   the severity of the heart attack – how much of the heart's muscle has been damaged during the attack
*   how long it took before a person received treatment – treatment for a heart attack should begin as soon as possible
*   general health

【37】Find out more about complications of a heart attack

【38】Preventing a heart attack
-------------------------

【39】There are some steps you can take to reduce your risk of having a heart attack (or having another heart attack):

【40】*   smokers should quit smoking
*   lose weight if you're overweight or obese
*   do regular exercise – adults should do at least 150 minutes (2 hours and 30 minutes) of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise each week, unless advised otherwise by the doctor in charge of your care
*   eat a low-fat, high-fibre diet, including wholegrains and at least 5 portions of fruit and vegetables a day
*   moderate your alcohol consumption

【41】Video: heart attack
-------------------

【42】This video explores the symptoms, surgical treatments and importance of reducing risk factors for a heart attack.

【43】Media last reviewed: 16 April 2021  
Media review due: 16 April 2024

【44】Page last reviewed: 13 July 2023  
Next review due: 13 July 2026

【45】*   Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: Lithium
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take lithium \- Brand names: Priadel, Camcolit, Liskonum, Li-Liquid
======================================================================================

【1】Who can take lithium
--------------------

【2】Most adults and children aged 12 years old and over can take lithium.

【3】Who may not be able to take lithium
-----------------------------------

【4】Lithium may not be suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor before starting to take it if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to lithium or other medicine
*   have heart disease
*   have severe kidney problems
*   have an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) that is not being treated
*   have low levels of sodium in your body – this can happen if you're dehydrated or if you're on a low-sodium (low-salt) diet
*   have Addison's disease, a rare disorder of the adrenal glands
*   have a rare heart condition called Brugada syndrome, or someone in your family has this condition
*   need to have surgery
*   are trying to get pregnant, or are already pregnant or breastfeeding

【6】Before prescribing lithium, your doctor will do some blood tests to check your kidneys and thyroid are OK. They'll also check your weight and continue to check it throughout your treatment.

【7】If you have a heart condition, the doctor may also do a test that measures the electrical activity of your heart (electrocardiogram).

【8】More in Lithium
---------------

【9】*   About lithium
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【10】Page last reviewed: 9 August 2023  
Next review due: 9 August 2026

source_info.title: Rivaroxaban
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take rivaroxaban
===================================

【1】Who can take rivaroxaban
------------------------

【2】Most adults aged 18 and over can take rivaroxaban.

【3】Most children who have had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or blood clot in the lungs (pulmonary embolism) can also take it.

【4】Who may not be able to take rivaroxaban
---------------------------------------

【5】Rivaroxaban is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【6】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to rivaroxaban or any other medicine
*   are trying to get pregnant or you're already pregnant – rivaroxaban can be harmful to your baby
*   have liver or kidney problems
*   have any injuries that are currently bleeding a lot, such as a wound
*   have a stomach ulcer
*   have antiphospholipid syndrome, a condition that affects the immune system and makes you more likely to get blood clots
*   have ever had surgery to replace a heart valve

【7】More in Rivaroxaban
-------------------

【8】*   About rivaroxaban
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking rivaroxaban with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【9】Page last reviewed: 15 March 2022  
Next review due: 15 March 2025

【4】Who may not be able to take rivaroxaban
---------------------------------------

【5】Rivaroxaban is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【6】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to rivaroxaban or any other medicine
*   are trying to get pregnant or you're already pregnant – rivaroxaban can be harmful to your baby
*   have liver or kidney problems
*   have any injuries that are currently bleeding a lot, such as a wound
*   have a stomach ulcer
*   have antiphospholipid syndrome, a condition that affects the immune system and makes you more likely to get blood clots
*   have ever had surgery to replace a heart valve

【7】More in Rivaroxaban
-------------------

source_info.title: Ibuprofen for adults (Nurofen)
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of ibuprofen
=========================

【1】Common side effects of tablets, capsules, granules and liquid
-------------------------------------------------------------

【2】These common side effects of ibuprofen taken by mouth happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【3】Headaches

【4】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to drink too much alcohol. It's important not to take any other medicines for pain to help with headaches. Talk to your doctor if the headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【5】Feeling dizzy

【6】If ibuprofen makes you feel dizzy, stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Avoid coffee, cigarettes and alcohol. If the dizziness does not get better within a couple of days, speak to your pharmacist or doctor. Do not drive or ride a bike while you're feeling dizzy.

【7】Feeling sick (nausea)

【8】Stick to simple meals. Do not eat rich or spicy food. Always take ibuprofen tablets, capsules, granules or liquid with a meal or snack or with a drink of milk.

【9】Being sick (vomiting)

【10】Have small, frequent sips of water to avoid dehydration. Speak to a pharmacist if you have signs of dehydration, such as peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat vomiting without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【11】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【12】Wind

【13】Try not to eat foods that cause wind (like lentils, beans and onions). Eat smaller meals, eat and drink slowly, and exercise regularly. There are pharmacy medicines that can also help, such as charcoal tablets or simeticone.

【14】Indigestion

【15】If you get repeated indigestion stop taking ibuprofen and see your doctor as soon as possible. If you need something to ease the discomfort, try taking an antacid, but do not put off going to the doctor.

【16】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【17】Common side effects of gel, mousse and spray
--------------------------------------------

【18】You're less likely to have side effects when you apply ibuprofen to your skin than with tablets, capsules, granules or liquid because less gets into your body. But you may still get the same side effects, especially if you use a lot on a large area of skin.

【19】Applying ibuprofen to your skin can sometimes cause your skin to become more sensitive than normal to sunlight. Speak to your doctor if this is a problem.

【20】Serious side effects
--------------------

【21】Call a doctor or call 111 straight away and stop taking ibuprofen if you have:

【22】*   black poo or blood in your vomit – these can be signs of bleeding in your stomach
*   swollen ankles, blood in your pee or not peeing at all – these can be signs of a kidney problem

【23】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【24】*   you have severe chest or stomach pain – these can be signs of a hole in your stomach or gut
*   you have difficulty breathing, or asthma symptoms that become worse
*   you get a severe headache, a high temperature or stiff neck, and a dislike of bright lights – these can be signs or inflammation of the protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord (meninges)
*   you have blurred vision or you see or hear things that are not real (hallucinations)

【25】Find your nearest A&E

【26】### Serious allergic reaction

【27】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to ibuprofen.

【28】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【29】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale 通用删除1(英):<u>(if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)</u>
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【30】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【31】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【32】Long term side effects
----------------------

【33】Ibuprofen can cause ulcers in your stomach or gut, especially if you take it by mouth for a long time or in big doses. If you need to take it for a long time your doctor may also prescribe a medicine to help protect your stomach.

【34】Other side effects
------------------

【35】These are not all the side effects of ibuprofen tablets, capsules and syrup. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【36】Information:

【37】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【38】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【39】More in Ibuprofen for adults (Nurofen)
--------------------------------------

【40】*   About ibuprofen for adults
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking ibuprofen with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

【41】Page last reviewed: 18 November 2021  
Next review due: 18 November 2024

source_info.title: Alcohol-related liver disease
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Alcohol-related liver disease
==========================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**Successful treatment for alcohol-related liver disease (ARLD) often depends on whether someone is willing to stop drinking alcohol and make changes to their lifestyle.**

【4】Stopping drinking alcohol
-------------------------

【5】Treatment for ARLD involves stopping drinking alcohol. This is known as abstinence, which can be vital depending on what stage the condition is at.

【6】If you have fatty liver disease, the damage may be reversed if you abstain from alcohol for a period of time (this could be months or years).

【7】After this point, it's usually safe to start drinking again if you stick to the NHS guidelines on alcohol units. However, it's important to check with your doctor first.

【8】If you have a more serious form of ARLD (alcoholic hepatitis or cirrhosis) lifelong abstinence is recommended. 

【9】This is because stopping drinking is the only way to prevent your liver damage getting worse and potentially stop you dying of liver disease.

【10】Stopping drinking is not easy, especially as an estimated 70% of people with ARLD have an alcohol dependency problem.

【11】Nevertheless, if you have alcohol-related cirrhosis or alcoholic hepatitis and do not stop drinking, no medical or surgical treatment can prevent liver failure.

【12】### Withdrawal symptoms

【13】If you're abstaining from alcohol, you may suffer withdrawal symptoms.

【14】These will be at their worst for the first 48 hours, but should start to improve as your body adjusts to being without alcohol. This usually takes 3 to 7 days from the time of your last drink.

【15】Many people initially experience disturbed sleep when abstaining from alcohol, but in most cases their sleep pattern returns to normal within a month.

【16】In some cases, you may be advised to reduce your alcohol intake in a gradual and planned way to help avoid withdrawal problems.

【17】You may also be offered a medicine called a benzodiazepine and psychological therapy, such as cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), to help you through the withdrawal process.

【18】Some people need to stay in hospital or a specialist rehabilitation clinic during the initial withdrawal phases so their progress can be closely monitored.

【19】If you're staying at home, you'll regularly see a nurse or another health professional. You might see them at home, your GP surgery or a specialist NHS service.

【20】### Preventing relapses

【21】Once you have stopped drinking, you may need further treatment to help ensure you do not start drinking again.

【22】The first treatment usually offered is psychological therapy. This involves seeing a therapist to talk about your thoughts and feelings, and how these affect your behaviour and wellbeing.

【23】If psychological therapy alone is not effective, you may also need medicine to help you abstain from alcohol, such as: 

【24】*   acamprosate
*   disulfiram
*   naltrexone

【25】Find out more about treatment for alcohol misuse

【26】### Self-help groups

【27】Many people with alcohol dependence find it useful to attend self-help groups to help them stop drinking.

【28】One of the most well-known is Alcoholics Anonymous 通用删除1(英):<u>(see the AA website for details)</u>, but there are many other groups that can help.

【29】See alcohol support for more information about the help available.

【30】Diet and nutrition
------------------

【31】Malnutrition is common in people with ARLD, so it's important to eat a balanced diet to make sure you get all the nutrients you need.

【32】Avoiding salty foods and not adding salt to foods you eat can reduce your risk of developing swelling in your legs, feet and tummy caused by a build-up of fluid.

【33】Get tips for a lower salt diet

【34】The damage to your liver can also mean it's unable to store glycogen, a carbohydrate that provides short-term energy.

【35】When this happens, the body uses its own muscle tissue to provide energy between meals, which leads to muscle wasting and weakness. This means you may need extra energy and protein in your diet.

【36】Healthy snacking between meals can top up your calories and protein. It may also be helpful to eat 3 or 4 small meals a day, rather than 1 or 2 large meals.

【37】Your GP can advise you on a suitable diet or, in some cases, refer you to a dietitian.

【38】In the most serious cases of malnutrition, nutrients may need to be provided through a feeding tube inserted through the nose and into the stomach.

【39】Medicine for symptoms
---------------------

【40】The use of medicine to directly treat ARLD is controversial. Many experts have argued there's limited evidence for its effectiveness.

【41】For people with severe alcoholic hepatitis, treatment in hospital may be necessary.

【42】Specific treatment with corticosteroids may be used to reduce inflammation of the liver in some people with this condition.

【43】Nutritional support is also an important part of treatment in these cases.

【44】Liver transplants
-----------------

【45】In the most serious cases of ARLD, the liver loses its ability to function, leading to liver failure.

【46】A liver transplant is currently the only way to cure irreversible liver failure.

【47】A liver transplant may be considered if:

【48】*   you develop progressive liver failure, despite not drinking alcohol
*   you're otherwise well enough to survive such an operation
*   you commit to not drinking alcohol for the rest of your life

【49】Taking medicines with ARLD
--------------------------

【50】If you have ARLD, it's important to talk to your GP or pharmacist before taking over-the-counter or prescription medicines.

【51】ARLD can affect the way the body processes some medicines.

【52】Page last reviewed: 20 September 2022  
Next review due: 20 September 2025

【53】*   Previous : Diagnosis
*   Next : Complications

【48】*   you develop progressive liver failure, despite not drinking alcohol
*   you're otherwise well enough to survive such an operation
*   you commit to not drinking alcohol for the rest of your life

【49】Taking medicines with ARLD
--------------------------

【50】If you have ARLD, it's important to talk to your GP or pharmacist before taking over-the-counter or prescription medicines.

【51】ARLD can affect the way the body processes some medicines.
