text.content:
【0】Treatment \- Alcohol-related liver disease
==========================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**Successful treatment for alcohol-related liver disease (ARLD) often depends on whether someone is willing to stop drinking alcohol and make changes to their lifestyle.**

【4】Stopping drinking alcohol
-------------------------

【5】Treatment for ARLD involves stopping drinking alcohol. This is known as abstinence, which can be vital depending on what stage the condition is at.

【6】If you have fatty liver disease, the damage may be reversed if you abstain from alcohol for a period of time (this could be months or years).

【7】After this point, it's usually safe to start drinking again if you stick to the NHS guidelines on alcohol units. However, it's important to check with your doctor first.

【8】If you have a more serious form of ARLD (alcoholic hepatitis or cirrhosis) lifelong abstinence is recommended. 

【9】This is because stopping drinking is the only way to prevent your liver damage getting worse and potentially stop you dying of liver disease.

【10】Stopping drinking is not easy, especially as an estimated 70% of people with ARLD have an alcohol dependency problem.

【11】Nevertheless, if you have alcohol-related cirrhosis or alcoholic hepatitis and do not stop drinking, no medical or surgical treatment can prevent liver failure.

【12】### Withdrawal symptoms

【13】If you're abstaining from alcohol, you may suffer withdrawal symptoms.

【14】These will be at their worst for the first 48 hours, but should start to improve as your body adjusts to being without alcohol. This usually takes 3 to 7 days from the time of your last drink.

【15】Many people initially experience disturbed sleep when abstaining from alcohol, but in most cases their sleep pattern returns to normal within a month.

【16】In some cases, you may be advised to reduce your alcohol intake in a gradual and planned way to help avoid withdrawal problems.

【17】You may also be offered a medicine called a benzodiazepine and psychological therapy, such as cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), to help you through the withdrawal process.

【18】Some people need to stay in hospital or a specialist rehabilitation clinic during the initial withdrawal phases so their progress can be closely monitored.

【19】If you're staying at home, you'll regularly see a nurse or another health professional. You might see them at home, your GP surgery or a specialist NHS service.

【20】### Preventing relapses

【21】Once you have stopped drinking, you may need further treatment to help ensure you do not start drinking again.

【22】The first treatment usually offered is psychological therapy. This involves seeing a therapist to talk about your thoughts and feelings, and how these affect your behaviour and wellbeing.

【23】If psychological therapy alone is not effective, you may also need medicine to help you abstain from alcohol, such as: 

【24】*   acamprosate
*   disulfiram
*   naltrexone

【25】Find out more about treatment for alcohol misuse

【26】### Self-help groups

【27】Many people with alcohol dependence find it useful to attend self-help groups to help them stop drinking.

【28】One of the most well-known is Alcoholics Anonymous 通用删除1(英):<u>(see the AA website for details)</u>, but there are many other groups that can help.

【29】<mark>See alcohol support for more information about the help available.</mark>

【30】Diet and nutrition
------------------

【31】Malnutrition is common in people with ARLD, so it's important to eat a balanced diet to make sure you get all the nutrients you need.

【32】Avoiding salty foods and not adding salt to foods you eat can reduce your risk of developing swelling in your legs, feet and tummy caused by a build-up of fluid.

【33】Get tips for a lower salt diet

【34】The damage to your liver can also mean it's unable to store glycogen, a carbohydrate that provides short-term energy.

【35】When this happens, the body uses its own muscle tissue to provide energy between meals, which leads to muscle wasting and weakness. This means you may need extra energy and protein in your diet.

【36】Healthy snacking between meals can top up your calories and protein. It may also be helpful to eat 3 or 4 small meals a day, rather than 1 or 2 large meals.

【37】Your GP can advise you on a suitable diet or, in some cases, refer you to a dietitian.

【38】In the most serious cases of malnutrition, nutrients may need to be provided through a feeding tube inserted through the nose and into the stomach.

【39】Medicine for symptoms
---------------------

【40】The use of medicine to directly treat ARLD is controversial. Many experts have argued there's limited evidence for its effectiveness.

【41】For people with severe alcoholic hepatitis, treatment in hospital may be necessary.

【42】Specific treatment with corticosteroids may be used to reduce inflammation of the liver in some people with this condition.

【43】Nutritional support is also an important part of treatment in these cases.

【44】Liver transplants
-----------------

【45】In the most serious cases of ARLD, the liver loses its ability to function, leading to liver failure.

【46】A liver transplant is currently the only way to cure irreversible liver failure.

【47】A liver transplant may be considered if:

【48】*   you develop progressive liver failure, despite not drinking alcohol
*   you're otherwise well enough to survive such an operation
*   you commit to not drinking alcohol for the rest of your life

【49】Taking medicines with ARLD
--------------------------

【50】If you have ARLD, it's important to talk to your GP or pharmacist before taking over-the-counter or prescription medicines.

【51】ARLD can affect the way the body processes some medicines.

【52】Page last reviewed: 20 September 2022  
Next review due: 20 September 2025

【53】*   Previous : Diagnosis
*   Next : Complications

source_info.title: Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18)
source_info.text:
【0】Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18)
==============================

【1】**Edwards' syndrome, also known as trisomy 18, is a rare but serious condition.**

【2】Edwards' syndrome affects how long a baby may survive. Sadly, most babies with Edwards' syndrome will die before or shortly after being born.

【3】A small number (about 13 in 100) babies born alive with Edwards' syndrome will live past their 1st birthday.

【4】Cause of Edwards' syndrome
--------------------------

【5】Each cell in your body usually contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, which carry the genes you inherit from your parents.

【6】A baby with Edwards' syndrome has 3 copies of chromosome number 18 instead of 2. This affects the way the baby grows and develops. Having 3 copies of chromosome 18 usually happens by chance, because of a change in the sperm or egg before a baby is conceived.

【7】Your chance of having a baby with Edwards' syndrome increases as you get older, but anyone can have a baby with Edwards' syndrome. The condition does not usually run in families and is not caused by anything the parents have or have not done.

【8】Speak to a GP if you want to find out more. They may be able to refer you to a genetic counsellor.

【9】**Types of Edwards' syndrome**
------------------------------

【10】The symptoms, and how seriously your baby is affected, usually depend on whether they have full, mosaic, or partial Edwards' syndrome.

【11】### Full Edwards' syndrome

【12】Most babies with Edwards' syndrome have an extra chromosome 18 present in all cells. This is called full Edwards' syndrome.

【13】The effects of full Edward's syndrome are often more severe. Sadly, most babies with this form will die before they are born.

【14】### Mosaic Edwards' syndrome

【15】A small number of babies with Edwards' syndrome (about 1 in 20) have an extra chromosome 18 in just some cells. This is called mosaic Edwards' syndrome (or sometimes mosaic trisomy 18).

【16】This can lead to milder effects of the condition, depending on the number and type of cells that have the extra chromosome. Most babies with this type of Edward's syndrome who are born alive will live for at least a year, and they may live to adulthood**.**

【17】### Partial Edwards' syndrome

【18】A very small number of babies with Edwards' syndrome (about 1 in 100) have only a section of the extra chromosome 18 in their cells, rather than a whole extra chromosome 18. This is called partial Edwards' syndrome (or sometimes partial trisomy 18).

【19】How partial Edwards' syndrome affects a baby depends on which part of chromosome 18 is present in their cells.

【20】Advice for new parents
----------------------

【21】There's support available for whatever you or your baby needs.

【22】All babies born with Edwards' syndrome will have some level of learning disability.

【23】Edwards' syndrome is associated with certain physical features and health problems. Every baby is unique and will have different health problems and needs. They will usually have a low birthweight and may also have a wide range of physical symptoms. They may also have heart, respiratory, kidney or gastrointestinal conditions.

【24】Despite their complex needs, children with Edwards' syndrome can slowly start to do more things.

【25】Like any child they'll:

【26】*   have their own personality
*   learn at their own pace
*   have things that are important and unique to them

【27】Try not to think too far ahead and enjoy time with your baby.

【28】Screening for Edwards' syndrome
-------------------------------

【29】If you're pregnant, you'll be offered screening for Edwards' syndrome between 10 and 14 weeks of pregnancy. This looks at the chance of your baby having the condition.

【30】This screening test is called the combined test and it works out the chance of a baby having Edwards' syndrome, Down's syndrome and Patau's syndrome.

【31】During the test you'll have a blood test and an ultrasound scan to measure the fluid at the back of your baby's neck (nuchal translucency).

【32】Read more about screening for Down's syndrome, Edwards' syndrome and Patau's syndrome at 10 to 14 weeks

【33】If it's not possible to measure the fluid at the back of your baby's neck, or you're more than 14 weeks pregnant, you'll be offered screening for Edwards' syndrome as part of your 20-week scan. This is sometimes known as the mid-pregnancy scan. It's an ultrasound scan that looks at how your baby is growing.

【34】Screening cannot identify which form of Edwards' syndrome your baby may have, or how it will affect them.

【35】Read more about the 20-week scan

【36】Diagnosing Edwards' syndrome during pregnancy
---------------------------------------------

【37】If the combined test shows that you have a higher chance of having a baby with Edwards' syndrome, you'll be offered a test to find out for certain if your baby has the condition.

【38】This diagnostic test involves analysing a sample of your baby's cells to check if they have an extra copy of chromosome 18.

【39】There are 2 different ways of getting this sample of cells:

【40】*   chorionic villus sampling, which collects a sample from the placenta
*   amniocentesis, which collects a sample of the amniotic fluid from around your baby

【41】These are invasive tests that increase your chance of having a miscarriage. Your doctor will discuss this with you.

【42】### Results from the diagnostic test

【43】A specialist doctor (obstetrician) or midwife will explain what the screening results mean and talk to you about your options.

【44】This is a very difficult situation and it's normal to feel a whole range of emotions. It may help to talk to your doctor, family and friends, or partner about what you're thinking and how you're feeling.

【45】If you're told your baby has Edwards' syndrome, either before birth or afterwards, you'll be offered support and information.

【46】You can visit the SOFT UK website for support and more information on Edwards' syndrome, and to contact other families affected by the condition.

【47】You can also contact Antenatal Results and Choices (ARC), which has information about screening tests and how you might feel if you're told your baby does have, or might have, a problem.

【48】ARC has a helpline that can be reached on 0845 077 2290, or 0207 713 7486 from a mobile, Monday to Friday, 10am to 5.30pm. The helpline is answered by trained staff, who can offer information and support.

【49】Read more about what happens if antenatal screening tests find something

【50】Diagnosing Edwards' syndrome after birth
----------------------------------------

【51】If doctors believe your baby has Edwards' syndrome after they're born, a blood sample will be taken to see if there are extra copies of chromosome 18.

【52】Treating Edwards' syndrome
--------------------------

【53】There's no cure for Edwards' syndrome.

【54】Treatment will focus on the symptoms of the condition, such as heart conditions, breathing difficulties and infections. Your baby may also need to be fed through a feeding tube, as they can often have difficulty feeding.

【55】Edwards' syndrome has an impact on your baby's movements as they get older, and they may benefit from supportive treatment such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy.

【56】Depending on your baby's specific symptoms, they may need specialist care in hospital or a hospice, or you may be able to look after them at home with the right support.

【57】Advice for carers
-----------------

【58】Supporting someone with Edwards' syndrome can be both rewarding and challenging.

【59】If you need help, or just want someone to talk to, there's lots of support available.

【60】Your guide to social care and support provides lots of advice on how you can take time to look after yourself, including:

【61】*   getting a break from caring
*   getting legal support and advocacy
*   taking care of your wellbeing

【62】### Speak to parents and families

【63】It can help to speak to other parents and families who know how you're feeling.

【64】You can do this by:

【65】*   getting in touch with people on forums and social media
*   going to a support group – ask your midwife or health visitor about available support groups

【66】Information about your baby
---------------------------

【67】If your baby is found to have Edwards' syndrome before or after their birth, their clinical team will pass the information about them to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【68】This helps scientists look for better ways to treat the symptoms of the condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【69】Find out more about the register at GOV.UK

【70】Having a child with Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18)
--------------------------------------------------

【71】3 families share their experience of having a child with Edwards' syndrome, also called trisomy 18. This video contains sensitive content that some may find upsetting.

【72】Media last reviewed: 20 April 2022  
Media review due: 20 April 2025

【73】Page last reviewed: 25 September 2020  
Next review due: 25 September 2023

【50】Diagnosing Edwards' syndrome after birth
----------------------------------------

【51】If doctors believe your baby has Edwards' syndrome after they're born, a blood sample will be taken to see if there are extra copies of chromosome 18.

【52】Treating Edwards' syndrome
--------------------------

【53】There's no cure for Edwards' syndrome.

【54】Treatment will focus on the symptoms of the condition, such as heart conditions, breathing difficulties and infections. Your baby may also need to be fed through a feeding tube, as they can often have difficulty feeding.

【55】Edwards' syndrome has an impact on your baby's movements as they get older, and they may benefit from supportive treatment such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy.

【56】Depending on your baby's specific symptoms, they may need specialist care in hospital or a hospice, or you may be able to look after them at home with the right support.

【57】Advice for carers
-----------------

【58】Supporting someone with Edwards' syndrome can be both rewarding and challenging.

【59】If you need help, or just want someone to talk to, there's lots of support available.

【60】Your guide to social care and support provides lots of advice on how you can take time to look after yourself, including:

【61】*   getting a break from caring
*   getting legal support and advocacy
*   taking care of your wellbeing

【62】### Speak to parents and families

【63】It can help to speak to other parents and families who know how you're feeling.

【64】You can do this by:

【65】*   getting in touch with people on forums and social media
*   going to a support group – ask your midwife or health visitor about available support groups

【66】Information about your baby
---------------------------

【67】If your baby is found to have Edwards' syndrome before or after their birth, their clinical team will pass the information about them to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【68】This helps scientists look for better ways to treat the symptoms of the condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【69】Find out more about the register at GOV.UK

【70】Having a child with Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18)
--------------------------------------------------

【71】3 families share their experience of having a child with Edwards' syndrome, also called trisomy 18. This video contains sensitive content that some may find upsetting.

【72】Media last reviewed: 20 April 2022  
Media review due: 20 April 2025

【73】Page last reviewed: 25 September 2020  
Next review due: 25 September 2023

text.content:
【0】Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18)
==============================

【1】**Edwards' syndrome, also known as trisomy 18, is a rare but serious condition.**

【2】Edwards' syndrome affects how long a baby may survive. Sadly, most babies with Edwards' syndrome will die before or shortly after being born.

【3】A small number (about 13 in 100) babies born alive with Edwards' syndrome will live past their 1st birthday.

【4】Cause of Edwards' syndrome
--------------------------

【5】Each cell in your body usually contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, which carry the genes you inherit from your parents.

【6】A baby with Edwards' syndrome has 3 copies of chromosome number 18 instead of 2. This affects the way the baby grows and develops. Having 3 copies of chromosome 18 usually happens by chance, because of a change in the sperm or egg before a baby is conceived.

【7】Your chance of having a baby with Edwards' syndrome increases as you get older, but anyone can have a baby with Edwards' syndrome. The condition does not usually run in families and is not caused by anything the parents have or have not done.

【8】Speak to a GP if you want to find out more. They may be able to refer you to a genetic counsellor.

【9】**Types of Edwards' syndrome**
------------------------------

【10】The symptoms, and how seriously your baby is affected, usually depend on whether they have full, mosaic, or partial Edwards' syndrome.

【11】### Full Edwards' syndrome

【12】Most babies with Edwards' syndrome have an extra chromosome 18 present in all cells. This is called full Edwards' syndrome.

【13】The effects of full Edward's syndrome are often more severe. Sadly, most babies with this form will die before they are born.

【14】### Mosaic Edwards' syndrome

【15】A small number of babies with Edwards' syndrome (about 1 in 20) have an extra chromosome 18 in just some cells. This is called mosaic Edwards' syndrome (or sometimes mosaic trisomy 18).

【16】This can lead to milder effects of the condition, depending on the number and type of cells that have the extra chromosome. Most babies with this type of Edward's syndrome who are born alive will live for at least a year, and they may live to adulthood**.**

【17】### Partial Edwards' syndrome

【18】A very small number of babies with Edwards' syndrome (about 1 in 100) have only a section of the extra chromosome 18 in their cells, rather than a whole extra chromosome 18. This is called partial Edwards' syndrome (or sometimes partial trisomy 18).

【19】How partial Edwards' syndrome affects a baby depends on which part of chromosome 18 is present in their cells.

【20】Advice for new parents
----------------------

【21】There's support available for whatever you or your baby needs.

【22】All babies born with Edwards' syndrome will have some level of learning disability.

【23】Edwards' syndrome is associated with certain physical features and health problems. Every baby is unique and will have different health problems and needs. They will usually have a low birthweight and may also have a wide range of physical symptoms. They may also have heart, respiratory, kidney or gastrointestinal conditions.

【24】Despite their complex needs, children with Edwards' syndrome can slowly start to do more things.

【25】Like any child they'll:

【26】*   have their own personality
*   learn at their own pace
*   have things that are important and unique to them

【27】Try not to think too far ahead and enjoy time with your baby.

【28】Screening for Edwards' syndrome
-------------------------------

【29】If you're pregnant, you'll be offered screening for Edwards' syndrome between 10 and 14 weeks of pregnancy. This looks at the chance of your baby having the condition.

【30】This screening test is called the combined test and it works out the chance of a baby having Edwards' syndrome, Down's syndrome and Patau's syndrome.

【31】During the test you'll have a blood test and an ultrasound scan to measure the fluid at the back of your baby's neck (nuchal translucency).

【32】Read more about screening for Down's syndrome, Edwards' syndrome and Patau's syndrome at 10 to 14 weeks

【33】If it's not possible to measure the fluid at the back of your baby's neck, or you're more than 14 weeks pregnant, you'll be offered screening for Edwards' syndrome as part of your 20-week scan. This is sometimes known as the mid-pregnancy scan. It's an ultrasound scan that looks at how your baby is growing.

【34】Screening cannot identify which form of Edwards' syndrome your baby may have, or how it will affect them.

<mark>【35】Read more about the 20-week scan</mark>

【36】Diagnosing Edwards' syndrome during pregnancy
---------------------------------------------

【37】If the combined test shows that you have a higher chance of having a baby with Edwards' syndrome, you'll be offered a test to find out for certain if your baby has the condition.

【38】This diagnostic test involves analysing a sample of your baby's cells to check if they have an extra copy of chromosome 18.

【39】There are 2 different ways of getting this sample of cells:

【40】*   chorionic villus sampling, which collects a sample from the placenta
*   amniocentesis, which collects a sample of the amniotic fluid from around your baby

【41】These are invasive tests that increase your chance of having a miscarriage. Your doctor will discuss this with you.

【42】### Results from the diagnostic test

【43】A specialist doctor (obstetrician) or midwife will explain what the screening results mean and talk to you about your options.

【44】This is a very difficult situation and it's normal to feel a whole range of emotions. It may help to talk to your doctor, family and friends, or partner about what you're thinking and how you're feeling.

【45】If you're told your baby has Edwards' syndrome, either before birth or afterwards, you'll be offered support and information.

【46】You can visit the SOFT UK website for support and more information on Edwards' syndrome, and to contact other families affected by the condition.

【47】You can also contact Antenatal Results and Choices (ARC), which has information about screening tests and how you might feel if you're told your baby does have, or might have, a problem.

【48】ARC has a helpline that can be reached on 0845 077 2290, or 0207 713 7486 from a mobile, Monday to Friday, 10am to 5.30pm. The helpline is answered by trained staff, who can offer information and support.

【49】Read more about what happens if antenatal screening tests find something

【50】Diagnosing Edwards' syndrome after birth
----------------------------------------

【51】If doctors believe your baby has Edwards' syndrome after they're born, a blood sample will be taken to see if there are extra copies of chromosome 18.

【52】Treating Edwards' syndrome
--------------------------

【53】There's no cure for Edwards' syndrome.

【54】Treatment will focus on the symptoms of the condition, such as heart conditions, breathing difficulties and infections. Your baby may also need to be fed through a feeding tube, as they can often have difficulty feeding.

【55】Edwards' syndrome has an impact on your baby's movements as they get older, and they may benefit from supportive treatment such as physiotherapy and occupational therapy.

【56】Depending on your baby's specific symptoms, they may need specialist care in hospital or a hospice, or you may be able to look after them at home with the right support.

【57】Advice for carers
-----------------

【58】Supporting someone with Edwards' syndrome can be both rewarding and challenging.

【59】If you need help, or just want someone to talk to, there's lots of support available.

【60】Your guide to social care and support provides lots of advice on how you can take time to look after yourself, including:

【61】*   getting a break from caring
*   getting legal support and advocacy
*   taking care of your wellbeing

【62】### Speak to parents and families

【63】It can help to speak to other parents and families who know how you're feeling.

【64】You can do this by:

【65】*   getting in touch with people on forums and social media
*   going to a support group – ask your midwife or health visitor about available support groups

【66】Information about your baby
---------------------------

【67】If your baby is found to have Edwards' syndrome before or after their birth, their clinical team will pass the information about them to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【68】This helps scientists look for better ways to treat the symptoms of the condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【69】Find out more about the register at GOV.UK

【70】Having a child with Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18)
--------------------------------------------------

【71】3 families share their experience of having a child with Edwards' syndrome, also called trisomy 18. This video contains sensitive content that some may find upsetting.

【72】Media last reviewed: 20 April 2022  
Media review due: 20 April 2025

【73】Page last reviewed: 25 September 2020  
Next review due: 25 September 2023

source_info.title: Stretch marks
source_info.text:
【0】Stretch marks
=============

【1】**Stretch marks are very common. They're harmless and often get less visible over time.**

【2】Check if you have stretch marks
-------------------------------

【3】Stretch marks look like lines or streaks across the skin.

【4】Stretch marks can be pink, red, brown, black, silver or purple. They usually start off darker and fade over time.

【5】Credit:

【6】Michael Heim / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-woman-displaying-stretch-marks-on-her-abdomen-after-pregnancy-caused-90328374.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=8CD2F7A0-4F23-46C7-B795-6746E63CD78D&p=278143&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dF6XPNA%26qt\_raw%3dF6XPNA%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d32846%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d1%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【7】Stretch marks are most common on the tummy, breasts, chest, upper arms, legs, bottom, hips or back.

【8】Credit:

【9】SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/481108/view

【10】Common causes of stretch marks
------------------------------

【11】Stretch marks are often caused by sudden growth or weight gain.

【12】You may be more likely to get them if you:

【13】*   are pregnant
*   are going through puberty
*   lose or gain weight quickly
*   are female
*   are overweight
*   use some kinds of steroid creams or tablets
*   have a family member with stretch marks

【14】Rarely, stretch marks can be due to a condition called Cushing's syndrome.

【15】Information:

【16】Find out more about stretch marks in pregnancy

【17】What to do about stretch marks
------------------------------

【18】Stretch marks usually fade over time but may not disappear completely.

【19】Many creams and lotions claim to prevent, reduce or remove stretch marks. But there's very little evidence these work.

【20】There are some treatments that may help make stretch marks look better, but they will not get rid of them.

【21】They include:

【22】*   retinoid (often called tretinoin) creams or hyaluronic acid – these may help if used on new stretch marks, but you should not use retinoid creams if you're pregnant as they may harm your baby
*   light or laser treatments
*   microdermabrasion, which removes a thin layer of skin

【23】You would need to pay for these treatments as they're not available on the NHS.

【24】Information:

【25】It's not always possible to prevent stretch marks. The best way to reduce your chance of getting them is by maintaining a healthy weight.

【26】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【27】You have large stretch marks and:

【28】*   more fat on your chest and tummy, but slim arms and legs
*   a build-up of fat on the back of your neck and shoulders
*   a red, puffy, rounded face

【29】These could be symptoms of Cushing's syndrome.

【30】Page last reviewed: 07 December 2021  
Next review due: 07 December 2024

text.text:
【5】Credit:

【6】Michael Heim / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-woman-displaying-stretch-marks-on-her-abdomen-after-pregnancy-caused-90328374.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=8CD2F7A0-4F23-46C7-B795-6746E63CD78D&p=278143&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3Dbar%26st%3D0%26pn%3D1%26ps%3D100%26sortby%3D2%26resultview%3DsortbyPopular%26npgs%3D0%26qt%3DF6XPNA%26qt\_raw%3DF6XPNA%26lic%3D3%26mr%3D0%26pr%3D0%26ot%3D0%26creative%3D%26ag%3D0%26hc%3D0%26pc%3D%26blackwhite%3D%26cutout%3D%26tbar%3D1%26et%3D0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3D0%26loc%3D0%26imgt%3D0%26dtfr%3D%26dtto%3D%26size%3D0xFF%26archive%3D1%26groupid%3D%26pseudoid%3D32846%26a%3D%26cdid%3D%26cdsrt%3D%26name%3D%26qn%3D%26apalib%3D%26apalic%3D%26lightbox%3D%26gname%3D%26gtype%3D%26xstx%3D0%26simid%3D%26saveQry%3D%26editorial%3D1%26nu%3D%26t%3D%26edoptin%3D%26customgeoip%3D%26cap%3D1%26cbstore%3D1%26vd%3D0%26lb%3D%26fi%3D2%26edrf%3D1%26ispremium%3D1%26flip%3D0%26pl%3D

【4】Stretch marks can be pink, red, brown, black, silver or purple. They usually start off darker and fade over time.

【5】Credit:

【6】Michael Heim / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-woman-displaying-stretch-marks-on-her-abdomen-after-pregnancy-caused-90328374.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=8CD2F7A0-4F23-46C7-B795-6746E63CD78D&p=278143&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dF6XPNA%26qt\_raw%3dF6XPNA%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d32846%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d1%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【7】Stretch marks are most common on the tummy, breasts, chest, upper arms, legs, bottom, hips or back.

【8】Credit:

【9】SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/481108/view

【10】Common causes of stretch marks
------------------------------

【11】Stretch marks are often caused by sudden growth or weight gain.

【12】You may be more likely to get them if you:

【13】*   are pregnant
*   are going through puberty
*   lose or gain weight quickly
*   are female
*   are overweight
*   use some kinds of steroid creams or tablets
*   have a family member with stretch marks

【14】Rarely, stretch marks can be due to a condition called Cushing's syndrome.

【15】Information:

【16】Find out more about stretch marks in pregnancy

【17】What to do about stretch marks
------------------------------

【18】Stretch marks usually fade over time but may not disappear completely.

【19】Many creams and lotions claim to prevent, reduce or remove stretch marks. But there's very little evidence these work.

【20】There are some treatments that may help make stretch marks look better, but they will not get rid of them.

【21】They include:

【22】*   retinoid (often called tretinoin) creams or hyaluronic acid – these may help if used on new stretch marks, but you should not use retinoid creams if you're pregnant as they may harm your baby
*   light or laser treatments
*   microdermabrasion, which removes a thin layer of skin

【23】You would need to pay for these treatments as they're not available on the NHS.

【24】Information:

【25】It's not always possible to prevent stretch marks. The best way to reduce your chance of getting them is by maintaining a healthy weight.

【26】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【27】You have large stretch marks and:

【28】*   more fat on your chest and tummy, but slim arms and legs
*   a build-up of fat on the back of your neck and shoulders
*   a red, puffy, rounded face

【29】These could be symptoms of Cushing's syndrome.

【30】Page last reviewed: 07 December 2021  
Next review due: 07 December 2024
